name: ASUS Prime AP201 33-Liter MicroATX Black case with Tool-Free Side Panels and a Quasi-Filter mesh, with Support for 360 mm Coolers, Graphics Cards up to 338 mm Long, and Standard ATX PSUs
description:
• Quasi-Filter Mesh Panels: A mesh design comprised of over 57,000 precision-machined 1.5mm holes increases airflow and provides a compelling view of the components within your build
  • Optimized for Cooling: With support for 280 and 360mm radiators and up to six fans, the AP201 is primed to deal with the thermal onslaught of high-performance hardware.
  • Industry-Leading Spatial Efficiency: Despite a 33L footprint, the AP201 supports ATX PSUs up to 180 mm long, graphics cards up to 338 mm long, custom liquid cooling, and various storage devices.
  • Tool-Free Side Panels: A simple yet secure clip mechanism allows chassis side panels to be easily removed and resistant to accidental dislodging.
  • Sizeable Cable-Management: The AP201 features an extended motherboard tray with strategically placed cutouts and a 32 mm gap to tuck cables out of sight.

reviews.review:
Currently living with family and downsizing for when I move out. I also feared tempered glass breaking in the move, so I thought downsizing to MATX was the best way to go.

Got this case because of the various storage/ fan configs you can plan, and for the ATX PSU support. My Corsair 850W PSU did fit even though it's a touch long, but I'm able to install it in the middle slot position while still being able to install both an SSD AND have plenty of cable clearance for my cables both on the bottom while having plenty of space above to run the extension cable from my power supply to the back of my case.

This case is roomier than I expected, and my commander Pro stuck to the PSU cage without extra tape or anything (though it has to be in a certain spot so it doesn't fall).

While there is SOME cable managenent behind the motherboard tray, there's not quite as much as I'd like, however, mounting the power supply in the front helps. There's also a small removable should that helps block the PSU and most cables from view from the side. There's also a collum on the other side of the case that hides some of the other cables well too.

This case can really breathe but only has one fan filter on the bottom. I had to get some magnetic DIY fan filters for the sides to help reduce dust, but it is getting more dusty that my old build, but it's fine since I dust regularly. The mesh it comes with dies diffuse the RGB well and it looks cool.

The frame is also completely toolless, except for the one cable shroud near the power supply. But taking off the sides, top or front of the case is fast, easy and painless, only requiring a good grip and some light force.

The only complaints I have is that their USB C header is useless to me currently because the Asus board I have only has a USB 3.0 and 2 regular USB headers which are occupied by my commander Pro and my AIO. I could split one port but I don't want extra splitters kicking around in there or adapters and splitters just to use a USB slot that I don't have anything to use with anyway. The power button is also BRIGHT at night and flashes in sleep mode. It grew so annoying while I was trying to sleep that I immediately unplugged the power LED.

Currently ASUS is having controversies with the quality of some of their products, but for now, their case seems solid and my be the only recent Asus product that I'm satisfied with and trust. If this doesn't bother you, then this is a good choice for an MATX build.
It’s not bad

The case is easy to work on. The only issue I found was the rear fan is only a three pin fan making it annoying to control. And if there was a little for space for cable management on the other side. My psu has thick cables and was a chore. It’s on there with a slight buldge. Would buy again for another system if need be.

I love how simple the case is. It’s really easy to built in and you can put a lot of components in it for it’s size without compromising on the cooling. Maybe one down side is the cable management isn’t really great and when you lift the case the balance is weird since the psu is in the front but you eventually get used to it. Also it’s not really silent. I recommend this case, it’s great for the price.
Excellent case easy to work with and great airflow
A dream to work in. Easy cable routing and the seamless panel pop off is such a QOL I didn't know I needed.
but once assembled i love it

This case is really good for powerful small form factor mATX builds. It is currently housing a 5600 CPU, 32gbs of RAM, and a 4070ti GPU with an 850w ATX PSU. This case is able to keep all the components cool and quiet. Cable management for this case is good, the back of the motherboard tray gives quite a bit of room to store all the cables needed. I am not running any SSDs or HDDs in this build, your results may vary if you choose to do so. Overall this case is sturdy and built well.

I'm very happy with this case.

Pros:
- Front, top, side panels and the bottom filter all can be removed for easy access to internal components. The panels use captive bead style locking and don't require tools to (dis)assemble.
- Mesh on all sides for good air flow.
- Enough space to easily route all the cables.
- Fits standard size GPU, PSU and fans.
- Space for multiple 2.5" drives.

Cons:
- Unclear PSU mounting instructions. The PSU is mounted up front and I mounted mine with the intake fan facing to the front and the exhaust facing to the top of the case. The manual doesn't show which way to mount the PSU and the 90deg angled power cable extension seems to suggest mounting PSUs with the intake fan facing the inside of the case (my power cable extension is 90deg angled to the front and then does a 180 and goes all the way to the back of the case). Make sure to mount the PSU with the fan facing outside for better airflow.
- While 3 2.5" drives can be mounted in the case there is only one cradle. The other 2 are screwed directly to the case. My SATA power cable doesn't fit if the drive is mounted flush with the case in the non-cradle spot. I was able to mount the drive at a bit of an angle with only 2 screws on the back/non-connector side. Not ideal but the drive does feel securely mounted.
- With my graphics card there is around 0.5in of space between the bottom case fans and the graphics card and the card covers the fans almost entirely. This does not inspire confidence in the 2 bottom fans being able to effectively deliver air to other components.
- No space for a front intake fan.
- With 3 top fans mounted the power switch on my PSU wouldn't be accessible. I mounted 2 fans on the bottom, 1 on the back and 2 up top leaving 1 top space empty.
- Top panel has to be removed to access the PSU power switch.

It's not the smallest case out there, but it's certainly high quality.
There's a surprising about of room to build. The tight fit pieces can be taken out and placed back in quite easily.
Cable management channels are spacious, and there's some cable ties included.
Air Flow seems to going extremely well, though I guess that's a given seeing as the whole case is basically a mesh.
The actual quality of the parts is more than I'd ever expect for this price. The case feels stable. The side panels pop off and snap back on very easily.
At this price range, it's an absolute recommendation.

Computer is completely silent at idle, makes a tiny bit of noise during gaming that’s completely blocked out by headphones, and it’s not annoying to anyone else in the room.

I’ve set airflow to intake on bottom and rear, exhaust through aio on top.

Fits 360 aio and 3080 ti FE. Specs say only two 120mm fans fit on the bottom, there are only screw holes for two 120mm fans but if you get fans that connect to each other like lian li Uni fans you can put three 120mm fans on the bottom no problem. I replaced the included rear 120 with another lian li Uni fan and set it as intake with a magnetic dust filter on the outside. I thought I’d save room by using an sfx power supply but the frame that holds the power supply is larger so I don’t gain any video card clearance (not even needed with founders edition cards) with the smaller psu, sfx cables are tight, had to use a cpu power extension cable. I’m using the middle mount for the psu, and the included internal ac power extension pressed into the fan frame on the aio, it tweaked things a bit and couldn’t use all of the screws to mount the radiator. I decided to get a slim right angle extension from MODDIY part# C0507. Wish these were available on Amazon as it took a couple weeks to ship from China. With this cable installed I’m pretty sure I could move the psu bracket to the top position if I replace the radiator fan with a slim 120 to get full gpu clearance if I ever need it.
Great job Asus, I ordered a replacement on Tuesday and got a new one on Saturday in Colombia! That's incredible, thank you. The other case was indeed damaged this one turned the PC on no problem.

Feels like it’s well built, and has room for all the stuff I needed to put in there. Pretty inexpensive for what you get. Six mounting points for 120mm fans, which is great. Dust filter mesh on the bottom, so I installed the intake fans there.

name: HYTE Y60 Modern Aesthetic Dual Chamber Panoramic Tempered Glass Mid-Tower ATX Computer Gaming Case with PCIE 4.0 Riser Cable Included, Snow White (CS-HYTE-Y60-WW)
description:
• Panoramic Views: No corner pillar. The Y60 features a 3-piece panoramic tempered glass design for the ultimate photo and display potential. See your build the way it was meant to be seen from the left or right side of your desk with a simple turn.
  • Exclusively Vertical GPU Mounted: Why would you want to see your graphics card any other way?
  • Included PCIE 4.0 Riser Cable: A protective riser cable canopy integrates beautifully into the case, allowing for half-height PCIE cards behind the throne of the vertical graphics card. The protective shroud is the first of its kind, made specifically for the Y60.
  • Antechamber Construction: Segment cables from thermal components and turn your PC into a work of art.
  • Cold Floor Cooling: Eliminate hot spots with sweeping lateral vents from fans tastefully tucked into the basement of the Y60.

reviews.review: Gran calidad de materiales y acabados y gran envío de amazon en doble caja
Hyte has probably the best looking and well designed cases for air flow imo!

First of all, it's a great looking case. The build is solid and doesn't feel cheap. That being said, I do find some faults, that admittedly, I should've done more research. The 3 panes of glass have gaps between them and other larger vents/holes throughout. There's a massive amount of space from the viewing side, but for a dual chamber, you're limited due to rear removal drive bays taking up needed space. You can leave the drive trays out, but the covers are integrated, leaving more gaping holes. You can't use the "basement" if you're using bottom fans. BUT all the fan mounts have non-removable restrictive filters (unless you want to leave off the panel they are connected to). My guess is that you're supposed to point all the fans inward to counterbalance the mesh restriction and create enough positive pressure to vent out all the cracks. Other cases I've built in this price range (Corsair, Lian Li, Fractal) have put more detail into the build. Really interested in seeing if Montech's King 95 will solve these issues at a much lower price point.

I’ll keep this quick. I went for a 1440p @ 100 fps system.

Intel i7 13700k w/ DeepCool AK620
DDR5 Memory
Radeon 6700 XT (to keep it under budget)

Pros: Easy to build in. I converted the set up from liquid cooling to air cooling and have yet to thermal throttle in synthetic tests or extended gaming. CPU is never above 75* while gaming, GPU floats around 70*-90* depending on the game. If you are building a similar system, stick fans in it in a positive pressure configuration that doesn’t clash and you’ll be set.

Paint and finish is surprisingly good. No chipped paint, no smeary scratches, no wear marks that I didn’t put on the case by accident. Oops. I went with the Snow White (white interior & exterior) and I never noticed any glaring build or quality issues.

There’s plenty of space inside to do a custom water loop. DOUBLE CHECK that any fat radiator you have will fit!

Absolutely tons of tie down areas. If you want to cable tie cables, there’s a spot in a well thought out location to do so.

Aesthetics are great, but that’s 100% subjective and honestly doesn’t matter toooo much.

Cons: Mostly small and things out of company control. Mine lightly was damaged. Those small quick clips that secure glass and plastic panels were broken on one of the glass panels. I don’t think it was manufacturing but was due to shipping. The case is shipped with all glass installed, so maybe in shipping all the jostling broke those plastic clips? Maybe the company can figure out a different way to ship with the glass side panel off.

Some of the case screws are really tight. They paint the screw threads themselves, and combined with the painted case makes very tight screws. Threading & unthreading strips the paint off the screw threads, which is normal. But kinda annoying when you can just paint the screw heads to avoid all of it.

The instructions don’t include how to take off the PCIE riser cable to upgrade it, if you can even do that. It’s a PCIE 4.0 according to manufacturer, so when I upgrade GPU I will need to upgrade that. I’d like to not go in blind and undo all the screws and possible mess something up. Please update the manual.
looks really good and pretty good airflow if you set the left 120mm fan to blow out the case and everything else in

name: NZXT H5 Flow RGB - White
description: • NZXT H5 Flow RGB - White

reviews.review: good cheap case
Great manual, wish there was an extra daisychain cable for external RGB but you could get one for 10 bucks.
El gabinete llegó en perfecto estado y se ve hermoso, el gabinete que más recomiendo.
This case both looks very aesthetic while still having tons of room for components. Plus the back allows for great cable management. Overall a great purchase. Would recommend.
Bought this for my first build. It’s great overall (most importantly it looks good) but I will say, figuring out where the built in fan and rgb cables go is tricky for a beginner.

La paquetería entrego el paquete en muy buenas condiciones y el producto llegó muy protegido en excelentes condiciones, me encantó el gabinete es tal cual la imagen que está en la página es mi primer PC y cuando la tenga armada pienso hacer una actualización, con foto de como se ve con los componentes, de verdad todo fue muy rápido llegó un día antes de lo esperado y el producto para mí gusto es un 10 :D .
Replaced an old h700i with the H5 Flow RGB. I love this case.

name: Noctua NH-U12A chromax.Black, 120mm Single-Tower CPU Cooler (Black)
description:
• Proven premium heatsink (more than 100 awards and recommendations from international hardware websites), now available in an all-black design that goes great with many colour schemes and RGB LEDs
  • Top-tier performance in 120mm size for excellent compatibility: fits most tower cases (158mm height), doesn’t overhang the RAM slots, doesn’t block the PCIe on most ATX & Micro-ATX motherboards
  • Dual state-of-the-art NF-A12x25 120mm fans with Low-Noise Adaptors and PWM for automatic speed control: full cooling performance under load, whisper quiet at idle!
  • Includes high-end NT-H1 thermal paste and SecuFirm2 mounting system for easy installation on Intel LGA1851, LGA1700, LGA1200, LGA115x and AMD AM5 & AM4
  • Renowned Noctua quality backed up by 6-year manufacturer’s warranty, deluxe choice for Intel Core i9, i7, i5, i3 (e.g. 14900K, 14700K, 14600K) and AMD Ryzen (e.g. 7950X3D, 7900X3D, 7800X3D, 7700)

reviews.review:
Went with the Noctua NH-U12A chromax.Black because I didn't love the look/size of the NH-D15. I was considering going with a AIO for my 5800x but Noctua has never steered me wrong before so air cooling it was. With the U12A my CPU temp idles around 36c and under load hasn't gone over 73c (usually it hovers around 60-65c)

Gotta say this is my new favorite cooler!! The covers (NA-HC7 chromax.black.swap) and vibration pads (NA-SAVP1 chromax.white) are extra but a nice plus for customization as well!!

Bought for the hype, stayed for the Performance. Easy mounting system, included cpu thermal compound, included TWO fans in the box (Awesome). Installing is straight forward and easy, lots of instructions and varying mounts for the CPU currently being mounted. Included 4pin PWM splitter was huge for splitting the cpu fan header, and the height doesnt put any of the casing at risk.

Keeps my 7700x Nice and cool

What can I say. It’s Noctua. It performs within 1-2 degrees of a D15. But much smaller. So it has great case/video card/ram clearance. Still extremely beefy. Added heat pipes, denser radiator. The best fans. All make this one of the best air coolers available.
If you want specifics. I switched from a 240 AIO top mounted in a Meshify C case with 5 Arctic p12 fans. This cooler dropped my temp during stress tests 10-15 degrees on CPU max temp. From 76 down to 62. Amazing results in apples to apples comparison. And no imperial noise data. Just to say that my noctua set up much quieter than AIO with better performance. My graphics card temps went up 2-3. Which is. It ideal, but we’ll worth the trade off. I’ll just play with my fan curve.
I’m not sure I’ll ever go back to AIOs. People that say air coolers don’t look nice have not seen a nice one. I am converted.

Unfortunately my product arrived damaged. Please see pictures. No idea how this happened unless it was opened up prior to me receiving it. Package looked new and sealed. I understand things happen, but when I spend almost 200 dollars on a cpu cooler, I expect it to be mint. I do not want to go through the hassle of sending it back, because I need it, but it leaves a little bit of a sour taste in my mouth.
Cooler gets 5 stars - experience with top tier product arriving damaged is the sole reason for my non 5 star overall rating.

The U12A is a great air cooler albeit the most expensive one. I use it in a small mATX case (inwin 301) where airflow is poor. Does a great job cooling an r5 3600 idling in high 30s to low 40s. In cinebench r23 max temp 74 degrees and while gaming up to 78 degrees max spike. I know the 3600 is not hard to cool. The U12A gives slightly better cooling performance than the wraith prism. About 4-6 degrees delta but it's much better at being silent. At 100% max fan spin, while audible it is not very loud. I've also used this cooler with a 5900x in the same case and that CPU is a hot one! It can cool the 5900x in cinebench r23 at high 70s to mid 80s and idle at around 45-50 degrees. While gaming I saw the 5900x temps spike really high. CPU package up to 89 degrees and CCD1 go up to 93. That being said the U12A chromax black is still a great cooler that I can easily recommend. If your case is limited to 158mm cooler height and you're thinking about purchasing this... do it, you won't regret it.

It works very similarly to D15S on 12700K but it is a lot smaller and better looking and comes with two flagship NF-A12x25 fans that cost $44 each. I am not worried that this would bend the board and break off during movement either. It feels much more stable because of its size. I think most people should skip D15/D15s and buy this instead. The installation is also easier. I also had a chance to try Scythe Fuma 2 Rev B which cost almost half as much. It is similar in size and performs well but not good enough for 12700K imo. It was definitely running hotter during benchmarks. But if you want to save on cost, I would recommend that, not D15S. This is not twice as good as Fuma 2 overall, more like 20% better. Overall I think the heatsink itself is not anything special, it's the 2x NF-A12x25s that make it work. I think if you buy two of those and put them on a cheaper tower cooler, it would perform similarly. Most of the money here is going to those two fans.

I looked for alternatives but decided to bite the bullet and go for an all black , needlessly over expensive Noctua for my 12600K. I've not OCed the CPU and it runs at 32C+ with light work load, 63C - 72C gaming and 28C idle. I have no issues with build quality , noise , instructions and the mounting system I'm just pissed at having to pay $30 more for non-puke brown so 4/5 stars.
Noctua a réussi à descendre de 15-20 degré les température du processeur. Je vous le recommande. Vérifier que votre case à moins 160mm de profondeur pour la compatibilité.
Installation and use was straightforward and the system performed as expected. No fuss, no drama.

This review is for Noctua NH-U12A chromax.Black, 120mm Single-Tower CPU Cooler (Black).

When I finished putting my new build together, the wraith prism ended up being insufficient for the amount of heat the AMD Ryzen 5 7600X creates. I was seeing temperatures of around 83c to 87c (181.4F to 188.6F) whenever I turned on any game. Turn on a web browser and it would go up to around 76c (168.8F) in a room that's around 21c (69.8F) typically. At the time that I am writing this, I have BDO (Black Desert Online) running in the background, multiple browser tabs and Discord running - my CPU temperature is sitting around 68c to 74c (154.4F to 165.2F). That is a major difference in temperature from the Wraith Prism, especially since these newer CPUs are generally known to run hot. In terms of my case fan setup, I have three in front for intake, one at the back and two at the top for exhaust.

I know the aesthetic might not be the best looking for everyone since some people absolutely love fan halos - I assume you might be able to buy fan halos to put on it and fix that issue, however - my RAM has RGB lighting which projects nicely on the intake fan so it creates this kind of very light, pastel look to it. If you go for the classic brown Noctua, there are some incredibly clean and aesthetically pleasing builds I've seen using them that I would advise looking up if your worry isn't only functionality but aesthetic.

In terms of noise level - I have very sensitive ears and I don't hear anything from it - the fan noise I do hear is from my case fans instead, which aren't Noctua brand, they're some rather generic fans that came with this case.

In terms of installation - it was incredibly smooth. I went with U12A because of the amount of clearance my computer has for the tower and my intake fan had to be lifted a little due to where the RAM sits which is perfectly fine to do. The fans have little clips that just clip onto and hug the radiator so they are extremely easy to adjust if needed.

My advice for anyone considering a Noctua brand air cooler:

• Know the TDP of your CPU, it might be overkill for something with 65W for example but if you are looking to upgrade your CPU its a really good deal. How you use your computer is also a contributing factor to the amount of heat output - so do your research depending on how intense or complex the work you plan to do is, it could pull a lot more power and thus generate a lot more heat and maybe air cooling isn't enough to keep up with the heat output.

• Consider things like the average temperature of the room you do or will have the computer in, your build layout, the case size, case air flow, and the type of case fans you are using and/or plan to use.

• Compatibility & Clearance. You are able to check via Noctua's website if their coolers are compatible with your Motherboard, Case (not all cases are listed, but they have a formula to help you figure it out if need be), CPU, and RAM.

• Make sure you triple check your information on clearance to make sure you buy the appropriate Noctua to suit your needs.

To whoever buys a Noctua brand cooler, enjoy! They come with a 6 year warranty too - which makes it feel like a better and safer product to purchase considering most computer components will generally start to have issues between 3 to 5 years down the line, and in the case of just so happening to get a faulty unit. As a consumer I know how daunting it could be when you are in the market for computer components given the amount of choices we have - and when you see a product with x amount of awards and good reviews it really makes you think about if it really is good - especially considering certain companies just buy good reviews. I typically never leave reviews because I also am one of the consumers that prefers to do my own research instead of just trusting and hoping that the product reviews are indeed legitimate. However, I am thoroughly pleased with this product and hope by leaving a review I can help anyone who cares for informative reviews and is like me; Prefers air cooling and has gotten a CPU that for the first time just any cooler isn't good enough for gaming.

This is my first Noctua brand CPU cooler, but the second one I've purchased. The first one I purchased was a NH-D15 for a family member's build, he however has a full tower, so he has a lot more clearance to work with than I do with my mid tower and it works like a charm for him as well. However, in his case he had swapped from an AIO that was dead/dying - so I'm sure he would have seen a difference in his temperatures regardless of what he got as long as it wasn't defective.

I am thoroughly impressed by the quality and performance of this cooler. Running a Ryzen 7 5700g, and upgrading from a coolermaster A17C (similar to stock), that idled/performed at 72/85c.

The NH-U12A is currently idling/performing at 36/53c!

With auto-overclocking pushing the processor past 4ghz, that is a monumental improvement, and far greater that I had ever dreamed I would get for the price. This is a small case sharing space with a 3090ti, 2xNvme, 2xSSD, and 2xHDD; so it already has it's challenges, but even my PWM case fans are running 20-30% slower than before. Mobo and GPU temps dropped by 1-2c as result of lower ambient and probably better airflow in the case, overall.

The install used my existing AMD backplate, and the tower is offset to one side to allow for RAM clearance. I am running a micro-atx board in a somewhat cramped mid-tower case, and I was still able to install and work the fans in place fairly easily. Judging by the cramped conditions of my board, I would vouch for 100% universal RAM clearance, as the offset tower just does what it says it does; and the included fans are not thin by any means. As a bonus, the fans seem to be positioned just perfectly to draw intake air across the RAM an works well with my VR heatsink on the exit side of things.

The included fans are smooth as glass, and surprisingly quiet at full speed; but I had to manually run them to full, as the CPU wouldn't heat past 53c (Fan RPM 1300'ish). Primo fans, no RGB, but that's what I wanted for this rig. The wires are well sheathed in tubing and heatshrink- wire management approved.
If you've never dealt with this type of fan clip system, practice with them before you install the cooler. lol.

I bought the add-on, decorative cover NA-HC7, which looks amazing on the installed cooler, and requires less effort to install than removing the side panel to get to it. This add-on should be RGB, as the cutout design is just too perfect not to be backlit. This kit did add height to the cooler, and my case is fairly small, but the glass panel clears everything by about 2mm.

Everything came professionally boxed, shiny, and new; and you can just feel the care and quality in everything you touch, even the packaging.

I rarely write reviews, and I am rarely impressed; but I was on the fence for weeks about a cooling solution on this particular rig, and I wanted to ensure others in my position can absolutely trust this cooler.

Even versus watercooling, maybe. Dang.

I was going to return this and actually started a return. But decided to cancel that return and ended up keeping it. On my 13700k it kept it in the 60’s and low 70’s during gaming. Not ideal for me coming from water cooling but not dangerous and in safe limits. The thing I didn’t like about it most was my 4090 couldn’t be vertical mounted with this air cooler. For some that’s okay but for me it raises my ram temps by 15 degrees c in games being the back plate is right under the ram and heat rises right onto the ram sticks and also my 2 of my 4 nvme drives went up over 10 degrees c average being the 4090 dumps it heat on the motherboard nvme 1 and 2 slot with it mounted in the pcie slot. Then my 4090 mem temps raised 15c also not being vertically mounted. Seems wild but if you have a 4090 try it. Might surprised with the results. But it raised my whole system temps up and had to adjust my fan curve to the point it was unbearable to me. So I went with a Corsair aio again and all my temps dropped again. Cpu is easily under controlled on water. Which is expected. But using this now with my wife’s system 10700k at 5.1ghz on all 8 cores to replace my old cryorig h7 lumi that was struggling at 5.1ghz. Easily keeps the 10700k in check with no problems. Plus looks so good doing so. I love air cooling but didn’t want to buy a bigger new case to vertically mount my gpu with a air cooler to keep other components cooler.

Le NH-U12A est le Ventirad qui passe partout et qui ne limite pas les configurations pc "petit budget".
Ce ventirad est vraiment très polyvalent, silencieux et propose les meilleures performances du marché, Noctua est la marque le plus prisé dans le marché des ventirad.

Foncer la tête baissée si votre config est adaptée, vous ne regretterez pas.

Para usarlo con un 7950X he hecho varias cosas:
-Limite de 170w en PBO
-Establecer la curva negativa en PBO -15 (Varia en casa procesador)
-Voltaje Offset en -0.100v (Varía en cada procesador)
-Anclaje Noctua NM-AMB15
-Pasta térmica MX6
-Anclaje del procesador Theemalright AM5

Con esto consigo temperaturas:
•Cinebench R23 y 2024 de en torno 80-84° (38500 puntos y 2175 puntos)
•Prime95 en torno a 84° sin llegar al límite térmico

Temperatura ambiente 25°.

Va justo para el 7950x pero es normal, hablamos de una generación muy caliente, con un consumo y potencia brutales pero sin duda "limitando" un poco ciertos parámetros como he hecho tienes un disipador apto y además fiable.

name: StarTech.com 1U Server Rack Shelf - Universal Vented Rack Mount Cantilever Tray for 19" Network Equipment Rack & Cabinet - Heavy Duty Steel - Weight Capacity 50lb/23kg - 10" Deep, Black (CABSHELFV1U)
description:
• UNIVERSAL 19'' FIT: This 1U vented server rack mount shelf is designed to fit virtually any 19in server rack and can accommodate an internal depth of 10in (25cm) for your data, IT, networking, or other non-rack mount equipment
  • MAXIMIZE VENTILIATION: The vented shelf plate on the cantilever rack shelf ensures consistent airflow to effectively dissipate heat on servers; it also works great to keep your computer and AV equipment cool in your home, studio, or office space
  • HEAVY-DUTY & DURABLE DESIGN: Constructed with SPCC commercial cold-rolled steel, the sturdy front mounted cabinet shelf ensures long term durability and supports a total weight of 44lbs/22kg making it the perfect rack shelf solution for any environment
  • VERSATILE FUNCTIONALITY: At 10in deep, this fixed rack mount shelf is designed to work with any 19in cabinet or equipment rack; it provides additional storage space for mission critical hardware, and can even store your tools or audio / video accessories
  • STARTECH.COM ADVANTAGE: IT professionals' choice for over 30 years, this TAA compliant 1U vented server rack mount shelf is backed for life by StarTech.com, including free lifetime 24/5 multi-lingual technical assistance

reviews.review: This was a great product, quite strong, and will hold up well I think! The price wasn't bad either. I recommend it.
It can carry so much weight and all my items in my shed

This rack shelf is made of quality heavy gauge steel and is perfect for devices weighing up to 50 pounds.
Easy to install, vented for air circulation, deep 16-inch depth with no end lip, highly recommended.

It arrived with the mounting points bent pretty good. Not world ending as I was able to bend them back, just annoying as the product you ordered should arrive with no damage, but things happen. Overall really solid.

This is nice product with great build quality, but its provided rack screws only work with racks using snap in mounts and are the wrong thread for predrilled (usually 12-24 machine screws) racks.

I ran into this recently during my first use of the product, and it is probably a < $1 addition which would save some needless drama if these are installed to a new location in a time crunch. I've docked a star due to this, as not being able to install a shelf can quickly roadblock a new rack setup...

Shelf is solid and made from heavy gauge steel. Installed easy and looks good. Considering the strength of the shelf, it arrived with a severely bent mounting tab. It would have taken a considerable impact to bend this. This does not reflect on the quality of the shelf, rather the inadequate packaging could be a bit more robust to resist shipping stresses. It was a simple fix, but the powder coating did crack.

No big deal and can’t see the damage once installed.
Quality construction but like everything rack mount it it overpriced.
To expensive.

La use para soportar un servidor bastante pesado y lo soportó muy bien. Tiene un acabado de calidad. Es bastante sólido.
Si les echas un poco de peso (tres torres) se empiezan de doblar , pero aguantan bien .
Superb piece of rack kit for studio use.

name: DeepCool CC560 WH Mid-Tower ATX PC Case, 4X Pre-Installed 120mm LED Fans, Tempered Glass Side Panel, White
description:
• A mid-tower ATX case with great component compatibility and high-quality features.
  • Well-ventilated throughout with an airflow front panel and a large mesh top panel to ensure fresh air is circulating.
  • Ensure great cooling ability with four pre-installed 120mm fans with bright LEDs and optimized airflow.
  • Enough space to support multiple liquid cooling radiator configurations with room for 360mm/280mm radiators in front or 240mm on top.
  • Showcase your system build with a clean and clear full-sized window.
  • Install up to 3x 2.5in SSDs or 2x 3.5in HDDs in a removable drive cage for increased flexibility.
  • Keep important connectivity up front with USB3.0, USB2.0, and a combo audio jack.

reviews.review: Not looking to do anything complicated? This is perfect, quiet and decent cooling. Would have like to have more 2.5 inch bays but the 2 that are screwed to the case are good.

The case has 4 led fans included. It came with everything needed to attach the motherboard. The hard drive cage has two positions or can be removed entirely by 2 screws to fit a longer PSU if needed. Plenty of holes for wire management and a nice sized wire area behind the back panel. The glass panel came with plastic peel on both sides of the panel, which doesn't seem to be common but is a nice touch. Doesn't have rubber grommets around the wire holes but that is ok for the price, you could go up 30-40$ in case tiers to get those if they are important to you. Remember to remove the PCIe slot covers you will need open from the case before inserting the motherboard.

The case is visually nice as well, the white and black design looks good with a variety of component colors on the inside, you should be able to match almost anything with it.

The only complaint I have is the case did not come with a little screw bit to help put the motherboard stand offs in. Personally this does not matter to me as I have them already and other screw bits in my set. But for someone missing it, it does make inserting the standoffs straight a bit more difficult, Although it can be done by hand if needed, it will just be a bit more frustrating to do.

A decent case.

I have been building computers as an I.T specialist and hobbyist for over 25 years now, As A technician I have repaired a couple thousand machines over that time and probably built 50 machines for friends and family over the years.

This case is nothing special. It'll get the job done, but at $109 its overpriced. I know, that's the world we live in now.

I was getting an old P.C back from my son that I had built him in 2016 and I didn't realize he was sending the case back with the other components. The case from 2016 was a cooler master and when I compared these 2 cases (the original build and this case I ordered), they are virtually identical. I paid $30 in 2016 for that other case.

Had I known he was shipping the case back I would have saved the $109 on this one as it was no upgrade whatsoever (maybe a little cleaner). The old case has two usb 3.1 ports on the top of the case. This case only has one 3.1 port.

Oh and if you don't like green lights on your fans or it doesn't jive with your build don't order this as the lights aren't adjustable.
belle finition, acier bien plier peux être un peux plus mince que d autre plus chere mais tres solide
Off rip loving the design and spacing but could use some more white but all around looks beautiful
Ventilateur silencieux bonne puissance de lumière

easy peasy...no problems with the case other than i thought there was a scratch on the glass side panel but i was wrong. Peeled the usual outer layer of protective film off the glass after full assembly.
If this part of the build is satisfying to you...there are 2 layers; 1 on the outside and 1 on the inside of the glass. I'm new to pc building and this is the first case where i've encountered this.
Easy install, plug and play, I thought my power supply or the fans is defective but its my fault you can adjust fan speed and power on bios.

reviews.review: This case is awesome for PC builders both new and experienced, it has lots of space in the back if you're sloppy with cable management like me, and has more than enough interior volume to house larger parts. The fans and front panel connectors were easy to set up, and it's overall just a pretty good case.
There is nothing else in the price point that is solid and comes with lots of fans pre-wired. Back side is also spacious for lazy cable management :)
Nice layout, reasonable price. Love it.
Case was very easy to build in. Looks very good built very well. 10/10 would recommend

Facile pour accès au câble, porte vitré qui s'ouvre facilement. Ventilateurs RGM qui fonctionne très bien.

Je recommence fortement

But..
The front fans didnt work. Found them to be faulty replaced them with another set. After a week of trouble shooting customer service to get another set of fans or partial refund I gave up. They were doing everything possible to not have to get me new fans. So basicly overpaid for a case.

I purchased my first Musetex case for a pc build i was doing for a friend, I loved everything about the case! It is very light but sturdy, cable management is awesome, first pc that I was able to create a show quality PC with no effort, everything is slotted and tabbed in the absolute perfect spot for an atx case. The fans are super quiet and the rgb fans are just amazing! Super stylish for an amazing price!

I was jealous, and decided to purchace a case for myself and when I received the case, the side panel was badly damaged from delivery. I sent Musetex a message thru amazon explaining the situation and they responded within a few hours and said they would replace the side panel no problem. The very next day they sent me a complete replacement case!
Outstanding customer care!

In general, the case is rubust yet light, equipment runs very cool, fans have yet to ramp up at all under load, very sleek case for the price!
Only issue I had upgrading one PC running a Noctua nh-u14s fan was the door barely closed and would sometimes pop open due to fan height. I upgraded to a closed loop aio water cooler that was cheaper than the fan and the entire pc runs even cooler yet! (water cooler is the only way to go now these days, and looks 10x cleaner, and runs cooler)

So glad I didnt spend 2x the price on one of the other "popular" brands! - Customer for life! Thank You Musetex!
Muy buen acabado, de mejor calidad, en su empaque original y nuevo, se recibió en tiempo
Used with a MSI Tomahawk and RTX3080 card. Everything fit nicely. Case quality is great, especially for the price. The fans work well and are nice and quiet.

So this case was for my very first PC build ever and I have learned so much throughout this process. Anyway the case is gorgeous: I absolutely love the magnetic glass door. It makes going in and out of the PC for adjustments and changes an absolute breeze and you can show off all of your beautiful parts. The case also does very well for cable management. ARGB fans look awesome; overall I’m very pleased with the finished product. One thing to note because it took me a while to get it all figured out myself; the case description does note that your motherboard needs a 5V ARGB (3pin) connection. You’ll actually need two because the front fans and the rear/top fans connect via 2 separate 3pin connectors. My motherboard instead uses a 4pin connection so technically I actually wasn’t able to light my fans at first. After adding a 3pin to 4pin converter and adding a splitter to connect both fans, I got it working perfectly. Hope this helps anyone.

I had to bend the cage to make sure that cards are properly inserted in the motherboard and that are fastened "securely". Unfortunately I had to finish the build and I was stuck with using the case as is, that's why I could not return it.

However, I strongly do not recommend it, especially at the price is selling for. Flimsy with some rust spots and unusable unless you modify the case. Extremely disappointed, wasted money!

CONTRO : manca un filtro sul pannello laterale per le ventole intake / con una scheda ATX, i pin più bassi della scheda interferiscono con le ventole intake nel pannello inferiore (non ho potuto collegare il cavo della USB-C presente sul case perchè interferiva con le ventole (occorrono ventole slim)

Annonce conforme à la livraison par contre très déçu des commentaires qui disait comme quoi qu'il y avait les ventilos avec il n'en est rien ce commentaire et bidon faites attention lisez plus les annonces que les commentaires.

So the case was originally listed to come with 10 RGB fans, which is one of the reasons I bought it. They changed the description after I bought it and after I read one other review that said it didn't actually come with them. This isn't a big deal to me, I really liked the design of the case and was going to buy Corsair fans anyway, just like that I didn't have to right away while building my NEW PC(one less starting cost). the case does seem that it will have REALLY good air flow once, max 240mm AIO on the back does kind of suck, but you can run a 360mm on top and bottom, which is what I am doing anyways. Cable management to the motherboard isn't the best. There's 2 slots at the bottom of the case one isn't big enough to route the USB plug through at all and the other is further back and the only one at the bottom that you can actually fit the USB plug in and it makes it harder to do clean cable management. I like the power button on it. Downfall is that it only has 1 USB slot and 1 type-c slot on the case. So hopefully your motherboard has more than you needed. SATA and HDD mounts in the back of the case right under where the PSU is, you can take that out and it does help with routing any cables you need to if you put the mother board in 1st(I STRONGLY SUGGEST ROUTING ANY CABLES PRIOR, MAKES IT EASIER. I DIDN'T!!). Dust covers aren't really that great, they're not a fine mesh the holes are slightly large for a dust cover. One of the things I do like about this case is that I want to put a 5" monitor screen in it to show temps of everything and with the number of fans that you can actually put in this case. It frees up the rear fan spot to do that with it.

So overall, If you have want a decent, buy it. If you don't want to buy a lot of fans that don't come with the case, don't buy it. I'm still happy with my purchase as of right now. I haven't finished building my new PC as of yet though and still might change my mind about keeping this case, as I REALLY like the Hyte Y60 and almost bought it instead because it has the vertical GPU mounting ability that this one doesn't.

EDIT: I have to add on that taking the glass off the case is a slight pain. I like the fact that it's a tight fit but while you're building and you put t he glass back on to cover everything up, doing upgrades or just cleaning, it's slightly harder to take the glass off to do so.

reviews.review:
If you want to premium case with one of the best air flow system in the market..... This is the one!
It might be over $100 but it's totally worth it. Comes with two front facing argb fans, one rear non-rgb fan and one angled intake non RGB fan for the GPU in the bottom of the case.

It's all you could ever ask for.
And cable management is like heaven.
Lots of cable already routed to the case and they include a lot of zip ties and vecro cables.
ahhhhhh my first pc im soooooo happy to have chosen this case

It was able to fit my 4070ti and a 280mm rad. It also stays really cool with the mesh front and exra gpu fan. It does get really dusty but that's fine for me. The cable management is also the best I have ever done in this case. So much room for everything
This is a great case and looks really sleek and professional, only problem is that you have to buy the rgb controller separately in order for the lights to work properly

Swapped cases from a smaller Corsair to this H5 Flow and I couldn't be happier. The case looks beautiful and not at all inexpensive. Twin 140mm fans in the front also look great when lit up with ARGB. The side panel definitely is tinted so your computer innards aren't TOO visible, but ARGB definitely shines through.

It was a pleasure to build in with the nice removable tray for the front fans and has plenty of room on the back side to hide all of the shameful wires. It looks great and the angled GPU fan light shines through the bottom of the case which gives a nice "underglow" look in the evening.

I utilize Fan Control and have custom curves for all of my fans. When web browsing I am able to keep all fans at their minimum speed of ~6XX rpm to keep things quiet and the CPU stays around 30-35C. I never see 100% fan speed on my curves and the temps stay around 70C even with 100% CPU load over an extended time.

Pretty slick case rgb fans in the front are more vibrant compared to most does fit 240mm aio only problem is you can’t get your ram out once it’s mounted but that could be me for the price and airflow amazing especially that third fan it blows right on 3070 but with that being said I’ve never went over 140F on cpu or gpu I would definitely buy some of their higher up cases if this wasn’t a budget build you can’t go wrong with this case recommend for a first build or if you want to downsize a little

Nzxt 750c PSU (C- series)
Msi b550 plus
1tb Samsung 970 evo 3x4
Ryzen 9 5900x (12core)
Kraken 240aio 140F at its highest
Asus strix rtx 3070 8g OC 138-142F

I’ll make this short, coming from the H510 where I got 77-80C on my rtx 3070, I’m now at max 67C full load, when I upgraded to this case. I know, thermals could be better but still that’s a significant improvement. It’s compact and provides all your basic needs. Would recommend to both my friends and enemies.
