reviews.review:
I wanted to give it a 5 starts, but I think there is room for improvement.

The already-good things:
- Lots of well-designed space for cable management (best feature of this case in my view) which has its own partition/split and which is hidden from the user so that you can have a convenient and clean build
- Looks nice (ARGB, glass panel, etc.)
- Pretty spacious AND wide
- Very convenient to work with relatively speaking (e.g. every main screw is a thumb screw for easy access and modification)
- Big front intake fans
- Has an independent ARGB controller and associated control buttons on the front panel
- Lots of room for installing custom fans, radiators, etc.
- Allows for vertical GPU installation
- Supports large(r) PSUs, and the location of the PSU is well-chosen and convenient
- And more..

The has-room-for-improvement things:
- Heavy
- USB ports of front panel can be very tight, may damage your device or cable heads (not a big deal, but it can improve)
- Front intake fans are DC and not PWM (so you cannot make them run slower or faster as per your needs)
- Only one small exhaust fan (120mm) which is again DC and not PWM
- Top does not have mesh or breathable build or structure (so air circulation could potentially be affected)

As a computer case it does a pretty good job overall but there are two flaws that, had I known ahead of time, I would have bought another case.
First flaw is when I shut my computer off part of the inside of the case stays lit up with the RGB lights that do not shut off and because the case sides and front are glass its visible throughout the room.
The second and much more serious flaw are the front 2.0 USB ports, they are both such a tight fit that my wireless mouse receiver was so stuck that when I tried to remove it, it tore in 3 pieces and the outside rectangle of metal of the receiver I had to remove with pliers. I now have a brand new dead $80 with tax Logitech M575 trackball mouse thanks to this case.

This is a great case very large. Only 4 out of 5 stars as it should be able to larger mother boards then a EATX 12x10.5. Luckily my mother board was 12x10.9 so I made it work. Other then that I love that the cables and power supply are hidden. Has lots of locations for drives and great cooling features both for air and liquid.
I would recommend this product just be aware of your mother board size.

Très jolie tour et vraiment bien pensé. J'aime que le support pour carte graphique vertical soit inclus bien qu'il aurait pu y avoir l'extension comprise.

Les matériaux sont bon. Par contre, devoir démonter la partie du haut et l'avant pour nettoyer les filtres est un gros moin. Aussi, plutôt que d'avoir coller certain autocollants sur les plastiques protecteur, ils ont été collé directement sur le verre. Ca complique trop les choses et difficile d'enlever sans égratigner le verre.

41cm d'espace pour installer la carte graphic est un gros plus car plusieurs tours de cette dimension sont limitée de ce côté là. Pas de port USB 3.1 type C :-( Aussi, inutile de payer l'extra pour le model rgb. Juste acheter la moin chère et ensuite ajouter les fans voulu, c'est meilleur marché.

La nouvelle version a le PSU shroud que le vieu model n'a pas. Tres bien, mais Thermaltake aurait pu en mettre un en vente à bon prix pour ceux qui ont le vieu model car il est dans la nouvelle version, gratuitement. On peut acheter le PSU shroud sur certains site mais à 80$ c'est ridicule. Je vais en faire un moi même.

Le verre trempé sur 4 surfaces, wow! Très jolie! Un peut trop sombre mais avec un bon éclairage c'est pas très grave. Tres épais, très résistant! Mais aussi, plutôt pesant. Ma tour est d'un poid similair à mon full tower Corsair Obsidian 900D, qui est beaucoup plus grosse que celle si.

Il pourrait aussi y avoir quelques panneaux pour cacher les câbles, d'un côté et de l'autre. Pour les personnes comme moi qui adore faire des méga clean builds, ça serait idéal.

Pour finir, je recommande fortement ce produit! Bon tweaking!

Picked up this case to replace my daughter's PC case because her GPU was running warmer than I was comfortable with. I knew this thing was going to be big but I gotta say it is a VERY BIG CASE. It offers a lot of options in terms of fan radiator mounts and GPU mounting compared with other cases in the same price range. Very good value for the money if you have the space for this thing. My only dislikes with this product is the placement of the Power Button is easy to accidently hit if the case is placed below the desk which hers is, and the fact I had to purchase the GPU riser cable separately - they should include this. Aside from this, I would recommend it.

Pro's

The case is huge
Offers plenty of space for a custom loop cooling system/AIO cooling solutions
Various fitments of radiators and chassis fans.
Sturdy, thick tempered glass doors
More then enough space for Hard Drives
Supports vertical and traditional GPU mounts
Tons of space and superior airflow
Amazing cable management
2 front mounted USB 2.0 + 2 USB 3.0 plugs
Magnetic dust filters galore
Essentially an open case design.
Slick Blue Riing 140mm fans

Con's

Sheet metal is thin so screws strip easy
Holes for above screws are also not pre-tapped and are fine thread furthering the stripping likelihood
Thumbscrews are a bit of a pain to get in on glass elements
Wish I could install 3 140mm fans in front instead of 2.
Would be nice if there was a PSU shroud for a cleaner look
Side mounted AIO cooler's require careful consideration as hoses are often not long enough
One of my USB 2.0 ports is DOA.
Case is very heavy

This is gorgeous case and is good value when you consider the amount of space and airflow it affords you. Had the sheet metal been a tad thicker and/or the holes for the screws were tapped or the screws themselves were of better quality all around, then this case would be a solid 5 star baby.

A very large gaming case, with pretty good ventilation and great looks with tempered glass.

Here's what all I have stuffed in it; previous case was a Fractal Define R6 USB-C which I'll reference.

MSI x399 MEG Creation
AMD Threadripper 2990wx
128GB g.Skill 2933MHZ DDR4 Trident RGB RAM
2x 10TB WesternDigital Gold SATA
4x 250GB Samsung EVO 870 M.2 (on Asus PCIe bifurcation card; included AERO card is 2 slots and the fan rubs...)
Cooler Master TR4 360
EVGA 1600 Titanium Power Supply
EVGA RTX 2080TI black edition
Firewire card (old audio recording gear)
10GTek 2x 10GB fiber NIC (yeah, I have fiber in my house, fight me.)
4x 140mm case fans I transferred over from my previous case
2x 200mm that it came with
1x 120mm fan that it came with

First, let me start that I was OK with my previous case, in fact, I think it's a better quality case in terms of insulated panels, the way things fit...but what I didn't like about it was the radiator/fans were behind a door (though OK ventilation, wasn't that great, could watch temps drop with it open) and that the main heat exit was with the top panel removed (grill underneath) which I didn't care for as I'm always concerned about stuff spilling in since I have a toddler and I'm also a bit messy, as much as I try not to be; and having that open also made it overall have more noise.

What drew me to this case is/was the giant 200mm LED fans behind tinted tempered glass in the front. It certainly has a wow factor. The bad news is that these fans are using a proprietary connector/fan controller, which, while that does have the ability to extend to another controller board, no cable is included to do so. Also, the fans that are included are at a fixed speed; which I'm not in favor of. When my system is not in use; the beast that it is, I like to either shut off or minimize what I can (though keep it running as I do access it remotely); both as a power bill reducer and as a thermal load reducer. Costs money to run it, costs money to cool the room it's in too! Plus maybe that environmental aspect, but not a priority, TBH. So, in order to bling this out as much as possible, those awesome looking fans have to go along with the controller they run off of =/

It's worth noting that one can fit, barely, 3x140mm fans inside between the left and right chamber, and there's a vent with a magnetic mesh on the right side of the case, lined up for it. With my spare non-LED fans there, I can feel it pulling in air through that. Nice! I also put a 140mm temporarily on the bottom, though it's meant for 120mm; so there's only 2 screws holding it and it is wider than the bottom vent. Accomplishes the goal of putting cooler air directly on my video card; rather than before where it was sitting above the power supply getting air off the backside of the 360 radiator pulling air from the front.

To that note, I have the 360 radiator mounted on the inside top of the case. Slick mounting system allows one to bump the bracket for the radiator over if one uses a 280mm radiator or need to for a 360 if you have a hose clearance issue. I mounted it with the hoses towards the back, there's a gap between the IO area and the VRM area, where the radiator hoses clear through no issue. Related to the slick mounting system; if one does use a 280 up there, you won't be able to put 200mm fans on top. I plan to in addition as there is a bit of a stagnant area surrounding the radiator.

HDD mounting is rear, or optionally from the top; behind the top panel; not really sure why either would be preferred over the other. Not that keen on position, as it puts the HDDs right behind the CPU; both I am certain contribute to heating the other and likely makes for a hot spot inside teh case; as there are no fans to move air in that area; path of least resistance says all the air would flow from the vents near the front half of the case. Perhaps there's room for a 40-60mm fan nearby; will explore that. There's an option for a pair of 2.5" drives to be mounted on the bottom, but then no fans in that area. Also comes with a water pump/reservoir mounting bracket; normally they don't so if I opt to do a custom loop later, I can; but will lose a 120mm fan mounting area on the bottom.

I marked the case down a few notches on noise level; mainly, you'll hear everything inside it because the top and front have nothing to filter/diffuse it. The included fans are quiet though, just mine for the radiator are noisy, and I have aggressive fan curves to get ahead of the fireball that the 2990wx can be when a load is put on it. Of note, the only dust filtration are on the right side panel (magnetic) as well as on the bottom. Those front fans are going to pull in a decent amount of dust (and in my case, cat hair) but not that big of a deal; to that, I've found that the mesh filters that most systems are using don't filter THAT well anyway; still end up having to blow out dust every so often.

As for ventilation, it does really well, actually; better than I thought it would considering the open-top I was using before with my previous case, but the fan positioning on the bottom is so much better, and I'm not drawing in air to heat it up with the radiator and then have everything else just kind of deal with it; instead I'm drawing in a lot of cool air from the front, side chamber, and bottom, and then blowing it out the back and through the radiator. I thought my CPU temps would suffer a bit, but nope! I sit between 36-40c idle in a room that's around 75F ambient (vs previous it'd be about 38-42c) and when throwing something at it using all cores 100% using some testing software, it stabilizes at 60C (previously it'd hit max @ 65c and start dropping cores to 2GHz round-robin style to keep it from going over that), and I might be able to bring that down a bit with a bit of adjusting of the curves; especially once I get the replacement fans involved; as the fans I can control are topping out at 85% rate.

Overall pretty happy with the case. One more thing - the ARGB LEDs are fantastic in this series of fans, my toddler surprised me, I set it to blue (cullee bwoo!!!), then red (cullee wed!!!), then green (cullee geeen!!!), then I thought I'd trick him and put it on one that mixes and shifts it...cullee wainbow!!!! What? Who taught him that? LOL

I replaced a Thermaltake Chaser Mk-1 with this thing. I thought the old case was big. This case is wider and heavier, as well as just as tall. Preinstalled fans keep the air moving through the gaps. It's tranquil in its default configuration. I used an AIO to keep fan noise down.

I recently also picked up a riser cable since GPUs are now scarily large, and I hate how they sag in the PCIe sockets. Rotating the back plate around was reasonably straightforward, though the screws feel like they didn't go in the same.

The area behind the motherboard has plenty of room for extra cables and tie-downs. I had to trim down a drive. There are only two 3.5" HDD bays, with room for 2 2.5" drives in the front and apparently on the outside of the 3.5" drive bay, but I didn't have any drives that size to explore with.

Overall, this is a very nice case, and I'm thrilled with the purchase.

I absolutely love this case. I’m not the best pc builder, but this case makes it easy with the amount of options and space it provides.

Pros:
-Space for anything you could imagine to build inside of it.
-Swinging door for easy access (also easily removable if it gets in the way when building.
-Multiple USB ports on the front.
-Magnetic and sliding-tray dust filters to help keep the case clean.
-Screw mounts to allow for different size fans, AIO cooler radiators, etc. to be mounted properly.
-Large cable management area in the back, which also houses PSU, HDDs, etc. with ease.
-Easy-access, removable plates to access the HDDs without removing the entire panel on the back.
-Many other pieces that allow for different customizations with mounting of graphics card, etc.

Cons:
-HEAVY.
-Massive case, so you need space to put it.
Busque varios dias, un gabinete para poder poner mi Noctua NH-U12A, para aquellos que tiene fans de 200 mm, es tu case, la circulacion de aire es batante agradable para los ryzen 9

Very large case but I knew this going in. I decided to purchase this over the Lian Li and the Corsair due to the USB type C and the USB 3.0 ports on the front and the ability to use 140mm fans on this case. (Lian Li no fans included and only supports 120mm fans). The corsair does not have the USB -C or the USB 3.0.

Overall the case was fairly easy to work on. A few hiccups.
1. The case does not come with a pci-e riser cable you need to also purchase one. The 300mm Thermaltake is plenty long enough. I would recommend staying with the Themaltake riser because there are two screws on the vertical GPU plate that need to be connected to the riser cable and I am not 100% positive that they are universal.
2. Another vertical gpu mount note: It took me a bit to figure out but you can only mount the GPU in the vertical position when the top GPU back cover is removed. When you have the case you will know what this note means.
3. This case is really meant for water cooling and there is ample room for this. I may want to upgrade to water cooling in the future and hence the reason to buy the case.
4. The top and front fan mounting brackets can be repostioned which was a nice plus. I moved my top mounting bracket to a closer position to the glass panel so I was able to put my RGB and fan controllers on top of the case for easier access.
5. As on previous reviews the included RGB controller is solely meant for the included fans and has to be reset for the MOBO to control the RGB.
6. The rear included RGB fan did not have solid sides so I immediately replaced it with a corsair fan. It bothered the hell out of me to look at it.
7. The side mount fans are intake fans. I was originally going to mount my radiator there but, I would be recirculating hot air into the case.
8. I would not have this case on the floor or in any dusty environment. There is a half inch unfiltered gap around all of the glass on the case.
9. No one make white 200mm RGB fans. So you are stuck with the 200mm fans.
10. Very quiet for having 11 fans going. CPU runs 5 degrees cooler then my old Fractal design R4 case.
11. Only 2 slot for SSD HD drives in rear. Came with mounting brackets for the bottom of the case to mount more....but that would look stupid. M.2 Drives are so much better and I don't know who would need more then that.
12. Top of the case has to be jiggled a bit to go into place.
13. Power button does illuminate if you connect it correctly. (I saw a review that complained that it does not illuminate)
14. If you drill into the side you might be able to mount 3 140mm fans, misleading specs on website.
15. Ample room to run RGB lights around glass door, but because case is so big you may need extension cables.
16. This is an ATX case. DO NOT TRY TO USE FOR EATX.
17. This case is all glass so you need to have good cable management in the viewable side but the backside can be a disaster.
18. Make sure that you thoroughly plan out any cables for the bottom of the MOBO because you will need to unmount PSU, GPU and riser cable to make ANY adjustments to these cables.
19. There is very little room behind the PSU to route cables and you will need to unmount PSU to make ANY adjustments.
20. I love this case and would highly recommend to anyone but it is LARGE.

System
I7 9700K
Zotac Amp Extreme 2070
MSI Pro Carbon 390
OLOY 3600 RAM 16 GB RGB
Samsung SSD
Samsung M.2 PCIE 3
6 Corsair Fans and corsair 240mm radiator
3 Asiahorse Crystal Fans very cheap
EZ DIY M.2 Passive Radiator with RGB (I wanted color lol)

name: NZXT H7 Flow RGB CM-H71FB-R1 - Compact ATX Mid-Tower PC Gaming Case – High Airflow Perforated Front Panel – Tempered Glass Side Panel – 3 x F140 RGB Core Fans Included – 360mm Radiator Support – Black
description:
• HIGH-PERFORMANCE AIRFLOW: Perforated front and top panels direct filtered air through the case to cool down components and enhance performance.
  • VIVID RGB LIGHTING: Includes three pre-installed F140 RGB Core fans that connect to a standard 5V ARGB header.
  • DEDICATED GPU FAN: An angled 120mm fan draws air from below the case to provide direct cooling for your power-hungry graphics card.
  • SPACIOUS COOLING SUPPORT: Up to a 360mm radiator in the top and front panels, 3 x 140mm fans in the front, and a 140mm fan in the rear.
  • READY FOR PERFORMANCE: Fits most NVIDIA GeForce RTX 40 Series graphics cards with its 365mm clearance. Display your GPU vertically using the NZXT Vertical GPU Mounting Kit.* *Sold separately. Reduces clearance to 349mm.
  • EASILY MANAGE CABLES: Wide cable channels with hooks, bridges, and straps take the guesswork out of organized cable management.

reviews.review: This case was the one I chose to house my PC build. As you can see, it comfortably fits my 7900XTX which is a rather large card to put in a midtower case. This case runs quiet, has dust filters over every major airflow port, and keeps things cool inside. By far the best case NZXT has to offer if you don't care for a flashy looking case and care about your rig staying cool inside. I will definitely keep this case for the long haul. Another pro is how easy they make clean cable management and all the USB ports on the tower be connected via one cord. Simplifying the process.
Awesome case. Love it. Lots of room for fans and air flow. Only downside is it is a little cramped near the power supply so hard to get hands in there to plugin/unplug. Solid 9/10 from me.

I have had many cases from NZXT. But this is the first one where the window is very dark. It’s off putting. I noticed that almost all their cases are like this now.

NZXT RGB fans use proprietary connectors and this case didn’t come with any RGB controllers, instead it came with a proprietary extension cable that you can’t find anywhere else. Forcing me to purchase a NZXT RGB fan controller that is nowhere to be found outside of NZXT website and it will cost you 40-50$

Otherwise the case is alright, definitely on the small side. I will not be going with NZXT on any further builds as their parts availability is dismal compared to any other company.

I needed to make a family member a workstation computer, and decided to take the opportunity to try this out. I'd been really interested in it for awhile, as it was the cheapest non-ITX airflow case on Amazon, and honestly it met all my expectations and more. Building in it with a micro-ATX board was smooth, the airflow is solid, and while the cable management chamber wasn't on par with a $200 case, I was able to stow everything away without too much issue. Room for two SSDs and two HDDs (in addition to any M.2's your board can fit) offers more than enough expand ability for most people.

Obviously this case has its drawbacks. You're limited to 120mm fans and a single 240mm front radiator, building on a full ATX would probably be a bit less smooth, and if you've got a million RGB cables then you may very well run out of room to discretely stow them. But this isn't the case you get for flash - it's the case you get when you don't care about looks and just want something cheap and practical. If your overclocked I9 needs a 360 RGB AIO, then this isn't the case for you.

This thing has the room and airflow to support the latest tech running the latest games or programs at good temperatures, at a better price than anything else on the market right now. If that's what you're looking for, then this will provide.

I used this case on my first PC build, I think this is a decent basic case. I had no issues with the case everything lined up with the mounting of the Asus mother board. I used a full size mother board that's why I bought this case. I've been using the case for a two years now with no problems, and its pretty sturdy. I really like the glass window and I installed a LED light strip, it looks good. It comes with one case fan two wire but I added 3 extra 3 wire fans so I can control the fan speed. I used this case on a Intel i510400 build and there's lots of room for a full size graphics card but I haven't installed one yet just using onboard graphics. I would buy again if I need to build up another PC.

Overall, plenty of room to work. Odd configuration for front mounting fans. Metal has a somewhat cheap feel and some flex. This is too be expected in this price range. Some design choices for cable routing options (or lack thereof) make little sense. For instance, the access for routing your atx power cable is so small, fitting an 8 pin through it is near impossible. Some thumb screws are plastic. I find that inexcusable as a cost cutting measure. The rear chassis fan provided was horrible and borderline non-functional. I replaced that with a Thermalright 120mm fan. If it's within the budget, spend the extra $25-$30 and look at something higher quality.

I was looking for the cheapest respectable case in terms of air and cable management and I am very satisfied.
It's 60$ CAD, however I got it for 40$ CAD as "used" from Amazon. In my case, it came in perfect shape.
Cable management space is fair.
Air ventilation is good overall. I did add 2 extra fans for a total of 2x 120MM in the front and 1x120MM in the back. (It was a bit of a pain to get the front panel off to mount the front fans, but nothing bad.
It's got a cheap water cooling for the CPU with the radiator mounted to the top of the case with another 120mm Fan exhausting out the top.
I was able to add in 2 SSD and 2 large mechanical drives at the bottom on the opposite side panel in the PSU box taking the entire length.

It's got a cheap acrylic side panel. All in all, it looks and feels like an extreme budget case yet does everything it has to do fairly well. Perfect budget case for the price.

However, if you are willing to spend 80-90$, there are far more attractive cases out there.

Nice case. The thing I like about Cougar over Thermaltake is that the feet on the Cougar cases are much sturdier. I'm a computer tech and the Thermaltake cases have very fragile bottom case feet. Quite often they brake off in shipping. This is important because I don't want the hassle of returning a case. The case will also hold a system board and still have enough room in the front to install a CD/DVD player without it hitting the system board. Just a really nice low cost case.

This is my second Cougar case in the last 6 years. Although this MX330-G is a bit smaller than my old one, it's much easier to build in.
Pros:
• Very spacious inside.
• There are more than enough holes to make cable management a breeze.
• The PSU bay is large enough to accommodate a larger than ATX standard PSU and has more than enough room to tuck away unused cables if you don't have a modular PSU .
• There is a lot of room between the front panel and the front chassis frame. I had more than enough room for the fans. Fitting a water cooling radiator should be no problem.
• The airflow potential is outstanding. The mesh front panel and the top exhaust, plus the included 120mm rear fan make airflow, well, a breeze. I put two 90mm fans in the front pulling air in, and one 90mm fan at the top pulling air out. My CPU and GTX GPU are not getting even close to max temp under max load. Vape testing reveals the air is being pulled directly out of the two exhaust fans. The combination of spaciousness and airflow is really the best feature of this case. I would definitely recommend going double 120mm fans in the front, and double 120mm fans at the top, but 90mm is what I had already and it seems to be working fine.
• There are no sharp edges and everything seems to fit together as it should. The rigidity of the case is slightly better than expected for the price, but after installing the power supply, it felt even a little more rigid.
• The clear side panel glass has rubber grommets on both sides to prevent damage from overtightening of the screws. I really like this feature.
• The back side panel comes off and goes on easier than any other case I've ever dealt with, and the cable management concave area is bloody perfect size.

Cons: (it was pretty hard to find any real cons, so I'm just being nit-picky here)
• The clear side panel screws are just barely long enough. They do the job of holding the side panel on adequately, but I would have preferred and extra millimeter or two for some extra comfort-of-mind.
• When installing the mechanical hdd in the trays, you have to use slim topped screws. The standard hex-sided phillips screws will prevent the tray from sliding in.
• The external PCIe slot bracket thingy is kinda wonky and I'm not even sure of the purpose it serves. It must be removed to screw/unscrew PCIe card retaining screws, but it does not appear to offer any retention properties on it's own. I don't think it's there for anything other than looks.
• The optical drive mount should be a little longer/stronger. For any of the people still holding on to optical drives, I'd recommend using a short one in this case, rather than a standard size long drive.

Overall, this case was much better than expected for the $52 price and I would not hesitate to buy it again for future builds. The aesthetics are just fine with me. Considering the airflow tests I've done, I'm not sure why I would buy a more expensive case. I'm glad I got this instead of some of the $30-$40 cases I was looking at.

Don't get the glass panel, it adds weight. The two compartment design complements a modular PSU. The drive spaces, both 2.5 and 3.5 are underneath the mobo area. Most cables then go down holes under 00with the mobo cables coming back up thru different holes.

So here I am, writing this review for the case I bought using my newly built PC using the case as I write this. Honestly, for about $45, the amount in which I bought the case (not counting shipping fees and state tax), this is a pretty amazing case. Don't get me wrong, it's not the best case compared to more higher-end cases such as NZXT's H510 case, but for what its worth, if you want a PC case that looks pretty neat and has a high amount of airflow, then the Cougar MX330-G is the perfect PC case for you!

PROS:
- It has a LOT (and I mean a LOT) of airflow thanks to the mesh on the front and top panels, and it supports up to five cooling fans up to 120mm (two for the intake, one for exhaust, and two on the ceiling of the case), essentially keeping your PC nice and cool, even in the toughest workloads, meaning you won't have to worry so much about your PC overheating. It also supports water cooling radiators from 120mm up to 240mm.
- Supports up to two 2.5" SSDs and two 3.5" HDDs, allowing you to store as many games and software as both your SSDs and HDDs can handle when combined.
- Comes with a transparent tempered glass window panel, allowing you to see your parts nice and clearly. It's also perfect if you want to show off builds such as full RGB builds (like mine), or builds that utilize water cooling thanks to its minimalist style (more on that later).
- Supports graphics cards up to 350mm in length (up to 13.8")
- Very minimalist style and comes with dust covers for your PSU and 3.5" drive bay, making your PC look even better, especially when going for a theme/style for your PC.
- I/O Panel comes with two USB 2.0 slots, two USB 3.0 slots, Audio Jack, Mic In, and a Reset Switch.
- It also comes with a magnetic dust filter on the top of the case, essentially making sure little to no dust gets inside of your case, which also means you don't have to clean the inside of the case as often.
- The interior of the case is nice and spacious, allowing for upgrades as well for your starting PC too.

CONS:
- Cable management isn't the best with this case, but it's fine. (If anything, would recommend a semi/full modular PSU)

The Verdict:
While not the best case in the world compared to the more higher-end cases that are more costly, for what its worth (around $50 depending on where and who you're getting it from, not counting shipping fees and state tax), the Cougar MX330-G is nonetheless an amazing case, and is a great starting case for those who are getting into the world of PC building. It also makes for a good case when it comes to budget building too, the only downside being its cable management; it's not the best unlike other cases such as NZXT's H510 case, but it's fine nonetheless, as it is definitely outweighed by the many positives this case has to offer. If you're looking for a case that has a minimalist style, a tempered glass window panel, and excellent airflow but don't want to spend too much on the case, then Cougar's MX330-G just may be the case for you.

Throughout the past few weeks I've been constantly searching for a good case for my current rig as I've had the Corsair Carbide 100R for about 4 years, and as you can see I've decided on this one: the Cougar MX330-G.

Pros:
Good price
Great quality
Lightweight
Better air intake
Cable management
Stylish
sweg
Cons:
screws may be too small for mounting fans/AIO in inner front panel of case (I'd invest in extra screws just in case)
-------------------------------

First impression:
Aesthetically pleasing and lightweight with a high quality material especially for being around $50. As I'm sure many of you fancy looking at the beautiful lighting and components of your build, this give you a tinted tempered glass with four hand screws to allow you to easily access anything within. The metal mesh front of the case allows for more air intake (especially with my Uphere RGB fans).
-------------------------------

Testing Temps:

Idle temps:
System Temp: 28-34c
CPU Temp: 27-35 c

Gaming Temps: (MGSV PHANTOM PAIN)
CPU Temp: 45-50c
-------------------------------

Building Experience:

Taking off any panel of the case, whether it was cable side panel, tempered glass or front panel, everything came out with ease, that way you don't feel as if you're going to break the bloody thing. Expansion slots has a stylish screw cover that allows to access your screws without any frustration (at least in my opinion).

ATX Motherboard (MSI Z97A GAMING 6) went on without a hassle and there was sufficient room above to add/remove 120m fans, possibly 240mm liquid cooler. there is room for a 240mm liquid cooler at the front of the case and has a small indentation to ensure that it allows room to avoid the possibility of a difficult/tight fit. Additionally, although it comes with a Cougar 120mm rear fan, it is able to mount a 120mm liquid cooler for anyone who would want to.
Another point to add, as I was going over the dimensions of the case, my HYPER 212 BLACK EDITION fit perfectly.

Mounting the two 120mm fans at the front of the case and above was where I had a bit of an issue. I'm not entirely sure that all these case may have this issue, but I notices that the 4 long screws to mount the fans had an issue with going into the mounting holes. After some time, I had to reuse older small screws (from my Corsair Carbide 100R case) to mount the fans on both sections; I installed the bolts from the inner part of the front so the fans that sit in between the front panel and the inner front panel of the case are sturdy. For the top portion I mounted them normally with the corsair screws.

Attaching all the other components was just peachy.
-------------------------------
PC SPECS:
CPU: i7-4790k
GPU: MSI GEFORCE GTX1080 TI GAMING X 11G
SSD: Kingston SA400M8240G 240GB (SSD IN M.2 2280)
HDD: WD Blue 1TB (2012)
RAM: G.SKILL RipjawsX DDR3 1600 C9 2x4GB
PSU: Corsair CX750M
MBD: MSI Z97A GAMING 6

-------------------------------
Overall:

I'd definitely recommend this case to anyone who wants something different and is currently looking at the reviews to see if they'd want it or not. Just do it you doughnut; I did and I have no regrets... well except the mounting screws, but that's not gonna stop me from enjoying this brilliant case

name: Asus ROG Strix Helios GX601 RGB Mid-Tower Computer Case for up to EATX Motherboards with USB 3.1 Front Panel, Smoked Tempered Glass, Brushed Aluminum and Steel Construction, and Four Case Fans, Black
description:
• Mid-tower with support for EATX motherboards featuring a metal chassis, 4mm-thick smoked, tempered-glass full view side panels, three easy-to-clean dust filters, and space for 9 Storage drives
  • Premium cable management includes translucent rear panel, adjustable multi-function cover featuring GPU support brackets and pre-run chassis cables
  • Keep your cool with built in fan hub, four 140mm fans and up to seven optional fan-mounting points
  • Custom Liquid Cooling ready features a water pump/ reservoir mounting bracket and support for radiators up to 420mm in length and 90mm thick (with fans)
  • Graphic card mounting options include Up to 2x vertically mounted Graphics cards or 3x horizontally mounted Graphics cards using the 7 expansion Slots

reviews.review:
As soon as you open the box, you can tell the quality. Nothing cheap here, great construction, designed for easy cable management, 4 USB 3.2 ports (Type A) and 1 Type C in the front. 2 control buttons: 1 for the LED lights and 1 for the fans, making this super convenient if you don't want to open your app to adjust them.

The design makes it easy to built your computer, whether you're using an ATX or EATX board. Still using SATA Hard-Disk, all bays are hidden at the bottom of the casing.

One little "heads-up" on the size of the case, having space for EATX boards makes it bigger than most. Not dramatically bigger though. The extra space makes it easier to install components like a watercooler; additionally big fingers can do perfect cable management. Finally, this quality case is also heavier than most but with the 2 side and front panels made of tempered glass, it can't be light.

After building gaming computers for more than 20 years, this is the best casing I ever had.

Used this for my latest build and it’s one of the nicest cases I’ve used to date. Very solid case and well thought out design right down to the horizontal GPU braced. It does come set-up for a vertical GPU but you’ll need to order a very expensive riser cable which is almost double the price of any other riser cable I’ve used. I’m using an Asus Thor 850W RGB PSU and the basement is made for it with a nice window to view the OLED Live-dash panel. It really would be a loss not to use an Asus THOR PSU with this case. It’s kind of a neat idea, designing a case with the top straps made to carry it... but you’d need a couple Sherpas if you plan to go far. It comes with a fan controller but I think these are really an outdated concept and I never actually use them. It also comes with fans, typically I use my own and I have a large supply of unused fans.

Pro’s
-solid construction
-designed to transport
-everything lines up
-fan hub
-4 fans included

Con’s
-Heavy
-expensive
-no riser cable included
-four more fans

Conclusion
I’m very happy with this case, it is a good purchase even at the premium price point. It would have been nice for it to include that expensive riser cable. It would be nice if Asus kept their fans and controller, but instead included the riser cable.

The best cable management I’ve seen in the back of a case, all glass paneling provide excellent visuals of your creation.. absolutely 5 starts... this was my second pc build

The ASUS ROG Strix Helios GX601 White Edition is a high-performance mid-tower computer case designed to enhance your gaming setup with its stunning aesthetics and advanced features.

Pros:

1. Striking Aesthetics: The white edition of this case boasts a sleek and eye-catching design that’s sure to turn heads, especially among gamers who appreciate style.
2. Premium Build: It features an aluminum frame and tempered glass panels, ensuring not only durability but also a premium look and feel.
3. Optimized for Gaming: Designed with gamers in mind, it offers ample space for ATX and EATX motherboards, GPU braces for added support, and extensive cable management options.
4. Outstanding Cooling: With support for a 420mm radiator, multiple fan mounts, and excellent airflow design, your components will stay cool, even during intense gaming sessions.
5. Aura Sync Compatibility: The case is Aura Sync-compatible, allowing you to synchronize your RGB lighting with other ASUS components for a unified and customizable lighting setup.

Cons:

1. Price Point: The premium features and design are reflected in the price, so it might be considered an investment for those looking for a top-tier gaming case.

In summary, the ASUS ROG Strix Helios GX601 White Edition is a showcase-worthy mid-tower computer case that not only enhances your gaming setup but also provides excellent functionality. Its premium build, outstanding cooling, and compatibility with Aura Sync offer a high-end experience for enthusiasts. While the price may be on the higher side, the combination of aesthetics and performance makes this case a worthwhile investment for gamers and PC builders who want a standout rig. Highly recommended for those looking to take their gaming setup to the next level.

I'm so glad that i spent a little extra on this case. The glass is beautiful and it pops on and off easily and the rgb on the front is perfect this is going to be a classic for years to come. Having no issues with the ventilation with it running a 3090ti on low can't even hear the fans. It was a pain matching parts to the black since like the only other rog color is white or apparently Evangalion but that's my only possible complaint.

I love this case !!

Been using it for the past few months and it was very easy to set up with a lot of features.

PROS :
- The Price
- Great Looking from all sides
- Compact and not too huge
- Great air flow if you have the FANS
- Magnetic FAN filters to put on the all the FANS exists, easy to remove and clean with a little water and dry it out.
- The Glass Panel is solid and Very sturdy and no chances of coming off with crews in the back to gold it in place
- Comes with 3 ASUS ARGB 120mm FANS
- Comes with a small Cheap ARGB hub/controller that you can use to connect a few connections to connect your others parts (6 in total) to control all the ARGB stuff trough the connector at the front top with a button.
- Very light and have a lot of room and enough place to put SSD's or HDD's (2 or 3 of each if I remember)
- As a piece made to hold you headset which is cool I guess..
- Comes with an extra strap for the thing on the front (If I remember well), and can also be removed like I did.
- Ports on the front top of the case which are (USB 3.0 if I remember)

CONS :
- About The ARGB hub/controller that you can use to connect a few connections to connect your others parts (6 in total). Also, something I had to research and found out how because the I couldn't control the ARGB in the software. if you want to use the PC software's to connect your ARGB hub/controller you will need to do this once on the desktop. Hold the RGB button at the top of the case until it flashes a quick double after 5/10 seconds. Now you will be able to control it trough the ASUS AURA or other software's.

- Another issue with the ASUS and case and controller, is that if you chose Corsair RAMS like me and you don't chose RGB RAMS that is not compatible with the ASUS AURA software is that you now have to use two software's that are not compatible. ASUS AURA and Corsair iCUE are not compatible, but there is a small fix. Install the latest two software's and after that find (CorsairPluginForAuraSync_2.0.30) plugins. It's hard to find and the newest versions does not work so use this specific version. After you have installed all 3, now go in iCUE and in the RAM settings now un-click the (Enable full software control) and rest the iCUE service in the bottom button. now the RAM will show up in the AURA software,

At the moment I don't have any other CONS or things that makes it bad. That's why I like it.

Overall the case is not bad. Only bad thing about it it the built in RBG fan controller broke while I was working on it, but I have big hands and broke it on accident. Not a quality issue, just my clumsiness.
Un excelente producto, llegó antes de la fecha prevista, y en calidad excelente.

I assembled my PC myself. It was quite modular and easy to do with this. The inbuilt lights are great, fans are noiseless. The quality of wires is much better than Zebronics of similar price.
Overall, it is a great product.
Best cpu in this price.

name: Cooler Master NR200P White SFF Small Form Factor Mini-ITX Case with Tempered Glass or Vented Panel Option, PCI Riser Cable, Triple-Slot GPU, Tool-Free and 360 Degree Accessibility, with PCI Riser
description:
• Tempered glass or Vented Panel: The NR200P comes with the choice of a vented steel side panel for unrestricted airflow, or a crystal-clear tempered glass side panel to reveal the beauty of a computing beast.
  • Unrestricted Cooling Potential: Holds up to 7 fans. 5 sides of open ventilation. Fits CPU coolers up to 155mm tall or up to 280mm long radiators.
  • Full-size GPU Fitment with Vertical Mounting: Up to 330mm long triple-slot GPU support. PCI Riser included for a stylish vertical mount option.
  • 360 Degree Accessibility: Every panel and frame part can be dismantled to allow advanced disassembly and 360 degrees of access to work on components.
  • High-quality Materials: Thick, powder coated SGCC steel lasts the life time of the chassis and resists marring from transport or handling.

reviews.review:
I picked this up last week because I was tired of my old case which was dirty, dented, and dingy. I actually got this one "used-excellent" for $10 less and total cost was $100 (Canadian) after taxes. Why am I mentioning the price? Well...

The only reference I saw to the need for an SFX power supply was in a comment someone made - it's not (clearly) anywhere in the description or specs. So - when I took my old pc apart (which - with the exception of the case - had been fully upgraded in November) and started to put things in, I discovered that the ATX power supply I had was never going to fit. "SFX required" said that earlier-mentioned comment, so I went back to Amazon . ca and looked for one. Yeah, the cheapest one I could find was just over $200. Fine - it was a decent power supply, 80+ gold rated with a 7 year warranty, so i got it. I waited till the next day to continue the build and discovered much to my disappointment that the cpu liquid cooler i had for my previous PC was too big - and it was only a single fanned one - so off I trot to Amazon *again* to find a low-profile cpu fan. $76 and a day later, I have my CPU fan.

In case anyone's thinking "this guy's an idiot - why would he expect his old pc components to fit in an mini-ITX case???" - well, this idiot's previous set up was also a mini-ITX - it was just a different shape (more of a cube) so bigger things fit. Thankfully - my RTX 3060 fit just fine...except I can't put any fans underneath it on the bottom of the case, but that's fine, I have enough fans for now.

Having said all this, my verdict is that this is a really well built little case, very solid, there were enough screws and bits for whatever setup i needed, and while the instructions seemed a bit confusing at first, it was just because there were so many options for set up. This really is a beautiful case and I don't regret any of the required purchases - I just hate surprise expenses - but in the end, it was totally worth it.

The whole thing is now together, I have

Pros:
- The white model looks extremely clean and minimalist.
- All panels can be removed, along with most (all?) of the internal brackets. If you have difficulty building computers because of the lack of room to work, then this is the perfect case for you.
- There is two locations for the SFX power supply, allowing you to use wider (244mm) and taller (up to 226mm) motherboard. However this feature is practically pointless (see below).

The problem:
- Most mini-ITX motherboards cost at least the same price if not 25 to 50% higher than micro-ATX boards, you end up paying a lot more for less features (ex: 2 RAM slots instead of 4, only one M.2 instead of two, etc).
- The selection of mini-ITX motherboards is also extremely limited compared to mATX.
- While this case was specifically made for mini-ITX and three-slots-wide GPUs, this case should in theory also fit 3-slots micro-ATX motherboards. The problem is that 3-slots-tall micro-ATX motherboards are basically impossible to find depending on your CPU.
- If only they made this case one slot taller, it would also have been compatible with mATX motherboards. IMHO it's already way too big to be classified as a small form factor case, so what's one more slot in height?

TL;DR: if you're thinking about buying this case, make sure you complete your parts list and check that everything will fit. After over a week of futile research for 226mm or shorter mATX motherboards for LGA 1700, I'm regretting buying this case even though it is the most beautiful case I've ever owned.

This NR200P is fairly easy to work with as majority of the panels are removable for easy access; I did not have any issues installing a CPU cooler while the motherboard was pre-installed and I did end up using an EVGA SFX power supply for this system. Majority of the work is tucking in all the necessary cabling for the power supply which is assisted by the velcro straps on the power supply bracket.

I chose this case as it has a fairly small footprint and comes with a glass side panel that can be customized with a few vinyl decals; I appreciate that there is a pcie 3.0 riser cable for vertical GPU mounting and two black Cooler Master PWM fans included. I didn't end up using a lot of the accessories included with this case and I don't plan on swapping out the configuration too often; I am using M.2 storage drives exclusively as my ITX motherboard supports two NVMe SSDs and the case has a nice large cutout for easy access to the back of the motherboard.

Since this case does not have a USB-C front panel port, you can definitely opt for more affordable mini ITX motherboard options that do not have an internal USB-C Gen 2 front panel connector. I did end up re-routing most of the front panel connection cables behind the metal front panel to keep things clean; It is a challenge to integrate RGB fans with a controller as you may need to sacrifice a 2.5 inch drive mounting point.

Temperatures are good once you populate the top and bottom with 120mm fans; 31 degrees idle so far with an NH-L12s cooler and an RGB fan. Since there is an i5 10400f inside, this 65w CPU is thermally manageable in this case and I don't plan to do any overclocking. There is plenty of dust filtration to keep it clean inside.

Overall, I feel there is a lot of excess case parts when finally completing the build process and I am not sure if can find a use for them. It's a beautiful case with the glass panel; You really need to do some research and see what restrictions there are for component sizing. It may be difficult to fit a custom cable extension kit as there is very little room to tuck excess cabling.

Una gran opción que te permite tener un equipo completo en un espacio reducido. El metal es resistente y no se dobla con facilidad. Tiene rejas en las tapas laterales y permite colocar una MB mATX de las pequeñas y posiblemente una PSU de tamaño normal colgándola con los cinturones de velcro incluídos. También cabe una GPU de hasta 3 ventiladores pero hay que tener cuidado con las medidas antes de comprar la GPU para asegurar que quepa.

This review is for Cooler Master NR200P White SFF Small Form Factor Mini-ITX Case

I love this PC case. It's big enough to use large air coolers and large graphics cards, but it doesn't take over your whole desk. I especially like how you can take off the side panels and bottom when you are assembling your PC. It makes it so easy to access all the components and route your cables. I like this case so much that I bought an extra one when it was on sale, just in case a friend wanted me to build them a computer or something.

This is an excellent case, and one of the few mainstream and affordable small form factor PC cases. Its major relative compromise is the size, which is close to as large as "SFF" gets. The case is also heavier than most SFF cases, being mostly made of steel, versus aluminum or plastic. However, it has nearly no size or cooling limitations in its class. Aesthetically, it follows the general SFF PC trend of minimalist design. Anything I have planned for my build, be it the largest GPU I can afford, or adding some old 3.5" hard drives to my system, are possible in this case, which is easily transportable, though not quite backpack portable. I won't spend much time talking more about the positives of this case but I'll highlight some of my gripes, which should not be deal breakers, but ways that Cooler Master can improve the case without reducing its capabilities.

Though the NR200 can accommodate almost any ITX hardware, its layout design is not completely perfect. I would have appreciated some gaps in the frame or motherboard area for routing cables behind the motherboard. One of my PSU cables is routed between the motherboard panel and the case's right side panel (when looking towards the case), but it's the flat kind which raises the case's side panel ever so slightly. Others with round or quality braided cables looking to route their cables behind the motherboard without raising the side case panel will need to route the cables in the gap between the motherboard and the motherboard panel. Unfortunately, they will need to do this before installing the motherboard, and uninstall the mobo every time before disconnecting. Some extra spaces or gaps that allow the cable connectors to slide through would have solved this problem. Another gap for the 24 pin connector would have improved quality of life a little, too, though I'm not sure if that would be possible in a practical spot. Having the thick 24 pin cable extending from the PSU in its default position can press down on the GPU without some careful cable management. Fortunately, Cooler Master provided some velcro straps underneath the PSU that help with this a lot, likely because they anticipated this problem for most consumers. Still, I can tell that Cooler Master intended this case to be as easy as possible for beginners, and neat cable management and avoiding pressure on the GPU will likely be a fairly difficult step of building in this case. Finally, the case could perhaps use some lengthier front I/O cables, so that they could have been routed behind the motherboard without blocking the PSU fan.

Speaking of front I/O, I would have also preferred a USB type C connector on the front. I can understand that it was not included due to cost, but I would prefer a version of the NR200 with a type C port and no fans, and likely would have even paid $10 more for that tradeoff. My version of the NR200 is the base version which comes with one 92mm fan and one 120mm fan, and the included fans are fine; not exceptionally quiet but not annoyingly loud. Still, I might replace both of them with Noctua fans to get the quietest possible airflow, and the 92mm fan will definitely not fit when I upgrade to the CPU cooler I plan on getting. Though Cooler Master included fans to appeal to customers who will use stock coolers and don't want to worry about aftermarket cooling solutions, they still have an opportunity to cater to more enthusiast consumers (who constitute a large part of the SFF community). Many SFF builders will either not need the included fans, or prefer to choose their own. They likely also prefer having near to mid-term future proof features. A version of this case without fans and a type C port, offered at a small premium, would still be a great deal.

My unit also came with a minor defect - the metal frame (not sure of the correct term) of one of the USB ports at the top is not completely connected. The end of the metal frame is bent inwards slightly as shown in the picture. I haven't encountered problems while plugging and unplugging USB devices, albeit carefully, into the jack multiple times over the past couple of weeks, so I didn't deduct a star or try to get it replaced. I'm optimistic that it'll stay as-is and not get bent worse over time. If this is a problem in manufacturing, hopefully Cooler Master can address this issue.

This case is fantastic for its size. Every single panels comes off fairly easily, it was super easy to build in and it had enough room to fit a massive cooler in which means my Ryzen 5900x isn’t thermal throttling during testing,

This case is awesome, well designed, well made. This was my first computer build, and my son, who has some experience, questioned my decision to go with the NR200P given the additional challenge of working in a small space--until he saw it in person. He was so impressed, he wanted one for himself.

Here is my build:

Intel Core i7-12700K
ASUS ROG Strix B660-I (mini-ITX)
Nvidia RTX 3070FE GPU
Kingston Fury Beast DDR5 16 x 2 RAM (rgb)
EVGA Supernova 750W SFX power supply (note small form factor)
SK Hynix Platinum P41 2 TB m.2 SSD
SK Hynix Platinum P41 1 TB m.2 SSD
Thermalright Silver Soul 135 white cooler
Arctic P9 PWM PST 92mm fan
Arctic BioniX F120 fans x 2
Chassis fan hub CPU Cooling (the really cryptic looking one)

Noteworthy: The Thermalright cooler DOES fit, even with the glass side. Actually has some room to spare.

The Kingston RAM has only about 2mm clearance from the cooling tower. But 2mm is enough.

My fan hub sits behind the front panel, nicely hidden, because it's not pretty. I routed several things behind that panel. You can also place SSDs there, but mine are both m.2, directly plugged into the MB, so that front panel was wide open for wires.

I added two fans on the bottom and one at the back. Based on my review of the "literature" (YouTube), the best airflow with a cooling tower is to intake from the bottom and back, and exhaust thru the top. Including the fan in the center of my cooling tower, I have 6 fans in here and no problems with heat. The two stock fans are on top, and [update alert] a year later, they're still working flawlessly. I did add a magnetic filter on the back to block off the openings back there since I'm intaking air thru all those openings at the back. Technically, it's not held there by magnets. The tab from the case top holds it in place perfectly. My computer sits right next to an air filter which sits right next to a chinchilla cage, with hair and dust floating everywhere.
______________________________________

Everyone talks about the challenge of routing the cables in such a small case. For me, this was the fun part and I was very happy with the outcome. Like I said, I'm a first time builder, so I have no experience. Which means you can do it too. You can decide based on the pics whether you think I did a decent enough job.

Put together a second NR200P system to surprise my dad. He didn't need a dedicated GPU, or rgb RAM, but otherwise the builds were pretty similar, and it went equally well. LOVE LOVE LOVE the colors, too! I would've gone with pink if it hadn't been $50 more at the time of my build. Still kinda wish I had, because pink is my color. But the white looks really nice too.

Two great experiences with this case! Highly recommended.

name: Noctua NH-U12S chromax.Black, 120mm Single-Tower CPU Cooler (Black)
description:
• Proven premium heatsink (more than 200 awards and recommendations from international hardware websites), now available in an all-black design that goes great with many colour schemes and RGB LEDs
  • Slim 120mm size for excellent case, RAM and PCIe compatibility: Fits most tower cases (158mm height), doesn’t overhang the RAM slots, doesn’t block the PCIe on most ATX and Micro-ATX motherboards
  • Renowned, award-winning NF-F12 120mm Focused Flow fan with Low-Noise Adaptor and PWM for automatic speed control: Full cooling performance under load, whisper quiet at idle!
  • Includes high-end NT-H1 thermal paste and SecuFirm2 mounting system for easy installation on Intel LGA1851, LGA1700, LGA1200, LGA115x and AMD AM5 & AM4
  • Renowned Noctua quality backed up by 6-year manufacturer’s warranty, deluxe choice for Intel Core i9, i7, i5, i3 (e.g. 14900K, 14700K, 14600K) and AMD Ryzen (e.g. 7950X3D, 7900X3D, 7800X3D, 7700)

reviews.review: it runs very quiet, I got the white chromax cover to go over it and all together it looks beautiful in my pc.

I previously owned a Corsair H100iv2 CPU liquid cooler with idle temps of 19-25C, under max load 45C, 2hr stress test 52C. With the Noctua NH-U125 that I currently have installed 28-31C idle temps, under max load 50C, 2hr stress test 65C. At Noctua $94.95(CAD) vs Corsair $124.99(CAD) you get what you pay for. The price seems fair for its performance. Honestly, if you can expense a water cooler and trust having one in your build then I'd just go for it. If not, then this definitely would not be a bad start for an CPU air cooler.

*This is a 2nd review after ordering a 2nd fan for my Noctua NH-U125. I am now saying if you're going to get this CPU air cooler, order the 2nd fan with it as well!. Also, I figured if I could spend close to $150 for a Corsair liquid cooler for "bEsT PeRfoRmAnCe" then why not do the same for my Noctua?. Plus, you will not be upset with the performance! I can actually say I am happy with my overall purchase!. Idle temps 29-30C, casual load (e.x checking email, watching YouTube, surfing web) 30-31C, under heavy load (gaming, streaming, discord, music, etc.) 45-50C, 2h stress test 60-62C. I should also clarify or make sense to my previous post where I said "max load". I should've said "heavy load" as my "max loads" would've actually been the stress test temps. So, Noctua NH-U125 $94.95CAD + Noctua NF- F12 cooling fan $33.16CAD = $128.11CAD (before taxes) for the same performance as or better in some cases than a liquid cooler was a good purchase.

Notes:
Noise level is quiet. Much quieter than my previous liquid cooler or liquid coolers I've came across.
I run my fans at 64% which is around or little over 1200RPM on my front fan and 1500RPM on my back fan. I am comfortable with that as I receive desired/reasonable temps . (Note: Temps do spike and goes right back to its actual temp, but that's normal of a CPU to do that.)
I am a believer that ambient temperature affects CPU temps so I keep a window cracked about 4-5 feet away from my pc so its keeps the room cool and fresh air gets in. In the winter, I feel its a plus when the room gets cold as my temps are rock solid at times (I start to think my pc froze, lol).
Overall the best purchase you can make on a CPU air cooler. I would now even rule out getting a liquid cooler if you can purchase this with a 2nd fan.

Purchased this because I was unhappy with the temperatures my R9 3900x was sitting at with the stock Wraith Prism cooler. I couldn't decide between this and the NH-D15 (and D15S variant which is identical but with a single fan for $10 less). Eventually went with this U12S and am quite satisfied. I'm sure the D15 would outperform this cooler slightly, but it's also quite a bit bulkier and this seems to do just fine cooling a 3900x with Precision Boost Overdrive enabled.

It was pretty expensive for a tower cooler but I trust the reliability and build quality of this a lot more than an equally priced AIO water cooler, and in black it is pretty good looking if a little understated. I threw on a cheap Fractal Design Silent 120mm fan to pull air off, with the included Noctua fan pushing, and my temps dropped about 10-15 degrees to a much more comfortable zone.

Wraith Prism -
50-65 @ idle
85 - 90 @ stress test

Noctua NH-U12S -
35 - 50 @ idle
70 - 80 @ stress test

I didn't choose this for noise, but it's definitely quieter than the stock Prism cooler at equivalent load.

Mounting was relatively easy. I had difficulty aligning the actual cooler with the brackets and screwing it on, took a couple tries and smeared my thermal paste around but it did eventually seat itself and the installation was "easy", just took a bit of time to get right. Didn't even have to take the motherboard out of the case.

Note that this while this does come with the mounting hardware to accommodate an extra fan, it does not come with a splitter cable, so if you want to add a second fan to the cooler you will need to get one, or you can just plug the extra fan into a free motherboard case fan header. I had a Noctua splitter laying around from a previous build so I went that route.

I needed a new cooler for my ASUS Z390 TUF-Gaming Plus WIFI ATX motherboard since I lost the mounting plates for previous cooler (switched from AMD to Intel CPU). I heard the Noctua fans were really quiet and like everyone else I really can't stand that brown color. The backplate for the classic EVO 212 was too tall for my case (Elite 430)- again typical problems with EVO 212 just being such an awkward size for so many systems. Thought I'd give this a try because it looks awesome and have heard good things, and the price seemed reasonable.

Not only did the NH-U12S backplate fit just fine, it was far easier to install than the D92 I had previously. It fits perfectly and the instructions were fairly straight forward, with lots of guides online to help guide me.

The fan is remarkably quiet I honestly thought my previous fans were quiet but I'm going to be replacing every fan in my system now with Noctua (if I can find black) or something similar. It keeps the CPU very cool and even when it picks up at full RPM its very quiet - and I'm not even using the like adapter PWM switch it came with (which allegedly makes it even quieter).

Honestly this CPU cooler looks awesome and works awesome and was almost a joy to install (took me a while, but half of that was figuring out how to use the thermal paste LOL - twist the black cap - use pliers (carefully) if you need better grip). Only complaint is that I wish it came with a second fan so I could have the push / pull arranagement - it does come with the extra clip though so you can easily attach another fan - I just want all black instead of the antique signature brown lol)

5/5 would buy again. Looks almost apple-esque if you add a matching all black push fan.

J'en est entendu parler pendant des années ! ces fameux Noctua que tout le monde vante par sont efficacité , la en version noir Noctua offre selon eux efficacité et design , c'est se qu'on va voir !

J'ai deux machines , l'une très bien optimisé pour la chauffe ( i5 9600k - z390 msi mpg gaming edge ac ) et une autre qui est très mal optimisé pour cela mais qui est pourtant une copie conforme mais version concurrent ( Ryzen 5 3600 avec une X570 msi gaming edge ac )

Tester en bureautique et sur deux jeux bien particulier ( un jeux solo avec graphisme a fond et un autre jeux multijoueur a faible graphisme a 300fps ) The Witcher 3 et Apex Legends.

Comparé contre 2 Watercooling le L240 V2 anti-fuite ( que j'ai mis en push-pull c'est a dire 2 ventilateur devant et 2 ventilateur a l'arrière , aspiration et extraction ) et le L360 V2 anti-fuite de chez Deepcool donc du très bon a bas prix !

Config Intel : Le ventirad se comporte très bien a l'allumage du pc rien a dire avec une température général a 37 degrés ( pour un processeur boosté a 4.40GHZ ) , avec toute mes applications de démarrage ( j'en est pas mal ) j'ai constaté un pic a 57 degrés pendant 1~2 seconde ( tout a fait normal car il a du encaisser plusieurs applications ouverte d'un seul coup ) donc pour la bureautique c’est tout a fait se a quoi je m'attendais , aucune chauffe et c’est logique mais qu'en est-il des jeux ?
Je n'ai tester qu'apex legends sur la config intel ( étant un pc basé esport ) et il se comporte assez bien il est entre 51 ~ 61 avec une température général de 54 degrés en jeux ( autant dire que la aucun soucis et que le pic a 61 n'est absolument rien ! )

Pour le comparé a l'ancien L240mm V2 de deepcool qui était installé dans la configuration Intel a vrais dire il y'a pas de différence flagrante mais je tient quand même a la souligné.
avec le watercooling L240mm V2 ( que j'avais mis en push-pull je le rappelle ) je n'obtenais pas de pic au démarrage a plus de 45 degrés malgré les application qui s'ouvre ( plus de 25 applications environ ) mais le Noctua lui avais un pic a 57...en sois se n'est rien mais les chiffres parlent mieux , avec une température dans le bureau similaire a un degrés près.
En jeux la température est exactement la même hormis que le ventirad a un pic plus haut de chaleur et redescend plus lentement en température ( le pic le plus élevé sur le Deepcool L240 V2 étant 56 maximum et le ventirad 61 ) pas une grande différence et en rapport perf/bruit prix ? honnêtement sa se vaux , ils on quasiment les même performances.

J'avais acheter mon L240 V2 avec une promo + coupon Amazon pour 40 euro seulement !!! qui a des perf un peu mieux que le Noctua , tandis que le noctua coûte 70 euro , un peu chère mais sa fait le taff et il est très bon !

Le montage est d'une simplicité !! par contre les watercooling...avec le système RGB c'est d'un chiant...surtout si comme moi vous avez énormément de ventilateur de la même marque dans le pc pour tout relié...

Mais j'ai pas fini ! place a la partie négatif de se test !

Config AMD : J'ai conscient que le modèle de carte mère n'est pas réputé pour sont optimisation de VRM et de Vcore mais j'ai tout de même obtenue un score vraiment pas terrible...

En bureautique + charge d’applications au démarrage le Noctua encaisse un pic a 64 degrés !! ( processeur boosté a 4.20GHZ ) aie aie aie sa commence a piqué...mais se n'est rien car cela dure qu'au lancement des applications et sa se stabilise assez vite pour une température général a 48 degrés ( sur le bureau oui oui , j’espérais mieux... )
Sur Apex Legends j’obtiens une température entre 54 et...71 !! le pic ici est légèrement trop a mon gout mais sa se stabilise généralement vers 65 degrés....
Sur The Witcher 3 j’obtiens une température entre 53 et 69 avec une température général de 59...ici ça va rien de méchant non plus.

Mais la différence entre le watercooling L240 en push pull que j'ai aussi placé sur la config AMD est aussi peu flagrante , le watercooling s'en sors avec des températures légèrement moins élevé mais mon L360mm ( un très très gros watercooling donc , explose littéralement le Noctua coté stabilité et pic de chaleur )

Pourtant d'une marque peu connus ( Deepcool ) on m'avais dit que les watercooling de marque comme deepcool n'avais rien avoir avec les meilleur ventirad du marché et bien...d'après les test c'est faux !

Conclusion , une solution a air sera totalement compatible et gérable sur une config optimisé Intel mais chez AMD je préfère très largement la solution watercooling qui finalement d'après les "on-dit" n'est pas la uniquement pour faire jolie.

je comptais remplacer mon L360 de ma config AMD étant ma config principal mais finalement je l'ai mise dans ma config intel car je préfère la stabilité et la fraicheur de mon L360 dans ma config AMD.

( je tient a dire que dans se test le ventirad Noctua ne fait aucun bruit poussé a fond et qu'il était régler a fond constamment durant ces test c'est a dire 1500rpm environ )

Donc si c'est pour jouer uniquement sur une config intel et faire un overclock léger vous pouvez y aller mais si c'est pour du montage poussé/3D avec du AMD n'y penser pas...sa sera correcte mais sur de longue années le processeur va encaisser et ne pas aimer donc préféré les solutions Watercooling chez AMD.

Finalement monter sur un 9600k après plusieurs mois d'utilisation la qualité est irréprochable , je remonte la note d'une étoile , j'adore vraiment la simplicité de cette marque incroyable.

Edit : Finalement c'est normal pour AMD, leur processeur conduit largement moins bien la chaleur au "die" a cause de leur trop large capsule, donc non, il reste cependant très performant sur du Intel qui eux n'ont pas ce soucis.

Ya llevo 2 adquiridos y son simplemente geniales, ambos se utilizan con procesador i5 13400f y 13400, con la pasta térmica suministrada de noctua.
Se que son procesadores frescos en comparación con otros,pero escribo esta información por si a alguien le es de utilidad.
El acople con el procesador es completo y muy facil de poner.
El comportamiento en gaming para full HD en Cyberpunk 2077con una RTX 3060 ti en gráficos altos/ultra y RTX activo me dió picos de temperatura de 64°C, promediando aproximadamente 60°C con uso del procesador entre 60% y 85%, todo esto a una temperatura ambiente de 38°C.
Esto me lleva a pensar que posiblemente si este procesador esta al 100%, difícilmente la temperatura sobrepasaría los 70°C bajo estas condiciones.
El dicipador está en un gabinete NZXT
H5 Flow con 6 ventiladores noctua NF-P12 redux-1700, tres ingresado aire y 3 sacando, con una curva de ventiladores que prioriza que la GPU no pase de 74°C.
No tengo ningúna queja sobre el producto, siempre me llego en buen tiempo, por el tema de aduanas estos productos me llegan un poco más tarde que otros, pero al final la calidad del producto y las buenas condiciones en las que llega hacen que valga la pena la espera, en promedio el paquete no me tardó más de 10 días para México.

The Noctua NH-U12S chromax.Black is a top-tier 120mm single-tower CPU cooler that not only excels in cooling performance but also adds a touch of elegance to any desktop setup. This cooler has far surpassed my expectations, providing outstanding cooling capabilities with a sleek black design that complements my desktop aesthetics.

The standout feature of the Noctua NH-U12S chromax.Black is its exceptional cooling performance. The single-tower design, coupled with the 120mm NF-F12 PWM fan, efficiently dissipates heat from the CPU, ensuring optimal operating temperatures even during demanding tasks and heavy workloads.

The sleek black color scheme elevates the overall look of my desktop build. The chromax.Black design adds a touch of sophistication and seamlessly blends into various themed builds, enhancing the overall aesthetics of my system.

The NH-U12S chromax.Black is compatible with a wide range of motherboards and memory modules, providing sufficient clearance for tall RAM modules and ensuring ease of installation.

The SecuFirm2 mounting system offers a hassle-free and secure installation process, reducing the risk of damage during setup.

I appreciate the low noise level of the NF-F12 PWM fan, even at maximum speeds. This ensures a quiet and undisturbed computing experience, even during intensive tasks.

Noctua is renowned for its high-quality cooling solutions, and the NH-U12S chromax.Black is no exception. The cooler is built with precision and premium materials, ensuring reliability and durability.

In conclusion, the Noctua NH-U12S chromax.Black CPU cooler is a top-notch cooling solution that not only delivers exceptional performance but also enhances the visual appeal of any desktop setup. Its outstanding cooling capabilities, sleek black design, and quiet operation make it the perfect choice for enthusiasts and gamers alike. If you're looking for a high-performance CPU cooler with a touch of elegance, the Noctua NH-U12S chromax.Black is the ultimate option. I highly recommend this CPU cooler for its outstanding performance and the stylish aesthetics it brings to my desktop build!

Keeps my I9 12900k idling at 20-25 Celsius. In every game I play, (Elden Ring, Cs2, AC6, BG3, etc..) My cpu is never above 50 degrees, while being dead quiet. I've seen it hit 70 degrees maybe once ever, and it was dissipated in a second. Absolute GOAT cooler.

I used it on ryzen5 5600, and temps is stable at around 50-60°c . And only max out at around 65°c after hours of gaming. Recommend for anyone who is tired of aio coolers...it even works better than thermatake th360 with push/pull fan configuration.

name: Lian Li LANCOOL II MESH C RGB-S USB Type-C Included Mid-Tower Snow White - LAN2MRS.50
description:
• Country of origin : China
  • Package Quantity : 1
  • 3 x included 120mm 3-PIN 1300 RPM ARGB fans
  • Unprecedented modularity

reviews.review: Excellent airflow. Lots of options in general for ssds and room for long gpu's. Extremely impressive and complicated design that works. Some of the removeable metal parts could be called flimsy, but they do the job. The default configuration will work with no added fans. I added two 120s at the bottom(intake), and two 140s at the top(exhaust).

The case makes it easy to put all the pc parts together. This was the case I used for my first and only build, and had no issues. The side doors open like a fridge, which I think is really cute. The doors also detach nicely, making it easy for future upgrades.

Excellent case, swapped my old system into it without a hitch - using a handy YouTube video. It fits well under my desk and the front RGB fans look & work great. Case is nice & wide with lots of easy access panels. The only thing I could criticize is the PSU doesn’t slide through the back, so be careful installing!

The metal on this case is soft. The front mesh arrived dented from shipping. The styrofoam is hard so that transferred the pressure when the box was being dropped. The perforated psu shroud door and the two shroud top covers are flimsy soft and has lots of flex. The cable management bar is no different. It's a heavy case since almost everything is made of metal aside from the upper/lower part of the front grill, hdd sleds and psu dust cover.

The swinging glass doors are nice features but the back side near the motherboard tray is unnecessary. The metal cable covers are already covering the managed cables so there's no point. The glass panels has no handle so the bottom doors need to be opened before the it can be accessed. The three pre installed rgb fans use non-standard plugs. The means the rgb buttons on the case can't control other rgb fans if the original fan fails or the whole fans needs to be swapped out for a different brand.
Damage on box. But case was fine.
It's a really well made and beautiful case. Great air flow, easy to manage wires. 100% recommended!
Great product made of quality material . Would buy again

This case is lightweight and easy to work with, even for a first-time builder like me. It's spacious enough to fit all my components, and the mesh front panel provides great airflow. I'm really happy with this case, and I would definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a great mid-tower case.

Mi pareja ha montado la torre y no tuvo ningún problema para colocar las piezas, el montaje fue sencillo.
La torre es grande y de buen material, un poco pesada. Ha quedado estupendo el resultado. Llevo con ella más de 2 años y va cómo la seda.
Muito bom o gabinete e a cor branca e incrível.

For anybody wondering why this case incudes the name Mesh in its title it's because 75% -80% of the case has small holes all around to promote airflow, the only part that are solid are parts of one side where the motherboard sits and a small segment at the bottom front of the case. Couple this with excellent compartments and cable ties to also promote clean cable management, and the ability to customise the case internals to make space or move things around is another bonus. Great case.

Nice white case, it did come with extra slots for harddrives, but you can easily take them out to give yourself more space. The mesh at the front catches dust but a little bit of air fixes that. The case fans are pretty quiet.

name: SZD S580 ATX Mid-Tower PC Case, Desktop Gaming Computer Chasssis, Front I/O USB Type-C Port, Dual Tempered Glass Panels, High-Airflow Perforated Top Panel, Water-Cooling Ready (White)
description:
• Versatile Compatibility: The S580 Mid-Tower Gaming PC Case supports a range of motherboard sizes, including ATX, Micro-ATX, and Mini-ITX, making it a great choice for gamers and builders alike.
  • Stunning Tempered Glass: With 2 * 4mm thick tempered glass panels, the S580 gaming case allows you to showcase your high-profile components and RGB lighting in all their glory.
  • Modern Connectivity: The modern front panel I/O includes a USB 3.1 Type-C Port, USB 3.0 port, power button, and a combination audio/microphone jack, providing easy access to all your essential devices.
  • Spacious Interior: The S580 case can accommodate up to 10 x 120mm fans or 6 x 140mm fans plus 1 x 120mm fan, the top can be replaced by 1 x 360mm radiator. It supports VGA up to 360mm in length and CPU coolers up to 170mm in height, giving you plenty of room to build your dream PC.
  • Smart Cable Management: With intuitively placed cable routing channels and tie-downs, the S580 case makes it easy to create a tidy and optimized airflow, while also fitting up to 3 x SSDs and 2 x HDDs or 4 x SSDs and 1 x HDDs in the back bays.
  • Smart Cable Management: With intuitively placed cable routing channels and tie-downs, the S580 case makes it easy to create a tidy and optimized airflow, while also fitting up to 3 x SSDs and 2 x HDDs or 4 x SSDs and 1 x HDDs in the back bays.

reviews.review: A very modular case, supports 10 fans for amazing airflow. My parts run super cool in this case

I haven't even begun my build yet and have already found a problem with this case. My intent was to put a 360mm rad on both the top and side but there is absolutely no way the side mounts will take a 360mm rad.

Update:
