If you plan to water cool your gpu then you will almost definitely need to mount it vertically. I attempted to mount mine normally but the waterblock stuck out by about 1/2" too far to put the side back on the case.

The front glass panel, although designed to be removeable, can't be removed. The top part of the case overhangs the top edge of it preventing it from being removed. Although this doesn't affect the function of the case it does make it a little more difficult to build in it by limiting access.

There are six passthroughs for cables however only two have any protection on the edges. This means the protective case on the wires can be cut through quite easily while you pull them through. The two larger ones (with protection) are just a little too small.

The mobo sits very low in this case. If you put a rad and fans, or even just fans, on the bottom then the lower edge of and ATX mobo would be covered making plugging anything in along that edge difficult.

Cable management consists of "stuff it in the back and cover it up". There are no tiedown spots like are often found it better cases.

Overall: While I was able to do (almost) what I wanted to do in this case it wasn't easy. There is lots of room for improvement.

This case looks ok, but, no fans, and I think the screws are made of plastic, tried to put in a screw, and it broke off. I'm not a big man, just a skinny old goat, and I broke off a screw... go figure.
Hardware was missing in shipment
Okay case. Looks cool but you have to just figure it out. No guidance or instructions available. Lots of gaps for dust to enter (especially where your extra cards go)

Case is very nice for the price, has some sharp sides to it but nothing crazy, not a ton of cable space, had to take out the SSD holder for extra cable space, not hard to build just take your time, would 100% recommend.

Its cheap, tiny and cramped, and slightly different from the pictures. The holes for the wires on top and bottom are blocked by fans, you have to route everything first then install your radiator and fans. Radiator will not fit on the front. Front has a small gap between the fans and the front glass, the pics show this being enclosed. Both rubber gromets are barely on the case and pull through as soon as you tough them. It was cheap, but I kinda wish I would have done some more shopping or just went for the real version of the case.
Quality size of the pc

My first order arrived broken but the seller was helpful in sending a replacement.

The case looks nice and has a sleek appearance. Building in the case feels constrained as some areas where it is awkward to route cables. The motherboard sits extremely low to the bottom of the case and leaves minimal space to get cables to the bottom of the case. The limited amount of holes are made worse with how small the openings are and it's difficult to pass multiple cables through. The case has a generous amount of space in the back which makes cable managing easier, especially with the space for 10 fans.
Nice looking case. Just be aware it does not come with any fans. For the price I thought there were fans. But when I reread the description it says compatible with 10 fans.

name: Noctua NH-U9S chromax.Black, 92mm Single-Tower CPU Cooler (Black)
description:
• Proven premium heatsink (more than 100 awards and recommendations from international hardware websites), now available in an all-black design that goes great with many colour schemes and RGB LEDs
  • Compact 92mm size for excellent case, RAM and PCIe compatibility: fits most tower cases (125mm height), doesn't overhang the RAM slots, doesn't block the PCIe even on ITX motherboards
  • Renowned, award-winning NF-A9 92mm fan with Low-Noise Adaptor and PWM for automatic speed control: full cooling performance under load, whisper quiet at idle!
  • Includes high-end NT-H1 thermal paste and SecuFirm2 mounting system for easy installation on Intel LGA1851, LGA1700, LGA1200, LGA115x and AMD AM5 & AM4
  • Renowned Noctua quality backed up by 6-year manufacturer’s warranty, deluxe choice for Intel Core i9, i7, i5, i3 (e.g. 14900K, 14700K, 14600K) and AMD Ryzen (e.g. 7950X3D, 7900X3D, 7800X3D, 7700)

reviews.review: This isn't the easiest CPU cooler to install (hence only 4 stars), but fortunately it comes with well-written and easy-to-follow instructions. They are much better instructions than what I've found with cheaper CPU coolers. This is also a surprisingly large CPU cooler considering that Noctua sells even bigger ones. It is actually a pretty high-end cooler compared to other brands and will be more than adequate for all but the most avid gamers and overclockers. It is more than good enough for average to high-end use. Another nice feature is that it supports a wide variety of CPU sockets right out of the box. Not only does that mean you can use it on a range of today's CPUs, but if you ever upgrade there's a good chance you'll be able to use it on your next CPU too.
Best brand for air cooling on the market. Noticed significant temperature improvements once installing compared to stock air cooler.

After multiple reviews online this was my go-to and my gosh, not gonna lie this was worth. Not about to write a full essay but if you need decent cooling for a stronger CPU with a decent sized fan I highly suggest this. Went with the black and white touch in photo & video attached and will plan to keep upgrading with more fans over time. Hope this helps for someone who is unsure, highly rated and highly suggested for guaranteed satisfaction. Make it go brrr to keep that CPU cooled down. 🥶❄️

Since I have my PC, I always used the original Intel CPU Cooler included with my i5-4590. The fan has always been a bit noisy, especially when pushing the CPU. At idle, temp was around 35°C, but as soon as I was pushing the CPU, temp was reaching easily 70-75°C and the fan was giving the impression that it was going to come out of the case. I replaced the thermal paste 2 times with no effect.

Since I replace the cooler, the difference is striking. At idle, temp is 2-3°C lower ,which is not a lot, but the fan is so silent that I though it was not spinning. And when pushing the CPU, temp is at least 15°C lower. For now, after 3 weeks, the max temp I have reached is 55°C. I can hear the fan spinning like a slight hum, but the noise is a little bit less loud than my original Intel fan at idle.

Installation is pretty easy. With my Zalman Z1 case (not the Neo), no need to remove the motherboard to fix the support for the cooler. The trickiest part was to reinstall the fan on the cooler after fixing it on the motherboard. In my opinion, this is the biggest flaw, which is not so big when you consider the gain. The way to clip the fan to the cooler could be improved, but that's it.

Works great with my ryzen 5 3600. Considerably better than the stock AMD cooler. The AMD stock cooler kept my processor around 80-85°C with all cores at 100% usage, or "under a full load". The Noctua NHU9S kept my processor around 70°C consistently under a full load. While that may seem like a small difference, and both numbers also might sound really hot to some of you, the noctua cooler keeps the cpu right in the middle of the 65-75°C maximum temperature that I myself and other tech enthusiasts usually recommend. Even though the max temp of the cpu is technically higher than that, up to 110°C sometimes, I still dont recommend pushing it that far if you want system stability, and in some cases you can even kill your cpu by reaching those extremely high temperatures . If you're planning on doing a ridiculous level of overclocking, this cooler isn't for you. But for a gaming computer or even a workstation running at stock speeds or even some light to moderate overclocking, this cpu cooler, for me at least, hits the sweet spot of price to performance.

I used this for my first build. Am happy with the performance and it felt easy enough to install. I've bought Noctua's fans before and while their products are expensive they're worth the price.

Keep in mind that Noctua will send you mounting brackets for free if you want to mount their CPU coolers on new sockets.

This is a very bulky heatsink and fan, so make sure you have the room on your motherboard between your ram slots and the cpu. I had less than half an inch to spare once I had it mounted. I had to use a custom mounting with special screws as taking the motherboard out of my case and mounting a backplate was not really an option for me. That being said the quality of the fan and heat ink are top notch. Made a huge difference in my cpu temperature in stress tests and in gaming applications. They provide you with all you need to mount to an AMD or intel chip set board. Just make sure it fits, and you have the right socket etc, and you are golden. Great product, would buy it or other Noctua products in a future PC build.

Got a prebuilt computer for my birthday but the temps on the cpu hovered around the mid to high 70s °C. The switch was easy and now I'm 20-30 °C cooler with high load. Absolutely thrilled with the results

Al principio tenía algo de dudas sobre la funcionalidad tan maravillosa del disipador. Lo puse en un Acer predator orion 3000. Elegí este porque es de los pocos que caben en esta torre tan pequeña. El pc está muy bien en general pero venía flojo de refrigeración de fábrica, aunque con cooler máster. En cualquier cosa algo más exigente se ponía el procesador a 89-90°, eso es una barbaridad, rozando el límite ya. Después de poner noctua, desde el primer momento, los mismos programas y juegos de antes, mismas características, 25-30° menos que antes, de momento (3 días) ha llegado máximo a 65 °. Eso es la ostia de bajada de temperatura. Me sorprendí para bien, pero que vamos. Esperaba alguna mejora pero tanto ni imaginaba. Y luego el montaje super fácil. Ni siquiera fue necesario desmontar la placa de Acer. Fue desmontar el viejo, mirar las partes que venían para mí placa (1200lga en mi caso, pero ahí partes y para otros - 1700lx, amd, etc...) y probé 2-3 variantes de montaje sin quitar la placa y colocar el soporte que viene en la caja de atras. Total, en 5 min aprovechando el soporte de fábrica coloque las placas y tornillos necesarios para sujetar el disipador, un poco de pasta térmica después de limpiar el procesador de la vieja (ah, dentro de la caja viene una jeringuilla con pata térmica de la marca noctua, solo eso vale 10 euros, así que un detallazo!), apretar las dos tuercas con muelles para que reparten la pasta y se unan bien el radiador con el procesador, colocar el ventilador y enchufarlo y au. A funcionar. La verdad que una maravilla.

Apunto estuve de montar una líquida pero decidí darle una oportunidad a este pequeñajo.
Anonadado me he quedado. Montado en un i7 10700 que jugando (Red Dead Redemption, Uncharted, Last of US) solía llegar a los 91°C, ahora no pasa de 65-66°C.
Decir que vivo en Andalucía, estamos en agosto y no tengo aire acondicionado.
La verdad es que me ha impresionado.
Y no se escucha (aunque ésto no me importaba demasiado, solamente el no freír el procesador), si no fuera por las luces del equipo, no sabrías si está encendido o no.
Es más caro que otras alternativas, pero vale cada euro.

My CPU would crank all the way to 194F max temp with 100% CPU fan speed when playing Starfield. After installing this system, (which was very easy btw) The highest temp I've seen so far is 152F on the same game at 60% fan speed. I have a PO3-640, and despite having RAM in the slot closest to the CPU, the fan/radiator still fit without touching the RAM. And it is so. Much. More. QUIET. It's no wonder this system is so highly rated :D
Davvero un ottimo dissipatore, anche se per il costo non so se mi aspettavo di più o di meno in alcune situazioni

Great cooler! It fits perfectly on my Predator Orion 3000 and offers excellent performance, with a temperature difference of 20-30 degrees compared to the stock Intel cooler. The only downside is that it doesn't include the 12-mm M3 screws you need, which are necessary to avoid a complete disassembly of the motherboard from the case.

name: Miuzei Raspberry Pi 4 Aluminium Case, Raspberry Pi 4 Model B Metal Case, Pi 4 Alloy Armor Case with Cooling Column and Thermal Pads Compatible with Raspberry pi 4 B 8gb 4gb 2gb- No Pi Board
description:
• 【Upgrate 2 layers design】Miuzei Aluminum Raspberry Pi 4 b Case Easy-to-dissipate Metal Case Specially Designed for Pi 4 b. The 2-layer structure, faster installation. Perfect suitable for Raspberry pi 4 /4 b/ 4 model b 8gb 4gb 2gb;
  • 【93 pcs Metal Cooling Column】 The Miuzei Raspberry Pi 4 Armor Aluminum Alloy Case has 3 extra-large cooling columns inside. No need for fan cooling, forming a fast heat transfer system;
  • 【Cooling Column & Thermal Pad】 The Miuzei Raspberry Pi 4 Armor Alloy Case has 3 extra large cooling columns inside. The hot air can be transferred to the cooling columns through the Thermal Pads. A good hot air outlet system is formed;
  • 【Easy Access All Ports】Miuzei Pi 4 metal case has accurate port for the GPIO, HDMI, Micro USB, SD, and power supply connections. All ports and slots of the Aluminum Alloy Case can fit perfectly with Raspberry Pi 4 b;
  • 【Lifetime Warranty】You Can Get Miuzei Friendly Customer Service, Lifetime Efficient Friendly Customer Service Support and 18- months No Reason to Return and Refund.

reviews.review: Seems to be a very high quality product. comes with extra heat sinks and an optional copper heat sink for the cpu for extra cooling. case barely gets warm from regular use. all the slots line up with the connections perfectly and it has notches to allow extra cables like the gpio ribbion and camera ribbon, but they need to be installed before you put the case together.
Nice box but not perfect. The heating works well. I have a gap when I close the box, the quality is just an average.
Fits the pi 4 nicely

Basic but solidly built case, with a passive-cooling solution that works very well. No need to be concerned about fan failure, or the noise of a cooling fan. Functioning as a pi-hole and music server my pi is happily sitting in the low 40s celsius with this case with ambient at 24C (this is using the included copper shim, not tried without). Would certainly buy again.
This is a solid little case that works perfectly with no heat issues.
Ran a stress test on an RPI 4b with 4 GB and it kept the CPU under 60 degrees Celsius with the copper shim installed. For the value and performance I highly recommend this case.

Case assembled with ease with sturdy look and feel. Perfectly aligned ports except for the four holes to secure Raspberry Pi board to the bottom half casing. Only two are aligned the other two is not. Casing feels warm that means it is doing what is supposed to do, to passively cool you RPi without fan.
Exactly as described fits and works great

Both of my RPi's are used as controllers so these cases fit the bill just fine. The aluminum case disipates the heat very well, although I don't have to overclock the CPU for my jobs. The cases are light weight and easy to assemble. They come with choices for heat sinking materials - even if you want to overclock.

Good product - I recommend them.

The machine work and powder coating on this chassis were flawless! Very impressive. The board fits snugly and looks "tight" when fully assembled. If/when I buy more rbp's I'll be buying more of these.

This Raspberry Pi 4 case did not meet my needs, but the customer service was truly top-notch. We corresponded over several emails through Amazon. Of course, since we are in very different time zones, their responses were a day later, but they were very responsive. We have come to a satisfactory conclusion to this experience. I have used other products from them and this is the first that didn't meet my needs - I won't leave a specific review for the product because of the specific nature of my needs versus what the product offers.
I love this cover as it both looks slick, fits everything perfectly and does it's purpose!

Pretty sure this is some generic case where companies can slap their name on it because I have another from iuniker and there are exactly the same. Other than that, this case is prefect for what I need and can handle an overclocked raspberry pi 4. Wifi and bluetooth still work.

name: Corsair iCUE 4000D RGB Airflow Mid-Tower Case - 3X AF120 RGB Elite Fans - iCUE Lighting Node PRO Controller - High-Airflow Design - CORSAIR RapidRoute Cable Management System - Black
description:
• A Fitting Choice: The award-winning 4000D RGB AIRFLOW case provides amazing out-of-the-box cooling and RGB lighting for your next build, with three AF120 RGB ELITE PWM fans and an iCUE Lighting Node PRO RGB lighting.
  • Extreme Cooling Potential: A spacious interior fits up to 8x 120mm or 4x 140mm cooling fans, along with multiple radiators including a 360mm in front and 280mm in the roof (dependent on RAM height).
  • GPU Compatibility and Cooling: Support the latest graphics cards with room for up to a 360mm long GPU and two additional 120mm fan mounts on the PSU shroud for installing fans for direct airflow to the GPU.
  • CORSAIR AirGuide Technology: The AF120 RGB ELITE - White fans deliver powerful airflow at speeds up to 2,100 RPM and 65.57 CFM and feature CORSAIR AirGuide technology, which increases static pressure and focuses airflow for better cooling.
  • Modern Front Panel I/O: Puts your connections within easy reach, including a USB 3.2 Gen 2 Type-C port, USB 3.2 Gen 1 Type A port, and a combination audio/microphone jack.

reviews.review:
This case is great for the value, especially when on sale as it comes with 3x fans and the Node Controller as well. The AF 120RGB Fans alone (3x) alone would cost around $150~ alone. If you can get this case on sale, I would definitely hop on it. The price was amazing during Prime Day.

Lets get into the pros of this case:

1. The airflow of this case is great. Has plenty of room and space for air to escape.
2. There's a usb-c port on the front I/O which some people may find handy. Although, this depends entirely on your motherboard.
3. Vertical mount GPU applicable. You can mount your GPU vertically if you'd prefer as it comes with a vertical bracket.
4. Tempered glass panel for that clean look. If you're into that RGB look, this would be a no brainer of a case to display that RGB.
5. Comes with straps at the back for easy cable management.

Cons:
1.Of course with better airflow, it may be noisy for some as the case is not known to suppress the fans that well. This of course, depends on the fans you use.
2. There is only one USB Port in the front I/O. I would ideally wish they added at least 2 USB ports instead of one.

Overall, if you can get the case for a good price, I would definitely hop on it. If this is your first build, this case is pretty beginner friendly as well.
really like this case, would highly recommend this!

Overall, the case looks nice and does the job.

I had to remove some components from it to make my power supply fit. With all the cables, I felt the allocated room was rather sparce.

The annoying bit is stickers on 2 of the 3 front fans are misaligned, and it makes it look like the fans are wobbly and strongly cheapens the overall look.
High quality case, three high quality fans, budget price. Great!

love this case, the air flow is amazing and lowered my temps by 15-20 degrees
the extra rgb fans are great ,able to control all fan speeds through icue and lighting effects.
bon boitier le corcair 4000 bc expace
Roomy enough to make it relatively easy to work in. Plenty of fans; lots of airflow. Front RGB fans cycle through colors making for an attractive case.

The case itself is generally pretty nice. The cable routing inside is very easy to use and the case itself is roomy and easy to work in. The white colors looks great and the light from the fans comes out really nicely through the front.

The side panels are easy to take off and pop on and off securely.

My only issue is that it came with a wobbly pre-installed front fan that looks like it'd need to be replaced. A bit annoying that it didn't get caught in qc.

Un case veramente bello e ben costruito. Ho adorato l'aver trovato i cavi già instradati e racchiusi, inoltre le canaline per i cavi di alimentazione sono perfette e nemmeno un cavo sbuca fuori. C'è inoltre tantissimo spazio per i cavi non utilizzati in caso di alimentatori non modulari.
Il controller RGB incluso, già cablato e inserito, è un gioiellino e il software permette di fare delle magie incredibili. Oltre alle 3 ventole già incluse è possibile collegare all'hub RGB ben altre 4 periferiche, oltre che altri hub se necessario.
I pannelli sono rimuovibili e rimontabili con una facilità estrema, grazie a delle viti che anche svitate rimangono sul pannello.
Non ho mai avuto un case migliore di questo.
Llego en tiempo y forma, la calidad muy buena realmente es lo que ofrecen ademas de la funcionalidad y lo bonito del producto lo recomiendo !!!!
This case is one of the best, great airflow and super easy to build in.

I love it, a HUGE upgrade over my last Antec 9000 case. I can finally do some tidying and wire management and it has all the space you could want for your fans and GPU. Fits my RTX 3070 with no problem.
Il mio voto è 10

name: StarTech.com 4-Post 25U Mobile Open Frame Server Rack, 19in Network Rack with Wheels, Rolling Rack for Computer/AV/Data/IT Equipment - Casters, Leveling Feet or Floor Mounting (4POSTRACK25U)
description:
• ADJUSTABLE DEPTH: 4-Post 25U open frame server rack with 4 vertical rails and adjustable mounting depth 22" to 40" (56cm to 101cm); Compatible with various servers / switches / data / AV and other IT equipment; EIA/ECA-310-E Compliant
  • EASY ASSEMBLY: Mobile network rack with easy-to-follow assembly instructions and online video; Compact flat-pack shipping to avoid damage and facilitate installation; Total product height of 50.8in (129cm) with casters, 48in (122cm) without casters
  • COLD ROLLED STEEL: Durable 4 Post 19in open frame rack designed for ventilation with 25U mounting height and 1200lb (544kg) weight capacity (stationary); 3 install options included: casters, levelling feet, or base-plate to secure rack to the floor
  • HARDWARE INCLUDED: Rolling computer/data rack includes cage nuts and screws to mount equipment, easy to read Units (U) and depth adjustment markings, cable management hooks for organization, and required assembly tools
  • THE IT PRO'S CHOICE: Designed and built for IT Professionals, this 25U rack is backed for 2-years, including free lifetime 24/5 multi-lingual technical assistance

reviews.review:
Very solid server rack.
Instructions were a lot better than some other brands so that’s a plus too.
Very easy to assemble

I bought this to use as the base for a custom studio desk. It weighs more than me and I dont think I or anyone could damage it even If they gave it their all. This thing is deeper than what I need as Im mostly using it for audio equipment but my PC is mounted in it with loads of space. It also benefits from being able to mount stuff on both sides of the rack.
Im not a fan of the feet, opting not to use them because im on carpet, or the little bits that stick out on the bottom. Aside from that it's relatively heavy but seems indestructible.

Took a while to assemble, but once I got there I was very happy with the sturdiness. The quality of the wheels could probably be upgraded (I realize I am not advised to move it loaded but sometimes I raise the legs and reposition it a bit, eventually this kind of use would destroy the wheels under heavy load I believe - but again, they explicitly say do not do this.)

Once assembled, this should be a great rack with good features. As this review picture shows, the manufacturer chose to use little or no padding inside the unit's parts, and rather standard cardboard, such that this is what resulted. This may be relevant to you as well, so please be aware of the potential issues with this particular item.

This thing was a breeze to install, the instructions were meh, but honestly just look at the picture and read the instructions and it all makes sense, this is my first rack I assemble myself and I found it super easy.

PS, you don't really need 2 people, I had no problems with only myself. While the frame is semi heavy, if you just wheel it around its no problemo.

Not entirely sure if I like those wire management things on the side, but I'll see if I end up using it or not.

The rack is amazing for the price. I have worked with a few higher end racks that are closed concept, (in the $1000 range) and this rack is giving those a run for their money.
The rack is great for people that don't plan on buying in bulk, (I'm talking 100's) but still want to leave room to expand to a few more of these.
The rack comes with ALL the components, screws, and tools to get set up.
I personally rack-mounted my 24 port switch, as well as 2 servers, and it's amazing what I found out about this rack.
It came with the screws that my switch failed to come with to rack mount the thing, as well as the screwdriver to get them tightened, which not many products do nowadays.
The rack comes with wheels for operating, or bolts so that you can bolt it into the floor, the wheels are pretty sturdy for my use.
Putting it together was quite a task, but fun nonetheless

What else can I say, this rack does exactly what it should and is great quality, with an amazing price tag. Probably one of the best things I've purchased from Amazon.

I love the rack but to build it was not easy since the instructions included in the box did not make sense. I accessed support on the website to watch a video and it didn't show me what I needed to see. Only after contacting technical support through chat did they tell me that my instructions were out of date and incorrect. They sent me an electronic copy of the manual.

Nice unit and seems sturdy and looks very professional.

Instructions where good but could be edited to note how one person can assemble.
Be sure to tighten with level or tri-square and I have no flex in mine.

Good to start with and will see about customizing my side and top covers.

This is for home use and organizing. Has been fun for the 3 weeks and look forward to the fun a head.

I had been considering the 8U version of this same rack for quite some time, but when Prime day rolled around, this 12U unit was actually on sale for less than the 8U rack. So I took the plunge because I needed a place to set up a renewed Dell R710 server.

It comes with a lot of nice extras that show StarTech has put more effort into its units than most of the knock-offs. It's made of very sturdy, powder coated steel. I really appreciate that it came with *all* of the tools that you will need to put it together -- including 2 wrenches and a Philips screwdriver. The instructions are well written and come in a nice little plastic pouch should you need them again. More than enough hardware included as well.

Be sure to measure your server before putting this together. I ended up going about six inches longer because of the measurements listed in the manual. Measure the mounting hardware of your server and make sure you get within a few inches of the fully-expanded rack-mounting. It wasn't too tough to adjust the size, though.

It works well with a Dell R710 server (see photo) and I plan to add beneath and possibly a fan/power-strip. It's supposed to be able to hold 1200 pounds and that's probably true. I'm not sure how easy it would be to move with that much weight. It's pretty hefty and the addition of a huge server makes it tough enough to move already. But it's not made to be mobile all the time. It's a good way to get things set up and put it in a cool closet when you are done.

I'm happy with this and I'd definitely buy from StarTech again. The quality is much better than what I expected. Solid 5 stars.

I was looking for a tall rack to use for my home theater that could fit all current and future planned components. The StarTech rack seemed like a better options than many others I viewed. Since it was on sale I pulled the trigger and glad I did.

This rack is well designed and was easy to assemble with just myself. I was able to put it together in about an hour and start loading components. With heavy amps installed low it was actually easier to lay the rack on it's back and load those first then stand it up. Everything fit well and the hardware worked well for assembly and loading equipment.

This beast really can hold a ton of equipment and i was even able to install my large switch on the back since components can be installed on either side. I purchased several velcro straps and the wide open angled vertical posts were perfect for running cables. I do recommend laying out all your components in s spreadsheet before ordering a rack and the extra filler plates you might need.

I ended up knocking off one star as it has a slight in lean from bottom to top since it is holding very heavy equipment. It is still stable and this is not a big deal but I will most likely end up installing some cables and turnbuckles on each side to pull it back into square.

Cuando lo abrí me eché las manos a la cabeza de tantas piezas y tornillos.
Pero en 1h y media lo tenía todo montado.
Me hubiera aclarado un poco mejor si en el manual estuvieran las cosas un poco más detalladas.
Una vez montado, se nota muy resistente y robusto.
Materiales y tornillería de calidad. Genial que venga con todo lo necesario para montarlo.
Great quality, easy to assemble, comes with tools that are better than expected. Adjustability is great, and can fit longer cases. Price could be a bit lower, but is somewhat comparable to others.

Montage très simple. J’ai changé un rack fermé de 20U manquant de profondeur pour celui là en 18U. La profondeur me permet au final de ne pas avoir de perte de place. L’open frame est bien plus pratique, a une bonne finition.

Les points à corriger.
Le manuel comporte une erreur avec un élément en trop.
L’emballage n’est pas adapté et arrive en très mauvais état.

name: Cooler Master MasterCase H500 ATX Mid-Tower Tempered Glass Side Panel, Transparent Front Option, Carrying Handle & 2X 200mm RGB Fans
description:
• Mesh and Transparent Front Panel – Both the mesh and transparent front panel are included for maximized airflow and offering a crystal-clear view of the fans
  • Dual 200mm ARGB Fans – The iconic, addressable RGB fans are the core of the H-Series in design and function, capable of operating quietly while moving high volumes of air due to their size
  • ARGB Lighting System – The pre-installed ARGB fans can be managed by either the motherboard or an included controller, connected by the included splitter, to create a comprehensive ARGB lighting system
  • Tempered Glass Side Panel – Gaming hardware, custom-loop cooling, and the pure pride of the builder is shown in panoramic view through an edge-to-edge tempered glass side panel
  • Optimized Airflow – Filtered ventilation on the top panel provides additional thermal support while also offering mounting options for future cooling upgrades

reviews.review:
Ventilation silencieuse et efficace,
Le boitier est rigide et toute la quincaillerie incluse
Très bonne construction. Intérieur facile à aménager. Bonne qualité générale. Seul léger hic, les pattes rendent la chose un brin faible sur le balan, mais rien d'épouvantable.

I was skeptical at first if this was gonna have enough room between the glass and gpu, but there is more than enough room! I also love the 4 usb ports and handle, such small details but they're everything for someone who needs those extra ports and easy transport. The fans are okay, they didn't give out thankfully but I am going to replace them.

I've only had this for about a week or two, but so far:
- It arrived in good condition and quickly
- PC setup in the case was very easy
- Cable management is great. Most cables can be hidden i the case behind the motherboard. There are areas all over for routing cables and securing them.
- The three fans that came with the case are all VERY quiet and move a ton of air. I have a high end gaming system, and a motherboard that supports liquid cooling, but I've gone with an air cooled setup.
- There is a lot of space in this case. I was able to attach a massive BeQuiet heatsink to the CPU with room to spare.
- So far temps in the case have been cool. No heat issues.
- It's also a very nice looking case, and solidly built.

- the only negative so far is that the ARGB lights on the lower front fan do not work unless I open the case and wiggle the connector for those lights. The female connector on the cable from the fan has holes that are just a bit too large. While the upper fan's ARGB connector is snug and works well. That lower fan works fine otherwise though.
I've put in a request with Cooler Master to replace the lower fan as per their instructions to me. I'm just waiting on them to proceed with that ticket. But as that fan works fine for moving air (it's main function), I'm not in any rush. And they were very quick with their responses to my inquiries.

Given my experience with Cooler Master so far, I would not hesitate to buy from them again.

Coming from a Silverstone FT02, the MC H500 is not in the same quality range and this is also reflected with the price.
I was shopping for a new case because I found out that my new EVGA RTX 3080 FTW3 didn't like to be installed vertically (10C higher temperature).
So, I began to look for a case that uses large fans because I was using 180mm fans since 2009 and really liked them.
Stumble across this H500 case with a mesh front, looked at it and thought that my new AP183 fans would fit.
Upon receiving the case and without testing the original fans 200mm, I proceed to cut out the front and installed my AP183 fans. It must be noted that doing so erase any possibilities of using 120/140mm fans in the future.
With the AP183 installed, the case performs beautifully in the noise and the cooling department.
The bottom 180mm fan is also perfectly aligned to feed fresh air to the GPU, which is not the case with the new Fractal Torrent case, for example. Also, with the use of the AP183 (and their special airflow pattern), at medium speed (around 800rpm), you can feel fresh air going to the last fan of the GPU. You also don't feel any hot air coming from the GPU and recirculating back into it.
Point to be noted, the GPU temperatures are better (around 2-3C) without the PSU shroud.
Finally, I really like how this case/project turned out, some work was needed, but it now performs beautifully.
I hope that my review can help some that are hesitant and would like to use their beloved 180mm fans.

Plenty of space inside to work, cable management is a snap, I have two complaints however.

One: There is no instruction manual - neither a physical one or one on Cooler Masters website - which would have made figuring out some of the rgb connectors a little easier.

Two: What genius thought up these harddrive bays? There's only two, and if you have a full size multimedia HDD you can either put it in the tray but not be able to place the pins in because the harddrive is in the way OR you can leave the pins in and not be able to get your harddrive in because the pins are in the way!

It LOOKS like you're supposed to put the harddrive in the tray, then put the pins on and slide it into a locked position, but this is impossible without somehow magically shrinking your harddrive, putting the pins in, and then magically expanding your harddrive because the sliding locks are inverse to each other!

I don't know, maybe an INSTRUCTION MANUAL could have cleared up my confusion or at least had the incantation I needed to recite to make it work as intended. In the end, I took some screws from my toolkit and screwed the HDD in the old fashioned way and sure enough, that worked. Please stop trying to reinvent the wheel guys.

As you can see the case itself is getting in the way of airflow, if you consider yourself a handyman I feel this would be a easy fix, just cut out the extra metal, but to the people that don't know how to or don't have access to tools, this could be a deal breaker given it came with the bigger fans you'd think they would design the case around that! BUT I've been using this case with no airflow problems, my cpu runs about 50C and my gpu around the same, I haven't overclocked or adjusted anything ( other then turning off the 0 rpm thing for the gpu) soo great case! It just bothers me that the fans seemed to be a last minute thought for this case and no adjustments where made, it would be nice to see another version that gives you a diffrent mount for the fans (like how you have the choice of metal mesh or plastic window in the box) that would fit the bigger fans

I'm a fan girl of NZXT's towers and was planning another NZXT-based build. I decided, however, to try something new, something that would be different from my regular builds. Cue in this Cooler Master H500.

It has been nothing short of amazing. If you'd like the "short and sweet" bulleted points, then just read this part, otherwise I've written a lot of information.
- a total of up to x6 (if solely using) 120mm fans, x4 (if solely using) 140mm fans, or x3 (if solely using) 200mm fans
- a front mesh panel that captures dust; there is also an optional acrylic panel that can be used instead if preferred (more on this later)
- tempered glass panel that has two screws that cannot be taken off (so it's no longer easy to misplace). The glass panel also has hinges at the bottom so it won't accidentally fall and shatter, etc
- supports ATX, mATX, or miniATX builds
- has x2 M.2 slots, x2 3.5" hard drive bays (an additional mount can be purchased to support 4 more), and x4 2.5" SSD bays. 2 SSD's can be mounted on the right side of the case with little plugs, therefore offering a tool-less assembly). The HDD drive bay can also be removed if you just plan on only using the 2 SSD mounts
- in regards to cable management, there is a vertical bar with rubberized routing holes. This is removable if you prefer a more spacious build
- x2 200mm CoolerMaster MasterFan 200R RGB fans installed in the front panel and 1 generic 120mm fan
- a removable PSU cover
- 3 dust filter covers (for the top, front and bottom of the case)
- a vertical GPU mount (riser cable not included)
- multiple zip ties in order to manage the cables inside (among other small things)

So, I won't be able to touch on everything, as I don't use the vertical GPU mount for starters, but I can give insight on other aspects. First off, this case comes with many fan placement options. For reference, I have x2 120mm fans up top, x1 120mm fan in the back, and x2 200mm fans up front. I currently have Corsair SP LL120 RGB's and they work great paired with the CoolerMaster fans. Side note, if you are in the market for the Corsair SP LL120 RGB's and would like it to pulse, breath, or mimic the 200mm fans, then you'll need to purchase the CORSAIR iCUE Commander PRO Controller.

Anyway, the case does come with a handy magnetic dust filter for the top of the case (fan area). 1 month later and I can tell that it is definitely doing its job. The front of the case has another mesh like structure and this allows for better airflow throughout the case. My build has been averaging 25-30C on idle with a max of 50C on high detailed games. Now, I have tried the acrylic panel and found that my temperatures, unsurprisingly, do go up: 30-45C on idle and 50-65C on load. It's not terrible temps but, while the acrylic does look cleaner, keep in mind that you're swapping temperatures for aesthetics.

The side tempered glass panel is another nice aspect of the H500. It's not clear like NZXT's line, but I would say it's around 40-50% tint, perhaps even 30%. It's definitely on the dark side. I didn't realise how tinted it would be, but it honestly looks amazing. Due to the 'heavier' tint, the cables inside are pretty much invisible and the RGB/lightning looks like its coming through the darkness. Honestly, it looks great and is definitely something I didn't know I wanted for my build.

The x2 200mm fan does deserve a mention as well, but this one's not as positive. It could be the lack of experience with RGB fans, but the cables were confusing as heck to pair with respective wires. I've didn't even spend as much time on the rest of the build combined compared to the fan wires themselves. I'm not going to lie when I say I cried a little out of frustration. The instructions aren't very helpful. If I remember correctly, the RGB cables were pinned into cables that were unnecessary towards the whole build. Figuring out that cable was not necessary took an amazingly stupid amount of time. After taking out the unnecessary cables and then figuring out the appropriate ones, it was smooth sailing after that. I'm not sure why it's become the new standard, but pictorial instructions are ridiculous. I can only imagine how difficult it would be for someone just starting out.

Cable management wise, there's really not much to say. It's superb and there's nothing difficult about it. You'll definitely need more zip ties than provided if you want a cleaner look. Also, the provided ties are surprisingly very thin so may snap easily if you stress it enough. There are notches on the cable side of the tower that allow you to zip tie cables on. Make sure to not zip tie in the panel grooves though. The rubberized routing holes and removable vertical bar is also appreciated.

Some small thing that don't really detract but should be mentioned: if you're not going to fill the inside of this case, then be prepared to hear A LOT of air being pushed around. I have a lot of open space and it does sound cavernous. Also, this case is very much on the heavy side. It weighs a whopping 23.2lbs, maybe 30lbs+ after all the components are installed, compared to NZXT's 17.9lbs.

If you've stuck it out and read through my long speech, then in short I highly recommend this case. I've been very pleased with it and I'm glad I took a chance. Like a lot of people have been saying, don't go for any other H500 (for example, H500P or H500M). Just stick with the H500-NO SUFFIX. It is Cooler Master's best - as of right now - and pretty much offers everything required for a high end build. This is a great starter case, offering excellent airflow and enough space to experiment around with. You won't be disappointed.

This case is well thought out with plenty of room behind the MB mount for cable management, but this comes at a price if you are mounting a larger CPU air cooling solution such as a Noctua NH-D15. The fan over the RAM slots causes the fan to sit high enough that it touches the glass of the case door. The case stays cool thanks to the two 200mm aRGB fans at the front of the case. That being said, one of the fans is not balanced correctly, so the LEDs look wonky and it adds to the noise level a bit. I would still purchase this case again despite the issues I mentioned.

This case sat unused for 3 years until I finally found the time to do my system build. I found it easy to work in and there was space for effective cable management.

Whisper-quiet while running and the large fans put on a good light show.

The Aorus master has a 3 pin and 4 pin d-led slots.
The H500 has a pre-installed ARGB splitter- with 1 cable that reads ASUS-MSI, and another that reads GIGABYTE.

But that gigabyte cable? Doesn't fit properly to the 3 pin slot. So what? do you use only 3 of the 4 pins on the 4 pin slot? Or do you use the ASUS\MSI 3 pin cable (which will fit on the 3 pin d-led)?

Yep..
Use the asus cable. Yes it works fine with gigabyte mobos- it's just a cable after all. Someone at COOLERMASTER needs to get the memo about this apparently, cause frustratingly enough- they have a faq for the 3 pin fans to the 4 pin connectors, but NOT the ARGB situation. I haven't seen it cleanly explained ANYWHERE, so there ya go. Even the manuals for gigabyte and the h500 were of little help on this confusion situation.

I hope I just saved a lot of you 12+ hours of dizzying hair pulling stressful research.
You are welcome internet.

Soo how is the case?
Well it's the first pc I've built since 2014, so maybe everything has gotten really good in that time but I don't know. I just know it's incredible.
The cable management.
The space.
The cooling.
The housing for psu and ssd\hdd.
all of it is such a big win!

It's soo quiet my jaw hit the floor first time I fired it up.
Seriously HOW IS IT THIS QUIET!?
I paired it up with a noctua d 15 which is also impossibly quiet.

In low mode (which is when you are in windows not gaming) it's but a tiny whisper. When gaming it gets louder but still a big improvement from my old coolermaster case from eons ago.

LIGHT SHOW!
The giant fans look downright industrial neon city. I am instantly addicted to 200mm fans and leds now. With how spacious this case is (this would have been called full tower at one time I bet lol) and how gorgeous the fans and lights are, with the glass side I am surprised how good it looks in person, and you better believe it looks great in a dark gamers room.

STURDY!
Wow is it heavy duty. The steel on this thing is thick. I don't think I'll have any issues with durability on this, at least not on the frame.

Front Port panel-
This is one the reasons I chose this over other 200mm case fan models (like the monotech). I love how the front panel is slanted, and works great for my needs. Having the case on the floor it's perfect to see what i am plugging into. 4 usb ports is plenty for anything I want to do, and the microphone port is on the side I want and need (less cable stretching)

BREATHE-
Vents vents vents, everywhere cept the back side panel (which is normal among cases). This case is soo big it has no problem breathing and keeping your stuff cool.

CONS-
The only con I can find- is the 200mm fans are soo quiet, I can hear some tiny wobble in both of them. I don't think it's a defect, more like normal operating noise you simply would not hear with normal noisy fans.

CONCLUSION-
I never imagined spending 100$ on a case before, now I can't imagine spending less. The h500 argb is incredible, and it's fun to see how much case tech has advanced in the past 10 years. Even if you are like me (not an expert pc builder) it's neat how easy it's getting to make sweet looking towers that make all those console kids pretend they are not impressed). This is all just part of PC MASTER RACE PRIDE! And what a proud day it is to be a member of this fine race of superior gamers. Don't buy a cheapy 40$ case that can't breathe then stuff a 3080 in there! Esp if you don't have AC in the summer =D.

Thank you coolermaster- but please update your instructions (esp on your web site), cause they utterly failed to mention the asus cable can and SHOULD be used for some gigabyte mobos.

title says it all, cat knocked it off the desk, smacked on the corner, the glass panel didn't break, the fans are a little wobbly now, and before where i would trust the carry handle 110%, I'm not so sure I would anymore. There's a bit of damage to the front panel but every single internal is perfect.

name: Cooler Master NR200 White SFF Small Form Factor Mini-ITX Case with Vented Panel, Triple-Slot GPU, Tool-Free and 360 Degree Accessibility, Without PCI Riser
description:
• Vented Panel: The NR200 is flanked with five ventilated steel panels for unrestricted airflow.
  • Unrestricted Cooling Potential: Holds up to 7 fans. 5 sides of open ventilation. Fits CPU coolers up to 155mm tall or up to 280mm long radiators. 3 Expansion Slots
  • Full-size GPU Compatible: Triple slot GPUs are supported with a maximum length of 330mm and maximum width of 156mm. Vertical mounting is optional.
  • 360 Degree Accessibility: Every panel and frame part can be dismantled to allow advanced disassembly and 360 degrees of access to work on components.
  • High-quality Materials: Thick, powder coated SGCC steel lasts the life time of the chassis and resists marring from transport or handling.

reviews.review:
I picked this up last week because I was tired of my old case which was dirty, dented, and dingy. I actually got this one "used-excellent" for $10 less and total cost was $100 (Canadian) after taxes. Why am I mentioning the price? Well...

The only reference I saw to the need for an SFX power supply was in a comment someone made - it's not (clearly) anywhere in the description or specs. So - when I took my old pc apart (which - with the exception of the case - had been fully upgraded in November) and started to put things in, I discovered that the ATX power supply I had was never going to fit. "SFX required" said that earlier-mentioned comment, so I went back to Amazon . ca and looked for one. Yeah, the cheapest one I could find was just over $200. Fine - it was a decent power supply, 80+ gold rated with a 7 year warranty, so i got it. I waited till the next day to continue the build and discovered much to my disappointment that the cpu liquid cooler i had for my previous PC was too big - and it was only a single fanned one - so off I trot to Amazon *again* to find a low-profile cpu fan. $76 and a day later, I have my CPU fan.

In case anyone's thinking "this guy's an idiot - why would he expect his old pc components to fit in an mini-ITX case???" - well, this idiot's previous set up was also a mini-ITX - it was just a different shape (more of a cube) so bigger things fit. Thankfully - my RTX 3060 fit just fine...except I can't put any fans underneath it on the bottom of the case, but that's fine, I have enough fans for now.

Having said all this, my verdict is that this is a really well built little case, very solid, there were enough screws and bits for whatever setup i needed, and while the instructions seemed a bit confusing at first, it was just because there were so many options for set up. This really is a beautiful case and I don't regret any of the required purchases - I just hate surprise expenses - but in the end, it was totally worth it.

The whole thing is now together, I have

Pros:
- The white model looks extremely clean and minimalist.
- All panels can be removed, along with most (all?) of the internal brackets. If you have difficulty building computers because of the lack of room to work, then this is the perfect case for you.
- There is two locations for the SFX power supply, allowing you to use wider (244mm) and taller (up to 226mm) motherboard. However this feature is practically pointless (see below).

The problem:
- Most mini-ITX motherboards cost at least the same price if not 25 to 50% higher than micro-ATX boards, you end up paying a lot more for less features (ex: 2 RAM slots instead of 4, only one M.2 instead of two, etc).
- The selection of mini-ITX motherboards is also extremely limited compared to mATX.
- While this case was specifically made for mini-ITX and three-slots-wide GPUs, this case should in theory also fit 3-slots micro-ATX motherboards. The problem is that 3-slots-tall micro-ATX motherboards are basically impossible to find depending on your CPU.
- If only they made this case one slot taller, it would also have been compatible with mATX motherboards. IMHO it's already way too big to be classified as a small form factor case, so what's one more slot in height?

TL;DR: if you're thinking about buying this case, make sure you complete your parts list and check that everything will fit. After over a week of futile research for 226mm or shorter mATX motherboards for LGA 1700, I'm regretting buying this case even though it is the most beautiful case I've ever owned.

This NR200P is fairly easy to work with as majority of the panels are removable for easy access; I did not have any issues installing a CPU cooler while the motherboard was pre-installed and I did end up using an EVGA SFX power supply for this system. Majority of the work is tucking in all the necessary cabling for the power supply which is assisted by the velcro straps on the power supply bracket.

I chose this case as it has a fairly small footprint and comes with a glass side panel that can be customized with a few vinyl decals; I appreciate that there is a pcie 3.0 riser cable for vertical GPU mounting and two black Cooler Master PWM fans included. I didn't end up using a lot of the accessories included with this case and I don't plan on swapping out the configuration too often; I am using M.2 storage drives exclusively as my ITX motherboard supports two NVMe SSDs and the case has a nice large cutout for easy access to the back of the motherboard.

Since this case does not have a USB-C front panel port, you can definitely opt for more affordable mini ITX motherboard options that do not have an internal USB-C Gen 2 front panel connector. I did end up re-routing most of the front panel connection cables behind the metal front panel to keep things clean; It is a challenge to integrate RGB fans with a controller as you may need to sacrifice a 2.5 inch drive mounting point.

Temperatures are good once you populate the top and bottom with 120mm fans; 31 degrees idle so far with an NH-L12s cooler and an RGB fan. Since there is an i5 10400f inside, this 65w CPU is thermally manageable in this case and I don't plan to do any overclocking. There is plenty of dust filtration to keep it clean inside.

Overall, I feel there is a lot of excess case parts when finally completing the build process and I am not sure if can find a use for them. It's a beautiful case with the glass panel; You really need to do some research and see what restrictions there are for component sizing. It may be difficult to fit a custom cable extension kit as there is very little room to tuck excess cabling.

Una gran opción que te permite tener un equipo completo en un espacio reducido. El metal es resistente y no se dobla con facilidad. Tiene rejas en las tapas laterales y permite colocar una MB mATX de las pequeñas y posiblemente una PSU de tamaño normal colgándola con los cinturones de velcro incluídos. También cabe una GPU de hasta 3 ventiladores pero hay que tener cuidado con las medidas antes de comprar la GPU para asegurar que quepa.

This review is for Cooler Master NR200P White SFF Small Form Factor Mini-ITX Case

I love this PC case. It's big enough to use large air coolers and large graphics cards, but it doesn't take over your whole desk. I especially like how you can take off the side panels and bottom when you are assembling your PC. It makes it so easy to access all the components and route your cables. I like this case so much that I bought an extra one when it was on sale, just in case a friend wanted me to build them a computer or something.

This is an excellent case, and one of the few mainstream and affordable small form factor PC cases. Its major relative compromise is the size, which is close to as large as "SFF" gets. The case is also heavier than most SFF cases, being mostly made of steel, versus aluminum or plastic. However, it has nearly no size or cooling limitations in its class. Aesthetically, it follows the general SFF PC trend of minimalist design. Anything I have planned for my build, be it the largest GPU I can afford, or adding some old 3.5" hard drives to my system, are possible in this case, which is easily transportable, though not quite backpack portable. I won't spend much time talking more about the positives of this case but I'll highlight some of my gripes, which should not be deal breakers, but ways that Cooler Master can improve the case without reducing its capabilities.

Though the NR200 can accommodate almost any ITX hardware, its layout design is not completely perfect. I would have appreciated some gaps in the frame or motherboard area for routing cables behind the motherboard. One of my PSU cables is routed between the motherboard panel and the case's right side panel (when looking towards the case), but it's the flat kind which raises the case's side panel ever so slightly. Others with round or quality braided cables looking to route their cables behind the motherboard without raising the side case panel will need to route the cables in the gap between the motherboard and the motherboard panel. Unfortunately, they will need to do this before installing the motherboard, and uninstall the mobo every time before disconnecting. Some extra spaces or gaps that allow the cable connectors to slide through would have solved this problem. Another gap for the 24 pin connector would have improved quality of life a little, too, though I'm not sure if that would be possible in a practical spot. Having the thick 24 pin cable extending from the PSU in its default position can press down on the GPU without some careful cable management. Fortunately, Cooler Master provided some velcro straps underneath the PSU that help with this a lot, likely because they anticipated this problem for most consumers. Still, I can tell that Cooler Master intended this case to be as easy as possible for beginners, and neat cable management and avoiding pressure on the GPU will likely be a fairly difficult step of building in this case. Finally, the case could perhaps use some lengthier front I/O cables, so that they could have been routed behind the motherboard without blocking the PSU fan.

Speaking of front I/O, I would have also preferred a USB type C connector on the front. I can understand that it was not included due to cost, but I would prefer a version of the NR200 with a type C port and no fans, and likely would have even paid $10 more for that tradeoff. My version of the NR200 is the base version which comes with one 92mm fan and one 120mm fan, and the included fans are fine; not exceptionally quiet but not annoyingly loud. Still, I might replace both of them with Noctua fans to get the quietest possible airflow, and the 92mm fan will definitely not fit when I upgrade to the CPU cooler I plan on getting. Though Cooler Master included fans to appeal to customers who will use stock coolers and don't want to worry about aftermarket cooling solutions, they still have an opportunity to cater to more enthusiast consumers (who constitute a large part of the SFF community). Many SFF builders will either not need the included fans, or prefer to choose their own. They likely also prefer having near to mid-term future proof features. A version of this case without fans and a type C port, offered at a small premium, would still be a great deal.

My unit also came with a minor defect - the metal frame (not sure of the correct term) of one of the USB ports at the top is not completely connected. The end of the metal frame is bent inwards slightly as shown in the picture. I haven't encountered problems while plugging and unplugging USB devices, albeit carefully, into the jack multiple times over the past couple of weeks, so I didn't deduct a star or try to get it replaced. I'm optimistic that it'll stay as-is and not get bent worse over time. If this is a problem in manufacturing, hopefully Cooler Master can address this issue.

This case is fantastic for its size. Every single panels comes off fairly easily, it was super easy to build in and it had enough room to fit a massive cooler in which means my Ryzen 5900x isn’t thermal throttling during testing,

This case is awesome, well designed, well made. This was my first computer build, and my son, who has some experience, questioned my decision to go with the NR200P given the additional challenge of working in a small space--until he saw it in person. He was so impressed, he wanted one for himself.

Here is my build:

Intel Core i7-12700K
ASUS ROG Strix B660-I (mini-ITX)
Nvidia RTX 3070FE GPU
Kingston Fury Beast DDR5 16 x 2 RAM (rgb)
EVGA Supernova 750W SFX power supply (note small form factor)
SK Hynix Platinum P41 2 TB m.2 SSD
SK Hynix Platinum P41 1 TB m.2 SSD
Thermalright Silver Soul 135 white cooler
Arctic P9 PWM PST 92mm fan
Arctic BioniX F120 fans x 2
Chassis fan hub CPU Cooling (the really cryptic looking one)

Noteworthy: The Thermalright cooler DOES fit, even with the glass side. Actually has some room to spare.

The Kingston RAM has only about 2mm clearance from the cooling tower. But 2mm is enough.

My fan hub sits behind the front panel, nicely hidden, because it's not pretty. I routed several things behind that panel. You can also place SSDs there, but mine are both m.2, directly plugged into the MB, so that front panel was wide open for wires.

I added two fans on the bottom and one at the back. Based on my review of the "literature" (YouTube), the best airflow with a cooling tower is to intake from the bottom and back, and exhaust thru the top. Including the fan in the center of my cooling tower, I have 6 fans in here and no problems with heat. The two stock fans are on top, and [update alert] a year later, they're still working flawlessly. I did add a magnetic filter on the back to block off the openings back there since I'm intaking air thru all those openings at the back. Technically, it's not held there by magnets. The tab from the case top holds it in place perfectly. My computer sits right next to an air filter which sits right next to a chinchilla cage, with hair and dust floating everywhere.
______________________________________

Everyone talks about the challenge of routing the cables in such a small case. For me, this was the fun part and I was very happy with the outcome. Like I said, I'm a first time builder, so I have no experience. Which means you can do it too. You can decide based on the pics whether you think I did a decent enough job.

Put together a second NR200P system to surprise my dad. He didn't need a dedicated GPU, or rgb RAM, but otherwise the builds were pretty similar, and it went equally well. LOVE LOVE LOVE the colors, too! I would've gone with pink if it hadn't been $50 more at the time of my build. Still kinda wish I had, because pink is my color. But the white looks really nice too.

Two great experiences with this case! Highly recommended.

name: Lian Li Lancool 216 RGB White Steel/Tempered Glass ATX Mid Tower Computer Case,2X 160 mm ARGB Fans Included - LANCOOL 216RW White
description:
• Mid-tower chassis configurable for air cooling and water cooling
  • Airflow optimized front, top and PSU shroud side mesh panels
  • Equipped with 2 x front 160 PWM fans ARGB and 1 x rear 140mm PWM fan
  • Supports 360 radiator at the top, front and a maximum of 10 fans
  • Includes rear PCIe fan bracket

reviews.review:
Love the airflow, great estatics, very complete with argb and pwm hub.
To bad the back fan isn't argb

Veramente un ottimo prodotto, la qualità Lian Li non si smentisce, stavolta anche ad un prezzo più che competitivo per la sua fascia ( 115€ s.s. comprese ). I materiali sono di qualità anche se alcuni inserti sono in plastica. Lo spazio interno permette di alloggiare qualsiasi scheda video attualmente in commercio. Ma il vero punto di forza di questo case è l'airflow, che permette di impostare delle curve di funzionamento delle ventole molto poco aggressive a tutto vantaggio della silenziosità di esercizio anche con carichi pesanti.

Che dire sul Lian li 216 RGB? Volete un case che si adatti a tutte le esigenze? Eccolo. Questo è spazioso, cable management top, fan hub ultra funzionale nel retro e un airflow da paura. È adatto sia a build con cpu cooler ad aria che a liquido (AIO o come vi pare). Oltretutto è fornito, per i più fuori di testa, di un supporto per ventola da installare sul retro della gpu, all'esterno del case. Per quanto mi riguarda, trovato in offerta a 95 euro non è un best buy ma IL best buy. Straconsigliato.

Um dos melhores, se não o melhor, pelo seu preço (R$700-800). A Lian Li coloca um carinho em cada peça do gabinete, até nos parafusos. Todas as partes podem ser desmontadas e o gabinete pode ser customizado ao seu gosto, pode mudar a posicao da placa mãe, a posição da placa, colocar uma ventoinha só pra exaurir calor da placa de vídeo, enfim, muita e muita coisa.

Recently acquired a 4090 FE and needed to upgrade from my itx cooler master nr200p to give it better cooling. Moved my system into the 216 and I love it. Normally I replace stock fans with noctuas but the front fans on the 216 are great, and everything is so so much more quite than when I my NR200P. I did use my itx motherboard as I spent enough on the 4090 to wait a couple months before any other big upgrades, and I just needed to move and remove some standoffs, no biggie. Excellent case, keeps stuff nice and cool, which in turn means it's surprisingly quiet even during blender renders and very intense gaming loads. Love the look too.

name: LIANLI A4-H2O Silver SPCC/Aluminum Mini-ITX Computer Case, PCI4.0 Riser Card Cable Included - A4-H2O A4 Silver
description:
• 11L case that can mount Founders Edition 30 series VGA and 240mm AIO.
  • Easy to install GPU via front panel access.
  • Removable bottom cover supports SSD mounting and cable management.
  • Removable fan bracket makes installation AIO and Radiator/fan combo at ease.
  • In collaboration with DAN CASE.

reviews.review: This is a very attractive case and it's well made. Compared to my previous "normal" ITX case, this one is the next level in terms of installation. It will give you trouble and frustration.

I've been buying PC hardware and building PCs for over 25 years, owned cases from Chieftec Dragon and older Lian-Li alu to modern NZXT and O11-like cases, but never had a PC case I liked as much as this one. It's quite sturdy and heavy, with thick materials, all of the panels and bays can be removed for a comfortable building experience, all internal screws are interchangeable, and I think it has a highly appealing, refined but simple, industrial look. I absolutely don't regret switching to ITX, and I'm happy that I don't have any glass on this case. Previously I had an O11-mini clone with glass everywhere, and it made me fixate way too much on how does the inside look, leading to a lot of pointless expense.

Of course keep in mind that you can't expect the exact same performance from these tiny ITX cases. I have a 3070Ti Founders Edition, which is not exactly energy efficient, nor does it produce a great airflow, and consequently it can start to throttle after a while on 100% performance, especially if the ambient temperature is high.

La cajita una pasada, un poco cara pero se paga el premium de marca y tamaño. La tuve que devolver porque la caja necesita estar ubicada en un espacio abierto (normal, nada especial) y en mi caso particular la quería para tener un ordenador potente pero pequeño en la tele del comedor, ubicada en un espacio cerrado, con lo cual la ventilación era nula y los componentes se me calentaban al ponerme a jugar a pesar de la refrigeración líquida.

La tuve que devolver la caja para comprar otra con entrada de aire/ventiladores en el frontal tras 2 semanas probando mil cosas porque no había manera de contener las temperaturas y desgraciadamente el embalaje original fue tirado por error ya que siempre me guardo todo religiosamente durante 1 mes. El vendedor (tercero) me abonó poco más de la mitad del importe sólo por esto a pesar de devolver el producto de manera impoluta, pero Amazon, como siempre, arregló la situación tras reclamar. Así da gusto.
Cette tour est géniale et permet même de rentrer une RTX 4070Ti Phantom Reunion.

I swapped all my parts from the pictured NZXT H210, and the build process was simple and stress free. I was starting to grow out of my old case, as I wanted something less obtrusive to take advantage of what ITX can really do. Since I didn't get custom cables, the stock PSU cables were quite rigid but luckily all the panels on the entire case are removable (and believe me, you're gonna have to remove them all). What really drew me to this case in particular is the price compared to the much more expensive FormD T1 and even the regular A4-SFX. But beyond that, I mainly liked how this case is simple without any obstructive lights or branding. This case is beautiful just by the fact that it doesn't draw attention to itself, which goes an extra step further since none of my components inside it have any RGB either.

Now for the part that really blew me away was the temps. This shouldn't be surprising because the NZXT H210 is notorious for being an oven, but somehow I was expecting such a small case like this one to run hot as well. GPU temps dropped by more than 10 degrees across the board. Full load previously was 84C but has been reduced to 72C now. For my normal usage (60-75%) the GPU stays around 64C. Compared to the H210, the noise level is much quieter and the GPU is no longer screaming for its life. Another thing I like is how the GPU is on the right side of the case. Most other sandwich layouts I've seen have it on the left, but since I put my PC on the right of my desk this means the loudest part will be facing away from me.

Overall, a great experience as a first time builder in a case this small. Lian Li has proven to be extremely high quality especially for this price point, and I like having the option to go liquid cooling later down the line next time I upgrade my PC again. I'm glad to be a member of the SFF PC community now with this case.

Edit: Took off 1 star due to riser cable issues. Got a new GPU today, found out that it wouldn't work properly unless I set the PCIe setting to 3.0 despite the case saying it supports 4.0. Not that big of a deal since realistically it makes no difference while gaming, but it is a bit misleading in this scenario.

Pros:

* Standoff extensions for the riser to allow 2-slot nvidia FE cards to have room to breath (necessary since they have a fan on the top not just bottom of the card)

* Great compact design that is very straightforward, didn't even need the manual.

* One of the few sandwich deigns that's easily purchased, most require waiting lists, second-hand markets, or crowdfunding campaigns

Cons:

* Motherboard tray is slightly misaligned with rear opening no matter what I did. Not a big deal, but it won't be quite as clean looking as it should be.

* Beware the CPU will likely run a bit hot since the top AIO is the only exhaust vent, and there isn't really room for any additional fans (with great effort I was able to squeeze a slim 80mm fan in the bottom but that was about it).

Misc:

* Requires a fair bit of disassembly to install AIO initially especially if you want to avoid remounting it with an existing motherboard.

* My specs: ASrock Phantom ITX B550, Corsair h100 240mm AIO, NVidia RTX 3080 Ti, SF600 Platinum PSU.

name: Bgears b-Voguish Gaming PC with Tempered Glass ATX Mid Tower, USB3.0, Support E-ATX, ATX, mATX, ITX.(Note: Fan NOT Included in This Model.Only b-Voguish-RGB(ASIN:B08W2MXBQJ) Come with ARGB Fans)Black
description:
• Package weight : 15.3 Lbs
  • 5mm thickness tempered glass Side window panel
  • Country of origin : China
  • Support water-cooling front-240mm top-240mm rear-120mm

reviews.review:
Very spacious to work in. I was not sure about the sturdiness, but that was a worry I should not have. The frame is very sturdy, no sharp edges. Was a bit cautious pulling the front glass off.
Delivery: The box was fully intact, that is always my biggest worry. Glass has no chips and is fitting well.
Is it a fish tank? I think it has some small surprises, for instance the grommets are well-placed. Paint quality is more than sufficient. I put in a full ATX board and there is plenty of space to put in a liquid cooler with three fans. The assembly was a bit tricky here and there, it is because I do not have a modular power supply. I would definitely recommend this case, if you like to look inside the computer. There is plenty of airflow as the front plate sits about 5mm away from the case. Yup, glad I put this together.
Pro: Easy to assemble and build in
Cons: none so far.

Edit: small update, I grabbed a bigger modular PSU and I just wish I could remove the disk cage without a drill (which I do not have).
Still very pleased with the case, just need to learn cable management.

When it comes to the tan installation the diameter of the screw holes are just a bit large. You could compensate and get larger ones but you risk bending the aluminum and breaking the glass front. The glass front is not removable either so you can only go in though one side. The way I had gotten around this was but using industrial hot glue. I just put some hot glue on each screw before threading it. What this does is dries and acts like self fighting washers. It does the job and I’ve had no worries.

It was mentioned in the product description that fans were not included. I found out why after delivery.
There are 3 Fan openings facing the front but all are useless because all the predrilled holes are too large to use standard computer hardware. Worse yet the space in between the computer case and the nonremovable tempered glass is way too narrow. A butter knife with a paper towel wrapped around the tip barely fits. The case has other fan openings which are fine.
To overcome the obviously defective case design requires the following. Buy a black foam board ($2.00)available at most dollar stores. Measure and cut the foam board to tightly fit the front
of the computer. Then carefully cut out of the board the openings for the 3 fans. I used super glue to attach the fans to the foam board. When installed, the board hides all the useless screw holes. The foam board is held in place from the inside with some tape. I will update this my review to include a picture of the fix.

Case gets very warm very fast. aesthetics is great, really nice to look at. But, the back side leaves next to no room for cable management. everything is a tight fit. Fitting an Aio in this case isnt realistic as the Aio's ive tried dont fit properly in the top or the rear exhaust vent. 120mm aio and 240mm aio didn't fit good at all. nevermind a 140mm or 280mm..

3/5 . Nice to look at, but next to no room for cable management in the back panel area. and if your Motherboard has a majority of its features and fan headers on the bottom, good luck.. the case is advertised as being able to have 3 fans on the bottom inside, which it wont if you have things plugged into the bottom of an Atx board. its advertised as supporting E-Atx.. I would NOT advise this and an Atx board is a tight enough fit and stand offs wont reach the end of an E-atx board, and half the standoffs dont even screw in. If your Motherboard has Shroud over the Vrm and heat pipes on the top, (example, x570 Meg Ace) you arent going to fit the 140mm advertised fan size at the top, and 120mm is a very tight fit. I have a 2070 super and a arctic air cooler, Duo series. the case is so tight the power cables of my Gpu are compressed against the glass and so is my Cpu cooler (bowing the glass), which is one of the more compact coolers, glass is cheap so risk of crack or break is very high. The Usb 3.0 cord is thick and large, being this tight it need a low profile cable!

I love the look, which is why i purchased this case, looks really nice. But No cable managment room, high temps and the squeeze of fitting everything really takes this case down some pegs. I had to remove the usb 3.0 cable from the case just to fit the bottom fans.. I really hope to see an updated version of this case. its a tie for 2/5 or 3/5.

had to install my windows then assemble my computer going to get an external usb dvd drive now. Update: finally completed my build that's when I noticed this was missing a cable vis blocker for the center. Which means I paid for new and got used

Dont listen to bad comment .
This case is a great budget case
It fit a 240/280 mm aio on top and a total of 9 case fan

Not plenty of room for cable management but you still can do something clean
I have this case since 2020

This case is amazing! Don’t listen to any other review. You get amazing cable management options, and a hinged tempered glass panel. People complaining there aren’t any fans are seriously idiotic for not reading the deacription. USING YOUR OWN FANS IS 100% BETTER! I recommend this case to anyone building a pc on a budget, I will be giving it as an option to all my clients!

-Gaetan Lahaie
Infinite Builds
Could have added more hard drive bays with sliders

Its size is very tolerable to work with, and its build quality is very stable and strong in my opinion. I am presently reviewing the b-Voguish case standalone; no fans/accessories or other parts along with it, and all I can say is I'd prefer if: the backcase had bigger/easier notches to hook onto to slide the plate back into place) The front glass was easier to detach for cleaning) More available slots to slide wires through the bottom plate and above the MB inside the case) Came with more wraps for cable management). Two complaints I have is the I/O panel at the top has ceased to recognize when or if my headset is plugged in after about a month, making it the issue where similarly you have to bend the phone charger cable a certain way for it to recognize it's in, and the mounting at the back is a little finicky to work with(Not a real problem, just personal opinion). Would definitely rate this a 5/5 if the I/O panel at the top still worked...!

Large and spacious inside. Full Glass door and front! WOW! This baby is awesome. My full size ATX and ATX Extended MOBOs fit in this puppy with lots of room for my huge graphics card, dual fan water CPU water cooler and 4-RAM modules. With the power supply & drive bays hidden underneath the interior space, there's plenty of room to mod your PC without concerns for space. There are no drives to block airfolow and wiring is completely hidden below or behind the MOBO.
.
The GLASS is thick and heavy, so bumping it won't break it. The side door can also be removed completely for full interior access for major mod work. With the front and side being mostly glass, you're allowed to show off your PCs guts and true coolness! The included RGB fans are huge 140mm's and push air in, beautifully. When everything is all lit up, the color takes over in a blackened room for cool FX.
.
The underside, holds and hides your power supply and all interior drives, whether 3.5" or SSD, there's room for them to live comfortably. The front fans cool the underside as well as the upper interior. With 3-fans in the front, you get lots of airflow. The top allows for 2-3 exhaust fans, and the back accepts a 120mm fan to blow hot air out the back as well. This is referred to as "positive-negative" flow balance. 3-in, 3-out. Well-designed for functionality and, well, just showing off!

Nice case for $40 used. Came in original box and with all the screws and parts. Side glass was not scratched or damaged. The only thing is the Supermicro mbd-x9drh-7f screw holes don't line up the ones in the case. Dual Xeon E5-2643 v2. 64gb ddr3 1600mhz, x2 lsi 9286-8e, 9271-8i, Solarflare SFN5122F.
This case looks great win u got things installed. But downfall is their not much room for wiring. I give it 4 because it turned out beautiful.

So I don't like that it doesn't come with any fans. I was surprised when I opened it up and found none. I went back and read the entire Amazon listing and did find in the question section someone asked if it came with fans and the answer was NO, but the listing sure does not make that clear and makes it look like it does in the pictures.
