For me CPUs like this, which are budget CPUs are mostly about the price. For $100 USD or less this is an excellent buy. If it's more than that, uhhhh. I'll take the 5600 for $130 Bob.

While this is a Zen 3 CPU, it's not PCIe gen4 and you should be aware of this before buying. It's not the same line of CPU that most Zen 3 CPUs which are Vermeer. This is Cezanne. There are 3 Cezanne CPUs, the other two are OEM only, meaning they only come in a PC you buy from a company that makes PCs like Dell, etc........ For the most part this isn't a problem because it's a budget CPU, however if you pair this with something like an AMD Radeon 6500 XT which only uses 4 PCIe lanes to connect to the CPU, you'll get bad performance. So don't do that.

Otherwise as long as you pair this with at least an 8 PCIe lane GPU it works fine. You take a tiny hit in GPU performance but not enough to worry about.

The bigger hit comes with the NVMe drives, especially in 2023 and going forward. There are now MANY NVMe disks that are a lot faster than 4GB/s, and to give as simple explanation as I can, a PCIe lane is a serial data line. The way a PCIe device/bus works is by grouping a certain amount of lanes so that you get the speed of a single PCIe lane times the number of lanes you have. Any NVMe disk has 4 lanes. It also means the port you plug it into along with what it connects to (CPU, motherboard chipset) has 4 PCIe lanes that it will connect with. So, you get 4 PCIe lanes. So now you need to know the data speed for each lane. For PCIe gen3, the speed of each lane is 1GB/s. For PCIe gen4 the speed of each lane is 2GB/s. So, with this CPU, the best you can get is a data transfer rate of 4GB/s to an NVMe disk. That's it. The newest disks coming out the end of 2022, and 2023 can hit speeds near 9GB/s. Now, most data transfers to/from NVMe disks can't run at that speed. However many disks can run many data transfers faster than 4GB/s, so that means a CPU that runs PCIe gen3 is slowing down modern NVMe disks that can run gen4 or now gen5 speeds. But that's not a statement that has a clear meaning, because just because a disk is called gen4, it doesn't mean most of the data transfers to/from that disk will run at the full bandwidth of PCIe gen4 x4 lanes = 8GB/s. Most gen4 disks rarely hit that speed if ever. Only the most expensive ones do. BUT once again many will run different types of transfers above 4GB/s.

So that's the description of what it means to have PCIe gen3 when dealing with modern NVMe disks. You're going to slow down some of the data transfers, not all, depending on how fast (which also means more expensive) the disk is.

Yes for a general purpose PC build this is good enough and it's a low cost option that's really good at $100 USD or less. However if the price of this starts to get closer to the Ryzen 5600, I'd rather buy the 5600 because that's PCIe gen4 which is as good as it gets with an AMD AM4 motherboard.

This is a great CPU for general use and budget/mid-range gaming! It's able to keep up with all my computing tasks and when gaming with my AMD RX6700XT. Seriously I am very impressed. I will say that when I first installed it, the CPU was running a little warm, but nothing too bad and after a few days it seemed to settle down and now typically sits around 55-65 degrees even while gaming/computing in this hot SoCal summer. I generally see about 20% to 30% usage while playing pretty recent games on 1440p and ultra quality. Would I prefer a 5600x, 5700x or 5800x? Of course, but for the price, nothing beats the value of this CPU and I'm just not willing to spend double the price on relatively limited performance increases. As long as you're not planning to do some extremely CPU-heavy tasks or overclocking, this CPU should fit your needs perfectly. The Wraith Stealth cooler is a nice free add-on as well, although I would suggest if you're looking for ultimate performance, you might want to contemplate a tower air cooler or AIO. However, the Wraith is more than adequate by itself. Anyway, I can't recommend this CPU enough. Keep in mind though, if you're used to Intel CPUs which typically come with integrated graphics, this CPU does not (only G series AMD CPUs like the 5600G for example include integrated graphics although they don't perform as CPUs as well as non G series), so you'll have to buy a graphics card. Also keep in mind X series CPUs like the 5600x are for extreme overclocking (I would go easy on overclocking non-X CPUs and for a lower ranged CPU like this one I would not recommend any overclocking at all). Hope that helps with your decision! Thanks for reading

Processore mid range ottimo, per il prezzo che costa io lo ho preso a 95 euro, riesce a dare delle ottime performance per giocare, editare e registrare, lo ho accoppiato con una RX 6650xt e 32gb di RAM a 3200mhz, mai avuto il computer così veloce, riesco a gestire tutte le mie applicazioni anche con giochi abbastanza pesanti e importanti aperti come GTA V e Destiny 2 con qualità al massimo e fare tranquillamente 100+ FPS, veramente consigliato per chi deve fare upgrade da un ryzen 3 e si trova ancora su piattaforma AM4, se invece volete un po' più di performance vi consiglio di cambiare scheda madre e passare ad AM5 per avere anche spazio per futuri upgrade da parte di AMD

Por lo tanto, no puedo ofrecer mi perspectiva en cuanto a esos juegos más demandantes.

Dicho esto, considero que este procesador es una excelente opción para aquellos que buscan un rendimiento sólido tanto en juegos como en aplicaciones de uso diario. Su precio asequible lo convierte en una opción atractiva para estudiantes y usuarios que no requieren un alto nivel de exigencia en sus tareas informáticas. En resumen, recomendaría este procesador para aquellos que buscan una mejora significativa en el rendimiento de su sistema sin tener que invertir grandes sumas de dinero.

name: AMD Ryzen™ 5 7600 6-Core, 12-Thread Unlocked Desktop Processor
description:
• POWERFUL GAMING STARTS HERE
  • 6 Cores and 12 processing threads, based on AMD "Zen 4" architecture
  • 5.2 GHz Max Boost, unlocked for overclocking, 38 MB cache, DDR5 support
  • For the state-of-the-art Socket AM5 platform, can support PCIe 5.0 on select 600 Series motherboards
  • AMD Wraith Stealth cooler included

reviews.review:
This CPU is a great value. Fast boost clocks, and runs relatively cool (compared to its sister chips), enough to be handled by an air cooler. (I used a Noctua NH-U12S Redux.) It's powerful yet efficient. Honestly, unless you're a content creator, unlikely you need more than six cores. I can't even get this thing to break a sweat in productivity (I work from home) and games. Highly recommend.

NOTE THOUGH: The one I got from Amazon was faulty. Probably just bad luck. But if your computer randomly resets, has memory errors (but none while using MemTest86 at stock), or ever freezes in the BIOS, return the chip and try again. I wasted so much time returning motherboards and RAM kits when it was the chip all along. Got my second chip from NewEgg and it worked fine.
After researching and talking to amd sales and making the final plunge I wasn’t happy with the speed and overall performance with my games

The CPU has plenty of power for modern games and code compilation. The CPU runs a bit hot with the included cooler but can still get good sustained boost speeds. At idle the CPU runs around 55-60deg C. My motherboard is stock configured to run the CPU fan at 70% at 60deg C temperature. With the included cooler + case fans the CPU can sustain 4.8 GHz boost on all cores with 100% load. The max boost speed of the CPU is 5.1 GHz. 4.8 GHz boost under sustained load on all cores seems OK to me although you could probably get a bit more performance with a better cooler. Under any considerable load the CPU runs at 95deg C, which to my understanding is what it's designed to do. Outside of gaming and code compilation the CPU rarely goes above idle speeds though.

This quick little chip is coping well with everything I am throwing at it, I use my pc mostly for gaming a lot of the games I play rely heavily on the cpu and this Ryzen 5 7600 is not even breaking a sweat, can’t comment on how well it copes with work uses, but if you are looking for a solid gaming cpu that won’t break the bank this is a good choice.

CPU runs hot. Better to use a big air cooler or AIO. Runs at 4.8 to 5.1 GHz and 85-98°C with stock cooler. Best starting point in the AM5 line up. This is better than 7600x because its about 3-5% performance increase for ₹2k, and the 7600x doesn't come with an included cooler.

I was going to build a streaming PC with the cheaper AM4 parts, then decided to go with AM5 so I could upgrade the CPU if I want to in the future. I was going to order the Ryzen 7800x3D but the deliver date for that was a month away. Was going to take the 7950x out of my gaming pc and swap it with the 7800x3d and put the 7950x in the stream pc, but I couldn't wait so I went with the 7600, non x, it saved me a good amount of money and came with a heatsink. Was enough power for the 4K60 capture card and Intel A380 GPU to capture my gameplay in 4K60 AV1. I think it's the wiser choice over AM4.

I simply love it. Super easy to install on the motherboard. It comes with a good cooler fan with a pre-applied layer of thermal paste (don't touch it, as I did). The "G" stands for graphics and a good graphic I'd say. Its Vega 8 processor make an excellent backup if you have a dedicated card, and if not, it allows you to go with some less demanding games and software. I was also surprised when I see its price below C$300

Sono rimasto sbalordito dalle prestazioni offerte dal processore AMD Ryzen 7 5700G. Ecco perché sono entusiasta di condividere la mia esperienza con questo gioiello di tecnologia:

Potenza Bruta:
Il Ryzen 7 5700G si è dimostrato un vero campione in termini di prestazioni. Con 8 core e 16 thread, offre un'accelerazione incredibile per qualsiasi tipo di compito, che si tratti di gaming, editing multimediale o multitasking intenso. Le applicazioni pesanti vengono gestite senza alcun problema, garantendo una fluidità senza compromessi.

Grafica Integrata Impressionante:
La GPU Vega integrata è una sorpresa molto gradita. Anche senza una scheda grafica discreta, ho potuto godere di un'esperienza di gioco straordinaria. Giochi meno esigenti possono essere eseguiti a dettagli elevati senza alcun problema. Questo lo rende una scelta perfetta per costruzioni di sistemi compatti o per coloro che desiderano risparmiare sul costo di una GPU dedicata.

Efficienza Energetica:
Sono rimasto sorpreso dalla gestione dell'energia di questo processore. Nonostante le prestazioni eccezionali, l'efficienza energetica è notevole. Il Ryzen 7 5700G è stato progettato per offrire potenza senza dover compromettere il consumo energetico.

Facilità di Overclocking:
Per gli appassionati, l'overclocking è un piacere con questo processore. Le prestazioni possono essere spinte ulteriormente, permettendo un controllo totale sulla potenza di elaborazione.

Compatibilità e Aggiornamenti:
La compatibilità con le schede madri AM4 è un punto a favore. Inoltre, la possibilità di aggiornare il BIOS per supportare le ultime tecnologie garantisce che il Ryzen 7 5700G sia una scelta futura-proof.

In conclusione, il processore AMD Ryzen 7 5700G ha superato le mie aspettative in termini di prestazioni, efficienza energetica e versatilità. Se stai cercando un processore che offra prestazioni di alto livello e una grafica integrata degna di nota, questo è sicuramente la scelta giusta. Lo consiglio vivamente a tutti gli appassionati di gaming e creativi che cercano il massimo dalle loro macchine.

...pour en tirer pleinement profit. Je ne vais pas réécrire tout ce qui a déjà été dit sur ce processeur, si ce n'est que pour le faire mouliner à 4,6 GHz en cas de tâche lourde il faut s'orienter vers un ventirad plus conséquent, ce que j'envisage de faire bientôt (minimum 4 caloducs + ventilateur(s) 120 mm).
En effet, il chauffe à 90° - 95° en cas d'utilisation à 4,6 GHZ, ce qui pourrait diminuer sa durée de vie (je ne parle pas d'overclocking). Sinon en utilisation "soft" avec turbo désactivé dans le bios ("core performance boost") il ne dépasse pas les 70° (40° en "idle"), mais comme je l'ai dit on ne profitera pas pleinement de ses capacités (de toute façon il diminuera lui-même sa fréquence max quand on dépasse les 90°)

I upgraded from a 2700X which was really good, However I hated not having onboard graphics to troubleshoot. While the On-Board graphics is powerful enough to do light gaming and basic office work It's only a Radeon Graphics APU, Meaning anything released in the last 15 years is probably outside of it's capabilities with exception to some online games (Runescape, League of Legends, ect). That's not really why you would want to buy this for a gaming computer, You could have a processor with more raw power and more L2/L3 Cache that would definitely do better, but... having onboard graphics is sort of like a spare tire. When a GPU inevitably breaks it's nice to be able to hop along and still use your computer until you get a replacement. It's for this reason I bought this processor, my GPU may break & I may or may not be able to buy another graphics card based on current prices (Things have gotten crazy on the GPU market.... most people can't afford mid-range GPU's anymore) I love my computer but I'm not that wealthy, having onboard graphics as a spare tire is infinitely more valuable than 5% increase in performance, Don't let that fool you though this APU is a powerhouse of AM4 Architecture and compared to my 2700x It's really fast, with higher turbo frequencies and a much lower TDP, It can still be overclocked (granted voiding your warranty in the process) for when you want to squeeze even more juice out of it. Overall it's a great CPU and I highly recommend it for anyone who can't upgrade to AM5 yet (All AM5's have built in graphics)

Un APU (CPU + iGPU), convaincant de part sa consommation modérée (grand max 90W au total CPU + iGPU), et une chauffe maîtrisée (jusqu'à 65W de TDP max), malgré une puissance clairement présente (autant pour la partie graphique (le plus puissant des iGPU) que CPU).

La rapidité d’exécution des calculs n'est pas dingue (légèrement inférieure à un 5600X, à cause du manque de cache...), il en résulte donc des performances gaming correctes, sans plus, mais sa puissance totale (8 cœurs 16 threads tout de même) est conséquente, et permettra une utilisation des logiciels gourmands sans aucun soucis, et un multitâche poussé.

La partie graphique permet du gaming léger (1080p low autour de 40fps en moyenne), et d'afficher de la 4k 60fps sur maximum 3 écrans (même si les cartes mères n'ont que 2 ports vidéos max...).
Cet iGPU est bien supérieur en terme de perfs à tout ceux de Intel (même le dernier UHD 770) d'environ 30%, et amplement suffisant pour toutes les tâches bureautiques.
Attention, l'iGPU ne disposant pas de mémoire vidéo dédié mais partagée, je vous recommande fortement d'opter pour de la RAM de qualité (minimum 2x8 Go en DDR4 3200 MHz), pour que la puissance de calcul graphique ne soit pas bridée. PS : pensez à activer l'XMP.

En revanche pour les petites config gaming (autour de 500 euros) sans carte graphique dédiée, j'aurai plutôt tendance à vous recommander le 5600G, dont les perfs graphiques et en jeu sont quasi similaires, seule la puissance brute varie (d'environ 30%), et de 60 euros en moyenne moins cher.
Pour les grosses config (> à 1000 euros), partez plutôt sur un 5600X ou un 5700X (et pour des config gaming entre 600 et 1000 euros, le 5600 tout court est top !!!).

Pour le refroidissement, le Wraith Sleath intégrée à cet version boxed est limite... on atteint les 85 degrés lors des grosses charges. Un ventirad doté de minimum 4 caloducs est donc recommandé pour ménager la durée de vie de cet APU.

Côté carte mère, une B450 est recommandée, attention, il faudra mettre à jours le BIOS.
Une B550 est également compatible avec MàJ du BIOS, mais celle-ci sont plus couteuses, et n'apportent rien de plus, cet APU se limitant à du PCIe 3.0, contre 4.0 pour les 5000 et 5000x (à prendre en compte si on veut faire du gaming).

- Parenthèse overclocking -

L'overclocking de cet APU est top. Il est facile, apporte beaucoup, et très stable ! Par contre ça chauffe et consomme plus du coup (Passé à 120w de conso pour +10% de perfs). Mais surtout le must, c'est l'overclocking de l'iGPU ! Je l'ai passé à 2400MHz, et j'ai gagné 15% de fps !
De plus, l'iMC dans cet APU est excellent, la RAM tourne bien même overclockée, même sur 4 rank, et même sur une CM Daisy-Chain !

Résumé :

Les plus :

- puissance brute
- efficacité énergétique
- rapport perfs/prix (pour 230 euros environ)
- la partie graphique convaincante
- l'overclocking fantastique !

Les moins :

- le ventirad
- le manque de cache (=> pas ouf pour du gaming)
- la concurrence avec le 5600G, et les 5000X*
- l'absence de PCIe 4.0 (que du 3.0)

Recommandé pour :

De la bureautique poussée.

Déconseillé pour :

Du gaming.

Voili voilou fin du pavé ;)

Questo 5700G è sostanzialmente equivalente ad un Ryzen 5700X con qualche limitazione da un lato e con qualche miglioria dall'altro.

La limitazione è data dal fatto che non supporta lo standard pci-e 4.0 ma solamente 3.0 (per quanto mi riguarda non è un problema). Il lato migliore è dato dal fatto che ha una GPU integrata (Radeon Vega) in grado di offrire un adeguato framerate anche ad alte risoluzioni con livelli di dettaglio medio. In più la presenza di una architettura 8 core /16 thread ne consente un suo utilizzo anche per supportare carichi di lavoro pesanti.

Stiamo parlando quindi di un processore di fascia medio-alta pensato per configurazioni office con heavy workload, media center o gaming di fascia bassa (se usato con la GPU integrata, medio-alta se usato per supportare una GPU dedicata)

Io personalmente ho acquistato questa APU per realizzare una postazione di lavoro tipo "workstation" dove sfrutto la potenza del processore per far girare qualche machina virtuale per la generazione/gestione di servizi home (quindi con un po' di disco e tanta RAM). La configurazione è la seguente:

- Asrock B450 Steel Legend (Bios Aggiornato)
- 4x16GB Corsair LPX 3600 CL18
- 2 x Crucial P2 1TB NVME,
- Thermalright SI-100
- Case SilverStone Grandia GD09
- Corsair TX650W Modulare
- 3 x 120 Arctic P12
- 2 x 80 Arctic P8
- 1 Fan Controller Lamptron FC5

My targeted use for the AMD 4600g was for a MiniITX based HTPC. For $99 this guy is a beast and was easily one of the best CPUs in this range. Anything cheaper saw sharp reductions in performance. I also paired him with a fairly quality $99 mITX board from gigabyte and the system is overkill for what I needed it for.

In 2022 the Intel i3 12100 (The later 13100 is more or less the same in performance and price) really tried to move in on the 4600g's spot. Now in 2023 the price difference is only around $15 and the intel does give a little better cpu performance, but if you were also interested in the gaming performance of the built in iGPU you will find the Vega7 graphics are a bit better. Not only in performance but also at the driver level, the AMD will offer significantly less bugs over intel. If you are looking to pair up with an external graphics card however the intel is probably better.

The cost of a MiniITX for the intel will also add an additional $15 at least (And this may go up, I found when I wanted to use some older intel processors in mITX builds the motherboards were all oldstock and significantly marked up). So the final build should you go with AMD should be cheaper, too.

Processeur reçu dans sa boîte d'origine, avec ventirad inclus (c'est pas clairement indiqué, du coup, ce commentaire peut aider ^^). Il est très performant et complètement à l'aise dans les tâches quotidiennes mais également dans la retouche de photos, l'infographie, la bureautique ... et YouTube en 4K.

Ce modèle possède une partie graphique Radeon Vega 7 très performante qui permet de faire tourner quelques jeux en faisant des compromis sur la qualité et la résolution.

Le ventilateur est silencieux dans les tâches quotidiennes et se montre un peu plus bruyant sans que ça ne soit excessif quand on sollicite la partie graphique.

Bref, c'est un chouette compromis si on ne veut pas trop investir (dans mon cas, c'était une machine d'appoint pour soulager ma machine principale).

Montei meu pc com este processador, ele é muito bom, a Vega 7(placa de vídeo integrada) funciona bem. Não é muito potente, em uma comparação com os consoles de mesa, esse processador seria como um Xbox 360 pró, aonde jogamos os mesmos jogos, com a mesma qualidade gráfica porem numa resolução melhor(FULLHD). Pelo preço vale muito a pena, e o processador em si abre muita margem pra upgrade, oq é ótimo.

description:

reviews.review:
After upgrading my graphics card from a GForce GTX 1660 to an RTX 4090, it was time to remove the CPU bottle-neck from some of my workflow. I did not want to go through the expense of upgrading my motherboard to support the newer generation of AM5 CPUs and so the best option I could find was a significant jump (in price) to the Ryzen 9 5950X.

Moving from a Ryzen 7 3700X to a Ryzen 9 5950X netted a 25% performance boost in my 3D rendering workflow. While the price-tag seems a bit steep for only 25% I am comfortable with the cost due to lowered render times. Imagine cutting 1h from a 4h render - every time.

I found that my CPU cooler (wraith prism) was not really able to keep up with the Ryzen 9 5950X under full-load and thermal throttling was observed. I've since moved to an MSI P360 AIO water-cooling system because water cooling offers more smoothing of heat cycles as compared to air-cooling which needs to throttle up and down as the load modulates. The net result is less fan spin-up/spin-down noise as well as less high-rate temperature cycling.

This review comes from Intel fanboy. In over 40 years that's all I have used all Intel X series CPU's and the latest was 12900k, yes 12900k. You would assume that is downgrade going to 5950X....think again.

Ween I first installed this 5950X and so the clock speeds and how cool it run straight from the box, I fall in love with this CPU.

Straight from the box means, PBO "auto" which realty means Off and this is also B2-Stepping batch, clocks all day long 4.9MHz-5050MHz and cooled by NH-D15...I absolutely love it.

Compare to 12900k that was constantly hitting 90C-95C and throttling like crazy, its like comparing night and day.

You can't beat 105 TDP 16 core CPU that can run comfortably 5GHz at 60-65C on any platform to Intel's base 125 TDP that runs 5.1GHz at 90C-95C on top of that, you need windows 11 for the e and p core to run properly.....no thanks.

Totally recommend and again that is coming from long time Intel fanboy.

As usual delivery was prompt. I was excited to get this chip in the 5 year old motherboard that had a ryzen 7 1700 in it. I updated the bios in the ASROCK X370 Taichi mother board, and swapped it out. Used some new Arctic MX-4, and had to order another water cooler. That is a different story, I got the new AIO and this chip is awesome. I build with UnrealEngine5, and the 16 cores 32 threads pushed hard and fast, as well as cool. Water cool this chip if you want some performance from it. 1.3 volts with all cores @ 4500. Runs very cool. I know I can get more, but I want to make this last a little. Well worth the bucks for a home workstation.
First one came dead on arrival, but Amazon stepped up quickly and sent a replacement for it. CPU is a bit pricey, but does everything really well. Thanks Amazon.
likes it

I've upgraded from my Ryzen 7 1800X recently. I waited coz I was hoping we'll have 5950X3D, but anyways. The gain in performance is substantial. Plus no more random freezes. (Yeah, it happened even after RMA, although less frequently, I suppose) I bought it at around CAN$660, when 7950X was still around CAN$790. I think it's worth the upgrade.

With the recent price drop I couldn't resist the beast that is the 5950x. Running on a B550 Mobo, 64gb of 3600 cl14 ram, and a 3080 ti.....and I could not be happier. Upgraded from a 5800x and the thing that surprised me most is the 5950x runs 7-10c cooler than the 5800x!!! I do very intensive VFX work in Houdini and this CPU chews through everything I throw at. Will run 4.5-4.6ghz on a full AVX workload on all 16cores, and 4.8-4.9ghz when gaming. Very temperature dependent so make sure you have a beefy air cooler or aio.

Wasn't ready to do a full system upgrade for 12th gen and DDR5 and I have 0 complaints.
The cpu provides a good and smooth gaming experience. I upgraded from ryzen 7 3800x to this and the performance increase is very noticeable.

Having recently transitioned to the AMD Ryzen 9 5950X, I must say it's a beast regarding raw performance. Sporting 16 cores and 32 threads is a testament to AMD's relentless pursuit of CPU dominance.

The CPU, in its stock state, without any overclocking, was unfortunately a bit too hot to handle with a standard cooler. This was evident as I experienced frequent blue screens of death (BSOD) in Windows, and temperatures soared to an alarming 90°C. High temperatures could harm the processor in the long run and hamper its performance.

However, the game changed entirely once I paired it with the Be Quiet! BK022 Dark Rock Pro 4. Not only does the cooler live up to its name by operating silently, but it also ensures that the CPU remains cool even under heavy load. After the upgrade, I observed a maximum temperature of 70°C with all cores being utilized. This is a commendable feat, given the power and potential of the 5950X.

When it comes to actual performance, calling the 5950X a 'monster' might be an understatement. With its 16 cores, I've been able to:

Video Editing: Handling 4K footage has been a breeze. Timeline scrubbing is smooth, and rendering times have been considerably reduced.
Photo Editing: High-resolution images, multi-layered edits, and batch processing are no match for this processor. Programs like Photoshop run seamlessly.
Video Encoding: Even in demanding formats, Transcoding videos is high-speed. The 5950X reduces the time taken for tasks that once felt painfully long.
Gaming: Playing modern AAA titles at ultra settings has never felt smoother. Paired with a capable GPU, the 5950X ensures no CPU-related bottlenecks.
Simulations & Rendering: Whether it's 3D modelling, animation rendering, or running complex simulations, the sheer power of the 5950X ensures tasks are completed in record time.
The performance is further accentuated by the 64GB RAM on my X570 motherboard, ensuring that multitasking is effortless and there's no memory shortage, even for the most memory-intensive applications.

In conclusion, the AMD Ryzen 9 5950X is an absolute powerhouse designed for enthusiasts and professionals who demand the best. However, to truly unlock its potential, it's crucial to pair it with a high-quality cooler like the Be Quiet! BK022 Dark Rock Pro 4. This combo ensures that you get the raw power of the 5950X without the heat-related issues. Look no further if you're in the market for a top-tier CPU setup.

Secured this processor on a particularly good deal and has been the keystone to my current build. Exceptional multi-core and even single-core performance, making gaming and high-load processes a breeze. Paired with liquid cooling this processor will last forever in a solid build for those who don't want to break the bank for next gen hardware with all new socket types and RAM requirements. A stellar processor all around even 3 years after initial release.

The 5950X processor is a beast. It annihilates everything I throw at it. The only downside to this chip is the cost, but that said, it's totally worth stretching to if possible as it'll be quite some time before another upgrade is needed and the performance it delivers is simply lovely. Even the intensive apps I use are smooth as butter and it provides the processing power to support the latest games. A powerful CPU like this will easily provide the speed to support the latest games and help the latest graphics cards reach their potential. Pairing a 4 series RTX GPU for example, with an older/slower processor, will cause bottlenecks, limiting the potential of both. With a 5950X, that simply isn't an issue, it's fantastic.

So yeah, pricey, but you get an awful lot for the money. I love this chip.

You need to pair it with a video card since this is a non-video version. Since I use CPU and not gpu for the encoding process, along my gtx 1650 is more than enough to meet my requirements. Pair it with water cooling for better temps. There is no way an air system can keep this babe cool enough at that workload.

reviews.review:
Product Came in good Condition, took me like 10-15 mins to install the Chip on a Asrock b45m Pro4 Board.
was Planning on upgrading to the am5 motherboards with the ryzen 7 7800x3D but i was like 100 200$ short. seen the reviews for this chip and it looked promising, i think i will be using this chip for awhile until it dies out gonna buy a new motherboard in like a few days (AM4) just to get more power into the chip itself. dont think asrock b450m pro4 circulates a lot power for these sort of chips. but testing a few games with this chip with a 3080 amp holo its damn well smooth and impressive and a more relaxing feel and responsive and snappiness better then the ryzen 5600x i had in my rig to tie down with the 3080 amp Holo. a 50 to 70$ cpu fan can keep this beast around 70c thats on like heavy games like cod cyber punk etc might jump to 80's thats just on base clock of 3.4ghz did not attempt to OC this chip yet but on the box it says boost clock to 4.5 but imagine what a few extra ghz can do for u in game if its already running so nice on base clock. Main reason i have not yet attempted to OC this chip is because alot source said even the platform for this chip recommends not to OC the Chip, due to damaging the chip faster but dont they all say the same thing for every chip.. but OC at ur own Risk I guess but its a 10/10 for me and if u install this chip an you get a encrypted key error to Press y or N, for your bios Keys Press Y an your good to go.. i overthink the process thinking i was going to completely brake my pc. but either or answer is correct and still boots but the N answer just reboots u right back to the black screen asking u the same answer. the right answer ended up Being the "Y" botton so go ahead and press that for me and enjoy your CPU <3.

This is a beast of a CPU, the 3D V-cache literally increased my fps upwards of 30 in certain games. It does run hot if you don't have a 360MM AIO, but if you use PBO2 and undervolt all cores by -25 you're good to go and it won't hit 60c while gaming. It made gaming waaaaaaaay smoother, I don't even notice any fps drops. This thing is awesome, worth the price, buy it.

Cant say much other than it's the best upgrade I've made and probably won't upgrade for a few years, and probably wont need to until an issue actually arises. The performance difference wont be noticeable with anything "better" unless you're processing videos or similar.

I upgraded from a 5600 to a 5800x3d and later bought an aftermarket CPU cooler to run lower temps during summer and for higher gaming performance.

This upgrade was massive for me for gaming as that is my main focus and hobby on my desktop. With the AMD 5000x series drivers for my bios already installed this was plug-and-play for me.

Gaming performance hit my target 144hz on my 1440p monitor in most games with reduced settings as framerate is my go-to in fast-paced games like FPS. I do occasionally reduce framerate in single-player games or games that are isometric to reduce gpu/cpu load and get more consistent frame-times when upping graphic settings. I would recommend this in most cases for the majority of gamers but this is still my preference.

Performance is SMOOTH and I do mean buttery smooth for me. The change in the 1% lows was immediately felt by me, but take this with a grain of salt especially if you are less experienced with high framerates/stutters and not a major PC enthusiast. Most people will game at 1080p on lower refresh rates, but please try to take this CPU to at least 1440p 90-120hz for optimal experience.

COOLER - I kept my wraith cooler from my older 5600 to start while I researched what cooler I wanted to go with but I did game on this cooler for over a month. The wraith cooler was more than sufficient in most scenarios but due to the summer heat, and more demanding games my CPU temps were going above 80C and causing my room to get hotter and some CPU throttling requiring more tampering with settings and research into curve optimization. Much of my room heat comes from my PC due to it being closed, but it is an older house, a lightly insulated wooden home, with 5 windows, along with a mini-fridge and a bathroom that seems to absorb heat from somewhere. This temp was not ideal for me due to my room often being above 80F and during the heatwaves and AC work done up to 88 or higher in my room.

COOLER Pt 2 - To reduce my room heat and reduce CPU thermal throttling I purchased an aftermarket CPU cooler with 6 heat pipes. This dramatically reduced my CPU thermal throttling reducing my average temps by 10-20F which also reduced temps on my GPU. The cooler I bought was around 40-50 bucks so if you are interested that is more than enough to cool this CPU for its lifetime.

Curve Optimizer(WARNING!! this may void your warrant) - When using a curve optimizer with this CPU you will see a sizeable increase in performance and thermal temps. You can use a no-update manual optimizer like PBO2 Tuner or research into making it always optimized with bios settings. Idle temps get the most benefit from this and second is when performing at medium-high load in my experience. Idle temps were 5-10F reduced and medium-high load temps were in a similar range and sometimes far better due to increased CPU performance as well.

This CPU is an incredible value for anyone that is enthusiastic about gaming performance. Be aware that there is a newer generation of x3D cpus but the current dollar-to-dollar value for 7000x3d cpus is not close enough to consider for anyone that does not want a maxed-out expensive system.

On sale, the 5800x3d CPU is an absolute NO-BRAINER for gaming, but please be aware you need to buy a cooler, and you may need a bios update PRIOR to installing your CPU if you do not already have an AMD 5000 series CPU. If the 7000x3d series goes on sale and you are building an entirely new system, you should be aware of RAM costs and Motherboard costs as well as this can be a dramatic price differential for cheaper system builds if you are not careful.

AMD Ryzen 7 5800X3D

Ich hätte es nicht gedacht, aber auch 2023 noch spielt nicht nur die GPU bei der Spiele-Performance eine Rolle.

Vorher war bei mir ein Ryzen 5 3600 verbaut.
Grafikkarte: RTX 4070 Ti
RAM: G.Skill 32 GB 3200er DDR4-RAM
Auflösung: 1440p, UWQHD (3.440 x 1.440)
Nachdem die neue Grafikkarte verbaut war, sollte nun auch eine neue CPU her.

Im Desktopbetrieb habe ich gefühlt nur einen geringen Geschwindigkeitsschub (vorher: pfeilschnell, jetzt: pfeilschnell+).

Im Gaming-Betrieb kommt es auf das Spiel an... da gibt es Titel, die kaum oder nur etwas schneller laufen, etwa +10%, andere wieder, wo ich über +50% mehr FPS bekomme:
Z.B. 120 FPS z.B. bei Horizon Zero Dawn bei 1440p und alles auf max. sind schon ne Hausnummer, wenn man vorher mit dem Ryzen 5 3600 bei 75 FPS war. Hammer!
Was mich dabei erstaunte: Die neue CPU führt auch auch dann zu mehr FPS, wenn vorher wie nachher beim Gaming gar keine 100% CPU-Auslastung vorlag, wenn man also eher an eine Grafikkartenlimitierung denken würde.

Von der Leistungsaufnahme her ist der Ryzen 7 5800X3D im Desktopbetrieb eher noch sparsamer als die alte CPU vorher, da läuft sie so etwa bei 35 W, das passt.
Im Gaming-Betrieb unter Last zieht der 8-Kerner dann natürlich etwas mehr, etwa 100 W, damit etwa 30W mehr als die alte CPU, was aber den Kohl dann auch nicht mehr fett macht, wenn nebendran eine RTX 4070 Ti Strom zieht.

Die CPU ist nicht ganz billig, aber ich bin's zufrieden und bereue den Kauf nicht.
Auf der AM4-Plattform gibt es für den Gaming-Bereich nichts schnelleres (und wird es höchstwahrscheinlich auch nicht mehr geben).
Ich denke allerdings, dass sich sowas (die Grafikkarte auch) nur dann lohnt, wenn man sein System mit höherer Auflösung als Full HD betreiben möchte und wenn man schon ein AM4-Mainboard hat, das man noch eine Weile behalten möchte.

Wichtig bei der CPU:
Eine performate CPU-Kühlung verbauen, sonst regelt die CPU ab, wenn sie zu heiß wird!
Bei mir ist ein Thermalright Peerless Assassin 120 SE verbaut, was prima harmoniert.
In dieser Kühler-Leistungsklasse sollte man schon arbeiten. Oder eine WaKü verbauen.

I had a 5600x which has worked very well for me, paired with a 6800xt. I wasn't going to upgrade this time round as priceing to jump to AM5 right now is a little steep. However, I ended up not being able to help myself :D

Now I'm not sad that I got it & I'm pretty sure when I upgrade my GPU it shall stand me in good stead but so far I've not gained any performance in any game I play from it. In fact, due to the lower clock speed, possibly lost a few frames in some titles. I suspect the 5600x was to well matched with my current GPU (GPU bottle neck).

I think, if you have a 5600x and a GPU comparable to the 6800xt/3080 or under, you might as well skip the 5800x3D. If your GPU is more powerful though, it's probably a worthy upgrade.

This CPU does wonders with any AM4 platform. Its use of the extra 3D V-Cache allows it to be used even with top graphics cards such as the high 30 and 40 series. I paired this CPU with my 3060ti and it works great. The only issue that I have encountered with this processor is its very high temperature. The max temperature that this CPU can reach is 90 degrees which is a lot higher than other CPU's. I reached near or around this temperature with a stock AMD fan cooler. Therefore , I had to purchase a AIO cooler in order to bring the temperatures down. This also improved my performance significantly as the processor now runs 40 degrees cooler!

Una CPU che non ha bisogno di presentazioni, ha rinnovato una piattaforma vecchia di 6 anni come am4. Non mi dilungo troppo nel presentarla, volevo solo comunicare per chi avesse dubbi sull upgrade che vale assolutamente la pena se avete da un 5600x in su in abbinata ad una GPU di fascia alta, in quanto prima il 5700x non riusciva a stare completamente dietro alla mia 7900xt. Con l'x3d invece viene spremuta a dovere quasi sempre al 100%.

I have this installed into an Asrock motherboard. It works great. I was a little misinformed about the built in graphics and thought when I bought it was I was getting Iris Xe, but it's something called UHD. The product description clearly says UHD, so my bad really. Most of the other Intel 12th gen chips with graphics processing have Iris Xe which has many more graphics processing units. For sure the UHD is fine for many things including streaming video. Not sure about 3D gaming, though. Had I know it was UHD and not Iris, I might have saved $30 or so and bought the version without the graphics. On the other hand, I liked the idea of onboard graphics as a backup or alternative. In either case, this i3 runs like a champ compared to the quad core phenom ii based system it's replacing.
I'm not sure it's relevant here but I think I should mention that my Asrock board can't make use of the on board UHD graphics when you set BIOS to legacy mode. You need to use the UEFI mode in order to use the on board graphics. Not sure if that's typical of other boards or board brands. With my Asrock board, you need a discrete graphics card to use the legacy bios mode to boot from an old non-UEFI installation of windows. If that doesn't make sense to you, don't worry about it.

I'm very impressed with this CPU. If I had the money I would get the I5-12600 Non-K for video work because of the extra cores but the I3-12100 is freaking amazing. This is the most powerful CPU I have ever used. It can do the video editing I need done for now until I get better. It uses hardly any power, stays cool and is capable of much more than I need for now. I had never been able to do video editing before because the computer would lock up regardless of how fast the HDD was or how much RAM I had.

First off, I enjoy building SFF (small form factor) type builds.

The current generation of CPU's were more power hungry, which resulted in more heat to dissipate. Trying to cool a Ryzen 9 7900X on a CPU cooler rated for max 100W is quite difficult, so therefore you have to go towards cases like the NZXT H1 V2.

This particular chip allows you to not only have near identical performance to the Ryzen 9 7900X with PBO, but also gives you SFF allowable performance at a lower wattage that still provides you power.

So far today using this has been great, and I recommend this chip to anyone that wants a newer generation chip without the abismal power draws that have been required as of late.

Edit 1/17:

From normal use I have seen no difference between this model and the X model. I had both chips in my NZXT H1 V2, liquid metal as the thermal application, and by far the non X model does much better in this type of SFF build. It still will boost, however if you are like me, work from home, and use this all day long in most cases, you aren't going to want the CPU blasting at full power over the entire work day.

Quick note: temps are much better, my fan curve was not changed and the temperature is a lot more tolerable compared to the X version, so my CPU radiator fan does not spool up as much as it did with the X. I let it hover between 50C-65C for daily use and the fans are quiet, with the X the fan was at half or more RPM constantly to keep it at around this temperature and would sometimes hover in the 70's. So, if you are temperature concious then the non-x version is great.

With that said I am pleased with the product. I do feel though this model needed to be priced at $399, as we have seen the 7900X is selling at this time around $425 on sale.

Again, I will reiterate, the allowances in this chip should have been more prevalent in the X version, as I feel like we were kind of ripped off slightly this generation on CPU's and GPU's.

Edit 1/20:

This will be my final edit. I am boosting to around 5.5 MHz with the wattage anywhere from 60-90W. My temperatures are sustaining on load no more than 68C on a single 140mm AIO in the NZXT H1 V2. This is great, I am maintaining the frequency, but with a much lower power draw.

One item I would recommend is getting an aftermarket chip mounting plate for this chip, weirdly it did make a difference for this chip, around 1-2C lower than the stock MOBO chip mount. I'm using the following mount: Thermalright ASF-Black AM5 CPU Holder, Corrective Anti-Bending Fixing Frame, AM5 Full-fit Fixed Non-Marking Mounter, AM5 Anti-Bending Contact Frame, CPU Cooler Standard, I am also using the following paste: Thermal Grizzly Conductonaut Thermal Grease - 1 Gram Set + 3 Applicators + Pads - Liquid Metal Thermal Paste for Cooling The CPU, GPU Value Pack.

So far so good, would recommend, and again this is what the first chip should have been - AMD is trying too much to be intel, sure make your server chips, but we buy AMD for efficiency, not brute power in most cases. Sure, there is threadripper, but most of us are casual users. Regardless, this is the chip we all wanted, it's powerful, efficient, and over-clockable.

reviews.review: I'm upgrading from an old AMD FX 8320 chip and that was an 8 core 8 thread 3.5ghz cpu. i could overclock it to 4ghz no problem but it was DDR3 1600mhz ram. I'm using the stock Intel cooler that came with my 12700 and the highest I hit in games is about 79c, most of the time is stays in the low 70s. Idle temps stay in the 30s. That's with the cpu wattage unlocked and raising the pl1 and pl2 settings a bit in the bios and a single intake and single exhaust fan in a mid size case. I learned a long time ago that ambient room temp and fan curves are very important. You want to exhaust as much hot air as you can out of the case as fast as possible. You can mount a skyscraper to your CPU and have 12 case fans, if your room temp is high and you don't set proper fan curves, you'll still run hot. I don't care about cinebench or other benchmarks, most games people play and apps people use on a daily basis will never stress the CPU anywhere near what a benchmark will. If you do a lot of heavy video editing and conversion work and raise your wattage limits way up then yes go for a higher end cooling solution .

Edit: I've since installed an Intel RH1 cooler (the one that comes with the i9) on this chip and it dropped my temps by an average of about 8c. I know I can buy a third party cooler but I don't want a huge cpu cooler in my case and I don't want to play with brackets that may not fit 100% correctly. You can find new RH1 coolers on ebay for pretty cheap.

New build:
Corsair Icue 7000X Full Tower RGB
Ryzen 9 7900X CPU
32GB DDR5 5600 Corsair Dominator RAM
1 TB Crucial M.2 Gen 4
XFX Merc 319 Radeon 6950XT 16GB Graphics Card
Corsair 1000w PSU
Gigabyte X670 Elite AX AM5 Motherboard
Corsair iCUE H150i Elite LCD XT Liquid CPU Cooler (360 AIO mounted to top as Exhaust
6 Corsair ML140's Fans (10 total fans including those with the case/aio with 6 as intake and 4 for exhaust).
Lian Li Strimer V2 RGB Cables for the GPU and Motherboard (they look very nice and controllable via the L Connect 3 software)
As I needed additional powered USB headers I also added a Corsair Internal 4-Port USB 2.0 Hub - 4X 9-Pin USB 2.0 Ports for the Commander Core XT and Lian Li Controllers to function.
Thermal Grizzly Kryonaut Thermal Paste (removed the stock paste with AIO using TG cleaner wipes as well for better contact).
ThermalRight AMD5 CPU Shield - This allows the AIO or Waterblock (if doing a custom loop) to make WAY better contact with the CPU HS. It can be a little nerve wracking as your removing the cpu mount and installing this one but its worth it. As the AM5 CPU has no pins (the mobo now has the pins), its imperative you are gentle on the placement. Best way I found to install this shield was to place the CPU into the socket, then remove the cpu holder so this way you can't damage the cpu or pins as they are socketed. Installing the shield from that point is easy, just don't overtighten it. Theres a bunch of youtube videos on this process. Definitely recommend reviewing them before attempting this step.

I upgraded from my old Ryzen 5 2600X system with a GTX 960 SSC 4GB card and a 512gb M.2 Gen 2 drive.

Needless to say this was quite the upgrade from my old system.
Cinebench scores on my 2600X even with a mild overclock was only around 7200.

After getting everything configured/setup and Windows 11 Pro installed with all updates and enabling EXPO1 (RAM OC) and enabling SAM in the BIOS I started my benchmarking.

Cinebench score with just EXPO1 enabled baseline was 28745. What a jump!
CPU temp on the multi-core threading with the 360 AIO only went as high as 82c (AMD rates these to run at 95c as normal operating temp so it was well below even that).
Haven't done any OC'ing other than enabling EXPO1 yet since I really don't need to as the CPU and GPU run everything maxed out.

Tested on a few games on max/ultra settings and below are what I got FPS wise:

The Division 2 (All settings maxed and on DX12) - Avg 125fps on 3440 x 1440 165hz resolution
Aliens: Fireteam Elite - Avg 160fps on 3440 x 1440 165hz resolution
Borderlands 2 (older game I know but love to play it with max settings) - Avg 476fps on 3440 x 1440 165hz resolution
Forza Horizon 5 - Ultra Settings (max) including Ray Tracing - Avg 155fps on 3440 x 1440 165hz resolution
Aliens: Colonial Marines (older game) - Avg 190FPS on 3440 x 1440 165hz resolution
Warframe - Avg 155fps on 3440 x 1440 165hz resolution

Pairing this CPU and GPU together worked great and the CPU itself is a beast. It does get hot when it turbo's up into the 5ghz range which is why you need a really good cooler (either AIO or custom loop) to keep the temps in check.

If you do that, this CPU will be everything you need and then some.

One thing I always tell people is to take your time, plan out your PC parts you want for what you want the system to do (video editing, gaming, streaming, etc). Don't be afraid to look around for good deals. I scored the AIO Cooler off Newegg for a much cheaper price than Amazon had it and it works beautifully and the LCD screen is just a nice "geek" factor to put JPG's or GIF's there.

Once you have everything, take your time when building it. You may run into an issue here or there which is normal. First boot on AM5 systems is sometimes slow (Memory has to train) and you may see it cycle on/off for up to 1 minute. Mine did this and on the 4th power cycle it posted and I could get into the BIOS and everything showed up correctly.

Good luck enthusiasts and hope this review helped with anyone looking at this CPU for their system!
Its worth it!

Pour ce qui est des températures,
il faut comprendre que c'est tout a fait normal que le processeur atteigne 95°C en charge. IL A ETE PREVU POUR.

je vous invite a faire vos recherches, mais en somme, AMD à designé les CPU Zen 4 pour atteindre leur température maximale de fonctionnement afin de bénéficier de toute la puissance a disposition. D"ailleurs, vous remarquerez qu'il n'y a pas de throttle, la fréquence boost est maintenue.

Il est toujours possible dans le BIOS d'abaisser cette limite de température, mais cela se fera au détriment des performances, du au fonctionnement même de ces Ryzen

Tant que la solution de refroidissement est bonne, le CPU ne "throttlera" pas, bien que la température puisse faire peur au premeir abord.

Here's my system build so that you have context: ASRock Steel Legend X670E motherboard, AMD Ryzen 9 7900X CPU, 2X32GB G.Skill Trident Z5 DDR5 6400 (F5-6400J3239G32GX2-TZ5RS), EVGA RTX 3080Ti, and CPU cooler beQuiet! Dark Rock 4 Pro. The system drives dual Dell Ultrasharp 27" 4K monitors. My goal for this system was easy yet intense multitasking and editing of very high resolution RAW photograph files. I could scarcely be more pleased with the results. The core clocks scale to system demands instantly and running multiple programs and monitor windows is effortless. Yeah, the CPU does run hotter than previous generations AMD 12-core/24-thread CPUs; but compare the thermal qualities to Intel's CPUs in this class! My CPU heatsink, even though running only one of its two included fans, has no problems keeping the CPU under 80C, even over sustained high system loads - and that, without being annoyingly loud. Low system loads typically produce CPU core temperatures of about 45C, with a CPU fan speed of 750RPM. I have no doubt I could drop the core temps under heavy load significantly just by adding the second CPU heatsink fan. My only negative comment here is that from purchase date to order delivery required a little over two weeks. Prime used to faster.

I'd been using the ryzen 7 5800x on am4 since 2021 so finally decided to pull the trigger on moving to am5 and moving to ddr5

Using a feature packed Asus b650e-e board which I got for under £300 especially since most affordable budget x670 boards start at £300 I felt that I'm not really missing out much on not going to x670 , now after updating the bios to the latest firmware I'd finally got my memory stable I'm using gskill trident z memory with cl30 6000mhz expo ram after tinkering in the bios I managed to get it running without issue, and have used pbo and curve optimizer to get a all core 5.2ghz!

Using cinebench multicore test I got a score of 28612 which coming from the 5800x is ridiculously good.

Now gaming

Using a 7900xt at 4k this is the first CPU I've seen reach 100% GPU usage no bottlenecking at all

For £393 I find this is a brilliant price for a 12 core 24 thread monster, I can understand why people would choose the 7900 especially as this CPU does use a lot of power and will hit 90c running benchmarks but gaming I never see it run past 60c.

And the 7900x3d was another £50 and at 4k I wouldn't really see anything different between the chips and less multicore performance

I think I'd recommend most people to get the 7900 as it's more powe efficient and less hot but if you are like me and not fussed about that then I definitely recommend the 7900x

Destroys everything I throw at it with ease. An excellent purchase. I use it for a mix of coding (mainly in PHPStorm), vector graphics (Figma), music production (Bitwig), and gaming (Starfield, Armored Core 6, Baldurs Gate 3, Dwarf Fortress) and I've never been able to bring it close to 100% utilization even running multiple applications and VM's. Mine actually stays at nice temperatures, I paired it with a Noctua NH-U12s and it's in a Pop Air mini case with an XFX 7900xtx. While gaming it'll hit around 78-82c, doing less intense things it can stay around 48-55c depending on ambient temperature. Given that AMD says it can run all day at 90c with no issues, my temps are excellent. I did disable boost mode and set it to clock at a stable 4.7ghz to ensure stability, it stays flat at that speed with no issues. Worth the money.

The Intel Core i9-13900K Gaming Desktop Processor is a powerhouse that caters to both gamers and professionals, offering exceptional performance and flexibility.

Pros:

1. Hybrid Core Design: With 8 P-cores (Performance cores) and 16 E-cores (Efficiency cores), this CPU offers versatility for a wide range of tasks. It excels in both single-threaded and multi-threaded applications, making it suitable for gaming and productivity.
2. Integrated Graphics: The integrated graphics allow you to run your system without a dedicated GPU if needed. While it might not be ideal for gaming, it’s a valuable backup for troubleshooting or when a dedicated GPU is unavailable.
3. Unlocked: The “unlocked” designation means you have the flexibility to overclock the CPU for even more performance, provided you have a compatible motherboard.
4. Exceptional Performance: The i9-13900K is built for performance, with high clock speeds and a substantial number of cores and threads. It can handle demanding tasks without breaking a sweat.
5. Intel Quality: Intel is renowned for the quality and reliability of its processors. You can trust that this CPU is built to last.

Cons:

1. Price: High-end performance comes at a high-end price. This processor may be overkill for users who don’t require extreme performance or have budget constraints.

In summary, the Intel Core i9-13900K Gaming Desktop Processor is a beast of a CPU that caters to power users, gamers, and professionals who require top-tier performance. It combines a hybrid core design with integrated graphics, making it a versatile choice for various tasks. While the price tag might be intimidating, if you’re serious about your computing needs and want a CPU that can handle it all, this processor is an excellent investment. Highly recommended for enthusiasts and professionals who demand the best!

The Intel Core i9-13900K Gaming Desktop Processor has completely redefined my gaming and computing experience, offering a level of performance that's truly in a league of its own. With an impressive 24 cores, this processor delivers raw power that translates into seamless gaming, multitasking, and content creation.

To start, the processing prowess of the Intel Core i9-13900K is jaw-dropping. The 24 cores and 48 threads make it a true powerhouse, capable of handling the most demanding tasks with ease. Whether it's immersive gaming, 3D rendering, video editing, or complex simulations, this processor doesn't break a sweat.

The gaming performance is a standout feature. With its high clock speeds and multithreading capabilities, the i9-13900K ensures buttery-smooth gameplay even in the most graphically intensive titles. The ability to run background applications without compromising gaming performance is a game-changer for streamers and content creators.

Multitasking reaches new heights with this processor. The 24 cores enable effortless switching between applications, ensuring a seamless workflow even with resource-hungry software. Whether I'm editing videos, running virtual machines, or working on complex projects, the processor's performance remains consistently impressive.

The Intel Core i9-13900K's compatibility with the latest technologies is worth noting. Support for PCIe 5.0 and DDR5 memory allows for lightning-fast data transfer speeds and optimal memory performance, further enhancing the overall computing experience.

Thermal management is another area where this processor shines. The advanced cooling solutions and efficient power consumption ensure that the processor maintains optimal temperatures under heavy loads, contributing to its long-term reliability.

In conclusion, the Intel Core i9-13900K Gaming Desktop Processor has exceeded my expectations in terms of performance, gaming prowess, multitasking capabilities, technology integration, and thermal management. Its 24 cores offer a level of processing power that's perfect for gamers, content creators, and professionals seeking exceptional performance across the board. If you're looking to elevate your gaming and computing experience to unprecedented heights, the Intel Core i9-13900K is undoubtedly a worthy investment. It has earned my highest praise and has become the centerpiece of my high-performance desktop setup.

This processor is all-rounder for every tasks you do on PC from small to CPU intensive applications. If you are looking for vast performance with heavy production tasks this is very nice to have. Best to use with Motherboard DDR5 and PCI-E 5.0 supported motherboards.

When it comes to going over the top for a PC upgrade, this CPU is the undisputed heavyweight champion. I, too, dabble in video editing, 3D modeling, and an array of demanding tasks, and let me tell you, this powerhouse just devours them with sheer gusto. Paired with a Kraken water cooler, it operates like a well-oiled machine, showing absolutely no signs of throttling, even under the most intense workloads. And as for those so-called "CPU-intensive" games, well, they might as well be child's play for this beast. If you're seeking the best of the best, look no further – this CPU is the crown jewel in the kingdom of processors, and it's here to make your computing dreams come true. It's not just top-tier; it's top of the world, and it laughs in the face of anything you throw its way. A true marvel of technology that's worth every penny!

name: AMD Ryzen™ 9 7950X 16-Core, 32-Thread Unlocked Desktop Processor, Cooler not Included
description:
• The best for creators meets the best for gamers, can deliver ultra-fast 100+ FPS performance in the world's most popular games
  • 16 Cores and 32 processing threads, based on AMD "Zen 4" architecture
  • 5.7 GHz Max Boost, unlocked for overclocking, 80 MB cache, DDR5-5200 support
  • For the state-of-the-art Socket AM5 platform, can support PCIe 5.0 on select 600 Series motherboards
  • Cooler not included, liquid cooler recommended. OS Support : Windows 11 - 64-Bit Edition, Windows 10 - 64-Bit Edition, RHEL x86 64-Bit, Ubuntu x86 64-Bit

reviews.review:
I've been using this chip for awhile, and I really don't have any complaints. It took some time for Asus to get its EFI straightened out, but it is working well now. The processor itself has alwys worked well.

AM5 motherboards require a couple of tweaks to work properly, like setting up memory training, but that is easy enough to do, and really isn't a processor issue.

I only use two memory sticks, so I haven't had any issues with low memory speeds. 64GB @ 6000MHz is more than enough for my purposes.

This chip handles everything with aplomb. With good memory and a good NVME SSD, it is pretty well unbeatable.

Great chip! Recommended.

I upgraded my Threadripper 2950x with this 7950x and I'm impressed with the overall performance increase, particularly in the single core performance. I pulled the trigger on this instead of waiting for Threadripper 7000, or for more specific info on Sapphire Rapids because the 7950x offers almost everything I was looking for.

It would be nice to have 4x or 8x ram channels but I find that ddr5 offers a lot of performance on only 2 channels. It would also be nice to populate all 4 ram slots for a full 128 gb, but I'll maybe upgrade to the next gen CPU in the hopes of a better memory controller that can handle higher speed ram when all 4 slots are populated.

It would also be nice to have the extra pcie lanes that you get with HEDT/WS platforms, but I was able to find a nice board that does all that I need; and most of what I want. Specifically I wanted at minimum one pcie 5.0 X 16 slot and two pcie 5.0 nvme X 4 lanes direct to the CPU without borrowing lanes from the X16 slot or anywhere else. I found that easy enough. Anyway, the chipset i/o on the x670e boards are pretty nice and for my purposes I don't expect to see much bottle-necking on the devices I connected through the chipset.

Overall this chip, and the overall platform, is solid and will hopefully be upgradeable to the 8000 and 9000 series processors when available for even better performance and memory support (I would have given 5 stars if I could run 4 sticks of ram at 6000 mt/s)
Très content du résulta.
Does its job well.
Great CPU

This cpu is a monster. Nothing seem to be out of it reach. Running pretty high in temperature, will go to 95 degree celsius under full load, wich is normal on this gen. Using it whit a 360mm AIO. My CPU boost up to 5,85GHz wich is very impressing for a stock cpu.

price was too high when I bought it. going from 5950x 7950x not seeing mind blowing difference, mainly future proofing, nothing more. 7xxx series is not plug and play like past cpu's. long boots, latest bios required, expo is a must, etc. don't dislike the cpu, just not a fan of this generation (costly upgrade), assuming things will get better as time goes on. not seeing >5.4 in any benchmarks and I'm nowhere near throttling. on the plus side, not seeing super high temps as reported online (35-46 on avg)
Vaut la peine d'être acheté, très content de la performance de ce processeur.

What I like to do is run CPU intensive things in the background while also playing games. Often times I can go in Ryzen Master and drop the clock and voltage down and things still run at a satisfying degree. I've used this playing at 1080p-2160p. Top to bottom no issues. Like 2 months later the 7950x3D was on sale for what I bought this for but it is what it is. AM4 lasted a long time. Someday I'll be buying some x3D 16 core from the last AM5 gen CPUs.

It's great when you have software that lets you choose to encode/simulate on the CPU and set how many cores to use. Give 8c/16th and play games without issue. I've kept up with bios updates so I haven't had issues with the overvolting EXPO stuff that was in the news. I use a Thermaltake Peerless Assassin to cool it and that's been adequate even when playing at stock voltages where it hits those 95 celcius temps. You can undervolt this thing, drop the clocks a bit and the performance difference is negligible.

If you're a software developer, you'll enjoy the amount of cores for running VMs, docker containers, compiling software, etc. I like photography so enjoy playing with RAW photos in Darktable and mild things in Krita. Going from a 4770k to this was a pretty massive change.

I feel like people buying CPUs seperate probably know what to expect. I was able to run a 4770k for 8 years. I don't want to run this for 8 years but I wouldn't be surprised if the performance in games at 2160p is so minor that I just keep going on with this and occasionally upgrading the graphics card

(geschrieben am 08.09.2023)

As a software developer, I spend a great deal of time compiling thousands of lines of C++ code so need a CPU that has exceptional multi-core performance. I bought the Ryzen 9 7950X for a new AM5 build to replace an ageing 10th generation i7 and I was delighted with the performance.

My previous system took almost 5 minutes to do a full build of my project but this CPU has cut the build time to under 30 seconds. I highly recommend this CPU if you have a requirement for heavy multi-core processing.

reviews.review: I got mine at a super flash sale at $599 CAD plus extra game as bonus from AMD. There is nothing I can complain as it's the current top 3 best gaming CPU as now Aug, 2023.

CPU IS EXACTLY AS ADVERTISED!!!
Only negative is the JEDI game code is no where to be found yet I bought this exact CPU locally and they gave the game code as well as being a little cheaper!

REASONS FOR LOSING A STAR!

2. -1 Slow to ship item.
3. -1 Item arrives damaged or defective.
4. -1 Poor quality or workmanship.
5. -1 Lousy communication.

If I leave a 1 star review BUYER BEWARE as a 1 star review is actually a ZERO star review!

The performance on this CPU is stellar, especially coming from an i7-3770 (11 years old now). The cpu utilization rarely goes over 10% during regular use. The problem I, and many other users are having is that the chip runs hot. I’m using a Noctua NH-D15 (a beefy boy) to cool this chip, yet it still sits around 50°C when idle, while my gpu is around 30°C.
Hard to make it work with x3d, be ready for many hours of youtube video. Permormance is not there pick intel or 7800x3d depends of your usage.

This thing handles everything like a dream! Don't be worried about idle temps if they're a bit higher than you're used to, that's normal. I'm around 43c on boot and 50c with standard game clients, discord, and browser running. Actual gaming temps over a sustained period don't seem to break 65c often and i'm happy with that, especially considering the insane efficiency of this thing. (I'm running a Deepcool LS 720 SE, it's a 360mm AIO)

Haven't felt a hiccup at all while using this CPU and I've been running games with lots of other stuff in the background. It's definitely not limiting my 7900 XTX whatsoever. If you're getting this one you're probably some level of a gamer and you won't be disappointed. Make sure you get the core parking to work correctly by following the steps from AMD, but it's super simple. I haven't had to use it because i've been happy with the stock performance, but the option to play with parked and non-parked cores to see if it makes a difference in specific games is there. You'll love this chip!

I installed this in my Asus ProArt x670e motherboard. I use an Arctic Liquid Freezer II 280 RGB AIO water cooler. I like that it switches between two chiplets one with higher frequency, the other with a higher cache. So you can have your cake and eat it too depending on if you are doing normal productivity type tasks or gaming. The switching between chiplets is done by Xbox game bar and is generally automatic. Nutshell is if Microsoft thinks you are running a game it switches to the X3D cache otherwise it uses the frequency optimized chiplet. You can check by bringing up the game bar with windows-g then looking at settings. The tdp is quite low at 120 watts, so it’s a very easy load for my water cooler, so my cooler is pretty quiet and it’s easy to keep the cpu well below its TJ Max. I also used the bottleneck calculator at the pc builds website, and per their estimation this CPU is well matched up to a Nvidia rtx 4070ti gpu. this was completely fine for my usage.

This is my first build; it's fast, and it has not overheated and caused a fire. I'm sure that only happens when you overclock it, which I have no need to. It works very well and I've had my computer running for two weeks now.

I got this thing for $440 on sale, just $40 more than 7800x3d. For that price, 100% worth it for multi-threaded work. A bit quirky with how to set it up (like battery performance being balanced?) and AMD auto-update being the most annoying thing ever- but besides that this things insane. Can run games like CS and OW 300fps without breaking 2% usage, all below 60 degrees Celsius. 100% recommend if you can get it around this price point.

I have to say I love this processor. I made the jump to a totally new platform. It is NOT without it's growing pains (which I can say now have settled at least for me).

A lot of YouTubers say get the 7800x3d... if you do need core speed for programs or have games that use core speed this makes alot more sense. I think (my opinion) that once the bios and drivers are more optimized to use the necessary cores that have cache, vs higher clocked cores for performance this will be a amazing buy.

Right now, it's a beast!

I run it on a ASUS ROG STRIX X670E-E... the bios here was an issue... with all 7000 cpus it seems over volting cpu/mem controller could cause damage to the cpu or motherboard. I was lucky... my pc shut off randomly several times and I had to manually reset the psu. It seems my psu was saving my hardware. I was chasing down a possible PSU, RAM and motherboard or cpu issue. I spent weeks troubleshooting to no avail, all the answers I got from everyone was to RMA... I wanted to narrow it down so I didn't have to wait weeks for the turn around of each part.

Finally I saw a new BIOs from ASUS.
1410 is the newest I am using but both this version and 1303 claim to limit SOC voltage to 1.3 which should mitigate the shutdowns and possible damage.
I really do love this chip and the X3D really is amazing in gaming. Really removes the lower .01 and 1% frame rates.
I'm totally happy with the performance and am playing with per core curve optimizer. Now that I have more stability I can play with the chip more.

Temps- from my observation the IO die temps at idle are in the 40C range... so that reads as the package temp... when actually the cores are in the 30s and 20s depending at idle. I also run a custom loop with dual 360 rads with the cpu and gpu in the loop. So I'm happy with the temps.

All in all a great cpu, if just gaming or want to save some cash can do a 7800x3d, if you can use the higher core speeds of a 7900x3d this cpu is for you.

Io ormai sono affezionato alla serie 9 dei rayzen, sono passato dal 5900x a questo 7900x3d.
Ho sempre scelto il 9 per la sua duttilità sia per il Gaming che per l ambito lavorativo e video editing.
Anche questa volta amd ha fatto un ottimo lavoro.

reviews.review:
Estaba un poco preocupado porque no había actualización del producto desde Amazon, tenía que ir directo con el servicio contratado y ahí estaba. Pero dentro del pedido hay una nota que te informa al respecto.
También había un dulce de regalo.
El empaque venía muy bien protegido, llegó el mismo día estimado. El producto en excelente condiciones. Estoy contento con la compra.

Amazon shipped this FAST and it arrived in two days. I don't know how this review will age, but in Oct 2023, this seems like the best Intel processor for $200 or so. It has a graphics processor built in (I have a GPU card, but it's nice to have some redundancy). Amazon's price was just a couple bucks over that of MicroCenter but saved me a trip there. Other than that, what can I say? Do the research regarding what chip will suit your purpose and budget.

I have purchased about 30 of these this year. They are my "go to" for a typical office build. Usually with the stock i5 CPU cooler/fan combo it is constantly running at full blast and super loud. With the i5-13400 the stock fan is just right. The processor is more than capable to handle your typical office tasks.

If you bump up to the i5-13500 or greater, I recommend a 3rd party cpu cooler that is quieter.

Works great with a dual fan 4070 in small SFF builds where you have limited cooler clearance height. Noctua L9i 47mm air cooler works great and keeps temps around 33C idle- 68C under synthetic load. 64-66C during extended gaming. No undervolting enabled, which could improve temps more if desired.

This CPU is a superb, i build my system without any GPU and it performed very well on some new games.
It's very fast for work, multimedia etc...

Now i add a 6750 XT to my system and my PC is so very fast now (Ultra settings in all games without problems). CPU never overheat (and i leave in a hot country). Thanks Intel !

plug and plug. superb performance gaming

Bios flash to update the motherboard for it to be able to use this 13th gen CPU, but the flash didn't work so the CPU could never be read by my ASRock Steel Legend motherboard. I have to buy a 12th gen CPU instead because of this problem assuming its the CPU that wasn't compatible with it.

Loving the price to performance with the 13600k, considering I made the upgrade from a 6700k. The technology is leaps and bounds for roughly same value.

Merci.

There's really not much that needs to be said. If you're upgrading to 13th gen Intel, and don't require the additional non-gaming related benefits of 13700k or 13900k, you can't go wrong with the i5-13600k. Even with XMP enabled to 6000Mhz & a Noctua NH-U12A tower cooler on top, this beast never gets truly hot in any game. Granted, I have a very good case for airflow, but regardless it's extremely rare I ever see this CPU hitting the 70's when gaming (this includes 1440p gaming at basically maxed settings), with plenty of utilization headroom on top of that. I paired this beastly CPU with the Sapphire Nitro Plus Radeon 6950XT & have been having an amazing experience all around. If you're deeply considering 13th gen, & your main focus is gaming, then the 13600k will perform up there with the best without all the additional heat the higher end SKU's give off. Genuinely give this CPU a 10/10, never in my life did I ever anticipate an i5 to be this great, but just goes to show it's more about the generation and less about the number after the i. If you're considering the CPU but unsure as to its performance, I promise you wont be disappointed with it one bit. Including with its temperatures. No under-volting needed.

The unlocked multiplier of this processor allows for easy overclocking, making it an excellent choice for enthusiasts and gamers who want to push their system's performance even further.

I appreciate the low power consumption of the i5-13600K despite its impressive performance, contributing to energy efficiency and reduced operating costs.

The Intel Core i5-13600K is compatible with the latest motherboard chipsets, ensuring seamless integration and future upgradability.

Intel is a trusted brand known for producing high-quality processors, and the i5-13600K continues that legacy, providing a reliable and stable computing experience.

In conclusion, the Intel Core i5-13600K (Latest Gen) Desktop Processor with its 14 cores is a performance beast, capable of handling the most demanding computing tasks with ease. Its balanced combination of P-cores and E-cores, unlocked multiplier, integrated graphics, and energy efficiency make it an ideal choice for power users and gamers alike. If you're looking to unleash the full potential of your desktop, the Intel Core i5-13600K is the ultimate processor that won't disappoint. I highly recommend this processor for its outstanding performance and the incredible multitasking capabilities it brings to my computing experience!

This was Intel's top line CPU in the 11th generation; it used the LGA-1200 socket which was only minimally different from the LGA-1151 socket (1200 pins vs. 1151 pins). The motherboards for the LGA-1200 required only small changes in production spec, and the coolers made for the 1151 chips work perfectly on the LGA-1200. By contrast, the 12th generation, using the LGA-1700 socket, required an extensive redesign of motherboards, and the coolers that got adapted over from the LGA 1151/1200 didn't really work properly on the 12th and 13 generation Intel CPUs. This i9-11900K will pull about 170 watts through the socket at factory overclock 100%, and that's right on the limit of safe operation for the vast majority of air or liquid coolers on the market today.
Super
This i9 was my first i9 series ever used since Extreme processor. Works great and sync well with RTX 3080Ti without bottleneck it.

reviews.review: I upgraded from a12700k with asus tuf z690 board and a arctic air 360 AIO. The 12700 K ran at about 50°C gaming.The 14700k runs in the mid 60s. However, this is obviously a refresh and NOT a new generation. Performance gains are limited and to get there they raised TDP and thus it runs HOT. I have a 240mm AIO and its.. fine.
