reviews.review: Zero problems here on an MSI Pro B550 with an AMD Ryzen 7 5700G Chip, running XMP Profile. No errors, no glitches, smooth performance. Each module has some good weight and they feel well constructed.

Not sure what some reviewers were talking about with Windows OS corruption issues (user error??), but these are simply plug and play.

I went into BIOS, disabled XMP, turned off the computer, removed my previous Corsair LPX, installed the 4 DIMMS of Vengeance RGB RT (64 GB), turned the PC on, went into BIOS again, re-enabled XMP, rebooted into Windows, checked that RAM speeds were at 3600 C16 as expected and voilà.

Runs at expected, no BSODs, no issues with RGB.

I have a 13700K slightly overclocked on an MSI Z690 Edge DDR4. I didn't try to OC the RAM over 3600 nor do I intend to.

Pretty good value IMHO
Super

Runs 3200 out of the box in my motherboard. It took a while for it to start working. Not sure why. Probably my motherboards problem. I put old ram in and that didn't work. Looking around google won't serve you. It will increase you panic. Most people are idiots when it comes to troubleshooting and will assume unlikely things. RAM is just a pain in butt, like anything else.
Just upgraded from 2x8G 3600Hz cosair LPX single rank RAM. Games like wolong are much smoother. How thirsty are modern games for RAM!

I've updated my post and will be returning this memory. After lots of testing and trying different configurations. I can confirm this memory is no good for Ryzen. It's on my QVL, but this memory runs way to hot to run on Ryzen. The lowest idle I get with this memory is 44C and a 140mm fan is on them. That's just nuts. I turned off the RGB lights as well and no difference. Nothing works CAS settings wise except for CAS 22 which is the default, not XMP rating. CAS 22 memory running at 44C idle with fan on it. This is ridiculous. I've tested two kits of this memory now with same issue. This is the lowest bin Micron memory and should not be sold for Ryzen. With the GPU going this memory hits 55C and then memory tests indicate errors. memory package says max temp is 40C which is a joke and simply not doable. What a scam this Corsair memory is. DO NOT BUY!!!!

Amazing upgrade over my old 3000CL vengeance, this type of ram is very optimized for CL 16 I could not overclock it by any amount even by 66 my system would shutdown, running a threadripper 2990 with a Asus ROG zenith extream, happy with the 3600, the xmp would give a .3 clock, so 3603mhz, RGB is also bright an awesome
I love the corsair icue argb, works great for and ryzen 7 2700x

Die RT-variante scheint in tests besser zu sein als die andren Corsair Vengeance 2x16GB Dimms. Leider macht Corsair nicht kenntlich ob es sich um dual oder single ranks handelt und so weiß man es nur mit software. Meine waren single ranks, was auf 1440p und höher den braten auch nicht mehr fett macht. Ich hab sie in mein neues B550 Tomahawk gepaart mit nem 5800x3D verbaut. Offiziell hab ich keine unterstützung für die Dimm-version gesehen aber die listen sind im besten fall veraltet. Sie wurden direkt anerkannt und laufen mindestens auf XMP1 mit 1800Mhz also 3600MT/s oder für alle die noch weniger ahnung haben als ich: "3600 Mhz" :) ..Was mir völlig reicht zum zocken und es scheint der sweet spot für einige AMD CPUs zu sein, vor allem sind die x3D chips sowieso weniger auf schnelle RAMs angewiesen dank riesigem L3 cache.
Die RGB-beleuchtung ist hell und bieten dank iCUE software viele möglichkeiten auf individualisierung. Tipp: MSI software, die die beleuchtung regelt deinstallieren, sonst bleiben die auf einer farbe hängen unter iCUE.
Alles in allem passable RAMs, wer auf dual ranks hofft kann gleich lotto spielen gehen oder wesentlich mehr bezahlen..oder eben 4x single ranks verbauen um dual rank zu erzwingen. Wie gesagt ab 1440p sowieso nicht wahrnehmbar.

Purchased because of brand reputation and the product lives upto the reputation. Looks good and stellar performance. Very happy. I do feel I need to disclose I am a Corsair fanatic. Ram, PSU, PC case are all Corsair as are my peripherals and other equipment.

Edit: despite performing well pc would crash constantly even though it would complete Cinebench tests. Memtestx86 revealed ram sticks to be faulty. Have returned. Evri the courier has collected returned item from the drop off point and have had returned product sitting in Evri warehouse for days at this point. Further delaying the return to Amazon, therefore further delaying the refund which will not be actioned until the product is in the Amazon distribution centrea. Only at that point can a refund be initiated according to Amazon. Then and only then I can be refunded and replace these ram sticks.

Unfortunately sometimes these things happen. I have also favoured Amazon for PC Parts and have spent several thousands of GBP on pc parts from amazon this year alone. In future I will be using alternative parts suppliers as Amazon return time scales are an absolute joke.

Changed the star rating to reflect the issues caused by the seller and the seller alone. Their return policies, their return time scales, their choice of return couriers.

For those of you that don't know Evri is the rebrand of Hermes who are notorious for delayed, missing and damaged goods.

These are some great sticks of RAM. They're sleek, dissipate heat effectively, and have nice lighting options for aesthetics. However, iCue might be one of the worst software options for hardware. It's nice that you can set options you want and remove the software entirely, but if you want the lighting to turn off when your PC goes to sleep, you'll need the software installed. While I'm hoping that lighting controls for the RAM will be coming soon to Windows with the lighting control that has popped up in beta versions of Windows, but overall not much of a dealbreaker. I say that it'a such a bad thing due to how mnay resources iCue seems to use. While active, my CPU temps rise from anywhere between 2-8 degrees celsius, even while idle. For something that is only supposed to be controlling lights, it is an extremely high amount of usage for what it should be. But apart from that, I've seen no problems and it's been a really great set of RAM for the price.

Très bonne performance et très beau éclairage, faisant du montage j'ai du passé sur du 4x16Go, il est conseillé de vérifier la compatibilité avec votre carte mère et qu'elle soit à jour.

- pour la b550 pas de souci le profil ou docp ma permis de les avoir à l'heure pleine puissance.

Ont peut prendre des Ram performante et dépassant les MHz de la carte mère mais il et conseillé de vérifier les compatibilités avec la carte mère utiliser.
Une fois installé aller dans le bios et activé Profil xmp ou docp si vous voyez bien 3600mhz mais que elle ce bride à 3200mhz c'est que votre carte ne prend pas le 3600mhz mais peut peut-être prendre du 3644mhz max et réglé pour le coup juste la fréquence et éviter de forcer le 3600 au risque d'avoir un système bancale.

Je recommande 😉

reviews.review:
So when I got the ram I ended up spending like 1 to about two hours trying to install it. I got a asrock b450 pro4 board. I got a ryzen 5600x cpu I recently had 16gb of this ram, then I decided to get the 32gb version of it. My motherboard max ram is 64Gb adding it up I was basically installing 48Gb all together. But for some reason when I add the two 16gb sticks with the two 8gb sticks, my computer for some reason would not boot up. Now this was me switching the rams around trying to figure out what was the problem. Because before I had some different brand name rams I mixed it with the Vulcan’s and it worked at 24gb but iv learned mixing different ram brands can cause issues and lower performance. But my pc still booted up, and ran pretty decent. But for some reason adding the same Vulcan Z”s 32gb with the 8gb ram did not boot up. At this point I was confused. Because it is so post to boot up, I ended up checking my motherboard website
I was missing bios update 8.01 v2 1.2.0.8 apparently this update is for amd/ intel motherboards as well. It is so post to help with memory of your motherboard. So if you don’t have it please download it! A lot people that have gaming computers pre built just to game don’t know about bios updates. After removing one of the 16gb sticks and leaving the two 8gb sticks my pc finally booted up. I am still confused to the point where I don’t understand why it dose not boot up with both 16gb sticks and only one. I’m still getting my 32gb performance on my pc so I am happy with it. Now I just have one brand new 16gb ram stick collecting dust until i can figure out how to install it and get my 48Gb performance. Honestly I don’t know if it’s the company because i have seen a few reviews that these type of sticks are corrupted. So if you decide on buying Vulcan brand ram sticks good luck it might work and it might not work so your playing a dirty ball game :) hopefully if you missed this review before u bought the ram, and u have the same problem and u manage to find this an u try my methods explain above. An it helps YOUR WELCOME :)

Bought 4 sticks for my 5800x and ROG STRIX B450-F GAMING II motherboard. 2 sticks work fine at 3596 MT/s, but only in the A2 and B2 slots. To get 4 sticks to work, I had to reduce the speed to 3533 MT/s.

I did not have to RMA this RAM, but at one point I thought I would need to, and I'm pleased to report that I was able to get an RMA number online within minutes with just the serial number from the RAM. Compare this to other manufacturers who require you to produce a receipt and supply the vendor name, purchase date, etc. I very much appreciate the no-hassle RMA process and lifetime warranty of this RAM.

This RAM works great on a Gigabyte AB350-Gaming-CF board with a Ryzen 3 2200G processor, with an XMPP profile enabled in the firmware. Recommended purchase.

First time building a machine in a long time so this is my first rgb ram. Cost was great at the time for the speeds. The rgb is very bright and syncs with some of the top rgb controls. I'm using aura sync and it worked flawlessly.
Both sticks are good out or the box, zero issues. I may even pick up another 8x2 set for 32gb of ram total. Without massive Photoshop or video editing 16 is probably enough already, and anything over 32 is definitely overkill.

I think this is the most RAM I have ever had in a computer I have owned. Long gone is the time when I exceeded the 4K of RAM in my Vic20.
I was looking for a little boost for my desktop, this was it. Easy enough to install for my who has been doing this for decades. Click add to cart, what do you have to loose?

The specs are exactly as advertised. Installed on MSI Pro Z690-A DDR4 mobo and had no issue with installation. The main reason I chose this over "gaming" specific RAM is that it's an excellent price and I don't want my computer to look like a 14 year olds idea of a space ship. So far so good.
Comme titré. L'overclock préétablit s'engage sans problème dans le bios.
just installed them fixed a ram issue i was having, seem to be more compatiable with my board, works exactly as advertise and also came very quickly

I recommend.
I ordered the MSi B450-A Max Pro motherboard when AM5 came out and paid around 80$ for it. A bit expensive but it is an ATX board. This RAM works with this motherboard right out of the box and is paired with an Ryzen 5900X. Super easy to install and flash with the BIOS button the Bios for the Ryzen 5000 series CPU's. Worked right out of the box. The board is better than the B450 board I have from Asus. Easy to install in my XPG Invader case.
At the beginning when freshly installed Windows 11 I got lots of sound problems. After installing the crap of MSi drivers and Utilities which actual version MSi's MSi Center was offering, my sound got messed up completely. Sound stutters becauso of the new sound drivers, Chipset drivers and the like. Headphones and 5.1 Speakers intermittently connected/disconnected causing delays and stutters. Looked like an software issue of MSi software. That foreced me to reinstall and erase from scrap Windows 10 and it offered then to upgrade to Windows 11. After that the problem was gone with only Windows drivers. Do not download the crap MSi Center offers. It can break your OS.
Other than that this board suggests it has 2 full fledged PCIE x 16 slots of the 3.0 type. At least that is what customers will think easily. Think twice. It has only one x16 PCIE 3.0 slot and the long one below has x16 openings but only half of those have connector pins installed and the manual says it is not even an x8 slot but rather an x4 only. And to add insult to injury that slot is only 2.0. Completely misleading for an new buyer.
On the lower slot I have the GT 1030 GDDR5 from MSi installed I had still from Q1 2020. It works on low settings on some games like HnG from 2016 and gets between 52 fps and 60 fps.
Other than that this MSi board works way better than the Asus B450 board I have on my other system from last year. The RAM slots are way easier to use and the sticks slide into them like lubricated. The dual channel works on this board which is on my Asus most likely defective (Asus refuses warranty). I use it with 32 GB (2 x 16) TeamGroup TCreate RAM sticks. High quality 3200 Mhz sticks for relatively cheap.
It is a good strong board with 2 massive coolers on the Mosfets. These massive coolers impressed me as an new inexperienced buyer for my very first build. So it slipped to me the issue with the PCIE "x16" slots.
This Motherboard worked straight out of the box. I use the Ryzen 5900X with this with an Gamemax Gamma 500 AM4 cooler. The coolers does not fit well the AM4 system since it's clip is way to stiff so I had to take the cooler off the CPU and bend a bit the clips till it fits just with a little pressure. Install the air coolers without too much pressure so it is not loose but can slide a bit is fine before snapping it gently in place. As original fit I got 66 Celsius to 70 Celsius on idle or doing basic work with that processor, but after bending the clips to aliviate the pressure I get now at the moment 51 Degrees Celsius. So if too much pressure is applied by the cooler onto the processor that rises the heat to a difference of about 20 Degrees Celsius. Any of these standard air coolers with heat pipes will be able to cool the Ryzen 5900X easily. While gaming it gets to about 61 degrees Celsius. My case has 3 fans in the front and 1 in the back.
MSi's UEFI is a bit confusing if one is used to the Asus UEFI. But it has basically the same features but it is way more confusing. The fans can be adjusted better on MSi's BIOS. But with this 5900X duo deca core CPU, the PSU is annoyingly loud all the time. While on Ecomode with 65 Watts the whole system draws on gaming about 150 Watts. The board seems to have no problems to deliver power to the 5900X.
Running Cinebench with this board and 5900X CPU with settings to Ecomode 65Watt, the case fans kick in, the CPU has an temp of 61 Degrees Celsius after 5 Minutes Cinebench, the Mosfets have an temperature of 58 Degrees Celsius and the PCH has an temperature of 50 Celsius while the Cooler Master Silencio 120mm fan I put on the Gamma from GameMax CPU cooler, turns 1000 rpm and all 4 Arctic F12 120mm case fans show an rpm of 700.
I am surprised how this GameMax Gamma air cooler is able to maintain cool this CPU. So the huge aluminum coolers on the Mosfets of the MSi board sure do their job.
The board has lots of fan headers. Thats very good.
I recommend this board for the AM4 system but be aware of the cheating PCIE slot advertisement, the sound problems and the rather difficult to use UEFI settings. But this is an robust board.

I purchased this for a non-rgb SFF build on a 12 series Intel system.

The product arrived very quickly and packaged nice for safe transport.

I needed lower profile memory for a SFF build and decided to try this memory out. I have seen it recommended by PC builders for the last few years and decided it must be sufficient.

I have been using this memory now for a couple months and am completely satisfied with the performance, reliability, and the great value compared to other big name brands. It is not that bad looking as well.

Performance wise, it is on par with any other memory with the same MHZ and timings. It also overclocks nicely if that's still your thing.

I would definitely recommend this to others

What can I say. If you're looking for speed and 32 over 16 GB, it's grat value for the price as of the time I'm writing this. I tried it in several amd boards ranging from b450's through x570's. Non of the had this ram on their QVL, but XMP/EXPO/DOCP all worked correctly on every board I tried it on. MSI, Asus, and several Gigabyte boards.

I ended up sticking it in my workshop computer. Simple Asus x570 tuf gaming plus wi-fi, running a Ryzen 7 5700g. Since the rig uses the on board IGP of the 5700g, it uses the system ram for video memory. The fastest you can put in helps, and this 4000 speed ram gets the job done at a great price.

I recently bought the TEAMGROUP T-Force Delta RGB DDR4 32GB for my gaming PC and I have to say I'm pretty impressed. The RGB lighting is gorgeous and syncs well with my motherboard. The performance is also top-notch, with fast speeds and low latency. The installation was easy, and the packaging was nice.

The only minor issue I have is that the RAM sticks are quite tall and they barely fit under my CPU cooler. I had to adjust the fan position a bit to make some room. It's not a big deal, but it would have been nice if they were a bit shorter or had a low-profile option.

Overall, I'm very happy with my purchase and I would recommend this RAM to anyone looking for a reliable and stylish upgrade. I give it 4/5 stars.

Por lo general soy muy generoso con las valoraciones, pero esta vez voy a comenzar por lo que no me ha gustado, en cuanto al rendimiento, dejan un poco que desear, no son malas, pero pierden contra memorias de menor frecuencia por su latencia de cl18, unas Hyperx a cl16 o cl15 muestran un desempeño mucho mejor aunque su frecuencia sea a 400 o 600mhz menos, supongo que para experimentar haciendo OC, modificando valores y movidas de esas, esta memoria irá muy bien, pero es un suponer ya que no lo he comprobado, en configuraciones estándar no la recomendaría como una memoria de alto rendimiento. Otro punto que tampoco me ha gustado tiene que ver con el RGB, pierde la sincronización y cada memoria va por su lado, con el software ICUE se puede encontrar alguna configuración donde esto no moleste, pero uno de los cuatro módulos funcionaba al revés que los otros tres y no hubo manera de corregirlo, quizás la halla, pero yo no lo ve visto, cosa que le juega en contra, porque debería ser "instalar y usar", así de fácil. Después el diseño es muy bueno, a mi me ha encantado, en eso se lleva un Diez, y lástima lo del rgb porque creo que es uno de los más brillantes, uniformes y bonitos que he visto, es muy bueno el color de la luz. Quiero marcar como detalle no como defecto, que son muy altas, por lo que si el sócalo está muy cerca de procesador, el disipador chocará irremediablemente con la memoria, por lo tanto verificad ese detalle en el diseño de la placa base antes de comprarlas, con sistema de bomba eso no tiene importancia, pero con disipadores grandes si. En fin un gran producto que se queda corto al rematar su concepto, memoria de alto rendimiento que rinde discretamente, el mejor rgb que he visto en ram, pero que no tiene una buena sincronización y un diseño premium que enamora, pero que puede ser un problema con otro hardware, le daría un 8, si en estos días consigo sacarle más el jugo, le daré 5 estrellas y justificaré el porqué de ello. Saludos.

In looking to upgrade the RAM in my workstation, I came across many options: heat spreaders, RGB, etc..
My workstation, however, requires JEDEC memory modules, which limited my choices somewhat. Not that it matters, as my workstation's case does not have a clear side panel to see what's going on inside.

I came across this Timetec Hynix 16 GB kit, and although I have never heard of Timetec, I have had Hynix based RAM in a couple of my previous workstations, and so decided to try this out.

The kit arrived in well packaged condition, seals intact and all.

Installation was fairly straight forward; remove old memory modules, align the notch of the new ones with the indentation on the memory module slots, and push into place.

Upon initial power up of my workstation, I was greeted by a blank screen for a good 15 - 20 seconds. Although terrifying at first, I did not get any BIOS POST beep codes indicating RAM issues, so I decided to wait it out instead of hard powering off and on again. Shortly after, I was greeted (and relieved to see) Windows 10 starting up; I guess my workstation needed some time to initialize itself with the newly installed RAM.

In Windows 10 Task Manager, the newly installed RAM appears to be running at the correct speed of 2666 MHz. So far so good, and the performance gain of having 16 GB of RAM is very much noticeable.

It may not have any fancy head spreader, or fancy RGB, but if you are in need of JEDEC RAM, I would highly recommend Timetec Hynix.

The delivery was prompt even during this Covid19 epidemic, even arriving a day earlier than I expected it to. Once it arrived, opening, unpacking the box, opening the package the RAM came in all took longer than the actual installation into my Acer Aspire desktop. All in all, it probably took less than 10 minutes from the time the delivery was dropped off to starting up the computer with the additional 16GB of memory.

To begin with I only had 1 stick of 16GB, so adding this doubled it to my computer's maximum of 32GB. Once installed, the boot-up time for my Debian-based Linux distro was noticeable quicker, as well as the time it took to automatically login. Furthermore there was a great increase in both the time it took to launch several apps along with running those several at the same time. For instance, prior to adding this RAM I was able to run several apps all at once, but each app made the computer lag a little bit more each time. Now I can run VLC, Firefox with YouTube playing, GIMP, Inkscape, my Terminal and Libreoffice without noticing any lag whatsoever.

I won't lie, there's probably some better, faster RAM available, but since I don't play any games, this RAM is a great, budget-friendly addition which makes using my computer quicker and more reliable for everyday use, plus coding, watching videos, playing music, and graphic design here and there, and so on and so forth.

If you need some additional RAM for the uses I've described, this 16GB will suite your needs perfectly. I imagine the same is true if you need Timetec's other sizes like 4GB, 8Gb, and 32Gb, in both the desktop and laptop varieties. I don't think the make single sticks of more than 32GB, but they do make kits ranging from 1x4GB, 2x4GB, 4x4GB, 1x8GB, 4x8GB, all the way up to 8x16GB and 4x32GB, both of which would give you a whopping 128GB RAM.

What's more all these various kits are quite reasonably priced. Like I said above, these may not be the top of the line when it comes to RAM like HyperX, Corsair, Patriot, or G.Skill, but at the end of the day all you need is budget-friendly, easy to install, and reliable memory, this Timetec Hynix IC 16GB DDR4 2666MHz RAM is a perfect fit. I also imagine the plethora of other kits made by Timetec will suit your needs for a good price and reliability as well!

I have no problem with the hardware of the rams, but the people who shell out extra for the rgb want it to work. It took a lot of fiddling around and honestly I’m not sure exactly how I did it but I’ve finally managed to get the iCUE software that’s used to configure the RGB to register both RAMs and have the lighting work on both. When the software works it’s great, giving you the option to have different lighting for start up/idle (“hardware lighting”) and active (“lighting effects”), which you can see demonstrated in my video. You can individually configure each led light in terms of their colour and effect (which is how I created the ‘twinkling’ effect on mine), so you can really get creative. There’s also an option to link the lighting with other Corsair hardware you have, but I don’t have any so I can’t speak on how well that works. The problem is I had no lighting for a week and when I play around with it, it can just suddenly stop registering the ram for no reason. When it works, it’s lovely, but just be aware that it’s fickle.

This works with the Dell model 3470/3471 Small Form Factor desktop. I have total 24 GB RAM but managed to use only about 49% of the total installed RAM with this system. So total 24 GB installed RAM is probably a little overdoing for normal entertainment applications and some light gaming. This system is for sure future proof. Since RAM pricing was about 30$ for an 8 GB stick and an 2R 16 GB stick was 53$, then my reasoning was why not go directly with the 16 GB RAM (2400 Mhz) stick? Since the machine has anyways only 2 RAM slots and former pricing was over 100$ for an 16 GB RAM stick. The amount of RAM should be now future proof for about at least 10 to 20 years since my 8 year old Dell laptop had back then 8 GB of RAM as well as did this new machine come with 8 years later. I am sure in 10 years machines will not need 24 GB of RAM and the quad core processor is up to date as well as did my quad core processor of the 8 year old laptop. Heck, even an 15 year old Sony W. Vista 1.8 Ghz core 2 duo processor is as snappy with Windows 10, only 2 GB of RAM and an new SSD as any new computer today - no measurable difference. As far as I understand this Memory is made by SK Hynix in Taiwan. For this Dell model best is to go with an RAM stick which has no heat sink since it's an SFF desktop.
I recommend this brand and particular RAM stick for this particular Dell model.

My Dell Inspiron 5675 had a 16 GB stick of Micron Ram in it when I purchased. I just finally got around to upgrading the RAM in preparation for Oculus Rift S coming out shortly. This was as much to add more system RAM as it was to have 2 sticks of RAM in place so the processor would work in dual channel mode with the memory. AMD Ryzen processors do really well in dual channel mode, there can be a good boast in performance. This begs the question, why do stock gaming machine makers like DELL and HP ship 8gb and 16gb systems with only one stick of RAM instead of 2 sticks of smaller size (2x8gb = 16gb) and 2x4gb = 8gb)? I guess it makes it less expensive to upgrade RAM like I did (and less expensive for the computer maker), but for people who never touch the hardware inside their computers, they are missing out on some performance boost.

Anyways, I matched up the Micron stick specs to this Hynix stick and it works perfectly together. CPU-Z program reports that it is running at 1197.1 MHz in dual channel, so that is 2400 MHz of lovely harmony.

I also upgraded another stock gaming system with an 8gb Hynix stick earlier this week (HP Pavilion 690-024), and had great results, so I was confident that this memory maker Timetec makes very compatible memory. This is good, because Ryzen processors can be more finicky about RAM than Intel processors. Their lifetime warranty is also important, but knock on wood, I won't have to test that one out.

reviews.review:
The Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL 32GB (2x16GB) DDR4 3600MHz memory kit is a compelling choice for users seeking both eye-catching aesthetics and high-performance memory for their gaming or content creation setups. In this review, I will share my experience with this memory kit, focusing on its design, performance, ease of installation, and overall value.

Design and Aesthetics:
The standout feature of the Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL memory kit is its stunning design. The sleek and low-profile aluminum heatspreaders not only enhance the overall aesthetics of the memory modules but also contribute to effective heat dissipation. The customizable RGB lighting offers an impressive range of vibrant colors and lighting effects, allowing users to personalize their setups and synchronize the lighting with other compatible Corsair products. Whether you prefer subtle illumination or want to create a mesmerizing light show, the Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL delivers on both style and visual impact.

Performance:
With a frequency of DDR4 3600MHz and low latency, the Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL memory kit provides excellent performance for demanding tasks. Whether you're gaming, editing videos, or running memory-intensive applications, this kit delivers responsive and smooth performance. The ample capacity of 32GB ensures seamless multitasking and the ability to handle resource-hungry tasks without experiencing any slowdowns. The high-quality memory chips and robust PCB design contribute to stability and reliable performance, even under heavy workloads.

Easy Installation:
Installing the Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL memory kit is a straightforward process. The memory modules fit seamlessly into most standard DIMM slots, and the XMP 2.0 support simplifies the setup process by automatically configuring the optimal memory settings. The Corsair iCUE software provides an intuitive interface for customizing the RGB lighting effects, allowing users to easily sync the lighting with other Corsair components and create a cohesive visual theme.

Compatibility:
The Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL memory kit is compatible with a wide range of motherboards and platforms, including both Intel and AMD systems. This ensures that most users can benefit from the exceptional performance and stunning aesthetics that this kit offers. It's always recommended to verify compatibility with your specific motherboard before making a purchase.

Value for Money:
While the Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL memory kit is priced at a premium, it offers excellent value for users who prioritize both performance and aesthetics. The combination of high-frequency memory, low latency, ample capacity, and customizable RGB lighting justifies the investment for enthusiasts and gamers looking to enhance their PC experience.

Final Thoughts:
The Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL 32GB (2x16GB) DDR4 3600MHz memory kit strikes an impressive balance between style and performance. With its stunning design, exceptional performance, easy installation, and compatibility with a wide range of systems, this memory kit is a worthy choice for users looking to elevate their PC setup. Whether you're seeking top-tier gaming performance or a visually stunning workstation, the Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL delivers on both fronts.

Disclaimer: I purchased the Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL 32GB DDR4 3600MHz memory kit independently and did not receive it as part of any specific program or incentive. My review is solely based on my personal experience and observations with this memory kit.

reviews.review: Works fine, no problems. The nice thing was the manufacture's website that assesses your computer for upgrades, and what type. was helpful, saved a lot of questions.

I bought this 8GB memory (https://www.amazon.ca/dp/B008KSHQBU/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_0) to try to expand Dell T3500 computer that has 6 slots memory lane and originally has a total of 12GB (= 6 slots x 2 GB/slot) memory.

So after the order is arrived today, I replace 2GB memory on DIMM1 slot with this 8GB and the windows 8.1 operating system reported 18GB total memory! while the DELL T3500 specs said it can only hold 4GB memory per slot. Crucial scanner also did not offer any 8GB memory/slot configuration

So, I am thinking to buy another 8GB to see if it still able to run the system smoothly. But I will wait for few days/weeks to see if there is no problems with this single 8GB memory expansion.

I am using Dell T3500 to run VMWARE and my MacOS Sierra running faster due to this 8GB memory

I got this idea to put the new memory to add into the existing max memory limit after I successfully expand 8GB (2 slot * 4GB memory/slot) E1-572-6870 Acer Aspire laptop into 16GB memory (2 slots * 8GB memory from Crucial)

I am puzzled why there is no serious discussion on the Internet forum on why this expansion beyond memory limit configuration is possible on DELL T3500 and on Acer Aspire E1-572-6870; anyway, I am happy today with the outcome so far.

I purchased this item to replace a cheaper model from another firm that did not work. I spent a few frustrating hours trying to find out what was wrong before contacting Amazon re a return. The return process was easy and when this one arrived I simply plugged it in and the desktop showed the ram at 16GB. The upgrade was as easy as it is supposed to be. This was worth the extra 20.00 over my original purchase and still less than many other name brands. I would purchase again.

I've been searching for an affordable way to upgrade memory from 16 to 32gb for video work. These used Crucial boards (great reputation) worked great in my old Optiplex 9010 SFF and passed the memory test analyzer in Windows 10 with zero problems. For the same cost of buying used through kijiji (even with the taxes) I got the return guarantee of Amazon. The delivery was next day for me. Definitely will buy memory again this way!

I changed the HDD for an SDD and increased the memory from 4GB to 12GB. I also installed Linux. It now works "better" than it did new with Windows. :-) The increased memory means a web browser with multiple tabs open doesn't slow the system response to a crawl.

Used the crucial.com scanning tool to tell me which memory module I needed for my machine. Ten second process. Plugged in, detected, and now my machine is running like it should! The fact Crucial will analyse and tell you what to order is perfect. No guesswork. No hiring a geek to figure it out.

No fault so far, I plugged two sticks into my computer, doubled my RAM, exactly as expected. I haven't done any benchmark testing, because I simply don't care that much, I'm a power user, I need every MB of RAM I can get, but I'm not a gamer, I just don't care if this brand is some milliseconds faster or slower than some other brand.
I ordered this module to double the RAM in my Lenovo H50-50 desktop computer. It arrived fast. So far it is working as expected. You can't really go wrong with Crucial products.

I have never witnessed the awesome performance upgrade that adding additional RAM to a PC can provide. Just WOW! The internet is becoming far more advanced with each passing day, and because of this simple, low memory tasks of that past are no more. Mostly everything requires lots of RAM, so if you only have 8GB of RAM you know the pain...So, after pulling my last hair out waiting for Google Chrome to load a webpage I decided to finally see if my PC was able to upgrade the RAM. Sho nuf!! I had 8GB installed and was expandable to 16GB so the decision was a no brainer. First of all, I couldn't believe how cheap RAM was...I was expecting to pay an arm and a leg for some reason...Anyway, if you have working fingers and are able to unscrew screws then you can do this, it's that simple! I managed my way inside my PC and popped out the two child's play 4GB RAM and stuck in the two brand new 8GB sticks giving me 16 total GB. My PC absolutely FLIES now!! I'm so mad I didn't do this earlier. It was so easy, so cheap, and the instant performance is unreal. Once you get the RAM installed in their slot, there is nothing else to do the PC software instantly recognizes the new RAM and takes over from there. I can't recommend doing RAM upgrade, especially for us lowly 8GB RAM plebes. Just do it, do it! Upgrade *if possible* and thank me later!

reviews.review: These worked very well for my grandson
Very clearly used... pins were corroded, heatsinks were covered in dirt and gouges. The pictures don't do the damage justice. The box was clearly resealed too. This is a scam product! Do not buy!

This RAM is a sleep design, operates well, and has tastefully minimal LEDs.

I had minimal trouble installing it (the Trident RAM sticks have offset metal at the top that can make pushing it down into the slot a bit of trouble in cramped systems like mine).

I was unable to get this RAM to operate with any overclock using my Ryzen 5 2400G processor. When I enabled DOCP, the system would repeatedly fail to POST before finally setting the RAM to default speed of 2133 MTS. I tried several times to manually overclock it well below the rated clock speed of 3600 MTS (including 3200, 3000, and 2800) but it failed each time. I finally relented and ran it at the stock 2133 MTS with no issues, including some benchmarks.

When I replaced the 2400G with a Ryzen 7 5700G, the system booted up and overclocked the RAM to 3600 MTS with no issues. The benchmarks showed the expected high performance.

When I first built my PC in 2017 I had 2x 2400MHz versions of these sticks. I wanted to buy more to fill out the last 2 slots but they were discontinued.

I got these to see if they'd be compatible and yes they are. I lose some of the listed speed because they're matching my 2400MHz sticks but I already knew that was going to happen and didn't care because I was originally planning to buy more 2400MHz sticks anyways.

So, if you're planning on getting these to use next to your older/slower speed Trident Z rgb ram sticks, go for it.

I have an old Asus P8Z77-V PRO with an i7-3770K CPU. I normally check the maker's Qualified Vendors List (QVL) for RAM before I buy it, and this RAM model was not on it even though the Patriot make was listed. Many people said it probably would probably work so I bought it anyway given the price (which 10 years ago would have been sky high). I had to seat it a couple of times before it would work. So if your computer doesn't boot, try one stick at a time to check each one. Then try seating it a couple times. Even a bit of dust or extra pressure might make a difference. This motherboard has color coded slots for dual-channel memory which is where it is supposed to go for just 2 sticks (vs 4). For regular computer usage, most software works within 8GB of RAM. But if you try some heavier-duty applications or games you will notice it uses as much RAM as it can get. World of Warcraft for example used upwards of 65% of the 16GM RAM after a while. I also dual-boot into Ubuntu Linux and with 16GB it just doesn't use any swap space at all. Quality brand. Nice heatsinks.

in my haste to get ram.... i got this quad pair ..but they will not work in my old rig...lol it only handles dual rank and not quad.... but i think i will keep them anyways ... get another rig and processor, need at least 8th gen intel icore to fore win 11 to work ..... got a look see at this ram in another rig.... took a bit of time to get my ram back lol... who knows... good friend... might just gift her these ones later !!

Finding quality ddr3 memory in 2023 is not so easy. Patriot is a known and we'll regarded ram brand, I was amazed that I could get 16gb for so little money yet with a full size heat sink! Fantastic.

Now a word about fitting these. I already had a pair of 8gb ram sticks installed from a decade ago when I first built my pc. These were 1600mhz corsairs. So fitting additional pair of 16gb patriots sticks also 1600mhz would be fine? Not so easy... If I removed the old sticks and inserted the new ones it worked. If I then added the old ones the pc kept shutting down. If however I installed the new patriot sticks in the second tier slots and the old corsairs in the primary slots it worked, but the motherboard down graded the clock speed to 1333mhz! A quick check revealed that the cas and latency of the old ram wasn't as fast as the new ones, even though they were all 1600mhz. Then I discovered the difference between jdec and xmp protocols. Basically the bios has xmp off by default. Turning this on allows the motherboard to operate the ram using the proper xmp profiles for each stick, so now they are all running at 1600mhz directly. In fact just switching on xmp gave my pc a 10% frame rate boost! Lesson learnt, turn on xmp if you have compliant ram sticks!

reviews.review:
So when I got the ram I ended up spending like 1 to about two hours trying to install it. I got a asrock b450 pro4 board. I got a ryzen 5600x cpu I recently had 16gb of this ram, then I decided to get the 32gb version of it. My motherboard max ram is 64Gb adding it up I was basically installing 48Gb all together. But for some reason when I add the two 16gb sticks with the two 8gb sticks, my computer for some reason would not boot up. Now this was me switching the rams around trying to figure out what was the problem. Because before I had some different brand name rams I mixed it with the Vulcan’s and it worked at 24gb but iv learned mixing different ram brands can cause issues and lower performance. But my pc still booted up, and ran pretty decent. But for some reason adding the same Vulcan Z”s 32gb with the 8gb ram did not boot up. At this point I was confused. Because it is so post to boot up, I ended up checking my motherboard website
I was missing bios update 8.01 v2 1.2.0.8 apparently this update is for amd/ intel motherboards as well. It is so post to help with memory of your motherboard. So if you don’t have it please download it! A lot people that have gaming computers pre built just to game don’t know about bios updates. After removing one of the 16gb sticks and leaving the two 8gb sticks my pc finally booted up. I am still confused to the point where I don’t understand why it dose not boot up with both 16gb sticks and only one. I’m still getting my 32gb performance on my pc so I am happy with it. Now I just have one brand new 16gb ram stick collecting dust until i can figure out how to install it and get my 48Gb performance. Honestly I don’t know if it’s the company because i have seen a few reviews that these type of sticks are corrupted. So if you decide on buying Vulcan brand ram sticks good luck it might work and it might not work so your playing a dirty ball game :) hopefully if you missed this review before u bought the ram, and u have the same problem and u manage to find this an u try my methods explain above. An it helps YOUR WELCOME :)

Bought 4 sticks for my 5800x and ROG STRIX B450-F GAMING II motherboard. 2 sticks work fine at 3596 MT/s, but only in the A2 and B2 slots. To get 4 sticks to work, I had to reduce the speed to 3533 MT/s.

I did not have to RMA this RAM, but at one point I thought I would need to, and I'm pleased to report that I was able to get an RMA number online within minutes with just the serial number from the RAM. Compare this to other manufacturers who require you to produce a receipt and supply the vendor name, purchase date, etc. I very much appreciate the no-hassle RMA process and lifetime warranty of this RAM.

This RAM works great on a Gigabyte AB350-Gaming-CF board with a Ryzen 3 2200G processor, with an XMPP profile enabled in the firmware. Recommended purchase.

First time building a machine in a long time so this is my first rgb ram. Cost was great at the time for the speeds. The rgb is very bright and syncs with some of the top rgb controls. I'm using aura sync and it worked flawlessly.
Both sticks are good out or the box, zero issues. I may even pick up another 8x2 set for 32gb of ram total. Without massive Photoshop or video editing 16 is probably enough already, and anything over 32 is definitely overkill.

I think this is the most RAM I have ever had in a computer I have owned. Long gone is the time when I exceeded the 4K of RAM in my Vic20.
I was looking for a little boost for my desktop, this was it. Easy enough to install for my who has been doing this for decades. Click add to cart, what do you have to loose?

The specs are exactly as advertised. Installed on MSI Pro Z690-A DDR4 mobo and had no issue with installation. The main reason I chose this over "gaming" specific RAM is that it's an excellent price and I don't want my computer to look like a 14 year olds idea of a space ship. So far so good.
Comme titré. L'overclock préétablit s'engage sans problème dans le bios.
just installed them fixed a ram issue i was having, seem to be more compatiable with my board, works exactly as advertise and also came very quickly

This seems to be very good and affordable RAM. Looks like high quality Made in Taiwan. Worked right out of the box.
I recommend.
I ordered the MSi B450-A Max Pro motherboard when AM5 came out and paid around 80$ for it. A bit expensive but it is an ATX board. This RAM works with this motherboard right out of the box and is paired with an Ryzen 5900X. Super easy to install and flash with the BIOS button the Bios for the Ryzen 5000 series CPU's. Worked right out of the box. The board is better than the B450 board I have from Asus. Easy to install in my XPG Invader case.
At the beginning when freshly installed Windows 11 I got lots of sound problems. After installing the crap of MSi drivers and Utilities which actual version MSi's MSi Center was offering, my sound got messed up completely. Sound stutters becauso of the new sound drivers, Chipset drivers and the like. Headphones and 5.1 Speakers intermittently connected/disconnected causing delays and stutters. Looked like an software issue of MSi software. That foreced me to reinstall and erase from scrap Windows 10 and it offered then to upgrade to Windows 11. After that the problem was gone with only Windows drivers. Do not download the crap MSi Center offers. It can break your OS.
Other than that this board suggests it has 2 full fledged PCIE x 16 slots of the 3.0 type. At least that is what customers will think easily. Think twice. It has only one x16 PCIE 3.0 slot and the long one below has x16 openings but only half of those have connector pins installed and the manual says it is not even an x8 slot but rather an x4 only. And to add insult to injury that slot is only 2.0. Completely misleading for an new buyer.
On the lower slot I have the GT 1030 GDDR5 from MSi installed I had still from Q1 2020. It works on low settings on some games like HnG from 2016 and gets between 52 fps and 60 fps.
Other than that this MSi board works way better than the Asus B450 board I have on my other system from last year. The RAM slots are way easier to use and the sticks slide into them like lubricated. The dual channel works on this board which is on my Asus most likely defective (Asus refuses warranty). I use it with 32 GB (2 x 16) TeamGroup TCreate RAM sticks. High quality 3200 Mhz sticks for relatively cheap.
It is a good strong board with 2 massive coolers on the Mosfets. These massive coolers impressed me as an new inexperienced buyer for my very first build. So it slipped to me the issue with the PCIE "x16" slots.
This Motherboard worked straight out of the box. I use the Ryzen 5900X with this with an Gamemax Gamma 500 AM4 cooler. The coolers does not fit well the AM4 system since it's clip is way to stiff so I had to take the cooler off the CPU and bend a bit the clips till it fits just with a little pressure. Install the air coolers without too much pressure so it is not loose but can slide a bit is fine before snapping it gently in place. As original fit I got 66 Celsius to 70 Celsius on idle or doing basic work with that processor, but after bending the clips to aliviate the pressure I get now at the moment 51 Degrees Celsius. So if too much pressure is applied by the cooler onto the processor that rises the heat to a difference of about 20 Degrees Celsius. Any of these standard air coolers with heat pipes will be able to cool the Ryzen 5900X easily. While gaming it gets to about 61 degrees Celsius. My case has 3 fans in the front and 1 in the back.
MSi's UEFI is a bit confusing if one is used to the Asus UEFI. But it has basically the same features but it is way more confusing. The fans can be adjusted better on MSi's BIOS. But with this 5900X duo deca core CPU, the PSU is annoyingly loud all the time. While on Ecomode with 65 Watts the whole system draws on gaming about 150 Watts. The board seems to have no problems to deliver power to the 5900X.
Running Cinebench with this board and 5900X CPU with settings to Ecomode 65Watt, the case fans kick in, the CPU has an temp of 61 Degrees Celsius after 5 Minutes Cinebench, the Mosfets have an temperature of 58 Degrees Celsius and the PCH has an temperature of 50 Celsius while the Cooler Master Silencio 120mm fan I put on the Gamma from GameMax CPU cooler, turns 1000 rpm and all 4 Arctic F12 120mm case fans show an rpm of 700.
I am surprised how this GameMax Gamma air cooler is able to maintain cool this CPU. So the huge aluminum coolers on the Mosfets of the MSi board sure do their job.
The board has lots of fan headers. Thats very good.
I recommend this board for the AM4 system but be aware of the cheating PCIE slot advertisement, the sound problems and the rather difficult to use UEFI settings. But this is an robust board.

I purchased this for a non-rgb SFF build on a 12 series Intel system.

The product arrived very quickly and packaged nice for safe transport.

I needed lower profile memory for a SFF build and decided to try this memory out. I have seen it recommended by PC builders for the last few years and decided it must be sufficient.

I have been using this memory now for a couple months and am completely satisfied with the performance, reliability, and the great value compared to other big name brands. It is not that bad looking as well.

Non of the had this ram on their QVL, but XMP/EXPO/DOCP all worked correctly on every board I tried it on. MSI, Asus, and several Gigabyte boards.

I ended up sticking it in my workshop computer. Simple Asus x570 tuf gaming plus wi-fi, running a Ryzen 7 5700g. Since the rig uses the on board IGP of the 5700g, it uses the system ram for video memory. The fastest you can put in helps, and this 4000 speed ram gets the job done at a great price.

I recently bought the TEAMGROUP T-Force Delta RGB DDR4 32GB for my gaming PC and I have to say I'm pretty impressed. The RGB lighting is gorgeous and syncs well with my motherboard. The performance is also top-notch, with fast speeds and low latency. The installation was easy, and the packaging was nice.

The only minor issue I have is that the RAM sticks are quite tall and they barely fit under my CPU cooler. I had to adjust the fan position a bit to make some room. It's not a big deal, but it would have been nice if they were a bit shorter or had a low-profile option.

Overall, I'm very happy with my purchase and I would recommend this RAM to anyone looking for a reliable and stylish upgrade. I give it 4/5 stars.

name: SiliconDust HDHomeRun Flex 4K ATSC 3.0 NextGen TV: 2/4 Tuners HDFX-4K(CA)
description:
• FLEX - the next generation HDHomeRun CONNECT 4K
  • Watch live TV on multiple devices simultaneously throughout your home with our Multi room Multi user network tuner solution
  • All the features of the HDHomeRun CONNECT QUATRO & 4K models plus optional DVR by connecting a USB hard drive (requires paid TV guide for DVR record)
  • ATSC 1.0 content is compatible with XBoxOne AppleTV iPhone iPad Win10/11 Mac Android FireTV Roku and LG devices. ATSC 3.0 content is compatible with XBoxOne AppleTV iPhone iPad Win10/11 Mac most-Android most-FireTV and 2019+LG devices
  • 4 tuners (2 ATSC 3.0, all 4 ATSC 1.0)

reviews.review:
First off I would like to say I’ve used other HDhomeruns in the past, a duo and a quattro. The Flex 4k is the next step.
The ATSC 3.0 standard is solid compared to ATSC 1.0
I was getting some fringe channels from Michigan across Lake Huron this past week through tropospheric ducting and while 1.0 channels weren’t available after a bit, the 3.0 channels stayed solid. I watched some NHL playoffs on ABC because I could.
The ATSC 3.0 channels look great and the lower bit rate shows that even using the HEVC codec makes video look sharp.
The only downside was getting the audio codec for my pc, but once I got the codec it was all systems go.
I have yet to try this with a firestick, but I would assume it would be great. As some of you know this is a network tuner. It’ll only play through an app or if you’re tech savvy you can take the channel stream and use many other programs to run the video stream.
Hooking it up is simple. Plug in the antenna in the coax input, plug an Ethernet rj45 cable in the Ethernet port. Plug in the power supply.
Download the software, update the firmware, run a channel scan and you’re good to go.
Luckily I haven’t come across any of the channels that have DRM, but as far as I know SiliconDust is aware and it should be fixed with a firmware update.
I use NextPVR to record any ATSC 1.0 channel, there isn’t anything besides the HDHomeRun app that can record the 3.0 channels, but you have to pay for that service (and I don’t know if it’s available in Canada).
This review is longer than anticipated, but I feel like I have so much to talk about.
Hope this helps other customers trying to cut the cord.

I live in Toronto and I am about 80 to 90 km away from Buffalo.

1) When I run the channel scans, the device DETECTS FIVE ATSC 3.0 channels from the US Stations (NBC, CBS, ABC, FOX, and MyNetworkTV)
2) Some of the channels are locked by DRM encryption and you will get a message saying "Content Protection Required". Although HDHomeRun can detect these channels, you will NOT be able to watch them.
3) As far as I know there are no Canadian stations that currently broadcast in ATSC 3.0 at the moment.

I don't think there is anything wrong with the device itself but the issue lies with the DRM encryption the broadcasters are using and also the fact that NONE of the Canadian broadcasters use ATSC 3.0 at this time.

Summary, if you live close enough to the US border, you might be able to pick up a few 4k channels but not all of them will be accessible. If you do not live anywhere close to the US border, you might not get any 4k channels at all.

Hopefully broadcasters abandon the DRM encryption and more Canadian companies implement ATSC 3.0 in the near future.
In Windsor area can get 33 channels

I bought my Flex 4K to to take advantage of the availability of ATSC 3.0 broadcasts now available in my area. I received my Flex 4K and it was installed in less than 15 minutes to install the hardware. I use the HDHomeRun app on my Apple TV, my LG TV, MacBook and Windows computers. It was very easy to install the software and picked up ATSC 1.0 and 3.0 channels in the area.

I was able to watch the television channels using any device but after a week, the product failed as it could not pick up a signal from my antenna and all of the channels were lost. I attempted to complete multiple channel scans to no avail. After working with their technical support who attempted to diagnose my technical logs off of my device for 3 days, I ended up having to return my Flex 4K to SiliconDust for a replacement. I received my new Flex 4K within 48 hours of letting me know that a replacement would be provided.

My replacement Flex 4K works fine. I find that the Flex 4K generally picks up the ATSC 3.0 channels without issue, but there are times where no sound is available or other times no signal is picked up. I find that I have to switch over to a ATSC 1.0 channel, then return to the ATSC 3.0 channel for the signal to be picked up. The Flex 4K picks up ATSC 1.0 channels without issue. I have not tried the USB port to attach a portable hard drive to the Flex 4K to enable the DVR features yet, but it is something that I plan to do shortly.

I notice that SiliconDust has been working on improving the firmware, so I hope that they continue to make frequent updates to improve the performance of the Flex 4K especially with the performance of the ATSC 3.0 channels. I also hope that they will make some changes to the LG app to take advantage of using the smart remote to be able to change channels with numeric pad rather than having to using the remote to pick the channel.

I think despite some of the issues that I have identified here, I have no regrets in picking up the Flex 4K.

The HD Homerun is one of the best electronic devices I have ever purchased and I have bought a-lot. Easy to install and the setup was a no brainer. I downloaded the app onto my iPad and I was greeted with the option to update which it did. I did not have to find the ip or anything, it just started on my network on it’s own.
I then did a channel scan and it did that. I selected a couple of options to send back diagnostic reports and be part of beta software. The tuners are more sensitive than my tv tuners so a got a few more stations. I set it up on my 3 Nvidia Shields, 2 Apple TV boxes and a PC running win 11. All without difficulty. I have yet to play with the Plex integration but so far it looks promising.
I am very pleased with the HD Homerun!

I had an issue with my first one, so I returned it in favour of a replacement.

When that one seemed to have the same issue, I contacted their PRODUCT support, and I was helped by someone who actually helped with the issue and understood the technology and was able to explain to me what was happening (it wasn't the product's fault) and help me in getting it fixed and figured out.

This item works really well, and I cannot recommend it enough.

This is the second time I've tried to post this review because the people at Amazon aren't smart enough to know the difference between a product review and a seller review, and keep flagging it as a seller review, which it absolutely is not.

reviews.review:
The Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL 32GB (2x16GB) DDR4 3600MHz memory kit is a compelling choice for users seeking both eye-catching aesthetics and high-performance memory for their gaming or content creation setups. In this review, I will share my experience with this memory kit, focusing on its design, performance, ease of installation, and overall value.

Design and Aesthetics:
The standout feature of the Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL memory kit is its stunning design. The sleek and low-profile aluminum heatspreaders not only enhance the overall aesthetics of the memory modules but also contribute to effective heat dissipation. The customizable RGB lighting offers an impressive range of vibrant colors and lighting effects, allowing users to personalize their setups and synchronize the lighting with other compatible Corsair products. Whether you prefer subtle illumination or want to create a mesmerizing light show, the Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL delivers on both style and visual impact.

Performance:
With a frequency of DDR4 3600MHz and low latency, the Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL memory kit provides excellent performance for demanding tasks. Whether you're gaming, editing videos, or running memory-intensive applications, this kit delivers responsive and smooth performance. The ample capacity of 32GB ensures seamless multitasking and the ability to handle resource-hungry tasks without experiencing any slowdowns. The high-quality memory chips and robust PCB design contribute to stability and reliable performance, even under heavy workloads.

Easy Installation:
Installing the Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL memory kit is a straightforward process. The memory modules fit seamlessly into most standard DIMM slots, and the XMP 2.0 support simplifies the setup process by automatically configuring the optimal memory settings. The Corsair iCUE software provides an intuitive interface for customizing the RGB lighting effects, allowing users to easily sync the lighting with other Corsair components and create a cohesive visual theme.

Compatibility:
The Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL memory kit is compatible with a wide range of motherboards and platforms, including both Intel and AMD systems. This ensures that most users can benefit from the exceptional performance and stunning aesthetics that this kit offers. It's always recommended to verify compatibility with your specific motherboard before making a purchase.

Value for Money:
While the Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL memory kit is priced at a premium, it offers excellent value for users who prioritize both performance and aesthetics. The combination of high-frequency memory, low latency, ample capacity, and customizable RGB lighting justifies the investment for enthusiasts and gamers looking to enhance their PC experience.

Final Thoughts:
The Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL 32GB (2x16GB) DDR4 3600MHz memory kit strikes an impressive balance between style and performance. With its stunning design, exceptional performance, easy installation, and compatibility with a wide range of systems, this memory kit is a worthy choice for users looking to elevate their PC setup. Whether you're seeking top-tier gaming performance or a visually stunning workstation, the Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL delivers on both fronts.

Disclaimer: I purchased the Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL 32GB DDR4 3600MHz memory kit independently and did not receive it as part of any specific program or incentive. My review is solely based on my personal experience and observations with this memory kit.

I recently purchased the Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL 32GB RAM kit, and I must say, it has exceeded my expectations in every way possible!

the performance of the Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro SL 32GB RAM is outstanding. It has significantly improved my system's overall speed and responsiveness. Whether I'm running resource-intensive games or multitasking between multiple applications, this RAM kit handles everything with ease. The 32GB capacity ensures that I have more than enough memory to tackle any task without experiencing any lag or slowdowns.

What truly sets this RAM kit apart from the competition is its striking design. The RGB lighting effects on the Vengeance RGB Pro SL are simply breathtaking. The vibrant colors and customizable lighting options allow me to create stunning lighting profiles that match my setup's aesthetic. The aluminum heat spreaders not only provide excellent cooling performance but also add a premium touch to the overall design.

Installation was a breeze thanks to Corsair's user-friendly software. The iCUE software allows for easy customization of the RGB lighting effects, and it integrates seamlessly with other Corsair components in my setup. Additionally, the XMP 2.0 support ensures that the RAM is automatically optimized for maximum performance, saving me the hassle of manual tweaking.

Corsair's build quality is top-notch, and the Vengeance RGB Pro SL 32GB RAM is no exception. The modules feel solid and well-built, assuring me of their durability. Furthermore, Corsair's reliable customer support provides an added layer of confidence, should any issues arise.

reviews.review:
Bought specifically for use with an MSI MAG B650 Tomahawk Wifi board, Ryzen 7 7700X and a Thermalright Phantom Spirit 120SE cooler. The cooler is so large the front fan sits on top of the RAM. This RAM is the lowest profile DDR5 quality (Hynix) RAM I could find at 6000MHz with a CAS Latency of 30. The others are either slower, higher latency or higher profile. Check that you have the latest BIOS as the RAM's rated voltage of 1.35 will be activated when you turn on EXPO. That is quite close to the SOC danger zone of 1.4V+, you need the new BIOS with built in safeguards.
The only downside if you are in the UK is that it ships from New Jersey, for me it took 9 days to arrive.

Works just fine but be aware, if you use a 7000 series AMD chip, you won't be able to use 4 sticks. DDR5 is very pick for Zen 4 architecture. Only 4 single channel sticks will work. 2. Dual-Channel Kit: The 16GB capacity (8GBx2) in a dual-channel configuration allows for efficient multitasking and smooth gameplay.

3. Low Latency: With a low CL16 latency, this RAM minimizes delays, enabling faster data retrieval and seamless gaming operations.

4. Stable Voltage: Operating at a reliable 1.35V voltage, this RAM maintains stability during extended gaming sessions.

5. Easy Installation: The 288-pin UDIMM design ensures straightforward installation in compatible motherboards.

Cons:
1. None Noted: The Silicon Power Gaming Series DDR4 16GB (8GBx2) 3200MHz RAM has met all expectations, and there are no reported drawbacks or issues during use.

In conclusion, the Silicon Power Gaming Series DDR4 16GB (8GBx2) 3200MHz RAM excels as a high-performance memory solution for avid gamers. With its fast speed, low latency, and stable voltage, this RAM kit optimizes gaming experiences and enables smooth multitasking.

With no reported drawbacks and widespread user satisfaction, I confidently rate the Silicon Power Gaming Series DDR4 16GB (8GBx2) 3200MHz RAM with a perfect five stars. Enhance your gaming setup with this reliable and high-performance RAM kit - a must-have upgrade for passionate gamers!

I would have loved 3600mhz but it's not that bad. I also would have liked a more "complete" heatsink but it's not really a problem. Overall, this is a good buy if it's going relatively cheap. 4.5 stars

Looking for 16GB of DDR4 for a new PC build I saw this and wondered if I should buy or stick with Corsair. I ended up going for these and they work just fine. Checking them out with CPU-Z program they show up as using Samsung memory which is reassuring. No reason to think these won't give years of service.

I installed this on an ASUS B350 Prime Plus MB sporting a Ryzen 5700G using DCOP memory settings. All timings were as advertised. I then ran Memtest86 overnight, 5 passes completed, no errors. I then ran a burn-in test for one hour using stress-ng (Linux). Stress-ng is a professional grade utility used to stress CPU, memory, I/O, OS, etc. No errors reported.

Afterwards, I ran some bench marks using Geekbench6 which uses real world applications to benchmark systems. I realized a 3% gain in single threaded mode and almost 8% in multi-threaded mode over the RAM I used previously (2133:13-15-15-36). Those are excellent results, keeping in mind that those results are for actual applications, not the synthetic benchmarks often used to measure RAM performance.

You can find marginally faster RAM but not at this price.
Ist vom System mit dem richtigen Takt erkannt worden und läuft stabil

Pros : the ram sticks are cheap, they do the job, they can be overclocked to 3600mhz at CL16

Cons : the XMP voltage is to low for the ram to be stable and may cause crashes so you have to manually set the voltage of the DRAM little by little until it is stable

Tips : if you want to overclock the ram to the max then set the XMP profile on then set the frequency at 3600mhz and set the Dram voltage between 1.4 to 1.45 to be stable. (DO AT YOUR OWN RISK)

reviews.review:
So when I got the ram I ended up spending like 1 to about two hours trying to install it. I got a asrock b450 pro4 board. I got a ryzen 5600x cpu I recently had 16gb of this ram, then I decided to get the 32gb version of it. My motherboard max ram is 64Gb adding it up I was basically installing 48Gb all together. But for some reason when I add the two 16gb sticks with the two 8gb sticks, my computer for some reason would not boot up. Now this was me switching the rams around trying to figure out what was the problem. Because before I had some different brand name rams I mixed it with the Vulcan’s and it worked at 24gb but iv learned mixing different ram brands can cause issues and lower performance. But my pc still booted up, and ran pretty decent. But for some reason adding the same Vulcan Z”s 32gb with the 8gb ram did not boot up. At this point I was confused. Because it is so post to boot up, I ended up checking my motherboard website
I was missing bios update 8.01 v2 1.2.0.8 apparently this update is for amd/ intel motherboards as well. It is so post to help with memory of your motherboard. So if you don’t have it please download it! A lot people that have gaming computers pre built just to game don’t know about bios updates. After removing one of the 16gb sticks and leaving the two 8gb sticks my pc finally booted up. I am still confused to the point where I don’t understand why it dose not boot up with both 16gb sticks and only one. I’m still getting my 32gb performance on my pc so I am happy with it. Now I just have one brand new 16gb ram stick collecting dust until i can figure out how to install it and get my 48Gb performance. Honestly I don’t know if it’s the company because i have seen a few reviews that these type of sticks are corrupted. So if you decide on buying Vulcan brand ram sticks good luck it might work and it might not work so your playing a dirty ball game :) hopefully if you missed this review before u bought the ram, and u have the same problem and u manage to find this an u try my methods explain above. An it helps YOUR WELCOME :)

Bought 4 sticks for my 5800x and ROG STRIX B450-F GAMING II motherboard. 2 sticks work fine at 3596 MT/s, but only in the A2 and B2 slots. To get 4 sticks to work, I had to reduce the speed to 3533 MT/s.

I did not have to RMA this RAM, but at one point I thought I would need to, and I'm pleased to report that I was able to get an RMA number online within minutes with just the serial number from the RAM. Compare this to other manufacturers who require you to produce a receipt and supply the vendor name, purchase date, etc. I very much appreciate the no-hassle RMA process and lifetime warranty of this RAM.

This RAM works great on a Gigabyte AB350-Gaming-CF board with a Ryzen 3 2200G processor, with an XMPP profile enabled in the firmware. Recommended purchase.

First time building a machine in a long time so this is my first rgb ram. Cost was great at the time for the speeds. The rgb is very bright and syncs with some of the top rgb controls. I'm using aura sync and it worked flawlessly.
Both sticks are good out or the box, zero issues. I may even pick up another 8x2 set for 32gb of ram total. Without massive Photoshop or video editing 16 is probably enough already, and anything over 32 is definitely overkill.

I think this is the most RAM I have ever had in a computer I have owned. Long gone is the time when I exceeded the 4K of RAM in my Vic20.
I was looking for a little boost for my desktop, this was it. Easy enough to install for my who has been doing this for decades. Click add to cart, what do you have to loose?

The specs are exactly as advertised. Installed on MSI Pro Z690-A DDR4 mobo and had no issue with installation. The main reason I chose this over "gaming" specific RAM is that it's an excellent price and I don't want my computer to look like a 14 year olds idea of a space ship. So far so good.

just installed them fixed a ram issue i was having, seem to be more compatiable with my board, works exactly as advertise and also came very quickly

This seems to be very good and affordable RAM. Looks like high quality Made in Taiwan. Worked right out of the box.
I recommend.
I ordered the MSi B450-A Max Pro motherboard when AM5 came out and paid around 80$ for it. A bit expensive but it is an ATX board. This RAM works with this motherboard right out of the box and is paired with an Ryzen 5900X. Super easy to install and flash with the BIOS button the Bios for the Ryzen 5000 series CPU's. Worked right out of the box. The board is better than the B450 board I have from Asus. Easy to install in my XPG Invader case.
At the beginning when freshly installed Windows 11 I got lots of sound problems. After installing the crap of MSi drivers and Utilities which actual version MSi's MSi Center was offering, my sound got messed up completely. Sound stutters becauso of the new sound drivers, Chipset drivers and the like. Headphones and 5.1 Speakers intermittently connected/disconnected causing delays and stutters. Looked like an software issue of MSi software. That foreced me to reinstall and erase from scrap Windows 10 and it offered then to upgrade to Windows 11. After that the problem was gone with only Windows drivers. Do not download the crap MSi Center offers. It can break your OS.
Other than that this board suggests it has 2 full fledged PCIE x 16 slots of the 3.0 type. At least that is what customers will think easily. Think twice. It has only one x16 PCIE 3.0 slot and the long one below has x16 openings but only half of those have connector pins installed and the manual says it is not even an x8 slot but rather an x4 only. And to add insult to injury that slot is only 2.0. Completely misleading for an new buyer.
On the lower slot I have the GT 1030 GDDR5 from MSi installed I had still from Q1 2020. It works on low settings on some games like HnG from 2016 and gets between 52 fps and 60 fps.
Other than that this MSi board works way better than the Asus B450 board I have on my other system from last year. The RAM slots are way easier to use and the sticks slide into them like lubricated. The dual channel works on this board which is on my Asus most likely defective (Asus refuses warranty). I use it with 32 GB (2 x 16) TeamGroup TCreate RAM sticks. High quality 3200 Mhz sticks for relatively cheap.
It is a good strong board with 2 massive coolers on the Mosfets. These massive coolers impressed me as an new inexperienced buyer for my very first build. So it slipped to me the issue with the PCIE "x16" slots.
This Motherboard worked straight out of the box. I use the Ryzen 5900X with this with an Gamemax Gamma 500 AM4 cooler. The coolers does not fit well the AM4 system since it's clip is way to stiff so I had to take the cooler off the CPU and bend a bit the clips till it fits just with a little pressure. Install the air coolers without too much pressure so it is not loose but can slide a bit is fine before snapping it gently in place. As original fit I got 66 Celsius to 70 Celsius on idle or doing basic work with that processor, but after bending the clips to aliviate the pressure I get now at the moment 51 Degrees Celsius. So if too much pressure is applied by the cooler onto the processor that rises the heat to a difference of about 20 Degrees Celsius. Any of these standard air coolers with heat pipes will be able to cool the Ryzen 5900X easily. While gaming it gets to about 61 degrees Celsius. My case has 3 fans in the front and 1 in the back.
MSi's UEFI is a bit confusing if one is used to the Asus UEFI. But it has basically the same features but it is way more confusing. The fans can be adjusted better on MSi's BIOS. But with this 5900X duo deca core CPU, the PSU is annoyingly loud all the time. While on Ecomode with 65 Watts the whole system draws on gaming about 150 Watts. The board seems to have no problems to deliver power to the 5900X.
Running Cinebench with this board and 5900X CPU with settings to Ecomode 65Watt, the case fans kick in, the CPU has an temp of 61 Degrees Celsius after 5 Minutes Cinebench, the Mosfets have an temperature of 58 Degrees Celsius and the PCH has an temperature of 50 Celsius while the Cooler Master Silencio 120mm fan I put on the Gamma from GameMax CPU cooler, turns 1000 rpm and all 4 Arctic F12 120mm case fans show an rpm of 700.
I am surprised how this GameMax Gamma air cooler is able to maintain cool this CPU. So the huge aluminum coolers on the Mosfets of the MSi board sure do their job.
The board has lots of fan headers. Thats very good.
I recommend this board for the AM4 system but be aware of the cheating PCIE slot advertisement, the sound problems and the rather difficult to use UEFI settings. But this is an robust board.

I purchased this for a non-rgb SFF build on a 12 series Intel system.

I needed lower profile memory for a SFF build and decided to try this memory out. I have seen it recommended by PC builders for the last few years and decided it must be sufficient.

Non of the had this ram on their QVL, but XMP/EXPO/DOCP all worked correctly on every board I tried it on. MSI, Asus, and several Gigabyte boards.

I ended up sticking it in my workshop computer. Simple Asus x570 tuf gaming plus wi-fi, running a Ryzen 7 5700g. Since the rig uses the on board IGP of the 5700g, it uses the system ram for video memory. The fastest you can put in helps, and this 4000 speed ram gets the job done at a great price.

I recently bought the TEAMGROUP T-Force Delta RGB DDR4 32GB for my gaming PC and I have to say I'm pretty impressed. The RGB lighting is gorgeous and syncs well with my motherboard. The only minor issue I have is that the RAM sticks are quite tall and they barely fit under my CPU cooler. I had to adjust the fan position a bit to make some room. It's not a big deal, but it would have been nice if they were a bit shorter or had a low-profile option.

Overall, I'm very happy with my purchase and I would recommend this RAM to anyone looking for a reliable and stylish upgrade. I give it 4/5 stars.

I got this to use in Dell optiplex that supports up to 1333MHz memory. In one of the Amazon "questions" a person asks if you can overclock this memory. A teamgroup representative tells them you can't over clock it...or under clock it. They said you must buy the ram that runs at the native speed you require. While it's perhaps true that this isn't the best ram to try to over clock, I'm sure this memory will under clock (run at a lower MHz) just fine.

Unfortunately I didn't see that the manual for my PC states that it can only support dimms in 1GB, 2GB, and 4GB sizes for a total of 8GB (it has two slots). While the CPU itself supports up to 32GB, it seems that the motherboard does not. Oddly enough it actually recognized the full 16GB. The memory clocked down to 1333MHz 9CL. The OS booted up. It would even pass 2 rounds of memtest86. Sadly it would always crash the PC on the third pass of memtest86.

The memory itself was perfectly fine. I ended up using it in another system that supports both 1600MHz and 32GB. I used two kits of two for a total of 32GB (4x16GB). A teamgroup rep will also probably tell you that you can't mix two identical but separate kits, but it completed 6 passes of memtest86 with flying monochromatic colors. Is 32GB overkill for a 4th gen PC? Probably...but at this price, why not?

It's nice that these are black instead of green or blue just on the off chance you're upgrading your old 2014 gaming rig with plexiglass side panel. Obviously these don't have RGB, but neither does the PC you're using them in.
