reviews.review:
The top row of pixels is cut off. The image information is sent to the screen, but it does not display the top row of pixels. The entire picture that the device receives is shifted up by 1 pixel, and the bottom row of pixels is actually a copy of the pixels above it. If you get this product, then perform a test: make a 1080x1920 image with a black background, and 1 white pixel in every corner. If you display the image full-screen, you will notice that the top 2 do not show up. I performed that test with 2 different graphics cards, and it has the same result.

It also does not work well with HDMI outputs. My computer supports hotswapping monitors, but this display seems like it doesn't. I should have taken the hint when people had to configure their raspberry pi in a special way to use this. I tried this with multiple computers. For the majority of them, it would not even display anything. Other monitors worked with those computers.

I returned the first one I got, they gave me the same one back, I returned it again, and finally they gave me an actually new one, and it had 100% of the prior problems.

Aside from the missing top row, the picture quality is decent when it works.

They at least contacted me via email after the second return, and I'll be following up to clarify the problems. So, they are trying to do good. I may try one of their other products and hope it behaves differently. Look at their website. They have a lot more information about their products there, including the physical dimensions of each display and how to get it working with your pi.

Note that this device only advertises 1080 x 1920 (portrait) resolution, not 1920 x 1080 (landscape) resolution, to the host. So unless you're using a device with an operating system smart enough to support display rotation, it will be operating in portrait mode--not what most users will probably expect, and enough to make some embedded systems fail silently when they can't find a 1920 x 1080 display. The monitor has no power/status LEDs or on-screen indicators, so it's hard to tell whether it's powered off, powered on but receiving no signal, or powered on but receiving a blank image. It also wasn't immediately clear how to turn it on. It comes with no documentation. I connected it to an HDMI source, pressed the power button, and nothing happened. Eventually I figured out to hold down the power button for a few seconds, this made it show a display for a moment, then turn off. I held the power button down again for a few seconds and it stayed on. The enclosure feels fairly solid for the price and the display looks nice, but it needs some better status indicators and it would be ten times more useful if there were a way to tell it to switch to 1920 x 1080 resolution. And a piece of paper explaining how to turn it on.
Plug n play right out of the box. Don’t expect the touch to be perfect. Less than a year in and it’s already having issues so the build quality is questionable.

I just received this 7-inch screen after a long wait. Much better than expected. I would even say it’s perfect. It’s light weight, the image is bright and clear, touch is accurate and just works.

If I could wish for one feature I would have the i/o ports attach with a ribbon/dongle from the back to make mounting to a dashboard or console more seamless. Also, if the brightness could be controlled through the USB connection. That said, the item is exactly as described and great quality.

I didn't want to give it one star but It won't turn on, I don't know if it's broken or I don't know how it works, I didn't want to return it because I liked the design and I want to figure out how this thing works.

reviews.review:
I have been using two monitors for ages, over the last five years I have been using 34" ultra wide monitors paired with a 27" 16x9 monitor, but I decided to try something new and purchased a Samsung CRG9 for gaming. After a couple of days, I was really missing my second display. I usually used it for keeping an eye on my temperatures and clocks while I'm gaming.
Needless to say, I thought a portable laptop screen might do the trick. Since it was just for displaying monitoring software I did not need anything high quality or fancy, so I ordered this 15" Koorui.
First oops was that I didn't realize my GPU did not have a USBc, but no problem since they also supplied an HDMI cable...oops again, there is no power adapter for the USBc cable...lucky I have a USBc on my motherboard, but they really need to include a power adapter with the monitor.
Initial inspection was much better than I thought it would be. The monitor feels a little premium, possibly due to the folio cover.
Powering on the device brought up the picture, and I was a little underwhelmed. The picture is slightly dull...just slightly. I tried adjusting the brightness and contrast, but it's as good as it gets. It's not bad really since I'm comparing it to the $1100 monitor above it, but it does do the job of displaying my monitoring software splendidly.

A couple of beefs. First, it would have been nice if the cables were longer. I had to use my own USBc cable because the one they provide is only about three feet long.
The second is that they, like the rest of the manufacturers, put the ports on the side of the display like a tablet.
Come on guys, this is a monitor, not a tablet. As you can see in the picture, the ports sticking out the side are an ugly quality of life issue could easily have been avoided. Recessing them in the back would have been perfect, but having them sticking out the back would hvae been fine as well. Anything but sticking out the side like this.

Other than that, it's the little monitor that could. It's working perfectly for the purpose I bought it for. Having it set up this way though, if I had to make the choice again, for this particular usage I would have picked a 14" model. The 15" is a touch too big for this purpose.

In any case, if this monitor turns out to be reliable then it's easily worth the price I paid ($117 + Tax). I would recommend it for this purpose.

For budget gamers like me who are also casual gamers, I got some tips to improve your experience with this monitor. Obviously for the price you will get what you pay for. However, you can still very much enjoy medium pace competitive gaming with the adequate tweaks in-game as well as in the monitor settings. I have enjoyed 60hz monitor experience for most of my time gaming and you should expect smoother gameplay as well as slightly more in-depth/ less pixelated video quality. That being said, there are limits to what games you can play. Using this monitor works well for me for Rainbow 6 Siege and Read Dead Redemption 2. I doubt playing fast pace triple-A games like Warzone will work with this monitor. Important to mention, after spending a few hours on this monitor I have gotten used to the ghosting where it seems not apparent to me anymore or it's so minimal. Just a warning though, do expect poor video quality to compensate for better motion. But overall in my opinion, the benefits outweigh the cons in my book. You sacrifice some video quality for more smooth motion as well as high refresh rate.

Steps to fix ghosting issues:
- Set contrast and brightness on monitor to 100/ max
- Turn on overdrive (OD) to extreme
- Turn on freesync premium and enable g sync in nvidia control panel
- Use Gamma 1 because you need that high contrast
- Ensure you use the 165hz in your windows setting as well as in-game setting
- In-game limit your fps to 165hz or unlimited
- In the nvidia control panel, manage 3D settings: turn low latency mode to ultra and power management mode to prefer maximum performance.

Now this part is subjective to users:
- In-game test out contrast and sharpness to near maximum effectiveness. You can over-saturate these effects which can become negatively impactful.
- In-game adjust brightness accordingly where you can see shades from black to white appropriately.

In conclusion, this monitor has been a good upgrade from my 60 hz monitor as it is smoother in gameplay and less pixelated when viewing from further distances. A good step forward from entry level gaming on a budget. Although setting up tweaks for games for the first time and later on will be an inconvenience but well worth it if you don't mind.

I love this monitor! I don’t know why I waited so long to have one. It came with a protective case-stand and 3 cords: usbC- usb-C, usb-usbC, and HDMI-mini HDMI. The only thing you will need is how to plug the usb to a power outlet. I didn’t need one because I already have one on my desk. I don’t do any design or any activities that require colour calibration, so the brightness and colours seem perfect to me. Connecting it was super easy and straight forward, no need to configure anything. The speakers are also pretty decent, and the monitor has a volume button on the right side next to the power button. If you push up, it will show the volume menu and if you push down it will first show the mode menu. From there you can choose: Standard, cinema, RTS, FPS or eye saver.

Bien pour le prix

Out of the box the fit and finish and magnetic flap/stand all feel very high quality.

Without reading the manual (which wouldn't have helped anyway), I figured out how to plug it in and get it up and running in Windows 11. Pretty intuitive and well integrated process.

My 13 inch HP spectre has 2 USB-c ports. This monitor also has 2 USB-c ports. A single cable between them will work with any pair of ports. however in that case the brightness is limited at 50% due to power limitation. By connecting the laptop charger to the Koorui monitor, and with a single USB-c cable leading back to the laptop, there's no longer any power limitation and I can get 100% brightness and 100% volume. The pleasant surprise for me was the single display cable, also *back charges* the laptop, although at a low wattage. I can leave the laptop in high performance mode, and the battery drains only very very slowly and can last at least 2 days.

I bought two of these Koorui's, the second one used HDMI to mini HDMI with Windows 10, on an eight year old laptop. That also worked flawlessly. However, a second USB-c power source was needed to turn on the monitor at all (which it would do at full power), because HDMI doesn't deliver power.

These Koorui monitor feel more comfortable to read than either of my laptops (one of which is a high end 4k screen). It has a matte finish and nice looking black to white transitions, making photos look very natural. I really like the colors and reading experience.

The only downside I found was the manual. It repeats hazard warning in six languages, but doesn't tell you you need to hold down the power button for a few seconds to turn it on, because the power button doubles as menu and select button. The entire monitor settings UI is handled with only 3 buttons. It work well once you figure it out, but the "manual" doesn't have a single mention of any of this. Nor does it discuss compatibility and power requirements. Why try so hard at making a great product, but remain at such an amateur level writing the manual? That's the thing that bugged me.

For gaming you only get 60hz refresh, so I haven't tried it for gaming and don't plan to use it that way. For remote learning and remote meetings, a highly portable second screen is a really nice thing to have. Overall for the extremely friendly price, I really appreciate being able to purchase this product.

reviews.review: This monitor is really nice. It comes with a neoprene storage sleeve, and two cables - an HDMI cable and a USB-C cable. The monitor works with USB-C to USB-C, or it works with HDMI. However, if you connect with HDMI, then you need a USB-C to USB-A cable (not supplied) to provide power to the monitor (so you have two cables going into the monitor). The picture quality is good and sharp. The brightness is good too. The stand is ok. It doesn't feel the most sturdy, but if you keep the monitor horizontal then it feels pretty good. When I put the monitor vertical with the stand, it feels a bit shaky and I don't trust it. I would probably use some other stand if I want to keep the monitor in vertical (portrait) orientation. The monitor is also slim and light, so it's easy to travel around. There were no dead pixels when the monitor arrived, and the colour was close to my laptop screen (not perfect, but good enough as long as you're not doing graphical work where calibration is required). The menu button at the back of the monitor feels a bit cheap, but it does the job that it needs to do. Overall this is a great monitor - even better if you can get it on sale!
Easily connected with my work computer and makes working from home much better! Monitor is bigger than I thought it would be and is super lightweight.

Even though i have a full setup of my 2 monitors at my desk, there are times i like to work in the evenings in my living room using my coffee table. The monitor is easy to plug into your laptop using the c type cable. No power cable mess-which is PERFECT. the resolution is great and the built in back stand works perfectly. It was totally worth the cost. The screen cover is a bonus to carry around in my laptop bag or backpack. If you r looking foe a LIGHT portable monitor, look no further. Highly recommend.
Perfect second monitor for my surface tablet. Let’s me do work while travelling. Very lightweight and perfect size. Excellent product.

Took this with me on a week-long work trip. It worked well and didn't take up space in my bag or on the desk. I appreciated the protective sleeve that came with it. Great value for the price, no issues with it!

Very pleased. Everything works as described. I use my Samsung phone and it connects to Samsung Dex with no issues, allowing me to use my phone as a mouse/trackpad. With a smartphone you can get by using the included type-c for data transfer and power, however, it will drain your phones battery at a decent pace. To avoid this, you can power the monitor with a usb type-c cable in one port, and use another type c port on the monitor for data transfer. (Make sure to use included cable and another good quality type-c cable) It connects flawlessly to my beelink mini pc. On which I have used it for light pc gaming; apex, forza, counter strike and everyday surfing and browsing. The pc worked flawlessly and only needed the provided type-c cable for power AND data transfer. The included mini hdmi will pair perfectly with my ps5 aswell. Can you say gaming on the go? Was so happy with my purchase I did an unboxing for it. For price/performance. I definitely recommend.
It is super light and powers up from a power brick you charge your phone with!
The screen is quite easy to setup and works great...but the build quality is nowhere near what it should be at that price point.

This is a review of VA1655(Standard Version), I also purchased the premium version VG1655 as well.
Purchased as an Used-Like New at $83.99(compared to $129) from ViewSonic Corp. After a week of using, for the summary, this is a mediocre portable monitor. It's probably not worth spend over $100 on this.
There are two main reasons you should avoid this monitor.

Color Gamut & Luminance:
1.Limited Color Gamut .(about 58.25% sRGB Coverage). For the sub $100 , you can buy a 24-inch IPS Panel Monitor(Normal PC Monitor) with 99% sRGB coverage.
2.Limited LCD Luminance(About 257.51 cd/m^2) For Monitor under 300 cd/m^2,it will be very hard to read outdoor.

Color Accuracy:
Apart from two main drawbacks, the color accuracy is also very poor. Under the factory default settings. The average ΔE*00 is 5.16 (Normal range ≤1.5 ), the max ΔE*00=21.83(Normal range≤4). It's extremely poor on displaying blue color.

Compared to Premium Version(VG1655)
Display Panel:
It also has a premium version, after analyzing it, I must say it's complete wasting money, the display panels is almost identical, similar Color Gamut and color accuracy. The premium version has a slightly brighter luminance 288 cd/m^2 compared to 257.51 cd/m^2.

I/O ports and Appearance:
In additional to the identical panel, the features seems identical too, same I/O ports configuration. Despite the standard one showing two icons for usb-c ports: usb-c power and usb-c display. After testing, they are actually the same , both can be using as USB-C display ports. The standard one has the lock port though.
The big differences between the standard and premium is the appearance .The premium has the metal frame and metal back cover(plastic frame and back cover on standard one), and support is a big full metal piece compared small plastic one on standard. They can both stand vertically at same angle. The stand version come with a monitor sleeve bag covered the whole monitor whereas the premium has the magnetic cover which only cover half of it. The standard weight lighter than the premium .

Accessories:
Both models come with 1 USB-c to USB-C cable, Full HDMI to Mini HDMI cable. For the premium one, it has one extra USB-A to USB-C cable and a Power adapter. Other than that, they are very similar. Since I already mentioned the bag and cover in the Appearance, I won't mention again.

Conclusion:
The standard VA1655 is worth to consider buying when below $100. For the premium VG1655, it's totally waste the money when spending over $20 or more for the identical performance. Not to mention the sound speakers are identical too. You won't get any better sound on premium one. I only recommend to buy the monitor for the everyday usage like school or office.

I bought the ViewSonic VA1655 last week and received it a few days ago. Here is an early review after connecting it to my stuff.

Sharpness:
The display is full HD, so it looks fairly sharp. It won't be as sharp as the retina displays of my 14-inch MacBook Pro M! or my 11-inch iPad Pro M2. But I think trying to retina on this portable monitor would be overkill.

Brightness:
At work, I use a Chromebook that is rated 220 nits. Its display is bright enough, even in the cubical/office space where many big windows expose lots of sunlight. Since the Viwwsonic VA1655 is rated 250 nits, I expected it would be bright enough. It is. I would not expect to be able to use it if I had a huge beam of direct sunlight on the screen, but frankly, I think I'd have some trouble using my iPad or MacBook that way.

Colors:
I connected the Viewsonic to my MacBook Pro M1, duplicated a photo, and displayed it on the Viewsonic and the MacBook. I did not see a difference. Granted, I am not a photographer, and I am a little colorblind. But I read reviews claiming the colors on the Viewsonic looked washed out, and I did see that. But those with higher standards than mine might want to put in the proper research, since I have read that the Viewsonic color gamut is not real high. Your milage may vary.

Gaming:
I do not play video games, so I cannot judge how well the Viewsonic handles that. I rated gaming at 3 stars to try to be neutral. And I know that not paying video games might damage my geek cred. I still read comic books.

MacBook Pro:
The USB-C cable connects to my MacBook Pro and the display and the display instantly shows up. It looks decent side-by-side. Not bad!

iPad Pro:
The USB-C connection works fine, although I had to find the right Settings and turn on Stage Manager to make the Viewsonic show as an external display without mirroring. I use a Logitech Bluetooth keyboard and mouse. The mouse is needed to navigate the Viewsonic display (I doubt that a touchscreen portable monitor would have touchscreen functionality with the iPad). But it does drain the iPad battery faster. I can plug power into the extra USB-C port on the monitor to charge the iPad, that works fine.

iPad Pro and USB hub:
I have a USB hub that I use to plug stuff into my iPad (like flash drives and external hard drives or SD drives). When I connected the hub to the iPad Pro, and then connected the USB-C data port on the hub to the Viewsonic, it did not carry a video signal. So I connect the Viewsonic display to the USB hub like this:
1. Bluetooth-connect my external keyboard and mouse to the iPad.
2. To power the Viewsonic, connect a USB-A-to-USB-C cable to a USB 3.0 port on the hub, then to the USB-C port on the Viewsonic.
3. To carry the video signal, connect the Viewsonic HDMI cable to the hub, and then to the Viewsonic mini HDMI port.
4. Optional: Plug power into the USB-C PD (power delivery) port on the hub to supply power to the iPad.
5. Connect the hub to the iPad USB-C port.
From this experience, my advice is if you buy a portable monitor, buy one with an HDMI port, two USB-C ports, and an audio port. I have used them on my Viewsonic VA1655. (Except the audio port, but I am sure it works.)

Audio:
The speakers sound tinny, but I did not expect good sound from them anyhow.
When I connect the Viewsonic to my MacBook Pro, I select the MacBook Pro speakers for better sound.
When I plug the Viewsonic into the iPad, the iPad audio automatically switches to the Viewsonic speakers with no option to switch back to the iPad speakers. (I believe this would happen with any portable monitor.) If I want better sound, I can connect to one of my Bluetooth speakers and switch to it. Or I could plug a speaker or headphones into the Viewsonic audio port.

The little kickstand:
Some reviews comment that the kickstand can break easily. I take that into account when I pull the kickstand out, I open it with care. I get my fingers in underneath, close to the hinge, to avoid stress on that hinge. The kickstand works well, the little rubber feet grip smooth surfaces well (in landscape orientation). The Viewsonic is steady enough on a flat surface in landscape orientation, but portrait is kinda tippy (I am unlikely to use portrait anyhow).

Weight and Sturdiness:
The Viewsonic VA1655 display is lightweight, which feels nice. It makes my old 22-inch display (lower resolution, so iPad would only allow mirrored display) feel like a boat anchor (I will donate it somewhere). The Viewsonic does feel plasticy, because it is made of plastic. No metal frame to sturdy it up. However, It does not feel flimsy. I keep it in the included pouch when not in use.

iPad as a MacBook:
The Viewsonic monitor and the USB hub will let me use the iPad more like a MacBook, which I am likely to do if I have to take my MacBook Pro into the shop. I can plug other devices into the hub, like a USB flash drive or an external hard drive or SD drive, but I have read that it is best to not plug too much into the hub at once. I have read that can overwork the iPad USB-C port and give the iPad a heart attack.

Price:
I bought the Viewsonic VA1655 for about about $100 (normally $140), so it was a very good deal. I am happy with it.
The stand is only on one side. So it's to easy to knock over. Also, it doesn't include a power plug? If using HDMI, will need a power plug. So there is an additional cost to own this monitor.

I've only had this monitor for about a week, but I've already used it in so many different ways....

I primarily work from home and I like to move around the house throughout my workday. Unfortunately, to be efficient in what I do, I really need at least two screens most of the time. I have two large full-size monitors in my home offiice, but they're bulky and a pain to move around. I recently read an article saying that single-board computer maker OrangePi was releasing a portable monitor and I was intrigued. That lead me to start looking at options.

As it turns out, there are a ton of portable monitors on the market, many cheaper than this one, but most of the ones I saw were from no-name manufacturers and I was concerned about their quality. In the end, I narrowed down my options to this one and one made by Asus. ViewSonic is a brand that I've know and trusted since the days of CRTs and, while I've never owned an Asus monitor before, I've been a big fan of their motherboards for many years. The Asus monitor, however, only had USB-C input, which made it a deal breaker, so I went with the ViewSonic.

The monitor is roughly the size and thickness of a laptop screen. It has a kickstand on the back that allows it to be positioned at any viewing angle. There are two USB-C ports, one mini HDMI port, and an 1/8" audio jack on the left side, a status LED on the right side, and two small speakers and a single four-way rocker button to control the settings on the back. The package included a 3ft USB-C cable, a 4ft HDMI to mini HDMI cable, and a Neoprene storage sleeve.

I bought this monitor mainly to use with my newer MacBook that I have for for work, but I also planned to use it with my older personal MacBook which only has a mini DisplayPort/Thunderbolt connector on it, which is why the HDMI input was important to me. With USB-C the monitor can pull power from the device it's connected to, but it can also be powered on it's own with a simple phone charger via the second USB-C port. HDMI connections don't provide power, so a power adapter is needed when using the HDMI port. The power adapter is not included, but pretty much any recent phone charger will do.

So, I said this thing has been extremely versatile, right? How have I been using it? Well...

My initial plan was to use it to work from the kitchen table, which I've been doing. I usually start my day by looking over my email and Slack message while I eat breakfast and now I can do that more efficiently by not having to move windows around as I look up things to form my email replies.

I've also found it useful to work from the couch in the evening. I set up the monitor on the end table and connect it to my laptop on my lap and I can easily take care of a bunch of the administrative busywork that I need to do while I watch TV. Doing this has let me stay more focused on meaningful work during the day.

I can also connect my Samsung phone to this monitor and, with Samsung's DeX feature and a Bluetooth keyboard, I can use my phone as a full desktop. I admittedly don't have a ton of use for this, but it's still kind of cool. The phone's battery can power the screen if I want, but if I connect a charger to the second USB-C port on the screen will actually feed power back to my phone to keep it charged.

During the winter, I have my bike set up on a trainer in my basement and I have a book holder that I attach to the handlebars to put my tablet on so I can stream TV while I ride. Well, now that I have this monitor, I can connect it to a Roku and have a much better view than I get from an 8" tablet screen. Unfortunately the trainer makes a lot of noise, so I have to use headphones in order to hear anything. On the tablet I use my Bluetooth headphones, but that's not an option with this, so I'm going to have to look for some kind of Bluetooth adapter.

And finally, just yesterday one of my Raspberry Pis stopped responding. Rather than pulling the plug on it to reboot it and hope for the best, I connected this monitor and a keyboard to it and was able to diagnose the problem and do a safe reboot rather than a hard power down.

So, as you can see, I'm pretty happy with my purchase. So far I've used the screen on my newer MacBook via USB-C directly, my older MacBook via a Thunderbolt to HDMI adapter, a Windows laptop via HDMI, a Roku Express via HDMI, and a Raspberry Pi via HDMI. All have worked flawlessly and I haven't had to touch any settings (other than volume). Color and brightness are good and the screen seems pretty responsive, though I've only used it for web browsing, business apps, Zoom calls, and a little bit of Netflix.

My only complaint is with the sound. The speakers are way too small to be very useful and the volume control, witch requires clicking through a couple of menus in the settings panel, is hard to access. It'd be nicer if the speakers were moved to the front or sides of the unit so that the sound would at least be projected toward you, and it would be nice to have dedicated volume control buttons to make adjusting easier, but I can't really complain given that 99% of the time I'll be using the speakers on whatever the monitor is connected to rather than the monitor itself.

So, if you're looking for a second monitor for a laptop (or anything else for that matter), you can't go wrong with this one.

I’m a rookie with this stuff. I can’t even figure out how to dim the screen. Setting up a Pi 4b, it was getting hotter than I’d like. I set a paper towel on the CPU heat sink and mocked up the fan. I saw that there was maybe 1/32” to the components on the display. I shimmed that with folded paper, then glued (Goat Tuff archery glue) the fan to the pin header. The Pi was still running warm with the case perimeter on. I removed it, and drilled a bunch of holes where there was no interference for air to flow. It now runs nice and cool, and I’ll have a friend with a nice soldering kit & a steady hand finalize the mod. If anyone can tell me how to dim this thing, I’d appreciate it.

Wanted this for my RPi3B+ since the RPi4 is usually either out of stock or extravagantly expensive these days. That said, GPIO pinout is the same on both devices as far as this screen is concerned. I got tired of hunting for a monitor and HDMI cable.

Once you follow the instructions (clone git repo, run script for your screen size) it will reboot and you'll be good to go. Booted with a tty console, too (no GUI on my devices). Note that text is not super clear and especially on a console will be very tiny by default (this can be changed at the OS level)

There's been some fairly negative reviews recently, but following the instructions on the business card-sized driver installation guide included in the box will get you setup right away. And at this size, an increase in DPI would not do much to improve text readability. I've got a 3.5" lcd which has a (horizontally oriented) resolution of 800x450 which cost 6 times what this screen does and text is only slightly easier to read.

It all looked pretty neat the 1st time a friend introduced me to, enough so that it actually spurred a larger interest in tech in general, more the hardware than software - coding might as well be Vulcan or Klingon for all I can make of it. The other part of that coin is I have no interest in grasping it either, a factor that's on me more than the products. As kits for STEM classes and such I can see where they are so useful as to be a mainstay, as well as totally changing computer technology, giving birth to the mini, fanless units taking over. In the end I'm still hoping to maybe recover at least a part of some of what I've spent on it all. At least I was able to return these for a refund, partial as it was.

I bought this case with the intention of making a point and shoot style thermal camera. The project ended up being a success, but I found that the screen is a real GPIO hog. My specific issue was that it uses all of your default I2C headers. Other folks who actually know what they're doing can probably work around this limitation with good circuit design, but since I'm an IT guy and not an engineer I had to make my hack work in software. This is by no means a fault with this case, and I am very happy with the finished product.

The screen is very responsive and worked well with a default raspberry pi image after following the included instructions. I did find that after installing the screen's drivers, my external monitors started reporting "out of range", which I am sure is something that can be worked around in software. It wasn't critical for my application, so I didn't bother.

Assembly was pretty easy, but there is no wiggle room. Since my build involved a few wires that needed to exit the case to reach my sensor, it was an extremely tight fit. Assembly doesn't leave much room for anything besides the screen.

The only thing that I can say could use improvement would be to use a screen that exposes the GPIO pins so that things like sensors can be attached for noobs like me who can't design circuits yet. That would make it a little more user friendly, but also understandably raise the price.

Overall, extremely happy with the product and would buy again for other projects without reservation.

Could not select anything w. pen or mouse. display was okay and easy to set up. I just copied and pasted the commands in a terminal. it rebooted automatically. I shut it down and installed the screen and it came up no problem.... other than not responding to my clicks. :-(
Addendum: after returning this and "uninstalling" the drivers, I had a hard time trying to get my audio jack working. It would function with a fresh installation but that would require reinstalling reams of programs I had spent months working on. After a week of searching for a solution, I finally came upon a hint after viewing the output of the dmesg command. There in the "kernel" section was snd_bcm2835.enable_headphones=0
I opened a terminal in the /boot directory and typed sudo nano cmdline.txt and added snd_bcm2835.enable_headphones=1 to the end of the line alt-x to exit "Y" to save, enter to accept the file save then reboot. After reboot right-clicking the speaker icon allowed me to select headphones for output. Good luck. YMMV since I could not state what else I'd done previous to that trying to get it working (any of which may have also contributed to the end result).

name: Waveshare 10.1inch Capacitive Touch IPS Display Compatible with Raspberry Pi 4B/3B+/3A+, 1280×800 Hardware Resolution, DSI Interface
description:
• This 10.1-inch IPS capacitive touch screen with a hardware resolution of 1280x800, adopts optical bonding technique, clearer imaging, display well and dustproof
  • Up to 10-point touch, depending on the operating system. Up to 6H hardness toughened glass panel
  • Can be directly connected to the LCD by the DSI interface of the Raspberry Pi, and its refreshing rate is up to 60Hz
  • When working with Raspberry Pi, the Raspberry Pi OS system driver is required and provided on the online wiki
  • Support Pi 4B/3B+/3A+, CM3+/4(requires extra DSI FFC Cable). Support backlight adjusted by software

reviews.review:
Overall, I like this screen. I glued it into a project box enclosure, and it works as expected after some configuration. NITs = cd/m2 must be >1000 to be sunlight readable. This screen is probably around 300-350 NITs at peak brightness, and is best suited for indoors. When executing the main installation command, don't forget to change the I2C bus to “1” instead of the default “0” as indicated on the waveshare readme. This allows the waveshare screen POGO pins to connect to the I2C “1” bus for touchscreen for use with RPi4B. Edit your RPi config.txt file after installation via Terminal-> sudo nano /boot/config.txt and delete or comment out the "ignore_lcd=1" at the bottom. You should also add to bottom of config.txt the following line to prevent RPi video output problems; display_default_lcd=1. The waveshare brightness application may work on the stock RPI image, however it does not work on the custom RPI 4B 64bit image I used. You can manually change the brightness through the following terminal commands instead:
sudo chmod 777 /sys/waveshare/rpi_backlignt/brightness
echo *> /sys/waveshare/rpi_backlignt/brightness #where * is a value 0-240

reviews.review: This thing has been very fun to play with so far, but I have a lot to learn. The quality is very good, and the screen looks beautiful. It is very small and has some nice sensors already built-in with the ability to add more with the GPIO pins. The USB-C port is very handy for powering this and connecting to PC.

I haven’t got to use it yet. I plan to set this up with audrino and gps to track top speed of Rc and drones. I’ve done it before with the simple 1 color Oled screen but this is like a full on lcd screen. As far as I could see there was no header pins in the box. Not the greatest in my opinion but maybe that’s common in this type of stuff. I’m new to the whole thing. But I was hoping to stack the screen on top but maybe that’s not possible to get the pins to line up.

Dieses Produkt wurde mir von Amazon kostenlos zur Verfügung gestellt. Von daher werde ich den Produktpreis nicht in die Bewertung mit einfließen lassen.

Das runde Display mit integrierten RP2040 Chipsatz hat mich mit seiner Vielseitigkeit und Leistungsfähigkeit beeindruckt. Die Integration des 1,28-Zoll-LCD-Bildschirms ermöglicht eine praktische und intuitive Benutzererfahrung. Die runde Form verleiht dem Board ein modernes Aussehen und passt gut in verschiedene Projekte. Die eingebauten Beschleunigungs- und Gyroskopsensoren eröffnen neue Möglichkeiten für die Bewegungserkennung und -steuerung. Mit 30 × Multi-Funktions-GPIO-Pins habe ich genügend Anschlussmöglichkeiten für meine Erweiterungen. Die Leistung des RP2040-Chipsatzes ist beeindruckend und bietet ausreichend Rechenleistung für komplexe Anwendungen. Insgesamt ein ausgezeichnetes Entwicklungsboard für Maker, Entwickler und Hobbyisten, die hochwertige Projekte realisieren möchten.

Das kleine Modul kommt in gut geschützt in einem wiederverschließbaren ESD-Schutzbeutel. Es beinhaltet einen Raspberry Pi Pico R2040 Mikrocontroller, sowie ein on-board 1.28 Inch LCD-Display. Dieses hat eine Auflösung von 240x240 Pixel und eine RGB Farbtiefe von 64K. Ebenfalls an Board, ein QMI8658C Beschleunigungssensor und Gyroskop.

Überrascht war ich, dass sich schon ein Demo-Code auf dem Board befindet. Unmittelbar nach dem Einschalten wird erst eine Farbfolge dargestellt und anschließend die Werte des Beschleunigungssensors und Gyroskops. Die USB-Batteriespannung wir ebenfalls ausgegeben.

Der Verkäufer hat bei diesem Produkt auch den Link auf das Hersteller Wiki von Waveshare angegeben. Dort findet man weitere interessante Infos und weitere Demo-Programme.

Ein tolles R2040 MCU-Modul, das mich positiv überrascht hat und volle fünf Sterne verdient!

it is useful for some projects not so much for other projects
Item is well made, good solder points at connectors. Bright, colorful screen, highly recommended.

The display is very fragile, and there's not much to hold onto when attaching it as a HAT. I cracked the glass trying to push it onto the board.

Data sheet suggests that the controller supports 4 colors and 64 shades of brightness for each color, but the included code doesn't give examples for this, only black/white. Not sure whether the display itself supports multicolor or not. Other panels that use this controller support white, yellow, blue, and black.

There are other features mentioned in the data sheet that there are no examples for in the software, like "dim mode" and "low power mode." Would be nice to have examples for these.

All in all, it's a nice little display.

In the past, the main drawback of TFT technology has been the low contrast. Using In-Plane-Switching (IPS), the color is induced in the same plane as the backlight (The term would be wrong in this case, as the light plane is no longer behind the color plane), resulting in very high contrast. This display looks like an OLED display, without the drawbacks of color-fading over time, and price. Driver software is widely available - in the picture I'm using the sample from circuitpython for this chip. So far I have only driven the SPI at 24 Mhz, which the driver chip handles without hiccup. With the high contrast, this 2 inch display is as readable as bigger displays. The resolution of 240x320 gives fine detail, but obviously requires longer for screen refresh, so it's a trade off. For me, IPS displays will be the choice if available, and this display does not disappoint. The board allows for through-hole soldering of your own wires, and the supplied connector with breadboard friendly wires makes prototyping a snap, no soldering required. I will probably use this display for my final result, but will take the connector off, as it requires too much space below the display board.
I tested several displays of different sizes and technologies. So far this is my favorite. What I haven't done yet is a power consumption comparison. When only few pixels are "active", OLED would usually consume less power, but I will see how it pans out.

name: ViewSonic VP3256-4K 32 Inch Premium IPS 4K Ergonomic Monitor with Ultra-Thin Bezels, Color Accuracy, Pantone Validated, HDMI, DisplayPort and USB Type-C for Professional Home and Office, Black
description:
• PREMIUM MONITOR: 4K UHD (3840x2160p) advanced ergonomic, 60Hz IPS monitor delivers lifelike colors perfect for the office, graphic design, photography and more
  • PANTONE-VALIDATED DISPLAY: Experience true color fidelity in every pixel. The rigorously tested VP3256-4K has been certified as capable of reproducing Pantone Matching System colors for professionals
  • AMAZING AT ANY ANGLE: A three-sided ultra-thin bezel shows off more of your masterpiece and less of the monitor
  • ULTIMATE COLOR ACCURACY: With a SuperClear IPS panel for 100% sRGB gamut coverage, 95% Adobe RGB and Delta E<2 accuracy, this monitor has been factory calibrated to deliver true-to-life images
  • REDUCE CABLE CLUTTER: Connect video, audio, data and power with a single USB-C cable and plug in peripherals like USB drives and mice with the USB hub

reviews.review: Don't write reviews often but thought I would for this monitor. The picture quality is fantastic at 2K, not as sharp as some of the 4k ones we tested but 2k at this price is a really fantastic work monitor for those that work doing online/digital marketing and dealing with photos, images, branding elements as part of their work. The really nice surprise was the benefits of USB-C/Thunderbolt. Have this monitor as an extended desktop on a MacBook Pro connected via USB-C/Thunderbolt and went from a power cable, monitor cable, desktop webcam cable and external USB drive cable down to just the USB-C/Thunderbolt. All of those components are now directly plugged into the monitor and I simply connect my MacBook Pro with one USB-C/Thunderbolt and everything works as before but without any dongles and not nearly the mess of cables. This monitor even provides power to the MacBook Pro via USB-C/Thunderbolt. Great picture quality and fantastic USB-C/Thunderbolt cable management. I'm guessing the 4k version of this monitor is top notch but it is much more expensive than the 2k. If you use a MacBook Pro, this is a fantastic option.
Belle qualité d'image, on ne l'achète pas pour le son des hauts-parleurs. La base est solide malgré une qualité de plastiques moyenne.

Recently I bought 3 new ViewSonic VP2756-2K monitors from another vendor. My set up has one Sapphire AMD GPU with 3 DP ports, using the same DP port cables. One of them has a bit pinkish White tone so I tried to order another one from Amazon in the hope of swapping with it. It turned out the white tone is even worse with yellowish tone and too much different in White with the 3 ones. I am not sure how pro it is and how these were factory calibrated that cause so much different in White tone even with the same model. So I had to return it.
Sadly. I bought these pro calibrated monitors with the hope for consistency of the multiple monitors set up but I could not achieve that.
But not chance, I got a damaged monitor, the USB-C cable works with a inhabiting son

I initially wanted a larger screen for work and my first purchase was the LG UltraGear 34GP83A-B. That other monitor was terrible for reading any text, the resolution was only 1440. This one is at 2160. The colours are amazing and I can read the text. This monitor is great for the office, photos, videos etc. Games on it also look great but its only at 60 Hz, which is fine by me as my primary use is for the office.
Best in class for designers and 3D artists
Précision des couleurs et taille d'écran de haute qualité !

I chose this monitor because it had a very impressive feature set for a great price. I use it primarily for editing photos. Colour reproduction and resolution and good. Plastic housing could be a little more sturdy, but otherwise it is without criticism. I have used it for a while now, without any problems. Installation was very easy. Highly recommended

Der Monitor ist in allen Belangen top. Ich benutze ihn für die private Bildbearbeitung, und da gibt es echt nichts zu meckern. Ich kann ihn uneingeschränkt empfehlen. Für mich ist der Monitor mindestens genauso gut wie ein Eizo, der um einiges teurer ist. Ich kann das beurteilen, da ich auf der Arbeit den Eizo benutze. Von mir volle 5 Sterne!!!

I nearly returned this and replaced it with the BenQ PD3220U 32 inch given the hype and many youtube reviews for that display...until BenQ themselves confirmed that the PD3220U is an 8-bit + FRC configured display and NOT a true 10-bit one. As such, I did my due diligence and my pros and cons did not justify the $600+ price difference between this Viewsonic and the BenQ. I use a Herman Miller monitor arm and therefore have no need for the metal base of the BenQ PD3220U (base is metal and stand is plastic). Similarly, a built in KVM switch is a nice to have NOT a must have for me, and lastly, I'm not willing to shell out $1K+ for a display that would soon be outdated by IPS Black or 32 inch 5K offerings (crossed fingers).
In light of that, I've used Viewsonic CRT monitors at work in the 90s but this is the first one I've owned – so far so good (knock on wood). In my experience, the Colorpro VP3256-4K has features and capabilities that closely if not exceed that of the BenQ PD3220U for $600+ less. The only differences I've found between them so far are the built in KVM switch, metal base, and hockeypuck in the BenQ – all of which I could live without but your miles may vary. Good luck!

Easy to install, works very well. The control buttons are on the back, hard to reach.
The size description on the Amazon web did not include the overall height, only the monitor height, a problem for me as I have a book shelf over the monitor.

I ordered this because of 1 day delivery, although I ordered two of them at the same time and one hasn't shown up yet (one would think that Amazon would deliver both of them at the same time). I usually order ASUS ProArt or BenQ DesignVue monitors.

Pros:
- Excellent color rendition out of box (SDR only)
- Sharp (1440p @ 27")
- Bright with Uniform brightness throughout panel
- Good viewing angles
- Good ergonomics with included stand, including vertical orientation
- Good heft, not too light. Seems solidly built.
- OSD buttons easy to use with lots of customization
- You can turn off the Blue LED Power Button through the OSD (great for photo / video editing)
- Included Speakers are surprisingly good, better than most Laptop speakers (Good for small room)
- Included HMDI cable has Ferrite Cores on either end to reduce EMI/RF interference (Good for Unshielded Studio Monitors)
- Stand easy to install but has VESA mount for wall-mount or monitor arm applications

Cons:
- 8-bit Color
- 60hz Refresh
- Does not include DisplayPort or USB-C cable. (I am using with a Desktop, so I can't try the USB-C feature until Discrete Graphic Cards start including them)
- USB 3 ports on the bottom, also did not come with USB 3 hub cable
- Included Speakers aren't very loud (quieter than typical flat panel TV sound)
- Included Speakers do not replace Bookshelf / Studio Monitors by a large margin (this is a given but might as well write that out)
- Included stand is good, but it does wobble if you lean on the desk or type ferociously

Overall, I'm very satisfied with my purchase.

name: KOORUI 24 Inch Computer Monitor, FHD 1920 x 1080p Office PC Monitor IPS Display 75Hz, HDMI, VGA, 75 x 75 mm VESA Mountable, Frameless, Eye Protection and Ergonomic Tilt Adjustment
description:
• SHARE THE PANORAMIC VIEW : The 24 inch monitor adopts a new generation of IPS Display, covering 99% of the SRGB color gamut and 8bit gray level over 16.7M color numbers. Thus the computer monitor can 100% restore true colors and present vivid details. Besides, the 178° wide viewing angle of this pc monitor allows you to enjoy a clear, sharp, and delicate images at any angle.
  • EXTREMELY VIEWING COMFORT: Find your best viewing position and stay comfortable by tilting the screen up to 5 degrees forward or 15 degrees backward. Flicker-Free technology, Blue Light Filter, Adaptive FreeSync technology automatically calibrates frame rates so you can enjoy ultra-smooth gameplay or working for all-day without any eyes uncomfort.
  • ULTRA SLIM DESIGN: The desktop monitor dopts edgeless design to make the picture more complete when multiple monitors connect. A great choice of business display for desktop, or laptop at home.

This HDMI monitor is with 60Hz refresh rate (compatible with most normal graphics cards) and FHD 1920x1080p resolution. You can connect the edge-less monitor to Xbox, PC and laptops etc, transmitting high-quality images, any switch between office and entertainment.
  • RELIABLE MONITOR: KOORUI owns super strength from monitor quality to premium service, making you assured. With a 3-year warranty, a 12-month replacement service and calling technical support. If you find any damage, malfunction or missing accessories, please feel free to contact us.

reviews.review: It worked with VGA.

I have bought few 24 inches monitors off of Amazon, these are the best quality for such a low price. I am so impressed that I bought three of them. I did play with the settings a bit until I got the image i was looking for. I use them for work and tuned the settings to display text as best a possible.
Works well but no clear control identification.

I was skeptical about investing in a brand I had never heard of before. But now that I have been using it for work since about 2 months, I am happy with it. My eyes are happy too, there is no glare from it as such. Looks neat on my desk. I bought two of them for a dual screen setup.

Do note... my review is for office work only (excel, word, powerpoint etc). I have not watched any movies etc on these monitors, so I cannot comment about that.

Not the greatest, not the worst. Certainly for the price (I got on sale) pretty decent little monitor. Needed a third monitor for a tripple screen scenario of legacy and crypto trading mostly, so no heavy graphics involved but video's are clear without lag.

It's perfect for my basic needs of virtual meetings and admin work. Not a super high quality screen in terms of brightness but for the price, it's pretty awesome. I'm loving having a large monitor to see faces on zoom now. Easy set up too.

I have a P-series Dell monitor and also, a LG for the same size of the screen. Put against each other, this screen just comes a very tiny bit dimmer than those screens, you probably won't notice the difference
All that for 30%-40% less in price tag... There one Dell comes close to this price range is the low-end S series, but they have very thick bezel and did not have IPS panel
So this one is the best combo of budget price and good display
Of course if you don't mind the limited connection: 1 HDMI and 1 VGA (who would use VGA for this type of screen?). Wish it would have 1 Displayport intead...
But overall I am happy, and would probably purchase more if needed to make the Video Wall
Does what it supposed to do. Colours are good but do not pop. Surprised it didnt come with a protective film, as the screen has two small marks out of the box
The brightness is the only thing that’s a problem for me. Other than that, a great buy

I use a two screen setup for home office use. Bought these when one of my old Samsung monitors that was from 2011 bit the dust. Could have bought a used Samsung to replace it for $90 but figured I'd get two new ones instead, as the other Sansung was probably not too far behind. And it was a great decision. Old Samsungs were 22" and the aspect ratio was slightly different. These are more widescreen than my old ones.

Great image quality for business use. I spend most of my time in Excel and often have a spreadsheet open on one screen and either a pdf or other similar document in the other as my source data.

Doubt I'll get 12 years out of these like the old Samsungs (that were around $250ish each back then), but for the price they are hard to beat.
Simple basic monitors. Only draw back is the mount doors not adjust up and down for height just let’s you adjust angle of screen
the display is pretty good, the colors are well too with this price point. the side brezels are fantastic

If you are looking for the best bang for your buck, this is the monitor to buy. I knew I could get better picture quality by paying more, but for the price I am extremely happy with this monitor. If it is not right next to a higher quality IPS or OLED display you will never know or care. While picture quality could be better and it could be brighter, I give it 5 stars simply for the value!

name: Portable Monitor Touchscreen - 14'' FHD 1920x1200P USBC Portable Monitor HDR Eye Care Ultra-Slim IPS Display, USB Type-C HDMI External Monitor for Laptop/PC/Mac/Phone/Xbox, Built-in Kickstand
description:
• 【FHD Portable Monitor Touchscreen】14 inch touchscreen monitor equips with an Ultra HD 1920 x 1200P resolution at 60Hz, IPS panel, 16:10 aspect ratio, 400 cd/m² brightness, 100% sRGB color gamut, 178° viewing angle, support HDR, delivering a wider range of colors and greater level of contrast for an immersive viewing experience.
  • 【10-Point Capacitive Touchscreen Monitor】This portable laptop monitor features 10-point multi-touch capability and sensitive touch design, provides you with a more responsive and accurate touch screen experience, as well as frees you from the keyboard and wires.
  • 【Plug & Play USB-C Monitor】No need to install additional drivers, plug-and-play. Support single one USBC cable connection for display/touch/power functions. You can connect the 14'' monitor via one usb-c cable solution to your computer or laptop without any cumbersome settings.
  • 【Extensive Application】Akntzcs 14'' touchscreen external monitor with 2 fully functional USB Type-C ports, one HDMI port, a 3.5mm headphone jack and two built-in speakers, OTG USB Port could connect the mouse keyboard. Easily access to various devices with 1 cable solution, compatible with most laptop, PCs, desktops, PS4/PS5, Xbox Ones etc.
  • 【Built-in Speakers & Kickstand】The built-in back stand can be unfolded to create a workstation anywhere, perfect on the go. With the VESA wall mounting holes(75*75mm) on the back of the monitor, you can also fix it to a computer stand and adjust its position at will. Additionally, the dual built-in speakers on this device deliver crisp and clear audio, making it a great choice for media consumption.

reviews.review: This is my third portable monitor. Bought one early on and it broke within a year. Then got a higher end 2k 17 inch but it's a bit big and uses that stupid mini hdmi. This one has full size hdmi and a built in stand. It looks fantastic with my MacBook Pro 14 and it's light as hell. Wish it had a case or protective cover as I'm afraid it might get damaged in the case. But so far it's fantastic. Touch screen doesn't work that well with mac and iPad as a side note. It does accept touch, but missed some functionality. Like on iPad I can't select play or pause on a video but I can scroll up and down on a website. Still awesome though. Haven't tried with windows. Have a feeling it's probably better on windows and android.

The screen is actualy pretty good, suprised that its a touch screen as when you open it theres no mention of it in the packaging. Plug it in via USB C to a mac and both touch and display works well. I like that its fairly bright and the colors are not awful.
Overall very impressed and bought 2.
1 arrived with a factory defect but thanks to amazon returns its not much of an issue.

name: KOORUI 22 Inch Computer Gaming Monitor, FHD 1080P Desktop Display with 2 Speakers, 100HZ Ultra Thin Bezel/Eye Care/Ergonomic Tilt, HDMI VGA Ports LED Monitor for PC, VESA Mounting
description:
• [Screen Size] 21.45 inches [Panel type] VA [Maximum resolution] FHD (1920x1080) [Aspect ratio] 16:9 [Contrast ratio] 3000:1 [Brightness] 250nit [Color gamut] 99% sRGB [Other features] Tilt angle Adjustable (up and down -5 to 20°), equipped with a speaker, you can enjoy the sound.
  • [Features] High refresh rate of 100Hz and response speed of 4ms for smoother images. FreeSync technology is also installed (G-Sync compatible), and by synchronizing the refresh rate of the GPU and the display, you can achieve the best gaming experience without tearing, stuttering, or screen lag. It is the best gaming monitor for FPS/TPS and action games.
  • [Overwhelming Contrast Ratio] The KOORU S01, 21.5-inch gaming monitor uses a "VA panel" that has excellent light blocking properties and a clear black color, and has a much higher contrast ratio compared to TN and IPS panels. It is a panel that can be taken out.
  • [Data Interface] HDMI (1.4) x 1, VGA x 1, audio terminal, built-in speaker, VESA arm compatible (75x7mm) [Main accessories] HDMI cable (1.4), adapter, stand, instruction manual. [Dimensional Weight] WxHxD(mm): 495x394x181mm; [Weight] 3.61kg [Packing Dimensions] WxHxD(cm): 558x379x122mm; [Power Consumption] 12V2A
  • [Warranty/Support] [3-year warranty] With a 3-year warranty service, the screen may not be displayed if the export signal source is improperly installed or the signal cable is improperly connected. If you have any problems or questions about the product, please feel free to contact us even on Saturdays and Sundays.

reviews.review:
I was looking for a quick and easy monitor that I could grab for work and this delivered basically next day.

Pros:
Relatively easy setup, good high quality visual. For basic office work solid option. Color correction not 100% so not the greatest for graphic artwork.

Cons:
The base and stand is a little tricky to connect to the actual monitor. I would recommend connecting the stand first before adding the base. There is a metal plate on the back of the monitor and you have to be very careful sliding it in, make sure it's at the bottom and you push forward all the way. Much easier when the monitor is laying flat on a surface.
I only used it for work and for that price, I think that this is a great monitor. It came packaged well and it comes with a HDMI cable as well.

I'm pleased with the monitor itself but I purchased this to save hooking up a second set of speakers. This is for a secondary computer in the office. Monitor is bright and clear. Many settings available for viewing if you want to reduce glare etc. Speakers are very tinny sounding so I usually keep the sound off. Since I bought this specifically to have use of the speaker function it's a bit disappointing.

Je l’adore !
Couleurs très belles
Livraison rapide
working
Needed a smaller monitor for extend DAW mixer view, it’s just right

I bought this item once, and was really happy with it, I bought a second time, product still good but screen color was not as vibrant as the first monitor i received. I tried changing every color setting on the monitor. I use the second one (i purchased) as my dual monitor and there is a noticeable difference.
Satisfied with the screen size, color and clarity. Speaker is good enough on this monitor.

Great for my personal needs.
If you are getting a monitor like this, high refresh rate and higher than FHD don't forget to double check your settings. I've seen a couple reviews that I think could have been solved by double checking this.

But on to the monitor itself. It's great! Bought it at ~$170 USD. Played games at double the quoted refresh rate and also at 30 fps. I haven't seen any ghosting, though this can happen apparently I may have just been very lucky so far. Refresh rates are great, playing Valorant, CSGO, and Apex hasn't been an issue. Losing gun fights in any of those games have been my own fault and not having hardware lag behind and my reactions not being able to quickly adjust.

If you aren't playing competitive games and are more looking for a media consumption tool or prioritize picture quality and color accuracy this probably won't be the panel for you. There are better options out there for that specific purpose but if you like to game and consume content this is a great bang for the buck monitor.

1 small gripe I would have, but I understand for the price point it can't really be helped is that the monitor stand that comes with it isn't height adjustable.
Not a big deal if you are planning on Vesa mounting it but something worth noting.

Also if you are planning on using this monitor and having sound out there are no on board speakers. Not an issue if you are planning on using headphones or have desk speakers but I have seen other reviews saying they were disappointed at the lack of them. So i figure I'd point that out if you were expecting them.

Overall for I'd recommend this monitor to anyone who needs a great budget gaming monitor. Like I said just make sure to double check your settings, on the monitor and on your PC, when you first plug it in.

I got two of these to be the "wingmen" for a 27" Dell U2719 I've had for some years. I wanted a triple monitor setup with the Dell centered, but I have a small desk, so larger monitors were going to overhang the desk sides and cause problems. These Koorui monitors are possibly the narrowest 21.5" monitor you can buy.

I can report that these are more than adequate, and raise that to fantastic given the price! Comparing them to a Dell Ultrasharp is hardly fair, but they're so close for day-to-day office productivity that I really don't notice. Another bonus is the PPI of 21.5" FHD to 27" WQHD is nearly identical. If you understood that, then you know why I think it's great. 😉

So, the nitpicks:

- kinda crappy blackpoint; would not recommend for movies or production graphics work
- the VESA mount area is flat at the bottom holes, and curved at the top ones; this means you will have to shim with spacers (I used three nylon washers at each of the top holes) if your VESA mount needs zero pressure to rotate correctly
- while these have speakers, they're an afterthought: you get what you pay for here

Overall, a superb value for adding some real estate, and a totally acceptable main monitor if you are on a tight budget.

I live on a sailboat with 12v power as most efficient options, so was looking for a decent inexpensive monitor that had a "brick" that provided 110v to 12v conversion. We eliminated the brick and wire the monitor direct to our 12v circuit breakers. The 12v plug needed seems to be fairly standard as I had previously bought 10 of them to use for other projects. I am NOT gaming or doing any high resolution color-critical work. The screen seems good and the price was outstanding. Though, wish it had built-in speakers. Shipped it to Malaysia where we were and it arrived intact. Amazon handled the duty and paperwork required to get it thru Malaysian Customs without any work on our part.

My monitor is used for for everything from Word Processing, Spreadsheets, Web Browsing, Streaming Video and occasional Gaming. I have found this monitor works great for me for all these tasks. Let me state that I am not a big time gamer. It allows me enough room and resolution to multitask and enjoy watching a lot of streaming video. I have used many monitors and this is my first curved one and I really like it. Great color, contrast and resolution and brightness....the overall clarity is great and for what I do and I like the 2K resolution. I had never heard of a Koorui monitor before, but took a chance on it because of price and features. So far after a couple of months of use I am very happy with it and only time will prove out its durability. Based on my experience so far I would recommend it to others looking for a nice reasonably priced monitor.

Tengo que admitir que tenía miedo que el producto llegara roto, pues una pantalla de monitor es muy delicada. Sin embargo, el producto llegó muy bien protegido, la instalación es clara y sencilla (sin necesidad de tornillos) e incluye un cable HDMI de poco más de un metro. Al principio tenía la impresión de que la pantalla era muy brillante, pero creo que esto se debe a que estoy acostumbrado a utilizar pantallas con muy poco brillo.

name: waveshare 4.3inch DSI Display 800 x 480, IPS Screen, Compatible with Raspberry Pi 4B/3B+/3A+/3B/2B/B+/A+, Compute Module3/3+/Compute Module 4 (No Touch)
description:
• 4.3inch IPS Display, 800 × 480 hardware resolution. DSI Display Interface. IPS Display Panel,160° Viewing Angle.
  • Support Pi4B/3B+/3A+/3B/2B/B+/A+, some CM3/3+/4 expansion board need a DSI-Cable.
  • Directly drive the LCD via the DSI port of the Raspberry Pi, and the refreshing rate is up to 60Hz.
  • When working with Raspberry Pi, it supports Raspberry Pi OS/Ubuntu/Kali and Retropie, and is driver-free.
  • Support software backlight adjustment, saving more power.

name: ViewSonic 15.6 Inch 1080p Portable OLED Monitor with 2 Way Powered 60W USB C, Pantone Validated, Factory Calibrated, Built in Ergonomic Stand with Protective Cover (VP16-OLED), Black
description:
• ULTRA-PORTABLE: With a weight of 2 lbs and a thickness of .8 in, this 15.6 in portable monitor slips easily into backpacks and purses.
  • BETTER VISUALS: Enjoy a premium viewing experience with an OLED screen. Experience true-to-life color reproduction, enhanced contrast and brighter images.
  • PANTONE VALIDATED & FACTORY CALIBRATED: The VP16-OLED has been rigorously tested and deemed capable of reproducing the Pantone Matching System colors for creative professionals.
  • 2-WAY POWERED USB-C: With dual USB-C Ports, the VP16-OLED can deliver data, audio, video and power over a single cable, with laptops able to power monitors via two-way power.
  • FLEXIBLE CONNECTIVITY: The VP16-OLED supports laptops, PCs and Apple/Mac operating systems with Micro HDMI and USB-C inputs.
  • INCLUDED IN THE BOX: Portable monitor with cover, power adapter, Micro HDMI cable, USB-C to USB-C cable, USB-C to USB-A cable and quick start guide.
  • Item weight: 2.2 pounds

reviews.review:
This 1080p VP16-OLED portable monitor is nearly perfect, but it does have a few minor annoyances. One great feature is that it can be powered using only a single Type-C cable, either via USB-A or the included power brick. The stand and hinges are solid and can be placed at multiple angles, and for gaming the screen can be rotated to TATE mode using the stand, very convenient. It's very lightweight, making it easy to use as a portable, table/shelf, camper monitor. The screen cover is made of a good quality, velour-like material, but the flaps can be inconvenient to fold in place. It's held in place with magnetic clips and does a good job of protecting the screen, but it takes some time with manipulation.

I like using this monitor for gaming in FPS2 view mode, as the colors look great on it. Retro gaming and Switch games look good on this OLED screen, although some gaming emulation devices with 720p output may fit better once overscan is turned on. One issue I've noticed is that when the color format is set to auto, it sometimes selects the full color range when it should be set to limited. This only happens with some devices, and you may need to be on the lookout to manually set the color format to full or limited to avoid greyish blacks. The power button and indicator are located on the side of the monitor, and the indicator is set to off by default (If I remember correctly). I think it would be more useful if it was set to on, so you could easily see if the monitor is powered on.

The integrated speakers are convenient, but don't have great sound quality as expected. The audio jack is weak, but useful to have. I can't speak to the Pentone validated colors, but out of the box I think this screen will be very appreciated for photo/video professionals who care about color accuracy, as long as 1080p is sufficient for their needs. The screen is very bright and should be usable outdoors. Overall, I would rate this lovely monitor an 8.5 out of 10, but it's really an 5-star amazon product.

Great screen, very good design, amazing screen for gaming and mobility, but limited to the native FHD resolution.

I hope this review helps anyone considering purchasing this kind of portable OLED screen.

Some info from the official specifications:
LCD Type: LTPS TFT active matrix
Color filter: RGB stripe
Glass surface: Anti-glare (Haze 25%), Hard coating (3H)
Color format: RGB (limited/full) YUV (limited/full)
Color mode: DCI-P3, sRGB, REC709, DICOM-SIM, User
View mode: CAD/CAM, Video Edit, Animation, Photo, FPS1, FPS2, RTS, Moba.

The screen itself is amazing - I'd say, better than most OLED laptop screens. I think it's better than the OLED on the Dell XPS13 as well as the I have a Dell and Lenovo Yoga 9i. It's on par with the Samsung Tab OLEDs, which are my favourite screens in this size range. The brightness (and obviously, contrast) is amazing. I'm not sure why Amazon wants me to rate the touch screen, since there isn't one :)

I have some design quibbles, though.

The bottom lip is really large, and the "Viewsonic" label on it is a bit obnoxiously prominent. The folding stand is pretty good; in my opinion, better than Asus ones, with the magnetic folding sleeve). However, I find the controls in the wrong place, since you can't access them, if you fold so that isn't elevated. Also, in portrait mode, you're pretty limited in the angles you can use it at.

I do not like that you can't attach it to a stand/tripod (as presented) without using a supplied adapter nut that protrudes from the bottom. Also, there is no possibility for putting this on a VESA or other mount.

I’ve only been using this monitor for a couple of days so granted it holds up and doesn’t develop any issues, this review will stand.

This is probably the best 60hz monitor of this size I’ve ever used. The colors are vibrant and accurate. The menu is easy to navigate. It’s super lightweight but also solid in build quality. It’s a 10/10. If viewsonic ever decides to make another one of these @ 120hz with gsync support, I will happily pick that one up too.

Right now I’m using this for gaming for my desktop while I wait for new 240hz OLEDs to release next year. After that I’ll use it specifically for video color work. The color is accurate enough that I’d use it for professional work. It’s not as accurate as a professional color monitor but it’s also 320 dollars, not 10,000 dollars.

I’d recommend this for anyone who is okay with 60hz. If you have a beefy graphics card, NVidia DSR looks phenomenal here and you’ll have a hard time distinguishing between this with DSR vs native 4k at this small of a size.

Easier to point out what isn't excellent here.

-1080p: As I was comparing it with an equally sized and overkill 4k monitor, there are some elements that are a little unsharp. 2k would have been perfect, and I'd have paid more for it. (If usb-c power permitted I suppose)
-The stand is wobbly and the monitor will move if whatever surface it's on is bumped.
-The preset profiles are a tad desaturated for my taste, and you can't alter that setting without making a "user" profile from scratch.

And that's it, everything unlisted is as good as you could possibly want from a one-cable portable oled.

I have multiple portable monitors. I have been disappointed in brightness and the "set up." By that I mean a lot of the way the portable monitors stand up are flimsy and difficult to maneuver. The stand on this one is the bomb!!! The color and brightness on this is the bomb. I don't game, so I haven't really looked at refresh rates, since I primarily use this for work when I travel, or when I just want to sit out on the patio with 2 screens. I actually bought this one for my husband because the perfect monitor we purchased for him is just not bright enough. I will be replacing my current portable monitor with another one of these. There are only a couple of things that could be improved: 1) touchscreen - but I don't know if that is possible with oled 2) I could do without the "hood", so I actually just snipped that part off to make it only a magnetic cover for protection when traveling. Otherwise, it is a wonderful portable monitor.

Using it alone side of my laptop as an external monitor. My Acer Concept D5 4k laptop monitor comes w/o any screen tuning software.

The external monitor comes with nice preset available w/o any software—you can access them from the build in screen’s menu. Plus, ViewSonic provides some software for advanced settings.

All that helps with alining color profile of laptop’s screen and the external monitor.

It’s an OLED monitor.

The only downside (besides the price) I could notice—the overall resolution. By looking at the 1k and 4k screens next to each other you can tell a huge difference. For such price it should be 2k quality.

This review covers the VP16-OLED. I found that all of the Viewsonic reviews are jumbled together.

Like:
Almost everything. The screen is spectacular. It's OLED, so black is incredibly black.
Inputs work well. I was able to connect all of my Macs (M1 Mac Air, M1 Mac Pro 14", 2016 Mac Pro 13") to this display using USB-C and power the display. NOTE THAT IT'S IMPORTANT TO USE THE RIGHT USB-C CABLE. This monitor was also able to power my Macs when connecting power to the monitor.
The HDMI port also works well. I was able to connect a Roku and watch TV.
Dislike:
The reason it got 4 stars rather than 5 is changing the volume requires diving into the menus. It's annoying, but considering the overall quality of the monitor, it's acceptable.
It would also be nice if the volume can be controlled through the HDMI interface. Then the Roku or FireStick interface would be able to change the volume.

Overall, this is a good purchase and perfect for taking on the road with me.

name: ViewSonic VP2456 24 Inch 1080p Premium IPS Monitor with Ultra-Thin Bezels, Color Accuracy, Pantone Validated, HDMI, DisplayPort and USB C for Professional Home and Office
description:
• PREMIUM MONITOR: This FHD (1920x1080p) advanced ergonomic 60Hz IPS monitor delivers lifelike colors perfect for office workers, graphic design, photographers and more
  • PANTONE VALIDATED DISPLAY: The VP2456 has been rigorously tested and deemed capable of reproducing Pantone Matching System colors for professionals.
  • EXCEPTIONAL COLOR ACCURACY: Enjoy 100% sRGB, EBU, SMPTE-C, Rec. 709, Delta E<2 accuracy and a color palette of 16.7 million colors for precise, lifelike images.
  • SINGLE-CABLE SOLUTION: Reduce clutter with a single USB-C cable that delivers data, audio, video and rapid 60W charging for smartphones and laptops
  • USB HUB: Plug in peripherals like USB drives and mice directly into your monitor with an integrated USB hub.
  • AMAZING AT ANY ANGLE: A three-sided ultra-thin bezel shows off more of what you make and less of the monitor.
  • FLEXIBLE CONNECTIVITY: The VP2456 supports laptops, PCs and Apple/Mac operating systems with HDMI 1.4, USB-C, USB-A/B and DisplayPort inputs.
  • INCLUDED IN THE BOX: LCD monitor, power cable, USB-C cable, HDMI cable, USB-A/B cable and Quick Start guide.

reviews.review: Display size is very good and needed for your office use. Black color looks very rich in office as well as home office setup environment. Sound quality is very good. It has app which you install on laptop to control all its features. It’s value for money investment.

The Thermaltake Smart 700W 80+ White Certified PSU is great when it comes to delivering consistent and reliable power to your computer. As a PC enthusiast, I was on the hunt for a power supply unit (PSU) that could handle my rig's demands, without breaking the bank.

80+ White Certified Efficiency:

Ultra Quiet Operation:
One of the most impressive features of this PSU is its ultra-quiet 120mm fan. Even during intense gaming sessions or resource-heavy tasks, the fan operates silently. It maintains a cool temperature within the PSU, ensuring long-term reliability without adding unwanted noise to your PC.

Multiple Connectors and Protection Features:
The PSU comes with an array of connectors, including PCIe, SATA, and Molex, allowing for versatile connectivity with various components. Additionally, it offers over-voltage and short-circuit protection, ensuring the safety of your components in the event of power fluctuations or surges.

Compact and Easy Installation:
The Thermaltake Smart PSU is designed to be compact and easy to install in standard ATX cases. The connectors are well-labeled and user-friendly, making it a hassle-free experience for both novice and experienced builders.

Competitive Price:
The competitive pricing of this PSU is a significant selling point. It offers high-quality performance and reliability without breaking the bank, making it an attractive choice for those on a budget.

In conclusion, the Thermaltake Smart 700W 80+ White Certified PSU is a fantastic choice for anyone in need of a reliable and efficient power supply for their PC build. La Nvidia GeForce GTX 1660 6GB de EVGA es una tarjeta gráfica de gama media diseñada para ofrecer un rendimiento de juego sólido y confiable sin romper el banco. Con su capacidad de 6GB de memoria GDDR5, esta tarjeta ofrece una cantidad adecuada de memoria para manejar juegos modernos de alta calidad, mientras que su arquitectura de Turing proporciona un aumento significativo en el rendimiento en comparación con las generaciones anteriores.

La GTX 1660 de EVGA cuenta con una velocidad de reloj base de 1530 MHz y una velocidad de reloj turbo de 1785 MHz, lo que significa que puede ofrecer una experiencia de juego fluida y sin problemas en la mayoría de los juegos modernos. Además, esta tarjeta es compatible con tecnologías avanzadas de juego, como la sombra de tasa variable (VRS) y la tecnología de trazado de rayos en tiempo real, lo que le permite ofrecer una experiencia de juego impresionante sin comprometer el rendimiento.

Una de las características más destacadas de la GTX 1660 de EVGA es su diseño compacto y de bajo perfil, lo que la hace perfecta para sistemas de juego más pequeños y con limitaciones de espacio. Además, el diseño de enfriamiento personalizado de EVGA con dos ventiladores ofrece una excelente disipación del calor y un rendimiento silencioso, lo que la hace ideal para sesiones de juego prolongadas.

En resumen, la Nvidia GeForce GTX 1660 6GB de EVGA es una excelente tarjeta gráfica para jugadores que buscan una experiencia de juego sólida y confiable a un precio asequible. Su diseño compacto, tecnología avanzada de juego y excelente rendimiento hacen que esta tarjeta sea una opción recomendable para aquellos que buscan construir un sistema de juego de alta calidad sin tener que gastar una fortuna.
