Otra característica impresionante de la B460M AORUS PRO es su diseño de enfriamiento avanzado, que incluye múltiples ventiladores y disipadores térmicos para mantener la temperatura de la placa base a niveles óptimos. Esto es especialmente importante para aquellos que buscan construir un sistema de juego de alta calidad que pueda manejar sesiones de juego prolongadas.

En cuanto a la durabilidad, la B460M AORUS PRO ha sido diseñada con componentes de alta calidad que han sido probados y certificados para cumplir con los estándares más exigentes. Esto significa que esta placa base es capaz de resistir una amplia variedad de desafíos y mantener un rendimiento óptimo a largo plazo.

En resumen, si estás buscando una placa base duradera, confiable y con excelentes prestaciones, la Gigabyte B460M AORUS PRO es una excelente opción. Con su diseño sólido, capacidad para manejar una gran cantidad de RAM DDR4 de alta velocidad y su sistema de enfriamiento avanzado, esta placa base es ideal para aquellos que buscan construir un sistema de juego de alta calidad y rendimiento duradero.

Nicolás Galvis

I recently picked up this PSU for my secondary PC, and I'm pretty happy with it. First off, installation was a breeze. The cables were all long enough to reach where I needed them, and I didn't have any issues plugging everything in.

This power supply is non-modular, which might be a downside for some people, but honestly, it didn't matter to me. The simple, straightforward design was just what I needed, and it saved me some cash compared to the fancier modular options out there. Another note is the colorful cables kinda stand out, but I don't care about the internal aesthetic of my PC.

For PSUs I'm all about sticking to trusted brands, and Thermaltake is good enough. It's a solid, no-frills power supply that does its job quietly and efficiently. If you're looking for a simple and reliable solution on a budget, I'd definitely recommend this over some no-name brand. It's a good pick for anyone who wants quality without breaking the bank.

ya tengo casi 1 año y medio usando esta fuente y la verdad no me ha generado ningún problema, pero no tengo componentes que generen mucho gasto de energia, asi que si tienes un pc de entrada o con especificaciones no tan potentes puede que te sirva, pero no la recomido para pcs mas potentes

reviews.review: Great product for the money.
Ma carte-mére ne décolle plus après 3 mois!

Described as cosmetic mechanical damage+packaging damaged. Worse than described. Regrettably one of 4 SATA connectors was severely damaged, the red & yellow wires with their crimped connectors had been pulled out of the housing & are damaged enuff that the connector cannot be reassembled, therefore is useless. I will be seeking a partial refund as "return & reorder" is impractical, its made in China. I will hav to purchase a SATA connector & splice it into the wiring harness. Disapointing. Usually warehouse deals are accurately described & a good way to keep things out of landfill.

Needed a cheap PSU, I got it.
I wanted a quiet PSU. I got it.
I looked for a cheap PSU. I found it.
I didn't want junk. I don't believe I got it.
Satisfied.
This power supply worked well, though a couple of the wire harnesses were a bit too short to go around the motherboard and video card. But the price was right

Bought this to replace an FSP 300W model 60THA. I was skeptical but decided to take a chance given the very low price.
Pleased to see it had exactly the same 24 pin connector for the motherboard with all the same color (voltage) wires as the FSP from my Acer TC780. The 4 pin connector for the board was slightly confusing as it appeared to be an 8 pin connector instead. That may be the reason this is described as a 12 volt supply. Ignore that description. The 8 pin connector is actually TWO connectors side by side. I only needed half of that and they were easily separated and had the correct yellow and black wires. The other connectors for my two hard drives are standard.
Yes, the fan makes a little noise, but I had a Dell computer in the 90s that made 3 times as much noise.
Overall, great value for the money and happy to have my computer running again.

Standard ATX, stays pretty cool, but definitely noisier than expected. Takes up to a minute for it to calm down from full RPM, no clue why? Hit up Canada Computers for a lightning deal & replaced with an EVGA for just under $1 pricier & it's silent. For the price the unit isn't really worth it. For me the only use will be to shove it in an old 2005-2008 refurbishment project.
Seems to be working well

Needed something to revive an old Optiplex. Used Dell PSUs were more expensive whereas you could get this new for $20 with free Prime shipping. So of course I went with this.

There are things to like about it. Namely, it works. And that's about it.

But if you will, let me go off about this specific PSU.

For starters, it's crazy seeing through-hole components used throughout the PSU. Absolutely no SMDs. This is like an early 2000's design but being sold as completely new in the 2020's. I didn't go as deep but I have a feeling everything on the board was hand-soldered. Heck, you still need to select the input voltage on the back still. Pretty old-school.
The heatsinks for the MOSFETs might as well be stamped out of aluminum soda cans, that's how thin they are. I'm surprised they can dissipate heat well enough for this PSU's 400W rating, which leads me to my next point.
This PSU is rated for 400W of output, 300W of which is for the +12V rail. The sticker on the side of the PSU rates the input as 12A at 115V. What that means is at full tilt, the PSU needs 1380W! That's absolutely insane! While I dare not want to find out if that's true, I have a feeling the paltry heatsinks I mentioned would probably be melting at that point, even with the 80 mm fan in the PSU. Speaking of which...
On the box, the fan is mentioned as a "80mm silent design" which is honestly laughable. The fan itself has no label or identification marks at all, and the quality of it sets the lowest bar of what could be considered a "fan". It operates at only a single speed: loud. But it definitely needs a fan because, well...
The efficiency is pretty low. While not a scientific test, I compared this PSU to another PSU with a known efficiency curve and placed it in an identical system. From my own calculations, this PSU struggles to hit 75% efficiency and it only drops from there (hopefully not to the 29% you can calculate from above). You can tell this PSU gets warm after decent use.
The wires are unsubstantial and thin, but they do connect things. Makes it pretty easy to cable manage actually so that's a small plus.
Finally, the casing. I think those metal tin cans that grandma's cookies come in are thicker than what encloses all these angry pixies. No, scratch that, these are sad pixies because I know I'd be one if I had the misfortune of being routed through this box.

But as much as I rag on this PSU, for $20, it does the job. And if you find yourself needing a new PSU but want to put the least amount of investment into it, well, here you go.

4 stars.

I'm writing this review to give my experience with this product. My experience was better than many other reviewers here. I am replacing an older 300 watt PSU in an HP tower. I found that the PSU case was very light weight and fit properly in the space available. The wires were long enough to to fit everywhere I needed them. I have a SATA DVD drive, IDE CD rom drive, SATA SSD, SATA HDD and a legacy IDE HDD, a SATA SD Card reader module, along with several cooling fans. I was able to connect everything to the power supply properly. Some reviewers stated there were not enough plugs, or the wires were not long enough, and that the SATA power plugs did not fit. I did not have any problems at all with my plugs fitting. I can't vouch for the longevity of this unit yet, but at this point I would recommend this as a value replacement for an older PC you are not ready to replace yet.

apparently ATX and Micro ATX are 2 different sizes. I needed to replace a Micro ATX power supply and kept choosing the larger ATX based on the image of the product. Finally got it right and book marked it for the future.

The fan on my old HP P7-1110 started making a very loud noise so I needed to replace the power supply. I chose to do this rather than just replace the fan out of ease of repair. I searched a lot on-line and had a lot of trouble trying to find something that I felt would fit the old unit. This Coolmax description said it was kind of universal, so for 20 bucks I figured I would give it a try. There were both very positive and very negative reviews so I was not sure what to expect.
As far as Amazon, somehow they managed to get it to me in a day, even though they are way backed up with holiday shopping, so thank you Amazon for great service.
After opening the box the power supply came in, I was a bit surprised to find no written instructions or any documentation at all. There was the power supply and a power cord; that's it.
I removed the old power supply from the computer casing but left all the wiring attached to it. Then I put the new unit in to see how it would fit. It was just about a perfect fit, except the A/C cord is in a different location, which was partially blocked by a piece of metal on the PC casing. I used a rotary tool to remove a bit of the metal that was in the way and then the new power supply fit with no issues.
After screwing it in place, I removed the wiring from the old power supply to the mother board, and replaced them with the wiring from the new power supply. I only had a total of 3 connections I needed to move so not too bad.
I plugged the computer in and the thing powered up no problem. So I unplugged it, zip ties the wires and replaced the cover to the computer. After setting it up again with the monitor, keyboard, etc., I started the computer up and it all worked fine.
The only issue I am not totally satisfied with is the noise of the fan. It seems to be blowing a lot more than the old unit. Of course, this is a 500 watt, replacing a 250 watt power supply. I simply couldn't find an exact replacement, as the computer is probably around 8 years old.
Other than the noise from the fan, so far everything is working fine. For the price I paid, I guess I should not complain. However, I did want to point it out so if someone is ordering this unit, they would know what to expect.
Simple and easy replacement. Worked perfectly. Don't forget to turn on the switch on the back! My tower has a separate power button but this item needs to be turned on as well.

reviews.review: Travail bien.

First off let me say that I picked this up as a warehouse deal for a few extra bucks off.

This is an EVGA unit and I have heard nothing but good things about them in the past and have used a 500w white model similar to this to replace a shoddy retail plus power supply in a friends computer - he has no complaints!

Seems solidly built, the sleeved cables are nice and I can’t foresee any issues going forward based on the reputation of the brand alone. I fairness I may follow up on this once all of the parts for this build show up and the machine is completed.

While I got a deal on the psu it came without the power supply power cable (luckily I have a few extra) and one of the retainer hook tabs for the 4 +4 cpu power plug was broken off when I opened the box.

Again this fairly minor in the grand scheme of things where I got it for a few bucks off but it could have been annoying if I had to run out and buy a new power cable and probably more expensive than if I had purchased a new unit for full price.
Never had any issues with EVGA, PSU’s or gpu’s. Solid make and works great.

Needed a new PSU for a PC I was refurbing in order to work with the GPU that was to go in it.
Normally I'd opt for something with at least an 80+ Bronze rating, but one from a reputable brand can be kinda expensive, so instead based on my, and others, experiences with EVGA, I opted for this budget option.

At first glance it looked decent build quality, felt fairly solidly built in hand but still a bit cheap. Everything even checked out fine when testing with my 24-pin PSU jumper, fan spun up which normally means it's all good.
Got everything installed inside the 2010 HP Pavilion Elite's awful mini-ATX case, and did the best cable management I could, despite it being cramped and having nowhere to hide the cables.
Made sure it was plugged into the outlet, flipped on the PSU, pressed the power switch and... Nothing. Tried reseating all the cables, still nothing.
I knew it couldn't be the components here, since from prior testing they were still working fine and 550W should've been more than enough for a Phenom II 1090T and R9 280X powered PC.

As a last ditch attempt, I thought since I used only one of the SATA power cables for both the SSD and Blu-ray drive as is normal, maybe I could try using both of the included cables, one for each drive.
Surprisingly, that actually fixed it and now it's working perfectly fine. Still not looking good for the PSU though, as any decent quality PSU should be able to handle at least a few daisy chained SATA peripherals, but it looks like this one can't.
At least now that it's working, I can say it does handle the overall system perfectly fine, while also running both very cool and quiet under load.

As much as I'm willing to endorse EVGA's more mainstream products though, I'm afraid I just can't really recommend this one. It's not bad, but it's still not good either. It's just okay.

When I replace the power supply I invariably check the weight. A good power supply is a heavy power supply and this is a good solid unit with a satisfying solidity. Once installed it ran so quietly that the cooling fans in the computer completely masked what little noise it added! Very happy with it, and plenty of “juice” on tap!
I bought this on July 2021, and it officially died on Sept 2023. For what I paid I guess... it is okay... However kinda disappointed on how long it lasted...
I cannot put a 5 stars for easy to install, as it wasn’t easy to install, but it wasn’t harder than another model, so I will still give it 5 stars. No issues here.

My new build is not very power hungry so I went for a lower cost PS. But, I had to return the first one I got as it was faulty. Following a conversation with a EVGA tech the first I got was not providing all the power it was supposed to. The second one works well and all is good. For a higher end build I would definitely recommend a Bronze or higher PS. I'm not much of a gamer so this one is more than enough for me. And thank you Amazon for an easy painless return process.

While playing MSFS 2020, my screen went black, the computer shut down, and my 750w Solid Gear ATX12V/EPS12V psu set off a spark, before I could unplug from outlet. Purchased from Amazon back in Feb 2015, for $35 ! So, I think I got my money's worth. Anyway, I decided to go with EVGA. The 750-N1 is just a basic psu. No frills, no modular connectors, no lights or RGB. But, the wires are sleeved (black) it's built by a reputable company, and it works. A+
needed a decent psu for my rtx card, so far so good for the 750w, i don't like those ketchup mustard color cables, i prefer all black cables and this does the job. lets see how long this will work.
The cpu power cable could stand to be a little longer but otherwise I haven't had anyt issues with with it.

It has everything you need to install. It runs smooth and low noise. Great vaule

Good
It comes with white cables, instant 5 stars.

I don't really have PSU testing tools, so I defer any serious considerations to them, but this model does have a lot of shining reviews by those who do have the tools (though of course reviews have to always be taken with a grain of salt. Or a whole shaker even these days.)

What I can tell is that it has all the outward signs of a quality PSU. It's quite hefty for its size, seems to have a good fan, etc etc. When I measure things like voltage via software (not sure how reliable that is, but it's the best I have,) they seem to be more stable than my previous PSUs.

One curiosity I don't really know how to explain is it has an extra relay inside doing who knows what. When you first turn things on, it's already able to handle the full power draw of the computer, so it's not like it's a low power switch for suspending or something -- it's straight to 100% before the relay even switches. I'm wondering if it switches on a capacitor after initial startup pull to handle power blinks and the like while avoiding that huge sudden instant draw you'd normally get, but this is merely a guess.

All in all I'm very much liking it. It's a tiny bit more compact to also work with smaller systems, but also fits fine in my mid tower (these days I guess that's considered a full tower, lol.) The modular cables work fairly well, though I wish the parts that can be put together or pulled apart (like the CPU power connector) snapped together more firmly so you don't have to carefully hold them together while inserting. I was pleasantly surprised it even included the latest 12VHPWR type-4 connector.

I guess if I had to try to choose something to complain about, I wish the power efficiency curve was a bit friendlier towards the low end. Most people aren't actually using anywhere near to 850 watts of power (a lot of people would be very shocked if they plugged their computers into a Kill-a-Watt or similar meter!) For most people normal usage and light gaming is easily going to fall into the bottom side of the curve and get somewhere in the vicinity of 75% efficiency. Ideally one would pick a PSU that more aligns with what the system actually uses (taking care to ensure sufficient current of course) but I can say I picked this one because I needed a PSU I could keep for many years to come and pretty much not even have to think about it no matter what I added to my system (within reason of course. I'm not likely to be adding any of the highest end CPUs or GPUs and especially not dual GPUs which is where one is most likely to start to actually get up to numbers closer to 850.)

I think most people will never come even close to fully utilizing this PSU making it a great option for a huge variety of systems (albeit at the cost of some efficiency loss for most.) From what I can tell I think we can count on it to hold up over time. Even the fan should be decent enough to not die too easily. Especially since most of the time on systems that aren't pushing it really hard the fan runs extremely quietly at a lower RPM.

reviews.review: Alimentation puissante et silencieuse, facile a installer avec les cables qui se debranchent de sorte que l'on utilise uniquement les câbles dont on a besoin dans la tour.

Overall, the Corsair RM1000x is a decent power supply unit (PSU) that comes at a relatively good price, especially if you can find it on sale. The sleek design and quiet fan operation are pluses, and the thick, durable cables indicate good build quality. However, there are a few drawbacks to consider.

Ease of installation may be a challenge, particularly if you have a smaller case. The cables are stiff and not flat, which can make cable management difficult, and they may not fit through smaller case holes or leave enough clearance to put the back panel back on. However, the cables are wrapped in mesh to help protect them, and once you get them plugged in, they are unlikely to break.

Speaking of the cables, the marketing images are misleading when it comes to the number of PCIe cables that come with the unit. Corsair should update the product descriptions to match the actual number of cables. The RM1000x comes with 3 PCIe cables that terminate in 2 8 pins for a total of 6 8 pin PCIe connections (Though for the newer GPUs it is advised to not use the additional 8 pin), And the RM850x comes with 2 PCIe cables that terminate in 2 8 pins as well for a total of 4 8 pin connections.

In terms of price, the RM1000x is a good value, especially if you can find it on sale. At the time of purchase, it was the cheapest name-brand 80+ Gold rated PSU available. Additionally, the warranty period is very decent, which adds to the overall value.

In conclusion, the Corsair RM1000x is a solid PSU with a few drawbacks to consider. If you have a larger case and don't mind dealing with stiff cables, this PSU is a good option. The build quality is high, and the price is reasonable, especially when on sale.
It works, that's all it needs to do. The modular cables work great - one criticism is that it only has 2 PCI cables, you'll need a 3rd if you're going to hook up a high-end video card.

My RM850x was starting to be a little limited, if you already have an RMx don't go for an RMe you will be very disappointed, the new connection system on the side is really very good, it makes the work a lot easier, on the other hand I think that it is not suitable for all cases, it comes with the new type 5 cable, the connectors which go to the power supply are smaller and the cables are easier to bend
Très silencieux fière de mon achat.

Brand is a decent quality, price was fair but slightly high for me. It was however cheaper then the lower wattage ones at the date of purchase so I got the 1000 watt when i could of been fine with a 750 watt. Does what it needs to and was a pretty generic install. wires seem to be of decent quality and seem to clip in firm as most brands do. Cannot go wrong with this powerhouse.
For Gaming

The fan is not moving unless I am doing some cpu or gpu stress test. It may be good for some quiet build but my other fans are loud Af. This battery is the only warm spot in my pc during gaming. I need it to spin to take the heat out of my case before it accumulating heat.

This is a great quality product from well-known reputable company, a PSU with great modularity and great performance, and frankly a good value. Lots of connectors and on the shift model, if that's what you're looking at side mounted connection points.

Here's where the details come in. Is this PSU is primarily for cases with side mounted PSU slots, while in a wider case this might work in a flat mount situation, most likely you are going to need a fairly wide case to house the wiring coming off the supply without bending the wires too much. Even then in some side mount cases, or the PSU is mounted on its side, the wires sticking upright can still impede on certain things, for example with the Lian-Li o11 dynamic XL, The upright facing ports for the connectors on the wires to plug into impede with the bottom hot swap hard drive bay. Now if I really wanted to press the wires down flat against the power supply unit I could probably still fit the hot swap bay in the case, but it wouldn't give much room for the wires, nor allow for much passive heat dissipation from the PSU. In this particular instance with the case I chose a standard end connector output PSU would have been the better choice, as there is ample room at the end for wiring clutter, but due to the hot swap bay mounted above the power supply unit, the side output of the shift model is not intuitive for my case.

Removal of the bottom hot swap bay in my case alleviated the issue, but also presents the inconvenience of not having all four hot swap bays available. I never thought I would use this feature, but over the years as I have acquired multiple hard drives and stored up massive amounts of data, it actually comes in handy for moving data back and forth between drives.

So no stars docked for the design it's actually great, just really think about whether or not you need the side output connectors and whether or not you will have enough room in your case. They make it more convenient to plug and unplug additional wires without having to remove the power supply unit completely, however you may run into spacing issues in smaller cases.

Situationally recommended.

I recently purchased the Corsair RM850x (2021) Fully Modular ATX Power Supply, and I must say, I am extremely impressed with its performance and features. Corsair has always been known for delivering high-quality power supplies, and the RM850x is no exception. Here's my review of this remarkable power supply.

First and foremost, the efficiency of the RM850x is outstanding. With its 80 PLUS Gold certification, it delivers excellent power efficiency, ensuring that my system consumes less energy and runs cooler. This not only helps in reducing electricity bills but also contributes to the overall longevity and reliability of my system.

The fully modular design of the RM850x is a game-changer. It allows for easy cable management, as I can connect only the cables I need and keep the rest neatly stored away. This not only enhances the aesthetics of my build but also improves airflow within the case. The modular design also makes installation a breeze, as I can effortlessly connect the required cables without any clutter or hassle.

One of the standout features of this power supply is its low-noise fan. The fan operates silently under regular loads, and I barely notice its presence. It only kicks in when the system is under heavy load, and even then, the noise levels are impressively low. The Zero RPM fan mode is particularly noteworthy, as it ensures complete silence during idle or low-power usage scenarios. This is a great feature for those who prefer a quiet computing experience.

The build quality of the RM850x is top-notch. The unit feels solid and durable, and the black finish gives it a sleek and premium look. The cables provided are of high quality and have a premium feel as well. The power supply comes with all the necessary protections, including over-voltage, under-voltage, over-power, over-temperature, and short-circuit protection, ensuring the safety of my components.

In terms of power delivery, the RM850x handles my system with ease. It provides ample power for my high-end components, including a demanding CPU and a high-performance graphics card. The voltage regulation is excellent, and I have not encountered any stability issues or power-related problems since installing this power supply.

One minor drawback of the RM850x is its size. It's a bit larger than some other power supplies on the market, so it might not fit into smaller PC cases. However, in most standard ATX cases, this should not be an issue.

Overall, the Corsair RM850x (2021) Fully Modular ATX Power Supply is an exceptional product that delivers on all fronts. Its efficiency, modular design, low-noise fan, and solid build quality make it a reliable choice for any PC enthusiast or gamer. With its impressive performance and thoughtful features, the RM850x is definitely worth the investment for those looking for a high-quality power supply to power their systems.

I highly recommend the Corsair RM850x to anyone in need of a powerful, efficient, and silent power supply for their PC build. Corsair has once again raised the bar with this outstanding product.

Got this PSU cause I knew it 1. had more than enough power needed for my new build and 2. the case it went into was designed by corsair, and was able to check clearance on everything. I didn't go with the Shift version of the PSU for the simple reason that although it's unique, I see a lot of people complaining about its practicality. So, I went with the 2021 version of the RM1000x.

The pros are basic. Strong but also stiff cables with protection in the proper places. Very easy overall install & modularity we've came to be familiar with when it comes to modern PSU's. Quiet operation, & plenty of peace of mind knowing I have plenty of power for my build (6950xt + 13600k).

CONS.... This is the biggest con thus far, and I will complain about it until the end of time. Not that it's ever been okay practice, but having your PCIE cables all have a pigtailed additional 6 pin is just miserable to deal with. My GPU requires two 8 pins & one 6 pin... that's three separate cables with three separate & dangling 6 pin pigtails that'll never be used. I can understand giving only 6+2's even though it should be practice at this point to have some full 8 pin's, but I'll never understand a 6+2's with pigtailed 6 pins on a 1000W unit..... JUST NO. Please, if you're reading this and considering this PSU, please keep in mind to use a separate PCIE 6+2 cable for each connection on the card, AND DO NOT USE THE PIGTAILED 6 PIN THAT'S ATTACHED TO THEM. For lower power cards back in the day this wasn't a huge deal but was still bad practice to daisy chain your PCIE connections like that. Nowadays, with the power these cards are capable of drawing, there's NO REASON a 1000w PSU would even give you the option to daisy chain. A pretty big & detrimental (in my opinion) overlook on Corsair's part. Luckily you can use a cable tie or strap & just bunch them all together but... no one that has built a pc will tell you it looks good.

other than that one major annoyance that I deem to be a con, great power supply.

While this looked really cool and I thought it would be a game changer, I would HIGHLY recommend anyone to really check against the case you plan to use and the internal configuration, ie. where the PSU will be mounted.

I used this with a Corsair 7000D, so there was a very good chance it would be compatible. While the idea of easier access of cabling via side mounting to the PSU, the thing I realized is that not all cases are aligned to this orientation. Most cases today assume rear mounted cables. This means that they don't always have enough clearance between the PSU and the side panel to accommodate the cables. Given I had a Corsair case, it wasn't a problem. The motherboard cable did seem to be a tight fit but made it work. With this PSU, I do believe it allowed me to keep the 2nd 3.5" drive cage closest to the PSU. If I had used traditional rear mounted cable PSU, I definitely would need to sacrifice this drive cage. It wouldn't be a huge deal breaker as I, like most people, are moving away from HDD to SSD.

It worked out for me. Was it mind blowing amazing or evolutionary? I don't think so... I don't think it will be until case manufacturers start considering this PSU into their designs. For now, it's best compatible with Corsair cases. For other brands, really think through whether you'll have the clearances you need. Otherwise, stick to traditional rear cable mounted PSUs.

The other reason why I got this particular PSU was because it was the only Corsair one that was ATX3.0 at the 1000W+ range. Needed ATX3.0 to ensure I had the native 12pin power cable for the RTX 4090 to minimize using the octopus adapter that is provide by the card for older PSU. This adapter could increase the chance of the "melting cable" situation for NVidia cards. Native 12pin GPU cable is the way to go. It also keeps things clean and minimized.

Sadly I got this to replace the one in my old DELL PowerEdge SC420 server, but the placement of the plug housing was just stuck out a little making it not fit without modifying the case a little. So I just put it in this DELL Optiplex GX620 and now I can use that video card I bought not knowing it required 500 watts to run properly. Lucky for me :).
This unit comes with +4 power for Pentium 4 boards, molax and sata power also FDD. Notice that the picture shows the cooling fan which means that it is upside down making the power plug on the left side not the right when installed. Runs very quiet. If you have an open back plate for PS this is a good choice for the 500 watt range.
Replaced defective power supply in a computer. May not be that easy to replace if you're not comfortable working in a desktop computer.

The Power Supply works amazing and got here really quick. My only problem was that although it was listed as compatible with the old Dell PC I was installing in, it did not fit the case. I had to use steel cutters to widen the gap in the metal on the back of the case to allow the power cord to be plugged into the supply. Aside from this everything was perfect.

name: GOLDEN FIELD GPG550 Power Supply, Full Modular 80 Plus Gold, 5 Years Warranty, Computer PC ATX PSU 550W
description:
• 【80+ GOLD】80 PLUS Gold certified, deliver up to 92% efficiency and reduce operating cost.DC to DC Circuit Design, Runs cooler and uses less power than less efficient power supplies
  • 【FULL MODULAR】Full modular cable design allow you to remove unneeded cables for maximum airflow and improving the thermal performance of the chassis.
  • 【120MM FAN】120mm smart temperature controlled fan, providing maximum airflow and near-silent operation.
  • 【COMPREHENSIVE PROTECTION FUCTIONS】Over Voltage Protection(OVP), Under Voltage Protection(UVP), Shot Circuit Protection(SCP), Over Current Protection(OCP) and Over Power Protection(OPP)
  • 【5 YEARS WARRANTY】The 5 years worry-free product experience process will be provided to you and the manufacturer will bear all the responsibility if any product problems happen.
  • PLEASE ATTENTION: IN ORDER TO REDUCE WASTE AND SAVE RESOURCES, ITEM NOT INCLUDE THE AC POWER PLUG CABLE. IF YOU REALLY NEED THE AC CABLES, PLEASE CONTACE US.

reviews.review: I bought this PSU back 1 or 2 months. I started hearing a clicking sound. Stuck my ear next to every fan there is. It's the PSU. Right now it's gone, the noise. I don't know if it will come back. Other than that, it's been quiet, doing it's job. I would guess my actual use could be a factor.

I have not even tested this yet but am really disappointed and unsure that I want even chance using this on my PC. The quick and dirty is that this lacks some very basic considerations that make me concerned of its quality. The cables are very cheap feeling, the gage of the wiring seems very thin and the coating feels like plastic. The PCIe cables are red, ruining the otherwise clean black cable look. The packaging is over done in its presentation trying to look like a higher end product and does achieve it, but never have I ever bought a power supply, cheap or expensive, some that did not even have a box, just vacuum sealed bag BUT ALL HAD A POWER CORD!!! HOW CAN YOU SELL A POWER SUPPLY WITH NO POWER CORD????

and last but not least is that they were not even smart enough to place there logo/specs so they could be viewed properly, it will be upside down in any configuration except for if you install in the bottom of case exhausting into your case??? It must be an oversight?

I'm really not feeling good about the rated quality of the PSU. I can't use this for the intended build because of the upside down logo but I will test the product soon and add to this review, in the near future

Edit: I did test this PSU, it did produce solid voltages in bios and in hwinfo. Under heavy loads or gaming, it maintained solid power. I did have left a pic of the build, the upside down logo will always bother me! But all in all for 57 dollars I payed, was a good deal. At its present price point, I would keep looking

Final edit, this PSU died after about 12 months
Nothing to complain about. Bought to replace an old PSU that died recently. So far so good running an old GTX 770 and a 100watts tdp CPU.

No complaints. Barely makes a noise. Bought simply to power my car audio in house. Very efficient and power delivery is great. Comparable to running my capacitor. Running a 80 amp sub amplifier and haven't popped it yet. Runs my subs hard with no distortion or white noise. Extremely satisfied. My neighbors on the other hand lol not so much....
Everything was good until we found out that it doesn’t come with a power cable. It’s basically a scam when you’re already paying 150 for it to not work lmao
Installed in few minutes, power supply runs quietly and efficiently, it looks and feels high grade, longevity will make it worthwhile.👍
Perfect for everyday use!
Product comes in box with the modular cables but no power cable to plug it in to the wall??? why would it not come with that in the box like every other power supply. DONT BUY

I got this as my PSU for my first ever PC build, and I do have to say that it is very quiet. It arrived sooner than it was supposed to(which is a plus). I will keep recommending this as I am very pleased with how easy it was to install. It simply is just a great bang for the buck PSU.
Just works. Clean install. Its a modular supply, except for the main Motherboard, and who cares about that.
I did not know what to expect. Great value for 650W bronze. Highly recommend.
Excelente

一度、BIOB画面を表示、10秒後に電源を切り、再度ONするも、起動しません。
知らないメーカーでしたので、試しにと思ったのが失敗でした。

name: Corsair RM850x Shift Fully Modular ATX Power Supply - Modular Side Interface - ATX 3.0 & PCIe 5.0 Compliant - Zero RPM Fan Mode - 105°C-Rated Capacitors - 80 Plus Gold Efficiency - Black
description:
• Fully Modular Micro-Fit PSU Connectors: CORSAIR Type 5 Gen 1 micro-fit PSU cables mean you only connect the cables your system needs while taking up less space.
  • Intel ATX 3.0 Certified: Compliant with the ATX 3.0 power standard, supporting the PCIe Gen 5 platform and resisting transient power spikes.
  • Zero RPM Fan Mode Support: At low and medium loads the cooling fan switches off entirely for near-silent operation.
  • 100% 105°C-Rated Japanese Electrolytic Capacitors: Premium internal components deliver unwavering power delivery and long-term reliability.
  • Modern Standby Compatible: Extremely fast wake-from-sleep times and better low-load efficiency.

reviews.review: Alimentation puissante et silencieuse, facile a installer avec les cables qui se debranchent de sorte que l'on utilise uniquement les câbles dont on a besoin dans la tour.

Overall, the Corsair RM1000x is a decent power supply unit (PSU) that comes at a relatively good price, especially if you can find it on sale. The sleek design and quiet fan operation are pluses, and the thick, durable cables indicate good build quality. However, there are a few drawbacks to consider.

Ease of installation may be a challenge, particularly if you have a smaller case. The cables are stiff and not flat, which can make cable management difficult, and they may not fit through smaller case holes or leave enough clearance to put the back panel back on. However, the cables are wrapped in mesh to help protect them, and once you get them plugged in, they are unlikely to break.

Speaking of the cables, the marketing images are misleading when it comes to the number of PCIe cables that come with the unit. Corsair should update the product descriptions to match the actual number of cables. The RM1000x comes with 3 PCIe cables that terminate in 2 8 pins for a total of 6 8 pin PCIe connections (Though for the newer GPUs it is advised to not use the additional 8 pin), And the RM850x comes with 2 PCIe cables that terminate in 2 8 pins as well for a total of 4 8 pin connections.

In terms of price, the RM1000x is a good value, especially if you can find it on sale. At the time of purchase, it was the cheapest name-brand 80+ Gold rated PSU available. Additionally, the warranty period is very decent, which adds to the overall value.

In conclusion, the Corsair RM1000x is a solid PSU with a few drawbacks to consider. If you have a larger case and don't mind dealing with stiff cables, this PSU is a good option. The build quality is high, and the price is reasonable, especially when on sale.
It works, that's all it needs to do. The modular cables work great - one criticism is that it only has 2 PCI cables, you'll need a 3rd if you're going to hook up a high-end video card.

My RM850x was starting to be a little limited, if you already have an RMx don't go for an RMe you will be very disappointed, the new connection system on the side is really very good, it makes the work a lot easier, on the other hand I think that it is not suitable for all cases, it comes with the new type 5 cable, the connectors which go to the power supply are smaller and the cables are easier to bend
Très silencieux fière de mon achat.

Brand is a decent quality, price was fair but slightly high for me. It was however cheaper then the lower wattage ones at the date of purchase so I got the 1000 watt when i could of been fine with a 750 watt. Does what it needs to and was a pretty generic install. wires seem to be of decent quality and seem to clip in firm as most brands do. Cannot go wrong with this powerhouse.
For Gaming

The fan is not moving unless I am doing some cpu or gpu stress test. It may be good for some quiet build but my other fans are loud Af. This battery is the only warm spot in my pc during gaming. I need it to spin to take the heat out of my case before it accumulating heat.

This is a great quality product from well-known reputable company, a PSU with great modularity and great performance, and frankly a good value. Lots of connectors and on the shift model, if that's what you're looking at side mounted connection points.

Here's where the details come in. Is this PSU is primarily for cases with side mounted PSU slots, while in a wider case this might work in a flat mount situation, most likely you are going to need a fairly wide case to house the wiring coming off the supply without bending the wires too much. Even then in some side mount cases, or the PSU is mounted on its side, the wires sticking upright can still impede on certain things, for example with the Lian-Li o11 dynamic XL, The upright facing ports for the connectors on the wires to plug into impede with the bottom hot swap hard drive bay. Now if I really wanted to press the wires down flat against the power supply unit I could probably still fit the hot swap bay in the case, but it wouldn't give much room for the wires, nor allow for much passive heat dissipation from the PSU. In this particular instance with the case I chose a standard end connector output PSU would have been the better choice, as there is ample room at the end for wiring clutter, but due to the hot swap bay mounted above the power supply unit, the side output of the shift model is not intuitive for my case.

Removal of the bottom hot swap bay in my case alleviated the issue, but also presents the inconvenience of not having all four hot swap bays available. I never thought I would use this feature, but over the years as I have acquired multiple hard drives and stored up massive amounts of data, it actually comes in handy for moving data back and forth between drives.

So no stars docked for the design it's actually great, just really think about whether or not you need the side output connectors and whether or not you will have enough room in your case. They make it more convenient to plug and unplug additional wires without having to remove the power supply unit completely, however you may run into spacing issues in smaller cases.

Situationally recommended.

I recently purchased the Corsair RM850x (2021) Fully Modular ATX Power Supply, and I must say, I am extremely impressed with its performance and features. Corsair has always been known for delivering high-quality power supplies, and the RM850x is no exception. Here's my review of this remarkable power supply.

First and foremost, the efficiency of the RM850x is outstanding. With its 80 PLUS Gold certification, it delivers excellent power efficiency, ensuring that my system consumes less energy and runs cooler. This not only helps in reducing electricity bills but also contributes to the overall longevity and reliability of my system.

The fully modular design of the RM850x is a game-changer. It allows for easy cable management, as I can connect only the cables I need and keep the rest neatly stored away. This not only enhances the aesthetics of my build but also improves airflow within the case. The modular design also makes installation a breeze, as I can effortlessly connect the required cables without any clutter or hassle.

One of the standout features of this power supply is its low-noise fan. The fan operates silently under regular loads, and I barely notice its presence. It only kicks in when the system is under heavy load, and even then, the noise levels are impressively low. The Zero RPM fan mode is particularly noteworthy, as it ensures complete silence during idle or low-power usage scenarios. This is a great feature for those who prefer a quiet computing experience.

The build quality of the RM850x is top-notch. The unit feels solid and durable, and the black finish gives it a sleek and premium look. The cables provided are of high quality and have a premium feel as well. The power supply comes with all the necessary protections, including over-voltage, under-voltage, over-power, over-temperature, and short-circuit protection, ensuring the safety of my components.

In terms of power delivery, the RM850x handles my system with ease. It provides ample power for my high-end components, including a demanding CPU and a high-performance graphics card. The voltage regulation is excellent, and I have not encountered any stability issues or power-related problems since installing this power supply.

One minor drawback of the RM850x is its size. It's a bit larger than some other power supplies on the market, so it might not fit into smaller PC cases. However, in most standard ATX cases, this should not be an issue.

Overall, the Corsair RM850x (2021) Fully Modular ATX Power Supply is an exceptional product that delivers on all fronts. Its efficiency, modular design, low-noise fan, and solid build quality make it a reliable choice for any PC enthusiast or gamer. With its impressive performance and thoughtful features, the RM850x is definitely worth the investment for those looking for a high-quality power supply to power their systems.

I highly recommend the Corsair RM850x to anyone in need of a powerful, efficient, and silent power supply for their PC build. Corsair has once again raised the bar with this outstanding product.

Got this PSU cause I knew it 1. had more than enough power needed for my new build and 2. the case it went into was designed by corsair, and was able to check clearance on everything. I didn't go with the Shift version of the PSU for the simple reason that although it's unique, I see a lot of people complaining about its practicality. So, I went with the 2021 version of the RM1000x.

The pros are basic. Strong but also stiff cables with protection in the proper places. Very easy overall install & modularity we've came to be familiar with when it comes to modern PSU's. Quiet operation, & plenty of peace of mind knowing I have plenty of power for my build (6950xt + 13600k).

CONS.... This is the biggest con thus far, and I will complain about it until the end of time. Not that it's ever been okay practice, but having your PCIE cables all have a pigtailed additional 6 pin is just miserable to deal with. My GPU requires two 8 pins & one 6 pin... that's three separate cables with three separate & dangling 6 pin pigtails that'll never be used. I can understand giving only 6+2's even though it should be practice at this point to have some full 8 pin's, but I'll never understand a 6+2's with pigtailed 6 pins on a 1000W unit..... JUST NO. Please, if you're reading this and considering this PSU, please keep in mind to use a separate PCIE 6+2 cable for each connection on the card, AND DO NOT USE THE PIGTAILED 6 PIN THAT'S ATTACHED TO THEM. For lower power cards back in the day this wasn't a huge deal but was still bad practice to daisy chain your PCIE connections like that. Nowadays, with the power these cards are capable of drawing, there's NO REASON a 1000w PSU would even give you the option to daisy chain. A pretty big & detrimental (in my opinion) overlook on Corsair's part. Luckily you can use a cable tie or strap & just bunch them all together but... no one that has built a pc will tell you it looks good.

other than that one major annoyance that I deem to be a con, great power supply.

While this looked really cool and I thought it would be a game changer, I would HIGHLY recommend anyone to really check against the case you plan to use and the internal configuration, ie. where the PSU will be mounted.

I used this with a Corsair 7000D, so there was a very good chance it would be compatible. While the idea of easier access of cabling via side mounting to the PSU, the thing I realized is that not all cases are aligned to this orientation. Most cases today assume rear mounted cables. This means that they don't always have enough clearance between the PSU and the side panel to accommodate the cables. Given I had a Corsair case, it wasn't a problem. The motherboard cable did seem to be a tight fit but made it work. With this PSU, I do believe it allowed me to keep the 2nd 3.5" drive cage closest to the PSU. If I had used traditional rear mounted cable PSU, I definitely would need to sacrifice this drive cage. It wouldn't be a huge deal breaker as I, like most people, are moving away from HDD to SSD.

It worked out for me. Was it mind blowing amazing or evolutionary? I don't think so... I don't think it will be until case manufacturers start considering this PSU into their designs. For now, it's best compatible with Corsair cases. For other brands, really think through whether you'll have the clearances you need. Otherwise, stick to traditional rear cable mounted PSUs.

The other reason why I got this particular PSU was because it was the only Corsair one that was ATX3.0 at the 1000W+ range. Needed ATX3.0 to ensure I had the native 12pin power cable for the RTX 4090 to minimize using the octopus adapter that is provide by the card for older PSU. This adapter could increase the chance of the "melting cable" situation for NVidia cards. Native 12pin GPU cable is the way to go. It also keeps things clean and minimized.

The Corsair RMX Series (2021) RM750x is a 750 Watt power supply that exemplifies reliability, efficiency, and modular design. This power supply unit (PSU) has surpassed my expectations, providing stable and consistent power delivery while offering a convenient and tidy cable management solution.

The standout feature of the Corsair RM750x is its robust 750 Watt power output. This wattage is more than enough to handle high-end gaming rigs and power-hungry components, ensuring that my system gets the required power for peak performance.

With an 80 Plus Gold certification, the RM750x guarantees high energy efficiency, reducing power wastage and lowering electricity bills. Its power efficiency also translates into less heat generation, leading to quieter operation and improved system longevity.

The fully modular design of the RM750x is a game-changer for cable management. It allows me to connect only the necessary cables, minimizing clutter and maximizing airflow inside my PC case. This results in a clean and organized build with improved cooling capabilities.

The PSU's zero RPM fan mode ensures silent operation during low to medium loads, as the fan only spins up when required, keeping noise levels at a minimum, even during intense gaming sessions.

The RM750x comes equipped with high-quality Japanese capacitors, ensuring exceptional reliability and stability. These capacitors contribute to the PSU's long lifespan and consistent performance.

Corsair is a reputable brand known for its high-quality PC components, and the RMX Series continues that tradition. The RM750x is a testament to Corsair's commitment to providing top-tier power supplies for enthusiasts and professionals.

In conclusion, the Corsair RMX Series (2021) RM750x is a reliable and efficient power supply unit that offers stable power delivery and a modular design for easy cable management. Its 750 Watt power output, 80 Plus Gold certification, and silent operation make it the ideal choice for powering high-performance gaming systems. If you're looking for a premium power supply with excellent efficiency and clean cable management, the Corsair RM750x is the perfect option. I highly recommend this PSU for its outstanding performance and the peace of mind it brings to my PC build!

For now, it's best compatible with Corsair cases. For other brands, really think through whether you'll have the clearances you need. Otherwise, stick to traditional rear cable mounted PSUs.

The other reason why I got this particular PSU was because it was the only Corsair one that was ATX3.0 at the 1000W+ range. Needed ATX3.0 to ensure I had the native 12pin power cable for the RTX 4090 to minimize using the octopus adapter that is provide by the card for older PSU. This adapter could increase the chance of the "melting cable" situation for NVidia cards. Native 12pin GPU cable is the way to go. It also keeps things clean and minimized.

The Corsair RMX Series (2021) RM750x is a 750 Watt power supply that exemplifies reliability, efficiency, and modular design. This power supply unit (PSU) has surpassed my expectations, providing stable and consistent power delivery while offering a convenient and tidy cable management solution.

The standout feature of the Corsair RM750x is its robust 750 Watt power output. This wattage is more than enough to handle high-end gaming rigs and power-hungry components, ensuring that my system gets the required power for peak performance.

With an 80 Plus Gold certification, the RM750x guarantees high energy efficiency, reducing power wastage and lowering electricity bills. Its power efficiency also translates into less heat generation, leading to quieter operation and improved system longevity.

The fully modular design of the RM750x is a game-changer for cable management. It allows me to connect only the necessary cables, minimizing clutter and maximizing airflow inside my PC case. This results in a clean and organized build with improved cooling capabilities.

The PSU's zero RPM fan mode ensures silent operation during low to medium loads, as the fan only spins up when required, keeping noise levels at a minimum, even during intense gaming sessions.

The RM750x comes equipped with high-quality Japanese capacitors, ensuring exceptional reliability and stability. These capacitors contribute to the PSU's long lifespan and consistent performance.

Corsair is a reputable brand known for its high-quality PC components, and the RMX Series continues that tradition. The RM750x is a testament to Corsair's commitment to providing top-tier power supplies for enthusiasts and professionals.

In conclusion, the Corsair RMX Series (2021) RM750x is a reliable and efficient power supply unit that offers stable power delivery and a modular design for easy cable management. Its 750 Watt power output, 80 Plus Gold certification, and silent operation make it the ideal choice for powering high-performance gaming systems. If you're looking for a premium power supply with excellent efficiency and clean cable management, the Corsair RM750x is the perfect option. I highly recommend this PSU for its outstanding performance and the peace of mind it brings to my PC build!

The power supply was really put to the test and installed in a DUAL INTEL XEON 32 core / 64 threat beast of a machine / server with a 2080Ti.... Honestly I thought this thing would cause issues out of the gate, but I was pleasantly surprised when everything went very smooth and I had only 1 issue. There was only a single 8 PIN header for cpu socket power, this was easy enough to resolve by purchasing an adapter cable for about 5 bucks. Most PSUs today have at least 2 of those headers, and if they dont they will come with an adapter which i had to buy.... But for the money i dont think you will find a better deal around... One thing i can't speak to yet is LONGEVITY. PSUs in this price range / quality level tend to age like fine milk and expire much more quickly than their more well built, much more expensive counterparts. Time will tell that tale and if it's still going strong here in a year or two i will def change this review to reflect that with a full 5 stars... FINGERS CROSSED!!

Used to replace a failed desktop power supply. Does NOT include a floppy power connector as listed in the posting and in the spec sheet, so I will either retire that tech or splice in the connector off the old power supply to the new power supply later if needed. I needed to use the 4+4P connector to power the motherboard, as the PCIe 6+2P connector can fit, but if you do try to use it, it will not power on the system and could result in permanent damage. Includes thumb screws for mounting which look tacky and protruding. I reccomend regular screws to try to deter it from being tampered with without tools. Other than that, it is quiet enough for me, tidy and works as expected.
The product image showed regular screws and a floppy power connector.

I purchased three of these for budget gaming builds, which have proven surprisingly good. The all-black cables, albeit thinner than most, are a nice touch. One thing of note: there is only one 6+2 cable, which is appropriate for a 550W PSU, but if you have a GPU with more than one 8-pin connector, this is not the PSU for you. That said, it is a good value that does what it is supposed to do. We'll see how they hold up long-term.

It's a fairly light unit with a very quiet blue led cooling fan. It arrived in excellent condition and was well packaged. Inside the box were 110 AC cable, the PSU, a bag with 4 screws for mounting the unit and some documentation. The bundled cables are all black but are not sleeved or in my opinion properly bundled presenting as a loose grouping of individual wires with only 2 zip ties installed to group each cable bundle . I placed a 4" zip tie every 3" to each cable bundle to prevent a rats nest of all the loose wires going every where within the build. It looks much neater now even in a case with minimal cable management capability such as the one I am using for this project, a Rosewill FBM-01 mini tower. I am still waiting for a FM2+ MoBo to arrive to finish putting together the project.

I did, however, pretest this PSU with a power supply tester and all the output lines are working properly. I'll supply more info when the build is complete and fully burned in. For now everything seems OK so it looks like I won't have to send this PSU back to Amazon based on my preliminary testing.

Here's the tester I use to pre-check PSU's I bought this after installing a dead PSU better a pre check than a disassembly.

https://www.amazon.com/Computer-PC-Tester-Connectors-Enclosure/dp/B076CLNPPK/ref=sr_1_4?crid=2T0Q4ADFHBPOM&dchild=1&keywords=power+supply+tester+for+atx%2Fsata%2Fhdd&qid=1597075680&sprefix=power+supply+test%2Caps%2C228&sr=8-4

EDIT

Got a FM-2 Mo-Bo and installed a A10-5700 APU and a Asus 750-TI with a 8GB set of Ram a 128GB TeamGroup SSD boot drive and a 500 GB Seagate data HDD. I also included a DVD burner as I have a stack of them to get rid of. I placed all of that in a Rosewill FBM-01 case, a little tight wo/ great cable management space but OK. The system has been running great since it was built on August 18th. As we have no issues for a full month from the build generally and specifically the Captain 550 PSU I am happy with the power supply performance thus far. If any issues arise in the future, although unexpected in this undemanding build, I will revisit my review.

2nd edit. It's the end of October and the unit is still running just fine. No BSD's of shutoffs or any other janky behaviors. For my use as a secondary computer for internet surfing and light gaming it meets my needs. I wouldn't use it in a more demanding rig doing video editing or class "A" games. I use my Ryzen R9 3950 PC for that but this unit comes in handy for when I am rendering video projects or when I am having Lara Croft kick some butt. Perhaps this PSU could do it but why torture myself on a basic computer to see. Anyway if you are building a budget PC then it would probably meet your needs too.

Not my first choice but the build I was working on only required one 8 pin PCI-E connector and this did the job just fine. Bare bones but does what it’s supposed to do.
Overall positive experience on all fronts

This power supply is so good I bought another one for my other rig and one for a gift for my brother for his rig. The cables are nice it makes virtually no noise even with the zero decibel off and you can't beat the price for a legitimate gaming power supply. I'm a bit of an rog Fanboy so take that in consideration. That said I'm an rog Fanboy because I've never had any problems with my RG stuff, it always performs at top level and never gives me any problems. I know they've had a few problems recently so do your research but this power supply is not a problem been running one for about a year the other one for a few months and my brother's been wanting one for a few months.

Easy to install, yes! Had all the connectors required to hook up my beast of a machine and still have left over connectors. I have 12x ARGB Devices, 6 of which are case fans 140mm x3 and 120mm x3, 4x 3.5" 7200rpm hard drives, 1x 2.5" hybrid drive, 1x CPU watercooler, a Ryzen 7 3rd gen and a very power hungry GPU that claims to require 500W. My Ram is running an XMP, my CPU is set to auto overclock and my GPU is also set to auto overclocking.

The cables were more than long enough to reach behind the back side of the case to keep them hidden. They were a bit on the stiff side which turned out to help me getting through some of the more difficult to route spots. I was replacing a lower powered PSU and not building a new machine so I had to work with pre-wired devices.

As far as fan noise, I have nothing to state bad about the noise. If you take a look at my setup listed above, I have quite a few fans active on my machine. To be honest, I have never heard the fan on this power supply or any others. Once my old GPU would reach the max performance, the fans sounded like they were trying to launch a small plane. My new GPU is so much quieter but still makes more fan noise than the PSU does.

I really love the fact this PSU is a modular cable design. This allowed me to use exactly the cables I needed minimizing the amount of cables in my machine and reducing wire clutter. The cables and connectors are all black which made them easy to hide in my machine.

Before upgrading to that powereful solution from Asus, I was experiencing random shutdowns of my PC with 750 W power supply. Now there are no more shutdowns. The quality of refurbished delivery is very good, all components are available and intact. It is a great PSU, and I do not notice any noise from it

The Thermaltake Smart 700W 80+ White Certified PSU is great when it comes to delivering consistent and reliable power to your computer. As a PC enthusiast, I was on the hunt for a power supply unit (PSU) that could handle my rig's demands, without breaking the bank.

80+ White Certified Efficiency:
The 80+ White certification guarantees efficiency, which is vital for reducing energy waste and heat generation. This not only saves on electricity bills but also extends the lifespan of your components. The Thermaltake Smart PSU excels in this regard, making it both cost-effective and environmentally friendly.

Ultra Quiet Operation:
One of the most impressive features of this PSU is its ultra-quiet 120mm fan. Even during intense gaming sessions or resource-heavy tasks, the fan operates silently. It maintains a cool temperature within the PSU, ensuring long-term reliability without adding unwanted noise to your PC.

Multiple Connectors and Protection Features:
The PSU comes with an array of connectors, including PCIe, SATA, and Molex, allowing for versatile connectivity with various components. Additionally, it offers over-voltage and short-circuit protection, ensuring the safety of your components in the event of power fluctuations or surges.

Compact and Easy Installation:
The Thermaltake Smart PSU is designed to be compact and easy to install in standard ATX cases. The connectors are well-labeled and user-friendly, making it a hassle-free experience for both novice and experienced builders.

Competitive Price:
The competitive pricing of this PSU is a significant selling point. It offers high-quality performance and reliability without breaking the bank, making it an attractive choice for those on a budget.

In conclusion, the Thermaltake Smart 700W 80+ White Certified PSU is a fantastic choice for anyone in need of a reliable and efficient power supply for their PC build. It delivers a stable 700W of power, ensures efficiency and quiet operation, and offers essential protection features. Whether you're a gamer, content creator, or simply need a dependable PSU for your everyday tasks, this unit provides it all. It's a five-star addition to any system, and I wholeheartedly recommend it for your PC build or upgrade.

The Thermaltake Smart 430W Power Supply has proven to be an invaluable addition to my PC setup. Its performance, efficiency, and reliability have exceeded my expectations, and here's why I'm giving it a five-star review.

First and foremost, the power supply's 80+ White certification is a testament to its efficiency. It operates with high energy efficiency, minimizing wastage and reducing electricity costs in the long run. This is a key factor for environmentally-conscious users like myself.

The continuous power output of 430W provides ample support for my system's components. It handles my CPU, GPU, and peripherals with ease, ensuring stable and consistent power delivery. This has translated into smooth and reliable performance during both casual use and demanding tasks.

The ATX 12V V2.3/EPS 12V compliance ensures compatibility with a wide range of systems, making it a versatile choice for various builds. The power supply also supports Active PFC (Power Factor Correction), contributing to better power utilization and reduced energy consumption.

Installation was a breeze, thanks to the clear and concise instructions provided. The included cables are of sufficient length, allowing for neat cable management within the case. This not only improves airflow but also enhances the overall aesthetics of the build.

The power supply operates quietly and efficiently. It doesn't produce excessive heat or noise, contributing to a more comfortable and enjoyable computing experience.

The build quality is commendable. The unit feels robust and well-constructed, instilling confidence in its durability and longevity. It's clear that Thermaltake prioritizes quality in their products.

In terms of value, the Thermaltake Smart 430W Power Supply offers an excellent price-to-performance ratio. It provides reliable and efficient power delivery at a competitive price point, making it a smart investment for any PC enthusiast.

In summary, the Thermaltake Smart 430W Power Supply has proven itself to be a reliable workhorse for my system. Hazme una reseña de la tarjeta de vídeo: Nvidia GeForce GTX 1660 6GB de EVGA

La Nvidia GeForce GTX 1660 6GB de EVGA es una tarjeta gráfica de gama media diseñada para ofrecer un rendimiento de juego sólido y confiable sin romper el banco. Con su capacidad de 6GB de memoria GDDR5, esta tarjeta ofrece una cantidad adecuada de memoria para manejar juegos modernos de alta calidad, mientras que su arquitectura de Turing proporciona un aumento significativo en el rendimiento en comparación con las generaciones anteriores.

La GTX 1660 de EVGA cuenta con una velocidad de reloj base de 1530 MHz y una velocidad de reloj turbo de 1785 MHz, lo que significa que puede ofrecer una experiencia de juego fluida y sin problemas en la mayoría de los juegos modernos. Además, esta tarjeta es compatible con tecnologías avanzadas de juego, como la sombra de tasa variable (VRS) y la tecnología de trazado de rayos en tiempo real, lo que le permite ofrecer una experiencia de juego impresionante sin comprometer el rendimiento.

Una de las características más destacadas de la GTX 1660 de EVGA es su diseño compacto y de bajo perfil, lo que la hace perfecta para sistemas de juego más pequeños y con limitaciones de espacio. Además, el diseño de enfriamiento personalizado de EVGA con dos ventiladores ofrece una excelente disipación del calor y un rendimiento silencioso, lo que la hace ideal para sesiones de juego prolongadas.

En resumen, la Nvidia GeForce GTX 1660 6GB de EVGA es una excelente tarjeta gráfica para jugadores que buscan una experiencia de juego sólida y confiable a un precio asequible. Su diseño compacto, tecnología avanzada de juego y excelente rendimiento hacen que esta tarjeta sea una opción recomendable para aquellos que buscan construir un sistema de juego de alta calidad sin tener que gastar una fortuna.

Escríbeme una reseña sobre la tarjeta madre: Gigabyte B460M AORUS PRO. Teniendo en cuenta que mi opinión personal es muy valorada por su durabilidad, funcionamiento y prestaciones

La tarjeta madre Gigabyte B460M AORUS PRO es una excelente opción para aquellos que buscan una placa base duradera, confiable y con excelentes prestaciones. Con su diseño sólido y su construcción de alta calidad, esta tarjeta madre ha sido diseñada para soportar una amplia variedad de procesadores Intel de última generación y proporcionar un rendimiento de alta calidad en todo momento.

Una de las características más destacadas de la B460M AORUS PRO es su capacidad para manejar una gran cantidad de RAM DDR4 de alta velocidad, lo que permite una experiencia de juego fluida y sin problemas. Además, esta placa base cuenta con una gran cantidad de puertos USB 3.2 Gen 2 y USB 2.0, lo que facilita la conexión de una amplia variedad de dispositivos externos.

Otra característica impresionante de la B460M AORUS PRO es su diseño de enfriamiento avanzado, que incluye múltiples ventiladores y disipadores térmicos para mantener la temperatura de la placa base a niveles óptimos. Esto es especialmente importante para aquellos que buscan construir un sistema de juego de alta calidad que pueda manejar sesiones de juego prolongadas.

En cuanto a la durabilidad, la B460M AORUS PRO ha sido diseñada con componentes de alta calidad que han sido probados y certificados para cumplir con los estándares más exigentes. Esto significa que esta placa base es capaz de resistir una amplia variedad de desafíos y mantener un rendimiento óptimo a largo plazo.

En resumen, si estás buscando una placa base duradera, confiable y con excelentes prestaciones, la Gigabyte B460M AORUS PRO es una excelente opción. Con su diseño sólido, capacidad para manejar una gran cantidad de RAM DDR4 de alta velocidad y su sistema de enfriamiento avanzado, esta placa base es ideal para aquellos que buscan construir un sistema de juego de alta calidad y rendimiento duradero.

Nicolás Galvis

I recently picked up this PSU for my secondary PC, and I'm pretty happy with it. First off, installation was a breeze. The cables were all long enough to reach where I needed them, and I didn't have any issues plugging everything in.

This power supply is non-modular, which might be a downside for some people, but honestly, it didn't matter to me. The simple, straightforward design was just what I needed, and it saved me some cash compared to the fancier modular options out there. Another note is the colorful cables kinda stand out, but I don't care about the internal aesthetic of my PC.

For PSUs I'm all about sticking to trusted brands, and Thermaltake is good enough. It's a solid, no-frills power supply that does its job quietly and efficiently. If you're looking for a simple and reliable solution on a budget, I'd definitely recommend this over some no-name brand. It's a good pick for anyone who wants quality without breaking the bank.

Over the course of the last 6 months, I have slowly pieced together components for a new personal gaming PC rig. Between finding stuff through either Amazon or Newegg, waiting for stuff to slowly go on sale or come down close to the MSRP, was like fingernails on a chalkboard. Unfortunately, CoVid-19 has caused a lot of price gouging in various items, especially in the market of PSUs.
When Amazon Prime day 2020 finally came around, I was excited to see what various computer components would be available. The last two items on my list were a PSU and RAM, of which the latter I ended up finding a good buy on a 32g RAM kit. However, I wasn't so lucky on finding the exact PSU to fit my needs. Not wanting to wait until Black Friday, I decided to bite the bullet and to find a top tier PSU, even if I had to splurge on it. I have already spent too much time trying to piece together components that I needed to build this computer incase something didn't work right out of the box.
Since most of the components in my new gaming PC were from ASUS, this PSU caught my eye. I figured that it would tie into the rest of the components nicely, even though the price was about $30 more than I would have liked to have paid, but was it really worth the $155?? (...this PSU looks so pretty!!) After tossing and turning a few night, and seeing that it was quickly going out of stock, I went ahead and bought this bad boy.
On the other hand, not to let you guys think this was an impulse buy, I did some extensive research on this PSU. First off, this particular model won't be found on any current heirarchy chart as ASUS uses another famous and good company that makes really great PSUs: Seasonic. Yup that's right, this uses a modified version of Seasonic's Focus Plus Gold series, which is considered a top end PSU. Secondly, the 10 year warranty was another reason that I knew this was a good buy as well.
After waiting four days for this PSU to come in the mail (and practically losing sleep over it cause I was so excited to finally build my computer) I finally couldn't wait to rip the package open to see all what was inside. What I found was: The PSU itself (duh!), a translucent ziplock baggie with some nice magnets to either put on the PSU, PSU shroud or chassis of your PC case, some small stickers to place on the I/O side of the PSU, the installation booklet, some velcro strips, four screws, and in a separate, sleek looking nylon bag, all the cables necessary to hook up your components to your motherboard, including two SATA cables with four headers and a molex cable. The cables themselves are sleeved as a whole (not individually sleeved) in a sturdy, black nylon material and there are no "ketchup and mustard" wires insight. The SATA and the molex cables, however, are the standard flat black cables. These cables are also VERY long, considering that my case is a mid tower ATX case. These could probably easy reach components in a full tower cases using an eATX motherboard without the need for cable extensions. The cables are also very flexible, not stiff like some other PSU brands with flat cables.
When I finally got everything hooked up, and turned it on for the first time, it was beautiful. Even though this PSU has a 0 dB button, with it turned off (the fan constantly running) the fan is virtually silent.
In the end, I definitely don't feel guilty splurging on purchasing this product. I definitely recommend ASUS PSU to anyone that wants to add elegance and a reliable PSU to their PC build. It may be a little pricer than some of the other PSUs in the same category, but I guarantee you won't regret it!

Me agrado mucho comprar este producto, siento que valió la pena al sacarlo de su caja y encontrar todo lo que está en la foto.

Para empezar trae algunas pegatinas imantadas para personalizar la fuente, fue un buen detalle. Aclarar que no trae ningún rgb para la gente que a veces solo le interesa eso.

También incluye algunas bolsitas con el logo de la marca las cuales voy a guardar porque se me hicieron muy bonitas, esto también lo manejan otras marcas.

Con respecto a los cables creo que si trae los necesarios para una PC actual, traen el suficiente largo, en ningún momento sentí que fueran cortos como me pasó con mi fuente anterior que apenas si llegaban los cables, aunque mi gabinete es media torre, tal vez en una torre completa quedé exacta.

También como extra incluye unos cintillos de plástico para amarrar cables y unas cintas de Velcro para el mismo propósito. La verdad muy bonitas.

Es la primer fuente que compro de Asus, siempre he comprado Thermaltake y cooler máster pero me agrado mucho la calidad de los materiales y lo que incluye. La caja llegó sellada en celofán a pesar de ser un producto importado.

Con respecto a la instalación fue muy sencillo e incluye sus 4 tornillos. Algo que me llamo la atención es un botón que trae para que supuestamente haga nada de ruido, el botón dice 0 dB, es decir, cero ruido, lo extraño es que al oprimirlo se apaga el ventilador y sigue encendida la fuente. No comprendo si eso debería ser así porque una fuente siempre debe enfriarse con su ventilador. No he intentado verificar si en algún momento enciende el ventilador con esa opción activada o si tenga otra forma de enfriamiento porque tener el ventilador de la fuente apagado se me hace algo peligroso así que mejor he desactivado esa opción, porque de todas formas la fuente es silenciosa.

En conclusión creo que es una excelente fuente, tengo poco tiempo con ella, espero me dure muchos años como mis otras fuentes que la más vieja ya casi cumple 15 años y sigue funcionado.

Si te sirvió mi reseña vota que te fue útil

reviews.review: I'm running an 80 watt Yaesu 2 meter Transceiver as a base and use this 30 amp PSU. It's working very well and have no issues what so ever. Clean power.
