Review update, 8/23/23:

I spoke with a power supply engineer that I've known for years. He advised that a properly designed DC switching supply should not "bounce on the way down", but its DC output should degrade smoothly to zero Volts w/o a "ringing bounce", and that this kind of bouncing is not good for anything in the "on position" that may still be connected to it. With regret, I returned the Jesverty 50A supply for a refund. Amazon was good to its word and processed the refund because I did the return in the initial 30 day ownership period. So, while the supply works great when powering up and staying powered (even when sourcing very high current demands), this shutdown anomaly is enough reason to return it. Sorry, This removes one more star from my rating.

Original review:

I had a Motorola TPN-1154A linear regulated supply as my main ham station source of DC Voltage. Moto designed this supply to regulate at 14.5VDC with up to a 15A continuous draw (20A on surges) with minimal change in its regulated, nominal Voltage output. I had used this supply for over two decades without incident.

Since I monitor its Voltage with a small DMM module, I recently noticed the Moto supply's output had climbed to 14.9VDC with no load. Most 12VDC devices do not like being fed with DC Voltages much above 15 Volts, so I felt uncomfortable with this recent development and didn't want my nominal Voltage to climb much higher.

After much searching at the ham stores and on Amazon, I decided to purchase the Jesverty SPS-5011 to be my new ham station supply. I have owned a number of linear supplies over the years I've been a ham as well as switchers from Icom and MFJ and even a generic LED light string 12V/30A switcher I bought to power an IC-706 radio. Some switchers are better than others. Most regulate their output Voltage quite well. Some, like my generic unit can be a bit noisy with switching regulator noise. The Jesverty SPS-5011 is certainly one of the quieter switcher supplies I've owned.

With its dual metering, switchable fixed 13.8VDC versus 9-15VDC adjustable modes, noise movement control (moves the AC chopper frequency to move "birdies" around), and great current sourcing capability (along with the expected good Voltage regulation, I am very happy with its features and performance.

Since I like to power down my ham station by switching off an AC outlet strip that the Jesverty is plugged into, I have noticed one thing I do NOT like. This single "nit" is that unlike the predictable drop of a linear supply's decaying DC output, and not like a similar drop in output when AC is removed from my Icom, MFJ, and even the 12V/30A generic supply...the Jesverty's DC output "rings" as it decays.

By this I mean that the DC output does not drop as a somewhat steady decay when AC is removed (even by switching the Jesverty "off" with its front panel power switch) but it actually "bounces on the way down to zero Volts output". One can see this with the Jesverty's panel lamps turning off and on several times before finally going out completely. I can also hear some popping in my amplified speakers as this Voltage bounces during its ultimate decay to being totally "off".

I'm not sure whether or not this is harmful to any of my equipment, so I do try to always FIRST turn off my radios before "throwing the big switch" on the AC strip. Since some of the radios do not have a hard, cold "off" mode (some parts of their circuitry is always drawing a bit of current when DC is present on their power cables, and they simply do a soft start when their power switches are depressed) I do have some minor concerns about this bouncy "on to off" transition behavior.

This is not so much a concern for me, however, that I feel I need to return this power supply. The other capabilities this Jesverty 50A supply has, for me, far outweigh this minor concern.

BTW, I diagnosed and repaired the Moto supply's creeping regulated DC Voltage issue and even changed some of its "select in manufacturing" resistor values in it to recenter its own DC output to exactly 13.8VDC...but I'm keeping the Jesverty SPS-5011 anyway. I'm that happy with it and feel it's that good of a purchase (unless it dies due to infant mortality).

I purchased two of these 8A adapters after trying a different (cheaper) brand that got very hot with 50% of the rated load. In my quest to find new adapters, I came across these and was delighted to see the reviews that said the adapter remained quite cool even at higher loads. The fact that it's UL listed is also nice (the other brand wasn't).

When they arrived, I was excited to try them out. I am using them to power a single strip of 12v LED lights that max out at 5A at full brightness. At 8A, this adapter should be well within its rated spec and should not get hot at all. Consistent with the other reviews, the adapter did not get hot. It was actually barely warm at all and this made me very happy.

On the other hand, as I went to check the barrel connector, it was insanely hot. The rubber(?) around the connector was too hot to touch with my fingertips for more than a second and as I got a little closer, I noticed a not so good smell as if something was melting. Upon visual inspection, there didn't seem to be any melting damage, but the fact that it was so hot was a no go for me as it is to be installed in a plastic housing and I didn't want the plastic to melt, more fumes being created from hot plastics/rubber, and/or risk potential fire of some kind (however small a risk that may be). The connector became this hot even with just half the load of the LED strip (2.5A).

I contacted the seller/manufacturer and to inquire if these connectors are rated for the 8A that the adapter is and also explained my experience with the very hot connectors under just 2.5A load. Their response was that the heat was normal (no it's not) and that my 2.5A load is "relatively large" (again, no it's not).

Out of frustration, I purchased a set of metal barrel connectors rated for 10A. Those arrived and I connected them and tested them with 2.5A load and the full 5A load. The metal connector barely became warm.

In summary - great adapter, but I fully recommend you buy your own female barrel connectors because the ones they include are no good unless you expect to only use a tiny, tiny fraction of the 80% of 8A this adapter is rated for.

Seems to work great powering some under the cabinet LED lighting. However, be very cautious of the adapter that comes with it to connect to your LEDs. It is not good for higher current loads. Running close to the rate 6A through this thing might lead to bad problems for you.

I had this powering two approximately 16 foot LED RGBWW strips, each controlled by a wireless LED ballast. One for under the cabinets and one on top to give accent colors. When i had both strips on with a lot of color, the adapter became very hot. Enough that I might have been able to get a burn if I had pulled the adapter off the cord and grabbed the metal with my fingers. I could feel the heat traveling up the cord of the power supply several inches and the rubber was softening. Thinking that maybe I miscalculated the current my setup would draw, I purchased a second of these power supplies. Now each are powering a single strip. But even with halving the load, both adapters get quite warm when I have RGB & WW running. The power supply seems like it is perfectly capable of providing all of the power needed for both strips but that hot adapter is not good at all. Excessive heat + electricity = smoke, fire, fuss, bother, and a very bad day.

I'm still debating it but I might cut the ends off of the power supply's cord and solder them directly to the leads going to the LED ballasts. I think that I would trust a good soldered joint that I created myself rather than those adapters.

Having had several cheap power supplies fail prematurely in the past, I'd rather pay more for one that will last. The description and good reviews led me to choose this one. I feel good about it so far. It's larger and heavier (13 oz) than my other ones and feels solidly constructed.

It's working great for my under counter LED light strips. It's replacing a 2A supply that would get very hot. I went with a higher amperage rating (8A) so it wouldn't have to work so hard and this one doesn't even get warm after several hours of use

The voltage measures at a steady 12.25v without load and does not fluctuate at all on the meter. It has a green LED indicator that's not too bright (which is good) and a large ferrite EMI ring on the output. It also comes with a screw terminal attachment, which I don't need but will come in handy for future DIY projects. I'm feeling very optimistic about this purchase.

I've started believing you have to over-spec power supplies for twice their LED loads to keep them from running hot. Not this one! I ran it for over an hour with a 7.5A load and it got warm but not hot. Plus the power-on delay is under 1 second (not 4 seconds like some losers I sent back). I'm sold! Buying more.

NOTE: Another reviewer pointed out how much heat you can get from those standard 12V barrel connectors... and I agree that if you're pulling more than about 5A you should cut off this connector and solder the connections. I've measured in the range of 0.1 ohms per connector junction, which will cost you almost a volt at rated power. If you want full brightness, you don't want 11V to your light strip.

name: Corsair RM1000e (2023) Fully Modular Low-Noise ATX Power Supply - ATX 3.0 & PCIe 5.0 Compliant - 105°C-Rated Capacitors - 80 Plus Gold Efficiency - Modern Standby Support - Black
description:
• Fully Modular PSU: Reliable and efficient low-noise power supply with fully modular cabling, so you only have to connect the cables your system build needs.
  • Intel ATX 3.0 Certified: Compliant with the ATX 3.0 power standard, supporting the PCIe Gen 5 platform and resisting transient power spikes.
  • Keeps Quiet: A 120mm rifle bearing fan with a specially calculated fan curve keeps fan noise down, even when operating at full load.
  • 105°C-Rated Capacitors: Delivers steady, reliable power and dependable electrical performance.
  • Modern Standby Compatible: Extremely fast wake-from-sleep times and better low-load efficiency.

reviews.review:
Bought this is October 2023 for the good cybernetics rating looked at the spec sheet from them and for the price ATX 3.0 standard gold rating it's a good deal is it the best efficiency no, particularly 5v standby voltage shows it was as low as 67% EFFICIENCY at 115V which in that result is lower than my 750w EVGA NEX bronze
but overall still more efficient and comes with the new 12VHWPR cable
Also built by HEC which is a taiwan company Imo i'd prefer over GreatWall their usual supplier.
I was tired of buying a cheap power supply that fails within the next 5 years and I was looking for a good ATX 3.0 power supply from a reputable brand and found the one on sale. Very satisfied.

I recently bought a new video card, and research suggested that I upgraded my PSU as well. I make good money so I figured I would just buy the 1000w over my 750w anyways. Both modular, so not much difference, wires appeared to be same, just with different shade on white numbering on the plugs - I switched out all the wiring and tucked it better than previously. PC runs quiet, the PSU is quiet I mean.

Super easy to install--love the modular setup, allowing you to only use the cables you require---cable management is already a pain, this makes it far easier and much cleaner install. Would purchase again.
This provides a lot of power. Does what you expect.

I dont have any pictures of this psu but i built a gaming pc for my brother and when it is paired with
Corsair H100x RGB Elite Liquid CPU Cooler
Corsair Force Series Gen.4 PCIe MP600 1TB
Corsair Vengeance LPX 32GB (2 X 16GB) DDR4 3600
ASUS TUF Gaming H670-PRO WiFi D4 LGA 1700 (or similiar motherboards)
Intel Core i7-12700K Desktop Processor 12

you can play fortnite, gta5 (at mid graphics settings) and many other games without a graphics card so when you add a gpu
it will unleash ALOT more potential my brother and i are very pleased so far and i still think he is running without a gpu
Good
It comes with white cables, instant 5 stars.

I don't really have PSU testing tools, so I defer any serious considerations to them, but this model does have a lot of shining reviews by those who do have the tools (though of course reviews have to always be taken with a grain of salt. Or a whole shaker even these days.)

What I can tell is that it has all the outward signs of a quality PSU. It's quite hefty for its size, seems to have a good fan, etc etc. When I measure things like voltage via software (not sure how reliable that is, but it's the best I have,) they seem to be more stable than my previous PSUs.

One curiosity I don't really know how to explain is it has an extra relay inside doing who knows what. When you first turn things on, it's already able to handle the full power draw of the computer, so it's not like it's a low power switch for suspending or something -- it's straight to 100% before the relay even switches. I'm wondering if it switches on a capacitor after initial startup pull to handle power blinks and the like while avoiding that huge sudden instant draw you'd normally get, but this is merely a guess.

All in all I'm very much liking it. It's a tiny bit more compact to also work with smaller systems, but also fits fine in my mid tower (these days I guess that's considered a full tower, lol.) The modular cables work fairly well, though I wish the parts that can be put together or pulled apart (like the CPU power connector) snapped together more firmly so you don't have to carefully hold them together while inserting. I was pleasantly surprised it even included the latest 12VHPWR type-4 connector.

I guess if I had to try to choose something to complain about, I wish the power efficiency curve was a bit friendlier towards the low end. Most people aren't actually using anywhere near to 850 watts of power (a lot of people would be very shocked if they plugged their computers into a Kill-a-Watt or similar meter!) For most people normal usage and light gaming is easily going to fall into the bottom side of the curve and get somewhere in the vicinity of 75% efficiency. Ideally one would pick a PSU that more aligns with what the system actually uses (taking care to ensure sufficient current of course) but I can say I picked this one because I needed a PSU I could keep for many years to come and pretty much not even have to think about it no matter what I added to my system (within reason of course. I'm not likely to be adding any of the highest end CPUs or GPUs and especially not dual GPUs which is where one is most likely to start to actually get up to numbers closer to 850.)

I think most people will never come even close to fully utilizing this PSU making it a great option for a huge variety of systems (albeit at the cost of some efficiency loss for most.) From what I can tell I think we can count on it to hold up over time. Even the fan should be decent enough to not die too easily. Especially since most of the time on systems that aren't pushing it really hard the fan runs extremely quietly at a lower RPM.

So i owned this for a month and it just died, so i went to the website to do a request but there is no phone service for a warranty request. It all jad to be done on the website. That part is a struggle for me and more used doing warranty support over the phone. I am visually impaired and emailed the company to explain to them what was going on. I got a phone number and was azked to see if it would help me, sure enough it did. The department dont do warranty replacements but they worked with me and hooked me up with someone who didn't mine taking thire time to help me put in a request. I am happy with thire customer support and was asked if i ever had any problems to call them and they would help me out with any warranty replacements even tho that department didn't support it. Thank you sooo much as that made it a breaze to get something going. I try to be independent and do something that would work for me. :) i hope replacement works i can understand not all defects are detected. It really ment a lot how the supprt team helped me

I didn't expect this to come with white cables but it did! Makes my all-white PC looks great, and has sufficient power for a 3090. Note that you'll probably need to get an extra PCIe cable if you have a GPU with 3 pins though, and PSU cables are NOT universal so you'll need to make sure they're designed for the RM.
Bueno

Of course they don't build this like most of their products they have them made in Asia by one of the respected suppliers to their spec. The Corsair quality can be trusted. Good product good price. Essentially Corsair is a world class marketing and customer support company. They use the best suppliers. Corsair can always be trusted.

name: Cooler Master MWE Gold 850 V2 Fully Modular, 850W, 80+ Gold Efficiency, Quiet HDB Fan, 2 EPS Connectors, High Temperature Resilience, 5 Year Warranty, Gold v2
description:
• Highly Efficient Performance : The 80 PLUS Gold certification guarantees a minimum efficiency of 90%.
  • 2 EPS Connectors : 2 EPS connectors included with all models for universal current generation motherboard compatibility.
  • High Temperature Resilience: The new gen offers an increase in operating temperature to its predecessor to a maximum of 50 degrees Celsius. FAN SPEED: 1500 RPM
  • FullY Modular: Modular flat black cables reduce clutter, increase airflow, and improve overall efficiency and thermal performance.
  • Hydro Dynamic Fan: The 120mm HDB fan creates less friction, for a smoothly and low RPM operations, while keeping the noise level down.

reviews.review: Acheté alors qu'il était en vente ($125): moins cher que tous les power supply achetés par le passé! Rien de mieux pour le prix et la puissance. J'aime bien le fait de n'utiliser que les fils nécessaires (boitier moins encombré de fils). S'installe comme un charme. Silencieux. Devrait me durer plus de 5 ans! Je recommande ++.

I have never really installed a modular power supply before and thought it might be a bit difficult, it was actually easier! Also I installed ALL the included cables but really if you don't need to, you don't have to. I just installed it, but I was very happy with how silent it is and how well it integrated into my system. It was a bit larger than my previous PSU, but everything aligned very well. I would definitely recommend this PSU.
Ma commande est arriver avec la boite d origine et elle est endommager …. Reste a. Voir si il n est pas endommager…….

I bought a second one and I'm hoping it will work. I wanted the same plugs as the old supply and this was the best choice. If this one goes I'll update review to "Stay away from" but until then fingers crossed.

Update second one arrived and I haven't had any problems. Seller replaced.

super easy to install, you can here no noise coming from it. Overall this was a great purchase and I have no regret I’ve had it for about 3 months now and my pc is doing just fine, I’ve had no problems with this Power supply unit.
Built my computer. Working well, no issues

Sent me a 750w instead of a 850w but quickly replaced it, however had to wait a few extra days and have to bring the 750w to the post office now. The 850w works great as intended , the cables included dont look to be the best quality and one was damaged in sealed new packaging. The 750w box i recieved looked like it was kicked around a bit with the corners crushed in, i was nervous my replacement would look simular but it looked much better. Beyond the cheap feeling cables they use and the mixup with my order that was fixed, im satisfied

Manual recommends using 3 PCIE cables for any GPU that requires it instead of daisy chaining. Problem is, this PSU only comes with 2 PCIE cables. So you either daisy chain or buy an extra cable. Was really hoping to get my PC upgraded today but I guess I won't be able to. Thanks cooler master.

I normally don't write reviews unless the item I bought is absolutely terrible or really really good but this PSU for it's value is pretty dang good not gonna lie! My Gaming PC that I built kept shutting down and restarting when trying to play any games and I had tried everything from Software to drivers and nothing fixed it. My next guess was the power supply being the culprit and after I swapped out my old one for this bad boy BOOM I can now play all my PC games again! LOL my next guess if this didn't work was the RAM BUT I've had no issues with this PSU as of writing this review within 2 days of having it and it being installed! I would've gave the "Easy to Install" a full 5 stars BUT power supplies are never a quick easy swap unfortunately. If you're looking for a decent PSU in a good price range I'd pick this bad boy up cause it definitely helped me out in a pinch for sure!

I got this when it was on sale 850 V2 for $70. It was a very good deal. I really appreciate this seller!

I use this with a power hungry 7900X. The PSU itself is not super quiet. It's ok. My last PSU was able to completely turn off fan, this one is always running at like 500-700rpm or something. But at this price, and 850W (849 of which are available on the 12V rail!). Also, it has only 2 EPS connectors, but you can always buy your own later. At my purchase price, it is great value for money.

Product came sealed, but in its brand packaging (no outer Amazon box, which is good for the environment, I guess)

Update:
1 month later, I still have no problems.
I notice the fan is kind of strange. It's not a smooth sound, it's kind of an warbling, like the blade or bearings are unbalanced. It was like this from the start, and has not changed. Also, the fan is supposed to be sucking from the top and blowing out the rear of the case, but if you put your hand over it you can feel it blowing out the top. Very peculiar. It's like the fan "sucks" literally/figuratively. Still, this was an amazing deal, if this lasts 5 years, it gets ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ from me.

Watch for when this goes on sale. PSU prices are volatile, but I found it at a decent price. Cooler Master is one of those names I trust when it comes to PSUs. Everything in your PC depends on the quality of the voltage it gets. The PSU is responsible to keeping that voltage "just right" within the parameters of your PC's requirements. You don't want to "cheap out" on that critical job. But some products you can trust, like this one. This is one of my favorite choices (but if you're overclocking a 12900k, you might want a higher wattage!) The two EPS connectors are good if your mobo has two 8-pin EPS headers onboard. I bought a 650watt for a non-technical friend's 5600x and a radeon 6600x. Should work well for him.

As far as I am concerned, this PSU is very good for its price, I waited a month to see how it worked, and so far everything is great, the noise level is imperceptible (the only noticeable noise is the standard CPU fan), cable management is great, in my personal case there is no need to buy extensions, more than for aesthetic reasons.
Runs so quiet don't even know its on. Would have been better with RGB tho. And no Eco-Fan mode.

name: NZXT C850 PSU (2022) - PA-8G1BB-US - 850 Watt PSU - 80+ Gold Certified - Fully Modular - Sleeved Cables - ATX Gaming Power Supply
description:
• MORE EFFICIENT: At 50% load and high-line input voltage, power conversion efficiency reaches 2% higher than 80plus Gold Standard.
  • FULLY MODULAR: Use only the cables you need to keep your system clean and organized. Black sleeved cable and a matte black finish seamlessly fit any PC style.
  • COMPATIBLE AND HIGHLY-TESTED: C series is built and tested with strict standards for trouble-free installation. It fits most ATX case and supports the latest NVIDIA and AMD GPUs up to 30 series and AMD 6000 Series.
  • MORE PRECISE AND ERROR-FREE: Micro controller (MCU) enabled protection mechanism monitors current and voltage and output wattage.
  • OPTIMIZED AND SILENT: Gold PSU includes low thermal dissipation optimization with upgraded components and optimized circuit design.

reviews.review: I replaced an older 500W that seemed to be huffing and puffing - way too much fan noise as well. Replaced with this NZXT C850 PSU and what a difference. no creaking, no fan noise and runs all components and peripherals perfectly!

Efficiency of the power supply here should match that of the Corsair RMx 2021 series for as of current, less money of the same wattage.

However, its packaging is extremely nice and unexpected. The storage for all excess cables is a very welcome addition. All the plugs and cables seem high quality, and the build quality is extremely solid too.

As long as you know what you're doing, this PSU has no fault. Turning on the zero-fan mode is a preference, but a very welcome one for me. The power supply is essentially silent under regular operations, even with my RTX 3080 attached. NZXT has some questionable products in the past few years, but this is not one of them. Extremely excellent purchase for the price, you cannot go wrong
This thing has a 10 year warranty and it's absolutely a must have. runs quiet, don't hear it and powers everything well. No complaints here.
Usage personnel

I bought this power supply for my build after everything was put together. The computer wouldn't turn on had to bring it into a computer repair shop they told me that my power supply is dead and they had to buy a replacement. So now im waiting to get my computer back and paying for a replacement power supply as well as a repair bill. Never trusting this brand again for power supplies.

My first one that I ordered was a DOA unit and had to return it for a replacement. Once I received the second one it worked perfectly fine. So make sure to test the power supply first before taking apart your build like I did.

I like this PS. I normally buy EVGA as they as always good quality and originally I bought an EVGA for this build; however, the cables that came with it were too short. This PS has long enough cables to actually get to the device that needs power. Quality it good too.
Es muy buena compra, apenas arme la PC, ya en unos meses actualizo, pero realmente es buena calidad, trae todo lo necesario.,
Funciona sin problemas. Que sea totalmente modular es muy bueno al armar tu PC
Excelente fuente, de calidad premium y con cables trenzados, todo de calidad muy alta, NZXT no defrauda, totalmente recomendo.

name: CORSAIR RMX Series™ RM750x 80 Plus Gold Fully Modular ATX Power Supply, 750W
description:
• Fully modular, so you only connect the cables that your system needs.
  • A 135mm ML fan utilizes a magnetic levitation bearing and custom engineered rotors for high performance, low noise, and superior reliability.
  • EPS12V connector for compatibility with modern graphics cards and motherboards. iCUE Compatibility: No
  • 100% Industrial-grade, 105°C rated Japanese capacitors ensure unwavering power and reliability.
  • Supports Modern Standby sleep mode for extremely fast wake-from-sleep times and better low-load efficiency.

reviews.review: Alimentation puissante et silencieuse, facile a installer avec les cables qui se debranchent de sorte que l'on utilise uniquement les câbles dont on a besoin dans la tour.

Overall, the Corsair RM1000x is a decent power supply unit (PSU) that comes at a relatively good price, especially if you can find it on sale. The sleek design and quiet fan operation are pluses, and the thick, durable cables indicate good build quality. However, there are a few drawbacks to consider.

Ease of installation may be a challenge, particularly if you have a smaller case. The cables are stiff and not flat, which can make cable management difficult, and they may not fit through smaller case holes or leave enough clearance to put the back panel back on. However, the cables are wrapped in mesh to help protect them, and once you get them plugged in, they are unlikely to break.

Speaking of the cables, the marketing images are misleading when it comes to the number of PCIe cables that come with the unit. Corsair should update the product descriptions to match the actual number of cables. The RM1000x comes with 3 PCIe cables that terminate in 2 8 pins for a total of 6 8 pin PCIe connections (Though for the newer GPUs it is advised to not use the additional 8 pin), And the RM850x comes with 2 PCIe cables that terminate in 2 8 pins as well for a total of 4 8 pin connections.

In terms of price, the RM1000x is a good value, especially if you can find it on sale. At the time of purchase, it was the cheapest name-brand 80+ Gold rated PSU available. Additionally, the warranty period is very decent, which adds to the overall value.

In conclusion, the Corsair RM1000x is a solid PSU with a few drawbacks to consider. If you have a larger case and don't mind dealing with stiff cables, this PSU is a good option. The build quality is high, and the price is reasonable, especially when on sale.
It works, that's all it needs to do. The modular cables work great - one criticism is that it only has 2 PCI cables, you'll need a 3rd if you're going to hook up a high-end video card.

My RM850x was starting to be a little limited, if you already have an RMx don't go for an RMe you will be very disappointed, the new connection system on the side is really very good, it makes the work a lot easier, on the other hand I think that it is not suitable for all cases, it comes with the new type 5 cable, the connectors which go to the power supply are smaller and the cables are easier to bend
Très silencieux fière de mon achat.

Brand is a decent quality, price was fair but slightly high for me. It was however cheaper then the lower wattage ones at the date of purchase so I got the 1000 watt when i could of been fine with a 750 watt. Does what it needs to and was a pretty generic install. wires seem to be of decent quality and seem to clip in firm as most brands do. Cannot go wrong with this powerhouse.
For Gaming

The fan is not moving unless I am doing some cpu or gpu stress test. It may be good for some quiet build but my other fans are loud Af. This battery is the only warm spot in my pc during gaming. I need it to spin to take the heat out of my case before it accumulating heat.

This is a great quality product from well-known reputable company, a PSU with great modularity and great performance, and frankly a good value. Lots of connectors and on the shift model, if that's what you're looking at side mounted connection points.

Here's where the details come in. Is this PSU is primarily for cases with side mounted PSU slots, while in a wider case this might work in a flat mount situation, most likely you are going to need a fairly wide case to house the wiring coming off the supply without bending the wires too much. Even then in some side mount cases, or the PSU is mounted on its side, the wires sticking upright can still impede on certain things, for example with the Lian-Li o11 dynamic XL, The upright facing ports for the connectors on the wires to plug into impede with the bottom hot swap hard drive bay. Now if I really wanted to press the wires down flat against the power supply unit I could probably still fit the hot swap bay in the case, but it wouldn't give much room for the wires, nor allow for much passive heat dissipation from the PSU. In this particular instance with the case I chose a standard end connector output PSU would have been the better choice, as there is ample room at the end for wiring clutter, but due to the hot swap bay mounted above the power supply unit, the side output of the shift model is not intuitive for my case.

Removal of the bottom hot swap bay in my case alleviated the issue, but also presents the inconvenience of not having all four hot swap bays available. I never thought I would use this feature, but over the years as I have acquired multiple hard drives and stored up massive amounts of data, it actually comes in handy for moving data back and forth between drives.

So no stars docked for the design it's actually great, just really think about whether or not you need the side output connectors and whether or not you will have enough room in your case. They make it more convenient to plug and unplug additional wires without having to remove the power supply unit completely, however you may run into spacing issues in smaller cases.

Situationally recommended.

I recently purchased the Corsair RM850x (2021) Fully Modular ATX Power Supply, and I must say, I am extremely impressed with its performance and features. Corsair has always been known for delivering high-quality power supplies, and the RM850x is no exception. Here's my review of this remarkable power supply.

First and foremost, the efficiency of the RM850x is outstanding. With its 80 PLUS Gold certification, it delivers excellent power efficiency, ensuring that my system consumes less energy and runs cooler. This not only helps in reducing electricity bills but also contributes to the overall longevity and reliability of my system.

The fully modular design of the RM850x is a game-changer. It allows for easy cable management, as I can connect only the cables I need and keep the rest neatly stored away. This not only enhances the aesthetics of my build but also improves airflow within the case. The modular design also makes installation a breeze, as I can effortlessly connect the required cables without any clutter or hassle.

One of the standout features of this power supply is its low-noise fan. The fan operates silently under regular loads, and I barely notice its presence. It only kicks in when the system is under heavy load, and even then, the noise levels are impressively low. The Zero RPM fan mode is particularly noteworthy, as it ensures complete silence during idle or low-power usage scenarios. This is a great feature for those who prefer a quiet computing experience.

The build quality of the RM850x is top-notch. The unit feels solid and durable, and the black finish gives it a sleek and premium look. The cables provided are of high quality and have a premium feel as well. The power supply comes with all the necessary protections, including over-voltage, under-voltage, over-power, over-temperature, and short-circuit protection, ensuring the safety of my components.

In terms of power delivery, the RM850x handles my system with ease. It provides ample power for my high-end components, including a demanding CPU and a high-performance graphics card. The voltage regulation is excellent, and I have not encountered any stability issues or power-related problems since installing this power supply.

One minor drawback of the RM850x is its size. It's a bit larger than some other power supplies on the market, so it might not fit into smaller PC cases. However, in most standard ATX cases, this should not be an issue.

Overall, the Corsair RM850x (2021) Fully Modular ATX Power Supply is an exceptional product that delivers on all fronts. Its efficiency, modular design, low-noise fan, and solid build quality make it a reliable choice for any PC enthusiast or gamer. With its impressive performance and thoughtful features, the RM850x is definitely worth the investment for those looking for a high-quality power supply to power their systems.

I highly recommend the Corsair RM850x to anyone in need of a powerful, efficient, and silent power supply for their PC build. Corsair has once again raised the bar with this outstanding product.

Got this PSU cause I knew it 1. had more than enough power needed for my new build and 2. the case it went into was designed by corsair, and was able to check clearance on everything. I didn't go with the Shift version of the PSU for the simple reason that although it's unique, I see a lot of people complaining about its practicality. So, I went with the 2021 version of the RM1000x.

The pros are basic. Strong but also stiff cables with protection in the proper places. Very easy overall install & modularity we've came to be familiar with when it comes to modern PSU's. Quiet operation, & plenty of peace of mind knowing I have plenty of power for my build (6950xt + 13600k).

CONS.... This is the biggest con thus far, and I will complain about it until the end of time. Not that it's ever been okay practice, but having your PCIE cables all have a pigtailed additional 6 pin is just miserable to deal with. My GPU requires two 8 pins & one 6 pin... that's three separate cables with three separate & dangling 6 pin pigtails that'll never be used. I can understand giving only 6+2's even though it should be practice at this point to have some full 8 pin's, but I'll never understand a 6+2's with pigtailed 6 pins on a 1000W unit..... JUST NO. Please, if you're reading this and considering this PSU, please keep in mind to use a separate PCIE 6+2 cable for each connection on the card, AND DO NOT USE THE PIGTAILED 6 PIN THAT'S ATTACHED TO THEM. For lower power cards back in the day this wasn't a huge deal but was still bad practice to daisy chain your PCIE connections like that. Nowadays, with the power these cards are capable of drawing, there's NO REASON a 1000w PSU would even give you the option to daisy chain. A pretty big & detrimental (in my opinion) overlook on Corsair's part. Luckily you can use a cable tie or strap & just bunch them all together but... no one that has built a pc will tell you it looks good.

other than that one major annoyance that I deem to be a con, great power supply.

While this looked really cool and I thought it would be a game changer, I would HIGHLY recommend anyone to really check against the case you plan to use and the internal configuration, ie. where the PSU will be mounted.

I used this with a Corsair 7000D, so there was a very good chance it would be compatible. While the idea of easier access of cabling via side mounting to the PSU, the thing I realized is that not all cases are aligned to this orientation. Most cases today assume rear mounted cables. This means that they don't always have enough clearance between the PSU and the side panel to accommodate the cables. Given I had a Corsair case, it wasn't a problem. The motherboard cable did seem to be a tight fit but made it work. With this PSU, I do believe it allowed me to keep the 2nd 3.5" drive cage closest to the PSU. If I had used traditional rear mounted cable PSU, I definitely would need to sacrifice this drive cage. It wouldn't be a huge deal breaker as I, like most people, are moving away from HDD to SSD.

It worked out for me. Was it mind blowing amazing or evolutionary? I don't think so... I don't think it will be until case manufacturers start considering this PSU into their designs. For now, it's best compatible with Corsair cases. For other brands, really think through whether you'll have the clearances you need. Otherwise, stick to traditional rear cable mounted PSUs.

The other reason why I got this particular PSU was because it was the only Corsair one that was ATX3.0 at the 1000W+ range. Needed ATX3.0 to ensure I had the native 12pin power cable for the RTX 4090 to minimize using the octopus adapter that is provide by the card for older PSU. This adapter could increase the chance of the "melting cable" situation for NVidia cards. Native 12pin GPU cable is the way to go. It also keeps things clean and minimized.

The Corsair RMX Series (2021) RM750x is a 750 Watt power supply that exemplifies reliability, efficiency, and modular design. This power supply unit (PSU) has surpassed my expectations, providing stable and consistent power delivery while offering a convenient and tidy cable management solution.

The standout feature of the Corsair RM750x is its robust 750 Watt power output. This wattage is more than enough to handle high-end gaming rigs and power-hungry components, ensuring that my system gets the required power for peak performance.

With an 80 Plus Gold certification, the RM750x guarantees high energy efficiency, reducing power wastage and lowering electricity bills. Its power efficiency also translates into less heat generation, leading to quieter operation and improved system longevity.

The fully modular design of the RM750x is a game-changer for cable management. It allows me to connect only the necessary cables, minimizing clutter and maximizing airflow inside my PC case. This results in a clean and organized build with improved cooling capabilities.

The PSU's zero RPM fan mode ensures silent operation during low to medium loads, as the fan only spins up when required, keeping noise levels at a minimum, even during intense gaming sessions.

The RM750x comes equipped with high-quality Japanese capacitors, ensuring exceptional reliability and stability. These capacitors contribute to the PSU's long lifespan and consistent performance.

Corsair is a reputable brand known for its high-quality PC components, and the RMX Series continues that tradition. The RM750x is a testament to Corsair's commitment to providing top-tier power supplies for enthusiasts and professionals.

In conclusion, the Corsair RMX Series (2021) RM750x is a reliable and efficient power supply unit that offers stable power delivery and a modular design for easy cable management. Its 750 Watt power output, 80 Plus Gold certification, and silent operation make it the ideal choice for powering high-performance gaming systems. If you're looking for a premium power supply with excellent efficiency and clean cable management, the Corsair RM750x is the perfect option. I highly recommend this PSU for its outstanding performance and the peace of mind it brings to my PC build!

name: XPG Core Reactor II Modular PSU: ATX3.0-80 Plus Gold - ATX - Fully Modular Power Supply - 10 Year Warranty - 850 Watt(COREREACTORII850G-BKCUS)
description:

  • Certified GOLD efficiency by both 80 PLUS and Cybenetics.
  • 100% Japanese 105℃ Capacitors for stability and reliability.

reviews.review: I previously bought a case+psu combo unit from a reputable manufacturer and the power supply was horrible. This one was whisper quiet, no coil whine, good quality. Highly recommended!

The noise level is very quiet but not at first ~ the PSU arrived with a slightly dented in plastic cover over the bottom end which the unit sits on. That meant that the fan blades were hitting the cover and was only fixed after we pulled the cover outward away from the blades inside. For an expensive device you would expect to have a metal covering and not thin plastic. Otherwise the delivery and the PSU works well.

Greta value for an 850 Watt power supply. I am using it for a gaming PC with a i5 13600kf CPU with a 3060ti GPU. Fully modular and steady power.

Can not beat the value. GREAT power supply.
Great PSU, fully modular and 80+ gold. However, there are other cheaper A tier PSUs. I got this on sale for half price so I jumped on it

I was using XPG Core Reactor 850W Gold PSU to power pcie risers and 3 AMD RX 5700 video cards. My load was more or less constant at less than half the rated capacity. My system ran for better part of two months without problems but all of a sudden two weeks ago I discovered the distinct smell of burning plastic coming from the vicinity of my computer / PSU. With all the advertised built in protections like OCP it was hard for me to get my mind around how the PSU itself could be the source of the issue, but indeed, as per pictures, this is exactly what now seems to be at the root of the issue.
I only wish I had to deal with coil whine or a PSU that tripped and was no longer functioning. Unfortunately my unit stayed on line creating a potential fire hazard. By virtue of the quality of the power it continued to feed my GPUs, it seems it also did what I now assume is irreparable harm to thousands of dollars of equipment I had connected to it.
I am thinking that given the cost of components like GPUs relative to PSUs, the cases where PSUs fail taking connected components with them are exceedingly rare. I would expect that, in the case of PSU manufacturers targeting builds with high end components, they would want to go above and beyond in their response to situations where failure of there PSUs have led to significant loss to attached components.
My initial attempt to address my situation with XPG was using the facilities of their website on the day my PSU failed. I have still received no response to this overture. A few days back I located and called a toll free number and talked to a service rep. I was underwhelmed with the quality of our discussion. He did say that he would address my case with management and get back to me but he did not commit to any timeline. Yesterday I received an emailed response saying XPG had converged on a rather limited response to my case. They would focus only on the PSU and look into issuing an RMA, assuming I was willing to pay the cost of shipping my PSU back to their facilities in California. In short, with XPG, I was left with a distinct impression that failure of their PSUs in a manner where connected components are lost is a distinct, perhaps even common possibility, and that one should not expect XPG to do much more than make a feeble attempt to replace the PSU itself.
My faith in XPG as a brand of PSUs has been destroyed. I don't think I can justify even the cost of one way shipping to get a replacement unit given my new sense of how prone this replacement might be to fail in the same way as my original unit and resulting financial impact.

... j'ai eu une petite frousse en ouvrant mon colis (voir photo): boîte originale sérieusement endommagée (mais boîte d'expédition en parfait état). Just right for the 4000D airflow case. And you get 4 PCIE cables instead of 2 on the 850x which killed it for me. Nice 16awg cables too for the mains. XPG non sarà un brand conosciuto come Corsair o EVGA ma l'alimentatore in questione (Core Reactor 850w) è di ottima qualità e non ha nulla da invidiare all'RM850x. name: Corsair SF850L Fully Modular Low-Noise SFX Power Supply - ATX 3.0 & PCIe 5.0 Compliant - Quiet 120mm PWM Fan - 80 Plus Gold Efficiency - Zero RPM Mode - 105°C-Rated Capacitors - Black
description:
• Compact SFX-L Form-Factor PSU: Delivers 850 of continuous power, ideal for power-dense small-form-factor PCs, or saving space in larger builds.
  • Fully Modular, Micro-Fit PSU Connectors: With flexible cabling, taking up less space for tidy cable management and compatibility in small cases.
  • Intel ATX 3.0 Certified: Compliant with the ATX 3.0 power standard, supporting the PCIe Gen 5 platform and resisting transient power spikes.
  • 120mm Rifle Bearing PWM Fan: Delivers quiet, powerful cooling, with Zero RPM fan mode for near-silent operation at lower loads.
  • 80 PLUS Gold-Certified: Operates at up to 90% efficiency, and Cybenetics-certified for lower power consumption, less noise, and cooler temperatures.

reviews.review:
Of note the PSU itself is quite small so perhaps that is part of design. It very frustrating to get everything in the build and then find out this power cable is about 3 inches too short with no way to move parts to accommodate it. Also its a new design designated type 5 and it is not backwards compatible with older designs or so it says in the booklet. Every other power cable I have has been closer to 20inches . If you are using a micro case or maybe some Mid towers it might reach, but not full towers. since I was not able to plug it in I do not know much else about the unit. I am sure its a fine PSU but they really need to put some kind of warning. would it really be that difficult to make the cable a few inches longer. Hopefully I can get a longer cable from Corsair.

UPDATE!! After some assistance with Amazon Customer service, I have been in contact with Corsair regarding the short cables, They are sending me new type 5 cables that are longer to work my full tower install. overall it has taken approximately 10 days to resolve the issue, and probably another few days to receive the cables once shipped. I have increased my rating by 1 star in view of the no hassle resolution. Hopefully They put a new warning somewhere in the description to inform perspective buyers about the short cables.

2nd update, My cables arrived Fedex from Taiwan on the 27th, Now the problem continues they sent cables the exact same length as the originals 400MM or 14 inches, they are still not long enough I need 500 to 600 MM to reach the Mother Board and CPU. I am not sure how they managed to do this They were given a detailed description. I have emailed Corsair again waiting for a response. This started on the 14th or Oct. I will probably be at least another week. I may just have to return the PSU and order a different one.

- Performance
- The Corsair SF Series SF750 is a beast of a power supply that can handle any high-end gaming rig with ease.
- It delivers 750 watts of continuous power with 80+ Platinum efficiency and a fully modular design that makes cable management a breeze.
- It is compatible with my AMD 7900 CPU and MSI 4090 Suprim X GPU, both of which are liquid-cooled by the Silverstone Slim 240 Vida radiator and fans.
- It also supports the latest ATX12V v2.4 and EPS 2.92 standards and is backward compatible with ATX12V 2.2, 2.31 and ATX12V 2.01 systems.
- Quality
- The Corsair SF Series SF750 is built with premium components and features a 92mm Zero RPM fan that only spins when needed, ensuring silent operation at low and medium loads.
- It also has a 105°C rated Japanese capacitors that provide superior reliability and durability.
- It comes with a generous 7-year warranty and a dedicated customer support team that is always ready to help.
- It also includes a SFX to ATX bracket that allows it to fit in any standard ATX case, giving me more flexibility and options for my build.
- Value
- The Corsair SF Series SF750 is not the cheapest power supply on the market, but it is definitely worth every penny for its performance, quality and features.
- It is one of the few SFX power supplies that can deliver such high wattage and efficiency, making it ideal for compact and powerful gaming systems like mine.
- It also saves me money on electricity bills in the long run, thanks to its 80+ Platinum certification that ensures minimal energy waste.
- It also comes with a variety of cables that are sleeved and flat for easy routing and neat aesthetics.

Had SF450 SF600 SF750, all these are great. Never had any issues.
Why this rather than CM V850 SFX? You get the better cables from SF750.
Parfait
as advertised
This is a replacement for an extremely noisy thermaltake unit. So far so good!

This is hands down the best SFX PSU out in the market. It's well rated at 750W with a platinum rating. My only knock is a very faint rattle I've noticed with some units. I first noticed this at night with no one around and nothing else on. I've tighted the case mounts to be sure but it's def the PSU.
Well made, lots of connections for peripherals. A great choice for a SFF build.

I have used SF750s in multiple builds across several years, and none of them have ever come up with an issue. They hold up fine to the voltage spikes present on higher end RTX 30-series GPUs, and despite the 750W rating on paper they perform fine up to ~900W for brief periods of time. Most of them do make an audible click when they reach a certain temp/power threshold, which is just the relay for the fan activating- but if you can hear this, then you can also be happy that your PC is nice and quiet. Fan noise is negligible.

Corsair provides a full set of braided Type-4 cables with the PSU- note that this does not include a 12VHPWR for the latest Nvidia GPUs, but the adapter works alright (if not, Corsair sells a custom cable, or you can have one custom-made). Their cables are also shorter length to make cable management easier in SFF builds, and velcro cable ties are included as well.

The SF750 I have now has been used with a 5900X/3080 Ti, 12900K/3090, as well as 5800X3D/4090 in a FormD T1 and has never had issues. QC and customer support are still leagues ahead of Cooler Master, and the SF750 has a proven track record. Unless you are willing to compromise and move up to an SFX-L sized power supply, the SF750 is still the best option for SFX-class PSUs on the market by far. The cases in which you need a 1500W power supply are few and far between.

Looking for a power supply that combines compactness, efficiency, and exceptional performance? Look no further than the Corsair SF Series SF750 750 Watt SFX 80+ Platinum Certified Power Supply. This small form factor power supply unit delivers reliable and efficient power, making it an excellent choice for compact PC builds.

Compact Design:
The Corsair SF750 power supply boasts a compact SFX form factor, making it perfect for small form factor PC builds or systems with limited space. Despite its small size, it packs a powerful punch, ensuring stable and efficient power delivery to your components.

Efficiency and Certification:
With its 80+ Platinum certification, this power supply offers excellent energy efficiency, reducing power waste and minimizing heat output. The high-efficiency design allows for cooler operation and lower energy bills. You can trust that your system is getting clean, stable power while minimizing your environmental footprint.

Reliable and Stable Performance:
The SF750 power supply provides a maximum output of 750 Watts, offering ample power for even high-performance components and demanding tasks. It delivers clean and stable power to your PC's components, ensuring smooth operation and protecting them from power fluctuations.

Modular Cable Design:
The modular cable design of the SF750 simplifies cable management and enhances airflow within your PC case. You can connect only the cables you need, reducing clutter and optimizing cable routing. This results in improved cooling and aesthetics, allowing for a clean and tidy build.

Quiet Operation:
Thanks to the Zero RPM Fan Mode, the SF750 power supply operates silently during low to medium loads, ensuring a quiet computing experience. The fan remains idle until the power supply reaches a certain temperature or load, keeping noise levels to a minimum.

Corsair Reliability:
Corsair is a trusted brand known for its high-quality and reliable products. The SF750 power supply is no exception, providing stable and efficient power for your system. It comes with a 7-year warranty, offering peace of mind and demonstrating Corsair's confidence in its product.

In conclusion, the Corsair SF Series SF750 750 Watt SFX 80+ Platinum Certified Power Supply is a compact and powerful solution for small form factor PC builds. With its efficiency, reliability, modular design, and quiet operation, it provides everything you need for a high-performance system without compromising on space. Invest in the Corsair SF750 and experience the reliable power supply performance that Corsair is known for.

Disclaimer: I received no incentives or discounts for this review. I am simply sharing my genuine experience with this product.

As soon as I replaced it with this thermaltake PSU, all the issues went away, even ones that I didn't think were related to the PSU. I have only been using it in my new build for about two months now, but it has performed very well so far. I needed to upgrade my power supply with the new power requirements of my 7900 XTX. It took forever to figure out that the connectors could be separated as the instructions were not terribly helpful. I have to admit, its odd that the fans do not immediately kick in, but its a nifty feature due to only turning on when needed. I would definitely recommend this to anyone needing the higher power output and for the money, it seems like a great purchase. I won't know about longevity for another year at least, but I am pleased so far.
This beast is quiet and powerful. The power supply is beyond sufficient to hold up a Meta Quest and 3060Ti 12GB. The cables are shielded but not clunky, very easy to install, such a Great buy!

name: Corsair SF1000L Fully Modular Low-Noise SFX Power Supply - ATX 3.0 & PCIe 5.0 Compliant - Quiet 120mm PWM Fan - 80 Plus Gold Efficiency - Zero RPM Mode - 105°C-Rated Capacitors - Black
description:
• Compact SFX-L Form-Factor PSU: Delivers 1000W of continuous power, ideal for power-dense small-form-factor PCs, or saving space in larger builds.
  • Fully Modular, Micro-Fit PSU Connectors: With flexible cabling, taking up less space for tidy cable management and compatibility in small cases.
  • Intel ATX 3.0 Certified: Compliant with the ATX 3.0 power standard, supporting the PCIe Gen 5 platform and resisting transient power spikes.
  • 120mm Rifle Bearing PWM Fan: Delivers quiet, powerful cooling, with Zero RPM fan mode for near-silent operation at lower loads.
  • 80 PLUS Gold-Certified: Operates at up to 90% efficiency, and Cybenetics-certified for lower power consumption, less noise, and cooler temperatures.

reviews.review:
Of note the PSU itself is quite small so perhaps that is part of design. It very frustrating to get everything in the build and then find out this power cable is about 3 inches too short with no way to move parts to accommodate it. Also its a new design designated type 5 and it is not backwards compatible with older designs or so it says in the booklet. Every other power cable I have has been closer to 20inches . If you are using a micro case or maybe some Mid towers it might reach, but not full towers. since I was not able to plug it in I do not know much else about the unit. I am sure its a fine PSU but they really need to put some kind of warning. would it really be that difficult to make the cable a few inches longer. Hopefully I can get a longer cable from Corsair.

UPDATE!! After some assistance with Amazon Customer service, I have been in contact with Corsair regarding the short cables, They are sending me new type 5 cables that are longer to work my full tower install. overall it has taken approximately 10 days to resolve the issue, and probably another few days to receive the cables once shipped. I have increased my rating by 1 star in view of the no hassle resolution. Hopefully They put a new warning somewhere in the description to inform perspective buyers about the short cables.

2nd update, My cables arrived Fedex from Taiwan on the 27th, Now the problem continues they sent cables the exact same length as the originals 400MM or 14 inches, they are still not long enough I need 500 to 600 MM to reach the Mother Board and CPU. I am not sure how they managed to do this They were given a detailed description. I have emailed Corsair again waiting for a response. This started on the 14th or Oct. I will probably be at least another week. I may just have to return the PSU and order a different one.

- Performance
- The Corsair SF Series SF750 is a beast of a power supply that can handle any high-end gaming rig with ease.
- It delivers 750 watts of continuous power with 80+ Platinum efficiency and a fully modular design that makes cable management a breeze.
- It is compatible with my AMD 7900 CPU and MSI 4090 Suprim X GPU, both of which are liquid-cooled by the Silverstone Slim 240 Vida radiator and fans.
- It also supports the latest ATX12V v2.4 and EPS 2.92 standards and is backward compatible with ATX12V 2.2, 2.31 and ATX12V 2.01 systems.
- Quality
- The Corsair SF Series SF750 is built with premium components and features a 92mm Zero RPM fan that only spins when needed, ensuring silent operation at low and medium loads.
- It also has a 105°C rated Japanese capacitors that provide superior reliability and durability.
- It comes with a generous 7-year warranty and a dedicated customer support team that is always ready to help.
- It also includes a SFX to ATX bracket that allows it to fit in any standard ATX case, giving me more flexibility and options for my build.
- Value
- The Corsair SF Series SF750 is not the cheapest power supply on the market, but it is definitely worth every penny for its performance, quality and features.
- It is one of the few SFX power supplies that can deliver such high wattage and efficiency, making it ideal for compact and powerful gaming systems like mine.
- It also saves me money on electricity bills in the long run, thanks to its 80+ Platinum certification that ensures minimal energy waste.
- It also comes with a variety of cables that are sleeved and flat for easy routing and neat aesthetics.

Had SF450 SF600 SF750, all these are great. Never had any issues.
Why this rather than CM V850 SFX? You get the better cables from SF750.
Parfait
as advertised
This is a replacement for an extremely noisy thermaltake unit. So far so good!

This is hands down the best SFX PSU out in the market. It's well rated at 750W with a platinum rating. My only knock is a very faint rattle I've noticed with some units. I first noticed this at night with no one around and nothing else on. I've tighted the case mounts to be sure but it's def the PSU.
Well made, lots of connections for peripherals. A great choice for a SFF build.

I have used SF750s in multiple builds across several years, and none of them have ever come up with an issue. They hold up fine to the voltage spikes present on higher end RTX 30-series GPUs, and despite the 750W rating on paper they perform fine up to ~900W for brief periods of time. Most of them do make an audible click when they reach a certain temp/power threshold, which is just the relay for the fan activating- but if you can hear this, then you can also be happy that your PC is nice and quiet. Fan noise is negligible.

Corsair provides a full set of braided Type-4 cables with the PSU- note that this does not include a 12VHPWR for the latest Nvidia GPUs, but the adapter works alright (if not, Corsair sells a custom cable, or you can have one custom-made). Their cables are also shorter length to make cable management easier in SFF builds, and velcro cable ties are included as well.

The SF750 I have now has been used with a 5900X/3080 Ti, 12900K/3090, as well as 5800X3D/4090 in a FormD T1 and has never had issues. QC and customer support are still leagues ahead of Cooler Master, and the SF750 has a proven track record. Unless you are willing to compromise and move up to an SFX-L sized power supply, the SF750 is still the best option for SFX-class PSUs on the market by far. The cases in which you need a 1500W power supply are few and far between.

Looking for a power supply that combines compactness, efficiency, and exceptional performance? Look no further than the Corsair SF Series SF750 750 Watt SFX 80+ Platinum Certified Power Supply. This small form factor power supply unit delivers reliable and efficient power, making it an excellent choice for compact PC builds.

Compact Design:
The Corsair SF750 power supply boasts a compact SFX form factor, making it perfect for small form factor PC builds or systems with limited space. Despite its small size, it packs a powerful punch, ensuring stable and efficient power delivery to your components.

Efficiency and Certification:
With its 80+ Platinum certification, this power supply offers excellent energy efficiency, reducing power waste and minimizing heat output. The high-efficiency design allows for cooler operation and lower energy bills. You can trust that your system is getting clean, stable power while minimizing your environmental footprint.

Reliable and Stable Performance:
The SF750 power supply provides a maximum output of 750 Watts, offering ample power for even high-performance components and demanding tasks. It delivers clean and stable power to your PC's components, ensuring smooth operation and protecting them from power fluctuations.

Modular Cable Design:
The modular cable design of the SF750 simplifies cable management and enhances airflow within your PC case. You can connect only the cables you need, reducing clutter and optimizing cable routing. This results in improved cooling and aesthetics, allowing for a clean and tidy build.

Quiet Operation:
Thanks to the Zero RPM Fan Mode, the SF750 power supply operates silently during low to medium loads, ensuring a quiet computing experience. The fan remains idle until the power supply reaches a certain temperature or load, keeping noise levels to a minimum.

Corsair Reliability:
Corsair is a trusted brand known for its high-quality and reliable products. The SF750 power supply is no exception, providing stable and efficient power for your system. It comes with a 7-year warranty, offering peace of mind and demonstrating Corsair's confidence in its product.

In conclusion, the Corsair SF Series SF750 750 Watt SFX 80+ Platinum Certified Power Supply is a compact and powerful solution for small form factor PC builds. With its efficiency, reliability, modular design, and quiet operation, it provides everything you need for a high-performance system without compromising on space. Invest in the Corsair SF750 and experience the reliable power supply performance that Corsair is known for.

Disclaimer: I received no incentives or discounts for this review. I am simply sharing my genuine experience with this product.

This PSU is so much smaller than I had first expected when I was viewing it online. Other common units I handle from companies like Corsair are much heavier and more difficult to handle. The modularity of the unit is impressive offering the newest generation of cords and efficiency. I would highly recommend for the power it offers in this small sized package, plus the price is very reasonable in my opinion

Bought a cooler master case that came with an 850 watt PSU and an AIO. The case was fine but I must have gotten a defective power supply so I started the RMA process. Figured I would sell it once returned and just order another PSU before I shipped it out so I wouldn't have any downtime. Figured I would futureproof my rig and go with a 1000W Gold. And this corsair is what I stumbled upon. Very glad I did. Absolutely silent and fits great in my case. Will buy Corsair power supplies from now on. Only thing that was confusing about this one was that the connections to the actual PSU themselves are smaller than standard, but fine since quality cables are provided in the box.
My old power supply got fried in an electic surge, got this to replace it and it has worked flawlessly, my only complaint is the wires, they were too short for my case so had to order another set.

With that said, however, I've watched this company rise from nothing & can say for certainty that I have no worry or fear that this will short out or mess up my $3000+ dollar pc gaming build. description:

  • Cooling Fan: 120mm fan design long life and fastest cooling time (3 Speed Fan Control Switch High quality gold-coated fan guard)
  • 20+4 pin x1
  • P4 mainboard x1

reviews.review:
These power supplies are perfect for older computers. They have way fewer parts inside and don't heat up as their original counterparts from 20 years ago. They're also much lighter as a result, but I think they will have greater longevity, producing less heat, and using newer components. Very satisfied and will likely buy more, to retrofit a retro PC collection, where the PSU's are beginning to fail of old age.

I've read many comments about bad or burning up power supplies, and I guess there's a high proportion that shares factory defects, but mine is absolutely fine. Maybe I got lucky, or maybe the failure will take place down the line, in which case, I'll update the review. I intent to use there with pre-pentium era retro machines. Those draw under 150W, so I'm not really stressing the power supply at all. I do not doubt the fact that the real power rating is 250W max (and not 500W, like the box claims). Just keep it under a lite load. For serious projects, buy rated PSU's for double the price. Don't expect miracles in this price category.

I have a 13-year-old PC whose power supply died. I have to build a new one but did not have time and needed it pronto. The new part was inexpensive and better than the old one. A one day delivery was amazing thank you.
Easy to install. Plug and play, nice and quite
My biggest complaint is the 120v power connection, it's so poorly made the plug only goes half way in before I needed to push it harder than a woman giving birth to make it actually connect
This replacement power supply was exactly as advertised and swapped out easily. The fan is so quiet that I have to occasionally check to ensure it's still working. Haha. Very happy with this part.

I have a Old Desktop PC which worked for 9 years on Rosewill PSU 400W which gave up finally. I went and purchased this 500W Cooolmax PSU which worked for 2 days. Then it started to have Random Shutdown. At first I thought this was a good PSU with great pricing from Amazon, but I decided to return because I did not want to Troubleshoot this PSU. I wish these PSU's are tested for functional durability. Also, the package had plastic wrapping but inside no instructions or Warranty Card. I trusted Amazon and installed but maybe I should be more diligent if I think I am getting an old returned unit that is unreliable.

Perfectly good drop-in replacement for generic PSUs found in basic Dell PCs and other "computer-in-a-box" units you may have in your midst. Noiseless for all intents and purposes. 120mm belly fan won't run most of time (if at all) unlike the 80mm rear fans on the cheapo(er) units. Disregard the reviews submitted by those who would expect champagne on a beer budget. Serious gamers and system builders know better. (Description is incorrect. No fan switch. I presume it is thermostatically controlled. There are very few components in the unit).

I have ordered many of these now and have only had one minor problem once. I once got one that did indeed work as it should, however the bearing in one of the fans was not what it should be. I got a free replacement and free return kit for the one that didn't work and have ordered many of them since then, and never had an issue with them.

Used this "Coolmax I-500 500W ATX 12V V2.0 Power Supply (not compatible with PCI-E)" PSU to get an old Athlon II based PC quicly back up and running. Original PSU is SFX form factor and is one of those briefly manufacured around 2005 or so and having a very high current rating on the 3.3V and 5V rails. The now-failed original had ratings of 3.3V @ 22A and 5V @ 30A. A modern replacement SFX form factor PSU of suitable ratings seems to be unavailable - even the premium high power 800W or 1000W SFX PSU's don't supply anywhere near this much current on the 3.3V and 5V rails.

This Coolmax PSU is ATX form factor (big) and should not and does not fit the subject PC's SFX form factor (small) case. It was therefore strapped to the side of the PC's case, and the case's cover left off. The Coolmax-provided cables were sufficiently long to reach the motherboard. This jury-rigged external PSU setup is working well. All output voltages are right on spec, and the Coolmax PSU runs cool, even though the Coolmax's 5V rail is rated at somewhat less current than that of the original PSU. The original PSU will be repaired and reinstalled as time permits, but until then, the old PC will chug on, powered by the externally-mounted Coolmax.
Very satisfied ... great Power supply replacement for my Lenovo.

I have an Inspiron 530 that i wanted to upgrade the Graphics card for (to use for CAD and Gaming, etc.), but the issue was that the Power supply was at 350W and i did not want to risk frying my computer(Yes, that can happen if you dont have enough power). I had a budget of $210, and i got the Sapphire Radeon R7 260X(Which is an amazing GPU by the way, check it out). The graphics card was about $150 and i needed something that could fit in my budget. Being priced at approximately $31, this was a perfect fit for me. At $193, i got 2 day shipping and got the parts.

HOWEVER: When i was installing this, i got a bit confused on the parts. It has multiple Peripherals, and only 2 SATAs. Now, The 2 SATAs i used for my 2 hard drives, but my DVD drives were unpowered, so they would not work. Be sure to look at the box, and it will tell you all the parts you need. So i ordered 2 adapters for Male SATA to Female Peripherals, at $4 a piece. Add another $8 to the original $193, you end up with $201.

When using the product: This Power supply is off the rockers. The fan is so quiet, i can barely tell that the Computer is on. It has 380W Dedicated to all other accessories like Graphics Cards, etc. The system i have only uses 120W out of the 500W total. This thing is absolutely perfect, and when matched with the Sapphire Radeon R7 260X, this system can be used as an ultimate Desktop.

My Specs:

Intel Core 2 Quad Q8200 2.33 GHz
4.00 GB DDR2 Ram
Windows 8.1 Pro
Sapphire Radeon R7 260X- 2GB GDDR5, with DVI, HDMI, and Display Port(Comes with DVI to VGA Adapter)
Dell Inspiron 530 Model Case(2009 Built)

If you are looking to upgrade your power for gaming,etc. Then pair this with the Graphics card i mentioned. But ultimately, This Power Supply has got to be the best power supply i have ever bought(The only one ive ever bought as well :D). $31 Well spent on a great piece of equipment!!

4 Stars rated since i had to buy the Peripheral Adapters.

One of the most important parts of a PC build is the PSU and the attachment cables that come with it, neglecting your motherboard with strangulating crisscrossing cables is just asking for trouble. I had to compromise my graphics card and half the components on my MOBO to get a connection to my CPU. Power units are supposed to have enough cable to go around, not across the motherboard and I had to flip the unit upsidedown to bring the cables closer to the motherboard So I could even have a chance of hooking up the 4pin CPU power Also, the gauge of wire is way too thin for proper current flow that would bottleneck the power causing heat and resistance, making connectors wear out faster and possibly damaging your motherboard. Also, if you have a 4/6/8 pin power connectors for your graphics card, then you have a choice of not plugging in your card or not plugging in o your CPU or buying an adaptor connector to daisy-chain 1-4 pin into 2-4 pin connectors for an 8 pin connector. It would be useless, as the PSU couldn't maintain that kind of current flow with cables it has now. This PSU is not for performance or even for a light gaming rig. Sure it is useful for repowering old hp and dell PC's as most of those rigs have top down PSU's (unit is above motherboard), or middle left of the board and that they rarely go above 300 watts, I decided not to risk my rig in an effort to save money, the monetary damages would far exceed the cost of 20 of theses PSU's
Works perfectly

name: Corsair RM1000x Shift Fully Modular ATX Power Supply - Modular Side Interface - ATX 3.0 & PCIe 5.0 Compliant - Zero RPM Fan Mode - 105°C-Rated Capacitors - 80 Plus Gold Efficiency - Black
description:
• Fully Modular Micro-Fit PSU Connectors: CORSAIR Type 5 Gen 1 micro-fit PSU cables mean you only connect the cables your system needs while taking up less space.
  • Intel ATX 3.0 Certified: Compliant with the ATX 3.0 power standard, supporting the PCIe Gen 5 platform and resisting transient power spikes.
  • Zero RPM Fan Mode Support: At low and medium loads the cooling fan switches off entirely for near-silent operation.
  • 100% 105°C-Rated Japanese Electrolytic Capacitors: Premium internal components deliver unwavering power delivery and long-term reliability.
