reviews.review: Alimentation puissante et silencieuse, facile a installer avec les cables qui se debranchent de sorte que l'on utilise uniquement les câbles dont on a besoin dans la tour.

Overall, the Corsair RM1000x is a decent power supply unit (PSU) that comes at a relatively good price, especially if you can find it on sale. The sleek design and quiet fan operation are pluses, and the thick, durable cables indicate good build quality. However, there are a few drawbacks to consider.

Ease of installation may be a challenge, particularly if you have a smaller case. The cables are stiff and not flat, which can make cable management difficult, and they may not fit through smaller case holes or leave enough clearance to put the back panel back on. However, the cables are wrapped in mesh to help protect them, and once you get them plugged in, they are unlikely to break.

Speaking of the cables, the marketing images are misleading when it comes to the number of PCIe cables that come with the unit. Corsair should update the product descriptions to match the actual number of cables. The RM1000x comes with 3 PCIe cables that terminate in 2 8 pins for a total of 6 8 pin PCIe connections (Though for the newer GPUs it is advised to not use the additional 8 pin), And the RM850x comes with 2 PCIe cables that terminate in 2 8 pins as well for a total of 4 8 pin connections.

In terms of price, the RM1000x is a good value, especially if you can find it on sale. At the time of purchase, it was the cheapest name-brand 80+ Gold rated PSU available. Additionally, the warranty period is very decent, which adds to the overall value.

In conclusion, the Corsair RM1000x is a solid PSU with a few drawbacks to consider. If you have a larger case and don't mind dealing with stiff cables, this PSU is a good option. The build quality is high, and the price is reasonable, especially when on sale.
It works, that's all it needs to do. The modular cables work great - one criticism is that it only has 2 PCI cables, you'll need a 3rd if you're going to hook up a high-end video card.

My RM850x was starting to be a little limited, if you already have an RMx don't go for an RMe you will be very disappointed, the new connection system on the side is really very good, it makes the work a lot easier, on the other hand I think that it is not suitable for all cases, it comes with the new type 5 cable, the connectors which go to the power supply are smaller and the cables are easier to bend
Très silencieux fière de mon achat.

Brand is a decent quality, price was fair but slightly high for me. It was however cheaper then the lower wattage ones at the date of purchase so I got the 1000 watt when i could of been fine with a 750 watt. Does what it needs to and was a pretty generic install. wires seem to be of decent quality and seem to clip in firm as most brands do. Cannot go wrong with this powerhouse.
For Gaming

The fan is not moving unless I am doing some cpu or gpu stress test. It may be good for some quiet build but my other fans are loud Af. This battery is the only warm spot in my pc during gaming. I need it to spin to take the heat out of my case before it accumulating heat.

This is a great quality product from well-known reputable company, a PSU with great modularity and great performance, and frankly a good value. Lots of connectors and on the shift model, if that's what you're looking at side mounted connection points.

Here's where the details come in. Is this PSU is primarily for cases with side mounted PSU slots, while in a wider case this might work in a flat mount situation, most likely you are going to need a fairly wide case to house the wiring coming off the supply without bending the wires too much. Even then in some side mount cases, or the PSU is mounted on its side, the wires sticking upright can still impede on certain things, for example with the Lian-Li o11 dynamic XL, The upright facing ports for the connectors on the wires to plug into impede with the bottom hot swap hard drive bay. Now if I really wanted to press the wires down flat against the power supply unit I could probably still fit the hot swap bay in the case, but it wouldn't give much room for the wires, nor allow for much passive heat dissipation from the PSU. In this particular instance with the case I chose a standard end connector output PSU would have been the better choice, as there is ample room at the end for wiring clutter, but due to the hot swap bay mounted above the power supply unit, the side output of the shift model is not intuitive for my case.

Removal of the bottom hot swap bay in my case alleviated the issue, but also presents the inconvenience of not having all four hot swap bays available. I never thought I would use this feature, but over the years as I have acquired multiple hard drives and stored up massive amounts of data, it actually comes in handy for moving data back and forth between drives.

So no stars docked for the design it's actually great, just really think about whether or not you need the side output connectors and whether or not you will have enough room in your case. They make it more convenient to plug and unplug additional wires without having to remove the power supply unit completely, however you may run into spacing issues in smaller cases.

Situationally recommended.

I recently purchased the Corsair RM850x (2021) Fully Modular ATX Power Supply, and I must say, I am extremely impressed with its performance and features. Corsair has always been known for delivering high-quality power supplies, and the RM850x is no exception. Here's my review of this remarkable power supply.

First and foremost, the efficiency of the RM850x is outstanding. With its 80 PLUS Gold certification, it delivers excellent power efficiency, ensuring that my system consumes less energy and runs cooler. This not only helps in reducing electricity bills but also contributes to the overall longevity and reliability of my system.

The fully modular design of the RM850x is a game-changer. It allows for easy cable management, as I can connect only the cables I need and keep the rest neatly stored away. This not only enhances the aesthetics of my build but also improves airflow within the case. The modular design also makes installation a breeze, as I can effortlessly connect the required cables without any clutter or hassle.

One of the standout features of this power supply is its low-noise fan. The fan operates silently under regular loads, and I barely notice its presence. It only kicks in when the system is under heavy load, and even then, the noise levels are impressively low. The Zero RPM fan mode is particularly noteworthy, as it ensures complete silence during idle or low-power usage scenarios. This is a great feature for those who prefer a quiet computing experience.

The build quality of the RM850x is top-notch. The unit feels solid and durable, and the black finish gives it a sleek and premium look. The cables provided are of high quality and have a premium feel as well. The power supply comes with all the necessary protections, including over-voltage, under-voltage, over-power, over-temperature, and short-circuit protection, ensuring the safety of my components.

In terms of power delivery, the RM850x handles my system with ease. It provides ample power for my high-end components, including a demanding CPU and a high-performance graphics card. The voltage regulation is excellent, and I have not encountered any stability issues or power-related problems since installing this power supply.

One minor drawback of the RM850x is its size. It's a bit larger than some other power supplies on the market, so it might not fit into smaller PC cases. However, in most standard ATX cases, this should not be an issue.

Overall, the Corsair RM850x (2021) Fully Modular ATX Power Supply is an exceptional product that delivers on all fronts. Its efficiency, modular design, low-noise fan, and solid build quality make it a reliable choice for any PC enthusiast or gamer. With its impressive performance and thoughtful features, the RM850x is definitely worth the investment for those looking for a high-quality power supply to power their systems.

I highly recommend the Corsair RM850x to anyone in need of a powerful, efficient, and silent power supply for their PC build. Corsair has once again raised the bar with this outstanding product.

Got this PSU cause I knew it 1. had more than enough power needed for my new build and 2. the case it went into was designed by corsair, and was able to check clearance on everything. I didn't go with the Shift version of the PSU for the simple reason that although it's unique, I see a lot of people complaining about its practicality. So, I went with the 2021 version of the RM1000x.

The pros are basic. Strong but also stiff cables with protection in the proper places. Very easy overall install & modularity we've came to be familiar with when it comes to modern PSU's. Quiet operation, & plenty of peace of mind knowing I have plenty of power for my build (6950xt + 13600k).

CONS.... This is the biggest con thus far, and I will complain about it until the end of time. Not that it's ever been okay practice, but having your PCIE cables all have a pigtailed additional 6 pin is just miserable to deal with. My GPU requires two 8 pins & one 6 pin... that's three separate cables with three separate & dangling 6 pin pigtails that'll never be used. I can understand giving only 6+2's even though it should be practice at this point to have some full 8 pin's, but I'll never understand a 6+2's with pigtailed 6 pins on a 1000W unit..... JUST NO. Please, if you're reading this and considering this PSU, please keep in mind to use a separate PCIE 6+2 cable for each connection on the card, AND DO NOT USE THE PIGTAILED 6 PIN THAT'S ATTACHED TO THEM. For lower power cards back in the day this wasn't a huge deal but was still bad practice to daisy chain your PCIE connections like that. Nowadays, with the power these cards are capable of drawing, there's NO REASON a 1000w PSU would even give you the option to daisy chain. A pretty big & detrimental (in my opinion) overlook on Corsair's part. Luckily you can use a cable tie or strap & just bunch them all together but... no one that has built a pc will tell you it looks good.

other than that one major annoyance that I deem to be a con, great power supply.

While this looked really cool and I thought it would be a game changer, I would HIGHLY recommend anyone to really check against the case you plan to use and the internal configuration, ie. where the PSU will be mounted.

I used this with a Corsair 7000D, so there was a very good chance it would be compatible. While the idea of easier access of cabling via side mounting to the PSU, the thing I realized is that not all cases are aligned to this orientation. Most cases today assume rear mounted cables. This means that they don't always have enough clearance between the PSU and the side panel to accommodate the cables. Given I had a Corsair case, it wasn't a problem. The motherboard cable did seem to be a tight fit but made it work. With this PSU, I do believe it allowed me to keep the 2nd 3.5" drive cage closest to the PSU. If I had used traditional rear mounted cable PSU, I definitely would need to sacrifice this drive cage. It wouldn't be a huge deal breaker as I, like most people, are moving away from HDD to SSD.

It worked out for me. Was it mind blowing amazing or evolutionary? I don't think so... I don't think it will be until case manufacturers start considering this PSU into their designs. For now, it's best compatible with Corsair cases. For other brands, really think through whether you'll have the clearances you need. Otherwise, stick to traditional rear cable mounted PSUs.

The other reason why I got this particular PSU was because it was the only Corsair one that was ATX3.0 at the 1000W+ range. Needed ATX3.0 to ensure I had the native 12pin power cable for the RTX 4090 to minimize using the octopus adapter that is provide by the card for older PSU. This adapter could increase the chance of the "melting cable" situation for NVidia cards. Native 12pin GPU cable is the way to go. It also keeps things clean and minimized.

The Corsair RMX Series (2021) RM750x is a 750 Watt power supply that exemplifies reliability, efficiency, and modular design. This power supply unit (PSU) has surpassed my expectations, providing stable and consistent power delivery while offering a convenient and tidy cable management solution.

The standout feature of the Corsair RM750x is its robust 750 Watt power output. This wattage is more than enough to handle high-end gaming rigs and power-hungry components, ensuring that my system gets the required power for peak performance.

With an 80 Plus Gold certification, the RM750x guarantees high energy efficiency, reducing power wastage and lowering electricity bills. Its power efficiency also translates into less heat generation, leading to quieter operation and improved system longevity.

The fully modular design of the RM750x is a game-changer for cable management. It allows me to connect only the necessary cables, minimizing clutter and maximizing airflow inside my PC case. This results in a clean and organized build with improved cooling capabilities.

The PSU's zero RPM fan mode ensures silent operation during low to medium loads, as the fan only spins up when required, keeping noise levels at a minimum, even during intense gaming sessions.

The RM750x comes equipped with high-quality Japanese capacitors, ensuring exceptional reliability and stability. These capacitors contribute to the PSU's long lifespan and consistent performance.

Corsair is a reputable brand known for its high-quality PC components, and the RMX Series continues that tradition. The RM750x is a testament to Corsair's commitment to providing top-tier power supplies for enthusiasts and professionals.

In conclusion, the Corsair RMX Series (2021) RM750x is a reliable and efficient power supply unit that offers stable power delivery and a modular design for easy cable management. Its 750 Watt power output, 80 Plus Gold certification, and silent operation make it the ideal choice for powering high-performance gaming systems. If you're looking for a premium power supply with excellent efficiency and clean cable management, the Corsair RM750x is the perfect option. I highly recommend this PSU for its outstanding performance and the peace of mind it brings to my PC build!

This would be a great cable extension kit except that the color of the PCI-E 12VHPWR cable doesn't match the other cables. The difference is immediately noticeable as they are pretty different shades of white with the 12VHPWR being much brighter white. The wire gage is also different, but that doesn't bother me as much.

Otherwise, the cables are very nice quality, the 24 Pin (Motherboard) and 8 Pin EPS (CPU) connectors are a thick gage that was easy to train and looks great. The included cable combs are surprisingly easy to get into place and slide easily enough to make training the cables very doable. The 12VHPWR cable comes with cable combs already attached which is a plus.

If the colors matched (or were at least a bit closer together) for all the cables this would be a 5/5... as is it's a good quality set of extensions limited by the fact that it's a bit of a mess aesthetically.

Silverstone SX300-B es el candidato excelente y accesible para alimentar sistema de bajo consumo, cuando importa protección estable de los componentes alimentados.

El producto se probó con:
--- Gabinete: Silverstone ML06 B/E
--- Tarjeta Madre: Biostar A68N 5600
--- Procesador: AMD A10-4655M (TDP 25W)
--- Gráficos: Radeon HD7620G integrados
--- 2x módulos RAM DDR3 1333Mhz 4GB
--- SSD SATA 120GB

A Favor:
--- Eficiencia 80 Plus Bronce.
--- Su fabricante OEM es FSP (famoso y ofrece buena calidad).
--- Equipado con 5x protecciones más importantes (OCP, OPP, OVP, SCP y UVP).
--- Cumple con estándar IEC 62368-1 (máxima seguridad a componentes alimentados en regulaciones de voltajes).
--- PFC Activo.
--- Un solo Riel +12V.
--- Formato SFX estándar (el más compacto de los SFX).
--- Cables de calidad, negros y flexibles (cómodos a la hora de instalar).
--- Conector PCIe de 6+2 pines.

En Contra:
--- No incluye adaptador SFX a ATX.
--- Utiliza ventilador de solo 80mm con rodamiento Sleeve Bearing (es aconsejable su uso en posición vertical).
--- La ventilación puede ser perceptible (depende de ubicación en el gabinete). Si los lados laterales de SX-300B tocan paneles del gabinete - podrían transmitir el zumbido de ventilador (se corrige con juntas o remaches de silicona). A carga baja su ventilador siempre gira al mínimo preconfigurado. Pero la mitad del ventilador está tapada de fábrica con placa de plástico transparente y fijada directamente en él, con objetivo de crear el túnel de enfriamiento, aumentando el flujo de aíre en parte más profunda del dispositivo, que puede crear ruido adicional.
--- Sus condensadores principales y secundarios no son japoneses.

Conclusión:
SX-300B es la fuente certificada y segura a precio accesible. Es conveniente para sistemas de bajo consumo, en especial con gráficos integrados, como CPUs R5 5600G (consume en carga máxima solo 100W) o R7 5700G (consume en carga máxima 150W).
Para mejorar la sonoridad de SX-300B le quité por completo al ventilador la placa de plástico transparente (tunneling) y además lo instalé con unos remaches de silicona en vez de tornillos - para eliminar vibraciones y posible zumbido.

I used this power supply when building a small PC around a Mini-ITX motherboard. I needed a "Flex ATX" power supply to fit in the small PC case. This power supply fit perfectly. My main concern is that I am not sure if the fan works. I've never seen it come on . The PC uses an Intel 12400 which has a TDP of 65 watts. With no other large power consuming components in the build, this PC does not use much power, therefore the power supply is not working too hard. So maybe the power supply doesn't need to turn on its fan. One option would be to include a switch to allow the fan to run full time or only when thermally needed.

This power supply does include all of the usual standard connectors, even a floppy drive connector. This a non-modular power supply, so you can't remove any of these cables. In a small PC, these cables get in the way. So be aware of the potential concerns there. Yes you could cut off and cap off the unneeded wires, but that will go beyond what most people want to do.

Ultimately this power supply did meet my needs and it looks like about the only name brand Flex ATX power supply that looked viable. I would buy this again.

reviews.review: I previously bought a case+psu combo unit from a reputable manufacturer and the power supply was horrible. This one was whisper quiet, no coil whine, good quality. Highly recommended!

The noise level is very quiet but not at first ~ the PSU arrived with a slightly dented in plastic cover over the bottom end which the unit sits on. That meant that the fan blades were hitting the cover and was only fixed after we pulled the cover outward away from the blades inside. For an expensive device you would expect to have a metal covering and not thin plastic. Otherwise the delivery and the PSU works well.

Can not beat the value. GREAT power supply.
Great PSU, fully modular and 80+ gold. However, there are other cheaper A tier PSUs. I got this on sale for half price so I jumped on it

I was using XPG Core Reactor 850W Gold PSU to power pcie risers and 3 AMD RX 5700 video cards. My load was more or less constant at less than half the rated capacity. My system ran for better part of two months without problems but all of a sudden two weeks ago I discovered the distinct smell of burning plastic coming from the vicinity of my computer / PSU. With all the advertised built in protections like OCP it was hard for me to get my mind around how the PSU itself could be the source of the issue, but indeed, as per pictures, this is exactly what now seems to be at the root of the issue.
I only wish I had to deal with coil whine or a PSU that tripped and was no longer functioning. Unfortunately my unit stayed on line creating a potential fire hazard. By virtue of the quality of the power it continued to feed my GPUs, it seems it also did what I now assume is irreparable harm to thousands of dollars of equipment I had connected to it.
I am thinking that given the cost of components like GPUs relative to PSUs, the cases where PSUs fail taking connected components with them are exceedingly rare. I would expect that, in the case of PSU manufacturers targeting builds with high end components, they would want to go above and beyond in their response to situations where failure of there PSUs have led to significant loss to attached components.
My initial attempt to address my situation with XPG was using the facilities of their website on the day my PSU failed. I have still received no response to this overture. A few days back I located and called a toll free number and talked to a service rep. I was underwhelmed with the quality of our discussion. He did say that he would address my case with management and get back to me but he did not commit to any timeline. Yesterday I received an emailed response saying XPG had converged on a rather limited response to my case. They would focus only on the PSU and look into issuing an RMA, assuming I was willing to pay the cost of shipping my PSU back to their facilities in California. In short, with XPG, I was left with a distinct impression that failure of their PSUs in a manner where connected components are lost is a distinct, perhaps even common possibility, and that one should not expect XPG to do much more than make a feeble attempt to replace the PSU itself.
My faith in XPG as a brand of PSUs has been destroyed. I don't think I can justify even the cost of one way shipping to get a replacement unit given my new sense of how prone this replacement might be to fail in the same way as my original unit and resulting financial impact.

  • Certified Full Protection: OCP/OVP/OPP/OTP/UVP/SCP, Safety/EMC Approvals: cTUVus, TUV, FCC, CB, CE certified.
  • Clean Black Cables: All black cables to match your other components, with sleeved motherboard connector to help with cable management.
  • Quiet Operation: Silent 120mm fan with sleeved bearing for smooth and quiet operation.
  • Guaranteed protection with 5 Year Manufacturer Warranty

reviews.review: No issues with this power supply. Be prepared for a challenge managing the cables. On the upside you'll never complain that a cable is too short!

Excellent PSU tres satisfait pour le prix et meme durable.

This Power Supply Unit (PSU) is of great value if your graphics card does not require a 6-pin ePCI GPU connector. Other than the lack of this style of power connector, I am pleased with the quality of the power supply and recommend it for basic to midlevel systems.
As a basic PSU, it’s perfect. It isn’t fancy, but gets the job done at the price

I buy these for budget and ultra budget builds. They run well during stress testing and the build quality I just a little more than what you would expect at this price. It’s also not as loud as you would think for a PSU that is under $50.

I had not used a Zalman PSU prior but I will keep this PSU in mind for future builds needing 600W of power. I could barely even hear the psu fan as the cpu fan is usually loudest. I built a Ryzen 5600G build with the Zalman 600W with intentions for adding in a GPU. A 600W should support most mid range gpus like the RX 6600 and RTX 2060.

A good basic non-modular power supply. Good price. Everything is connected and working as it should. As always, check that the power connectors on your motherboard and peripherals match before buying.

reviews.review:
Bought this is October 2023 for the good cybernetics rating looked at the spec sheet from them and for the price ATX 3.0 standard gold rating it's a good deal is it the best efficiency no, particularly 5v standby voltage shows it was as low as 67% EFFICIENCY at 115V which in that result is lower than my 750w EVGA NEX bronze
but overall still more efficient and comes with the new 12VHWPR cable

I recently bought a new video card, and research suggested that I upgraded my PSU as well. I make good money so I figured I would just buy the 1000w over my 750w anyways. Both modular, so not much difference, wires appeared to be same, just with different shade on white numbering on the plugs - I switched out all the wiring and tucked it better than previously. PC runs quiet, the PSU is quiet I mean.

Super easy to install--love the modular setup, allowing you to only use the cables you require---cable management is already a pain, this makes it far easier and much cleaner install. Would purchase again.
This provides a lot of power. Does what you expect.

I dont have any pictures of this psu but i built a gaming pc for my brother and when it is paired with
Corsair H100x RGB Elite Liquid CPU Cooler

it will unleash ALOT more potential my brother and i are very pleased so far and i still think he is running without a gpu
Good
It comes with white cables, instant 5 stars.

I don't really have PSU testing tools, so I defer any serious considerations to them, but this model does have a lot of shining reviews by those who do have the tools (though of course reviews have to always be taken with a grain of salt. Or a whole shaker even these days.)

What I can tell is that it has all the outward signs of a quality PSU. It's quite hefty for its size, seems to have a good fan, etc etc. When I measure things like voltage via software (not sure how reliable that is, but it's the best I have,) they seem to be more stable than my previous PSUs.

One curiosity I don't really know how to explain is it has an extra relay inside doing who knows what. When you first turn things on, it's already able to handle the full power draw of the computer, so it's not like it's a low power switch for suspending or something -- it's straight to 100% before the relay even switches. I'm wondering if it switches on a capacitor after initial startup pull to handle power blinks and the like while avoiding that huge sudden instant draw you'd normally get, but this is merely a guess.

All in all I'm very much liking it. It's a tiny bit more compact to also work with smaller systems, but also fits fine in my mid tower (these days I guess that's considered a full tower, lol.) The modular cables work fairly well, though I wish the parts that can be put together or pulled apart (like the CPU power connector) snapped together more firmly so you don't have to carefully hold them together while inserting. I was pleasantly surprised it even included the latest 12VHPWR type-4 connector.

I guess if I had to try to choose something to complain about, I wish the power efficiency curve was a bit friendlier towards the low end. Most people aren't actually using anywhere near to 850 watts of power (a lot of people would be very shocked if they plugged their computers into a Kill-a-Watt or similar meter!) For most people normal usage and light gaming is easily going to fall into the bottom side of the curve and get somewhere in the vicinity of 75% efficiency. Ideally one would pick a PSU that more aligns with what the system actually uses (taking care to ensure sufficient current of course) but I can say I picked this one because I needed a PSU I could keep for many years to come and pretty much not even have to think about it no matter what I added to my system (within reason of course. I'm not likely to be adding any of the highest end CPUs or GPUs and especially not dual GPUs which is where one is most likely to start to actually get up to numbers closer to 850.)

I think most people will never come even close to fully utilizing this PSU making it a great option for a huge variety of systems (albeit at the cost of some efficiency loss for most.) From what I can tell I think we can count on it to hold up over time. Even the fan should be decent enough to not die too easily. Especially since most of the time on systems that aren't pushing it really hard the fan runs extremely quietly at a lower RPM.

Thank you sooo much as that made it a breaze to get something going. I try to be independent and do something that would work for me. :) i hope replacement works i can understand not all defects are detected. It really ment a lot how the supprt team helped me

reviews.review:
Good quality overall and cheap price

Would recommend

It is a decent cheap PSU i have one in my CyberpowerPC RTX 2070 Super with a i7-9700k build runs great even with the GPU being overclocked no issues.... Had it over 2 months now i will report back if any issues.
Both my power supplies just randomly got fried in a month's time. Highly unrecommended

This unit came in a Cyberpower prebuilt I bought. Been troubleshooting spontaneous lockups and reboots after exiting a game or other high workload for the GPU (RTX3070). Found 12V feeds to the MB and 12 pin connectors to the GPU where sagging from 11.8x (Low to begin with) down to as low as 11.3-11.4 under load and then overshooting up to 12.3V when exiting a heavy load situation. Also .2V difference in two separate 8 pin connectors at all time, they're not balanced on the unit I have.

Long story still long, I replaced it with an EVGA 750G+ and no more issues. Voltages are spot on and rock solid at all times. Price difference between the Apevia unit and the EVGA is almost $10 cheaper at this time so it's a no brainer if I was in the market for a PS, by name brand (EVGA, Seasonic, Etc). I feel lucky my RTX3070 wasn't damaged.

Not impressed with Cyberpower either for using junk on a $2000+ prebuilt but about what I expected. With component availability/prices the way they are building from scratch just isn't practical right now.

This came with my Cyberpower prebuilt.

I7-9700k
16Gb Ram
2070 Super

While playing games like Tarkov, Valorant, Fortnite, Far Cry, and such. My computer randomly started restarting. I noticed this was happening under load.

I attempted to uninstall my graphics card drivers with DDU and did a clean reinstall. I thought it was my graphics card due to the restarting during games. Reinstalling graphics drivers did not fix the problem.

I then swapped the pcie cables that were plugged into the GPU again to try to fix the problem but it did not work.

Next, I attempted to update my bios since sometimes power management might be an issue there. Still no change.

After attempting a few other things like overclocking my CPU and Ram and constantly watching my stats. I decided to pull the plug on an EVGA 850w Gold and my computer has been running stable since.

Overall, I can't recommend a random brand for a PSU. Go with the well regarded ones for $20 more.

I been having issues non stop with this power supply I have changed my cpu my motherboard and my ram also my gpu and my pc will sometimes not want to boot with the dram issue so I went out bought new ram and still was doing the same thing. I have done a lot of reading and everything points to the psu. This psu is basically brand new it came in a prebuilt I bought off of my uncle like 2 months ago the psu is very unreliable

Just got it installed and wired. I bought this one because it has four PCIe plugs, seven SATA connections, even has 3 old school IDE connectors. The cabling is wrapped nicely in black mesh, which I didn't expect from a budget unit. It isn't modular, but the wiring is more than long enough for my mid ATX tower. Some ppl said the wiring is too short?? I have a mid tower and I had to curl amd toe back most of it. I guess maybe a full size tower would need creative routing and component placement, but the wiring on this unit is a little longer than standard. I've built many systems- some mine and quite a few for friends and such. These are standard length if not a bit longer. It's hard to find a PSU with more than 4 or 5 SATA connectors for less than 100$. This has 7. I have 5 HDD and 2 DVD writers so I need at least 7 without a hub. I can't hear ot at all. I only hear my case fans and the CPU fan. So far, I'm very happy with it. It is puttimg out nominally about 550W but specs say it can peak short bursts of over 850. IDK about that, I've icky had it for a few hours. Very happy with this purchase. Price is phenomenal for 800W with this many connectors.

I was really hopeful when buying from Apevia, since I believe they've turned the tide on their product quality and are now a brand worth buying from. And for the most part I can confirm that they do produce quality products now. However, there's just one problem I have with this 800W Gold power supply. The noise. The fan used to cool this PSU runs constantly, and sounds like a very muffled little engine just put-putting along in there. Since the rest of my PC is virtually silent, the noise from the PSU fan is very prominent. Gaming sounds fine, since the rest of my PC spins up anyway, but while editing photos and doing homework, this thing gets really irritating. I just can't keep a PSU in my PC that sounds like this constantly. Otherwise, if you already have noisy components in your PC, like an AIO pump or fans that stay on, then go for it. You can't beat this wattage and efficiency rating for the price.

I think that this could be a terrific bargain - due to two major reasons. Apevia (formerly Aspire) is still trying to "fix" an image that rightfully came from selling really bad power supplies in the early 2000's. And, this was largely the result of using Young Year as their primary OEM, a Taiwanese manufacturer that built some of the most inferior PSUs made and mislabeling them with false specifications.

Almost every major PSU brand uses an OEM. Most don’t actually manufacture power supplies, they use an OEM manufacturer. Apevia now uses a reputable and above average manufacturer now. Andyson is not as well known as some of the more prestigious OEMs like Seasonic or FSP - but they have a solid reputation. When you look at legit and credible reviews of their H6 800W (AD-800GGF) power supply (which coincidentally share the same model number) such as Johnny Guru and others online, its been noted for its excellent voltage stability, very good to excellent ripple control and nice looking power on transient results. Personally, I think it's the same exact unit - only relabeled. The only knocks are the lack of modular cables. The build is solid. "Electrolytics are mostly the good stuff with most of them Chemi-Con or Nichicon." A retail Andyson 800w Gold PSU sells for over a $100. But the company is not well known and still struggling for market share. So this is why Apevia with the market power is rebranding them.

You will notice that major builders, including Cyber Power, are using Apevia power supplies in their gaming systems. They're not doing this without a lot of thought. Andyson OEMs, rebranded as Apevia PSUs, are solid, well priced power supplies built well with reputable credentials. At low prices two to three times less the other good OEMs.

I will update this review - when the power supply arrives. I am replacing a 600w Thermaltake PSU in my 11 year old's computer. He has an AMD 1600 (really a 2600) which i bought here on Amazon on an MSI 450B motherboard as well as a PowerColor Red Devil RX 580. Since I am OC', both are pretty power hungry. This PSU one carries a 3 year warranty - which isn't too bad. And using it's old history against them. Hope this helps everyone and let everyone get a fair review of this PSU. I'll post again once i install the PSU.

Update: It arrived last week. My son, an avid gamer - has played on his esports rig all weekend. Not one hiccup. Build is solid and the fan is better than expected. Have not had any problems. I'm not going to compare the heft of this PSU to my 1600W but its seems very solid. No modular cables but everything is sleeved. And surprisingly, it has a controlled fan - which I didn't expect. Very quiet. More than I expected. Overall, I'm giving this a 4 for build and use and a 5 for value. Seriously, I think I got an 800W Gold Certified PSU by Andyson for $70. That is a bargain.

Just an important note: Please remember that PSU's are hit or miss. I can't verify the QC but overall, Andyson's QC is much better than most. I got a good one. Most have according to the review stars. YMMV.
works ok and is cheap.
Haven't started the build yet so it's still in the box, but it came quick and well/safely packaged in the amazon box.

name: Corsair HX1000i Fully Modular Ultra-Low Noise ATX Power Supply - ATX 3.0 & PCIe 5.0 Compliant - Fluid Dynamic Bearing Fan - CORSAIR iCUE Software Compatible - 80 Plus Platinum Efficiency - Black
description:
• Fully Modular Cabling: Connect only the cables your system needs, making clean and tidy builds easy.
  • Intel ATX 3.0 Certified: Compliant with the ATX 3.0 power standard, supporting the PCIe Gen 5 platform and resisting transient power spikes.
  • 140mm Fluid Dynamic Bearing (FDB) Fan: Delivers extremely quiet and long-lasting fan performance.
  • Powerful CORSAIR iCUE Software: Create custom fan curves, monitor power settings, and toggle between single to multi-rail overcurrent protection (OCP) on-thefly.
  • Zero RPM Fan Mode: At low and medium loads the cooling fan switches off entirely for near-silent operation.

reviews.review:
Easy installation and comes with all the power cables you could ever ask for!

My favourite part about this PSU is easily the ability to plug it into a USB header on your motherboard through the USB-C port on it (cable for that is included of course).

The ability to monitor every single power output on the PSU is amazing for anyone like me who loves to check over how all of their parts are performing, the monitoring panel in Corsairs ICue software shows everything for the PSU in it!

It's worth the money to me!
easy and straight fwd install.. just make sure you have the room for a slightly oversized unit depth wise.

To be honest, I barely need 850w for my system; but I bought this PSU because it interfaces with ICue and allows for power monitoring and fan curve customization. If any other smaller PSU had the ICue interface, I would have bought a more appropriate wattage.

It is running cool and silent and stays around 45c at low loads. Even during benchmarking, I never see above 50c'ish, and have not had the fan kick on at all.

The ICue interface is on the upper end of the spectrum when it comes to functionality and display. All that purple power looks great on the dash!

In the attached image, running a 3060ti under load at 300w and 94% efficiency.

Great product. Mechanical installation is a challenge if you need to brace it rather than lay it in the bottom of your case. This may be an issue as there are no tapped holes to screw into on the connector side. Luckily for me the four face plate taps allowed me to use washers to lap the case enough to make it a solid mount. I replaced my SuperMicro A7045 Server Case.
Been using corsair products for over 25 yrs they never let me down, put this power supply into a new build Great products
Love the 12vhpwr that comes with this psu, work great on my MSI 4090. The monitoring software is great for keeping tabs on system load. No regrets.
Purchased for son building a gaming PC, Works fine happy with purchase.

description:

reviews.review:
Make sure you're aware this is not going to mount into a mid tower case with the "normal" PSU mounting without an additional adapter plate as this is a flex ATX PSU. If you're going this route, you will likely need either extension cables or a different CPU or motherboard power cable, as these might not be long enough for such case.

As you can see in my picture, I ignored all of my own advice because I got this in an attempt to revive my very old computer as a bench setup vs a full time use "clean" build. I ended up just two sided taping the psu down to the bottom of the case & running the cables around in the most chaotic way possible. In my case, the CPU power cable was long enough, but the motherboard power cable was just shy of being long enough if I were to move the PSU back flush with the back of the case.

Anyway, it works. I'm using it to power an old and bulldozer 6100 which should be just over 100 watts at peak, and my old GTX 970 which is somewhere around 160 watts at peak. Including everything I'm probably close to 300W total, which is shy of the 400W claimed rating (which you should always aim to be below the rating in my opinion). I played a few older games and likely didn't reach the 300W theoretical power draw but I didn't see any power issues for what it's worth. I lack tools to get better current or power draw estimates than that.

I've never had a flex PSU before so this might be standard, but one thing I did notice is the lack of a on off switch near the AC plug on the back.

The fan is quiet enough, I didn't notice any noise over the rest of the computer.

As for pricing, it seems similarly priced to other Flex PSU. If you can live with or otherwise would want a standard PSU, i would stick with that vs this just for the price difference. Of you absolutely need a flex PSU, I don't see any reason to not get this one.

It's a power supply and it currently supplies power like i would expect so that's a 5 star from me. This will probably have an easier life in this bench setup that most people, so as for the longevity of it I doubt I'll ever see an issue with it. I'll edit the review if it does stop working on me soon enough for me to remember having left this review.

#ITEM: 400W Power Supply Flex ATX. #CONCLUSION: It's a great power supply. Fan is pretty quiet and wiring is easy. #WHOAMI: I'm an inventor/engineer, so I go deep on design and details. #MYAPPLICATION: I have a 1U server board that needed a power supply. It's hard to find a supply that will fit in a 1u case, but this one fit well. The fan is quiet, and it handles the draw of the CPU at 100% without any trouble. Normal server power supplies are crazy loud, so it was great to find this quiet power supply. Now I can use this machine as a daily desktop machine. #ENJOY

This is not a bad modular power supply. The 400 watt power supply is not too bad for what I need it for. It is not something you can really use for a crypto mining setup but this can be used to power your computer and GPU. I actually like having this in my small ITX case as it is a definite space saver. The installation can be tricky depending on what kind of case you have but I did use it as my motherboard testing center until I use it for my mini PC. In terms of pricing, I am not entirely sure it is worth the price due to the amount of modular plugs and the watts it provides. There is nothing too fancy about this in terms of color or look. It is just a simple black color PSU. It is just a smaller size. The fan is a bit noisy though. I honestly not surprised considering the compact size of this device. The connectors are all pretty simple. It is sturdy and easy to plug in. It has the same latches that prevent you from accidentally pulling the plug out. Depending on what kind of GPU, you can run a GPU on this power supply. The power supply does get a bit hot which makes me worried about it burning out. Overall I think this is an okay power supply but I cannot justify the high price as it is only 400 w. The power supply does run a bit too loud and hot but this is probably due to the compact size and fan. The plugs provided are enough to start and power most mid size computers but just know it is only 400 w. It can be mounted but it can be tricky depending on what kind of case you are mounting to.

This thing powered the system, and works, and has all the connectors that you would need for a smaller gaming system. I absolutely hate that it doesn't mount in the PSU area of the case. I really wish that it came with an adapter that would make it a little more elegant than just hanging out in the bottom of the case un-mounted. A bit noisy and has cycled on me a couple of times so I'm not sure if the PSU is faulty or if I'm demanding too much power from it. Will replace with something bigger like 750 watt that mounts in the intended spot for a PSU.

Slowly reassembling a mini ITX HTPC as I get various parts in hand for it. Wanted a better PSU as the existing one was a 275watt. This'll do it!

It's an older AMD with a blasted 95w CPU in it (try finding a good heatsink for this size case.... ew!), so I need something that can handle that, a low-profile 1050, and have enough overhead remaining (I'm of the mindset that one should determine their max load and get a PSU that can handle that plus another 30-40% beyond max TDP).

That this PSU is modular is a big deal, because if you deal with mini-ITX, you know you need to be creative in hiding all your cables properly. Thus far I haven't witnessed any rebooting as others have described, but I will certainly keep an eye out for that.

name: EZDIY-FAB PCIE 5.0 12VHPWR Sleeved Cable Kit, 16AWG Power Supply Cable Extension, PC PSU Sleeved Cable, 24PIN-ATX/(4+4) PIN-EPS/(12+4) PIN to 3X 8 PIN PCIE- RTX4080/4070Ti Extension Cable- White
description:
• Made of 16AWG high-density copper wire, easily handle your ultra 1000W+ power modular power supply, long-term stability and superior performance are the foundation for protecting your computer.
  • The terminal is made of alloy copper, providing support for a maximum output of 600W, stable performance and safety under high-load use, no frame drop , no screen flickering, and continuous power supply.
  • Premium quality PET sleeving will hold its shape with time, keeping the same look when building and not sagging like other softer braided offerings.
  • The new individually sleeved cables are heat-shrink free to ensure high-quality cable assembly and support for high currents in order to achieve superior performance and stability.
  • This 1 to 3x 8 Pin Sleeved extension cable replaces the complex connection configuration of the original 1 to 4x 8 Pin cable, which's configuration is unsightly and unsafe. Use the EZDIY-FAB extension cable, The best solution for safety and aesthetics.

reviews.review:
This would be a great cable extension kit except that the color of the PCI-E 12VHPWR cable doesn't match the other cables. The difference is immediately noticeable as they are pretty different shades of white with the 12VHPWR being much brighter white. The wire gage is also different, but that doesn't bother me as much.

Otherwise, the cables are very nice quality, the 24 Pin (Motherboard) and 8 Pin EPS (CPU) connectors are a thick gage that was easy to train and looks great. The included cable combs are surprisingly easy to get into place and slide easily enough to make training the cables very doable. The 12VHPWR cable comes with cable combs already attached which is a plus.

If the colors matched (or were at least a bit closer together) for all the cables this would be a 5/5... as is it's a good quality set of extensions limited by the fact that it's a bit of a mess aesthetically.
Makes my build look clean

name: Cooler Master V850 SFX Gold Full Modular, 850W, 80+ Gold Efficiency, ATX Bracket Included, Quiet FDB Fan, Semi-fanless Operation, SFX Form Factor, 10 Year Warranty
description:
• SFX Form Factor: High-quality PSU that's compatible with all SFX cases and suitable for mini-ITX system builds.
  • SFX-to-ATX Bracket: With the included bracket, users can install the V SFX Gold securely to an ATX case.
  • 80 PLUS Gold Certified: This certification guarantees a typical efficiency of 90% under normal operating conditions.
  • 16 AWG PCI-e Cables: The thicker 16 AWG PCI-e cables allow for higher currents, thereby improving both efficiency and safety.
  • Full-Modular Cabling: Modular cables reduce clutter, increase airflow, and improve overall efficiency and thermal performance.

reviews.review:
Powers an i7 10700k and rtx 3080ti with zero compromise.
Pricy for what it is but the weight savings, space savings and aesthetics more than makes up for it.

Ok... I figured for the $/Watt this can't be all that bad especially that it's an SFX and you cant find a SFX PSU over 700W other then this one (at this time). I was hoping that maybe there was a new revision that I would get that would resolve this stupid fan curve issue. I was disappointed to find out it ramps up and down constantly. It's almost like there is no PWM but just a simple binary fan execution.

Albeit, when the fan ramps up I'm usually gaming a wearing a headset and when I'm not gaming... well the GPU is pretty much just idling or consuming very little power for video watching that it's not enough to trip the 15% load limit for zero fan.

It's annoying. And loud. I'm hoping Coolermaster does something about it but it sounds like all you can do is RMA it for a refund or exchange but most likely you'll just get the same revision of unit.

Everything else is good. Cables are flexible and all black. Lots of output connections. Comes with a ATX bracket so you can use it with a standard ATX case.
Great product
First time ever building a pc with new parts definitely happy
Not many high powered SFX options out there for this price point. This is the revised version for sure. I can barely hear the fan at all. Props to cooler master for fixing their models

The main cable is missing 6 inches to be able to connect to the motherboard.
The main motherboard cable is 11 inches. Are you serious???
They are the length of the motherboard.
Unless you put the power supply ON the motherboard, I don’t see how this thing can work.
If the cable are too tight, they will break the connection.
I have a regular ATX casing, nothing special.
I was just replacing the power supply.

So they want to save pennies on the cables? Give your money to a decent company, not this one.
Came with a incomplete set of cables and I can't return it. Non functioning broken PSU that cost 200. Thanks for the paper weight
worked great, not too loud, but it died (pop, burning smell, wont post) after less than 2 months of operation.

Like any power supply, and I have had lots of them through my computer building years. Some good and some were terrible. I had three higher end corsairs fail right out of the box's during testing. The first one lit my board on fire before I started getting smarter. So ya never know right? This mighty little 850w fired right up, the testing mod says it is hitting at 110ms boot up speed which is at the highest end of the spectrum. May be due to the smaller caps they are using? My very first water-cooled mini ITX build so a small form size supply is crucial. I did my homework before ordering this one and time will tell how well it functions after I run it for awhile. Sadly my Mini ITX board is bad (turns out someone substituted a used bad board in a new box, yeah it happens to other people also). So this will sit a little longer before I can review it properly under load. All I have done so far is power up my water pump circuit and the fan hasn't come on yet. All I can say is the build quality is top notch!

I had doubts at this price it's actually a 850w gold. There's some bad reviews on it... I read em all. That being said price wins in the end. I bought this used/returned. What the hell. Currently it's powering a 12600k (overkill oops), 6400mhz ddr5, Asus Rog 760-i itx mobo, and a slim monster 4070ti. This PSU has not failed me. That's about as honest as I can get. I don't know if it's 850w, or actually 650w, but it's powering my SFF build very well. Best of luck for PC guys.

Only gripe is the GPU cables have 2 connectors per cable. Makes cable management ugly and hard to hide. If your gpu has 2 or more connectors use 2 or more cables. Never use a splitter. Will probably end up getting custom cables for this reason. Other than that, its a good unit.

Counting the days to build my first gaming pc since 2014, I come to the HUGE dissapointment after trying to plug this up. That the included 24 pin atx power would not reach over and plug into the board. So I had to buy a 24 pin male to female adapter in a huge messy hurry. Overall great whisper quiet installation and running, fits perfectly in my full tower case.
I really like this brand. This is my first sfx PSU period, as well as first fully modular model. Both features makes it much easier to manage cables in tiny cases.

description:
• 【Easy Upgrade】Solid state drive replaces traditional mechanical hard drive to upgrade your laptop or desktop computer. Superior transfer speeds enable faster startup, application loading, and responsiveness, improving overall system performance.
  • 【Excellent Performance】SATA SSD is silent, shock-proof, drop-proof and shock-proof, so you don't have to worry even if the computer falls. EDILOCA ES106 SSDmakes your game load times faster and gets the near-instant performance and gaming fun that solid-state storage brings.
  • 【3D NAND】EDILOCA ES106 2.5" SATA adopts advanced 3D NAND technology, and the components are carefully designed from start to finish. With SATA III 6Gb/S interface, the read speed can reach up to 550Mb/s, and the write speed can reach up to 500Mb/S, which greatly improves the performance and efficiency of your computer. You get the experience of fast transfers and faster file loading.
  • 【Super Compatible】Internal SSD compatible windows 10 / 8.1/8 /7, mac os 10.4 or later, linux 2.6.33 or later. The interface SATA Rev. 3.0 (6Gb/s) is backward compatible with SATA Rev. 2.0. (TIPS: Newly purchased SSD is blank, so you will need to format them in Disk Management before you can use them. Initial formatting involves locating the volume and creating partitions in Disk Management. After performing the formatting process, our computer will be able to recognize and use it.)
  • 【Warranty Service】EDILOCA has 3 year warranty service. We have strict control standards for our products, each hard drive has been tested countless times to ensure that there is no quality problem before sending it to you. If you have any questions about the product, you can contact us at any time. We will give you the most sincere service.

reviews.review: looks ok
I like so much
Very happy, fast shipping excellent product...
Bought it as a replacement drive for my 2015 Nvidia Shield Pro works good and sped things up
Works great. At this price it can be replaced if it dies in a few years.
For the price, it definitely delivers, and does the job. No complaints. Seems to be just fine.
Works as advertised and as expected

Storage capacity is as rated, materials are not the most durable and I would not suggest this for a portable device, but it works fine in a desktop.

Drive does not report any kind of statistics to monitoring software other than used space, so I'm a little worried about the longevity of it, but it seems to be holding so far.

Speeds are not quite as high as rated under tests, instead topping out around 480 instead of 550. This isn't the end of the world, but it does show a lack of quality control which again makes me worry for the long term.
タイムマシン用に一番安いのを買った。保険だと思っている、
buon prodotto

I like the product it's great, but it would be nice if amazon didn't promise 2-day delivery on so many things I order that ARE NOT delivered as promised..so the product gets 5 stars...amazon gets 1 star...do better or decrease the membership fee, you can't have it both ways.

so far ive got zero complaints! i put one of these into my fathers pc for games and it seemed to do well.
so i figured id bite the bullet and buy 8(2tb) for my rack mount server and ive gotta say theyre working great! going to buy a few more as some backups and hot swaps(so ive got them staggered) but ill update as things progress!!
Facile da installare, funziona bene e ha un ottimo prezzo. Lo consiglierei.

name: LinkMore XE200 1TB M.2 2280 PCIe Gen 3X4 NVMe 1.3 Internal SSD, Solid State Drive, Up to 2100MB/s for Latop and PC
description:
• 【Star up easily and quickly】PCIe Gen 3*4 NVMe 1.3 , hign speed interface help your computer boot faster to a new level. *Please make sure your devices are compatible with NVM PCIe before purchasing.
  • 【Effective transfer speed】Sequential read and write speeds up to 2000MB/s and 1500MB/s
  • 【Excellent performance for work and gaming】High speed, high performance, and low power consumption meet the various demands of gamers.
  • 【3 year warranty】: Made in Taiwan.Provide 3 year limited warranty and free tenique support.

reviews.review:
Product Info:
The drive specs on the back of the box: 256GB PCIe Gen3x4 NVMe M.2 2280 with a Read/Write speed up to 2500MB/s / 2100MB/s depending on the capacity. It also comes with a 3yr warranty.

I checked the datasheet specs on the manufacturer’s site for this driver and it seems the specs are a bit different. It shows a max of 2000MB/s Read and 1000MB/s write, so I wish they spent a bit more effort to provide the proper information on their packaging material.

Performance:
I put the drive through its paces using an external USB-C NVMe enclosure as well as in a computer and running benchmarks using CrystalDiskMark8 as well copying files to and from the drive.

USB-C NVMe Enclosure:
- CrystalDiskMark: Read = 1050.79MB/s and Write = 950.84MB/s.
- Windows Write: Writing a 12.7GB file into the drive took 34.28secs = 370.48MB/s Write speed.
- Windows Read: Copying out the same 12.7GB file took 37.4secs = 339.57MB/s Read speed.
- Windows Write (small files): Writing 5.98GB of smaller multiple files ranging from a few hundred megs to 1GB into the drive took 67.24secs = 88.94MB/s.
o This was exceptionally slow as the peak speed was 54MB/s, but subsequent copy of the same data files were able to copy at 389MB/s.
- Windows Read (small files): Copying the same 5.98GB of files out of the drive onto my laptop took 60.95secs = 98MB/s Read speeds.
o Recopying the same files out took only 16.31secs = 366MB/s

During the speed tests, it seems on initial write & read of multiple smaller files the drive seems to struggle with the throughput as you can see it spike upwards and then slows down and then keeps repeating, so the transfer graph is very jagged. Subsequent copies of the same files into and out of the drive seems to work as it’s supposed to. Not sure if there’s a caching issue or if there was some other factor causing the slowness.

HP Laptop Install:
To eliminate the USB port or enclosure as the speed limiting factor, I installed it into my laptop and installed a fresh copy of Windows 10 and reran the CrystalDiskMark tests and was pleasantly surprised that the max Read speed was 2360.39MB/s & the Write was 1200.26MB/s. The Read speeds jumped over 2X and the write speed up 25%.

I couldn’t run the Windows copy as the laptop only had one drive and it wouldn’t be a proper test to copy from itself into itself.

Overall, I found the LinkMore XE200 256GB PCIe NVMe 2280 M.2 drive performed very well. In an external enclosure, it performed OK, but that performance quickly jumped and exceeded its advertised specs on the manufacturer’s website datasheet specs when directly installed in a computer. The drive is actually faster than the original drive that came with the HP laptop and now is the permanent drive for the unit.

I won't spend a load of time and words going into reams of specs that are available in more detail from the seller. What I found is that this low-cost drive has so far performed almost as well as the higher priced big brand names. The only thing I can't comment on is how well it works over time compared to the other brands.
👀 The only spec I will include is a screenshot of the write speed when first used in an external 10Gb USB C enclosure before installing it in the PC. While not as fast as brand name drives, this is plenty fast for most applications. It is faster than most users would need a drive to be. Boot time and shutdown are measured in seconds.
» Pricing is in the ballpark with other after market brand drives of the same capacity.

Would I recommend this for a gamer, someone that uses photo/video editing applications, or someone who doesn't back up their important items? No, not yet. It will need to prove itself over time, and no amount of testing with Crystal mark or other performance software can provide that detail. For the average user that does back up their important items, it's a great way to upgrade an older laptop or add a second drive to a PC if the MoBo has space. If there are any problems down the road, I will follow up.

I have had it running on a PC as the OS drive that's been in operation 24/7 for the last four weeks. I'm using it to run a game server for some friends and which means there are a lot of writes, so this is a great test. It was installed with no issues, and both Windows 11 and Windows Server 2019 were installed without the need for any drivers. I tested it on Windows 11 but then installed Server 2019 for stability. Other than restarts due to updates, the machine has never gone down. It does have a decent heat sink on it and runs no hotter than the big brand name drives.

Do I have enough confidence that if I needed another drive, I would get a second one of these, yes. I will need a 1TB NVMe drive in a couple of months for a new build, and considering the performance is very good, and the drive is 35% of what I would pay for a brand name, yes, I'll save some money and order a LinkMore.

If you are an enthusiast looking for a M.2 NVMe SSD that's significantly above-average for your top of the line gaming gear or multimedia editing studio, then this is not for you and look elsewhere. If you are looking for something that's a significant upgrade to your existing/old SSD and in need of a budget drive as your system drive to speed up initial boot time, then perhaps give this a shot.

This is another one of those non-brand name NVMe SSDs that I've never heard of but it claims to be made in Taiwan which is much more desirable (if you build your own computers from parts especially in the 90's, then you know what I'm talking about); however, I see no indication that this is actually made in Taiwan so I'm not sure what to think of that at the moment.

With that being said, its performance is actually quite good considering its price.

Read: 2183 MB/s
Write: 1089 MB/s

Both its read and write speeds appear to be slightly higher than what's being advertised here 2000/1000 MB/s); however, it claims a much higher throughput (2500/2100 MB/s) from the box it comes with. Though, it does mention the speed varies and depends up capacity which is often the case for any flash-based devices including USB drives and NVMe/SATA SSD drives.

It's using Phison PS5013-E13-31 SSD controller which does NOT include DRAM cache which is one of the reasons that this is a budget NVMe SSD. Well, you get what you pay for and it's a reasonably trade-off if you are short on budget.

All things considered, this is a fairly decent budget NVMe SSD that's well-performed and it's reasonably priced at $34 for 256GB. It's a great upgrade for ordinary SATA SSD (assuming your MB supports and/or has the slot for it) and you WILL see noticeable performance boost in in comparison to SATA SSDs.

サブディスクとしてプライムセールにて購入（6,300円）。

PCIe Gen4にて接続。
公称通りの速度は出ており、値段を考えればコスパは抜群。
使ってみないと分からない為、耐久性は未評価。

ヒートシンクは忘れずに（メーカーによっては拡張M.2スロットにヒートシンクが既に付いているものあるので要確認）。
conforme a ma demande .

Now that NAND prices have plummeted, there are much better options out there for NVMe ssds. That being said, I have no complaints with this drive when used in an enclosure like a USB or as a backup drive.

reviews.review:
Reliability of SSDs has been sketchy since 2021. Samsung is no exception and they have one of the worst RMA service ever in Canada. In this context, I chose the next best with a decent RMA service in Canada: Western Digital.
So far, I am quite happy with my purchase. It came in perfect health and is still at perfect health after cloning my old Toshiba HDD on it. So far, so good. My SSD is of the newest generation and was manufactured May 23rd 2023. Speed is as advertised. My computer gets to the log in screen much faster and all the background apps load super fast. Games are impacted too, of course. Initial game launch, loading saved games and loading between levels takes half the time it used to take with my old 7200 rpm HDD. Even the graphics are impacted because textures load much quicker.
One thing I am not so sure about, though, is the Acronis True Image software that is provided. It is rather clunky and people have had problems cloning with it (errors, having to wipe the SSD and try again), so I decided not to use it, especially after I saw that it would hang for over a minute just when I clicked to bring up the cloning tool. That is NOT normal. If it hangs so much on that step, imagine how it will struggle when doing the actual cloning. I wanted to go with the free version of AOMEI, but apparently they have put their cloning tool behind a paywall. I ended up using Macrium True Reflect (free trial), but there are plenty others which would have done just as nicely. I was able to adjust my partitions exactly to my liking.
I hope I got one of the reliable ones and that it will not fail before several years. I will update my review if anything happens.

I wanted something that I could trust to Just Work™ reliably and leave another part of my system as the bottleneck without breaking the bank and that's what I got.

(Over the years, I've bought 500GB, 1TB, and 2TB units from this product line. At the moment, all three are installed in my dedicated gaming PC, daily driver, and laptop, respectively, I've had no complaints so far, and I trust that, if something DOES go wrong, WD's warranty service will be as effortless as it was when one of my WD Red drives failed.)

Fits well in my HP Pavillion 15, pre-installed with a Ryzen 4600 Processor and 16GB RAM. Now I can have GBs of stuff in and a bit less Read/Write Ops from the primary storage !! I will post here if something goes wrong with the performance.

Till then,
Cheers
Good quality ssd, been using it for just over a month now with windows 10 and no issues as at all. Not much more I can say.
Works fine and is faster to boot up and shut down.
Used this for upgrade for PS4 works Great and capacity has doubled my previous drive.
Been in computer for quite some time and has not failed, much faster than the older drives
Bought the 2 TB on sale and it’s worked great

Empecé a tener problemas con mi antiguo disco duro en mi pc. Supongo que empezó a fallar de los años y del uso. Porque dentro de la torre no sufre golpes ni nada por el estilo.

Es más... dentro está seguro y bien ventilado. Va sujeto con sus 4 tornillos.

Antes de que me falle el sistema y pierda mis archivos decidí comprar uno y jubilar mi antiguo disco que es de la misma marca.

Me lancé por un producto de segunda mano. Mi experiencia con estos productos es muy buena, ya que siempre los compro si hay en estado "como nuevo" y "muy bueno". Realmente vienen con algún desperfecto en la caja original y poco más. Algo que no me importa, es recibir la caja un poco doblada o rota por algún lado. Ya que el interior está bien y no afecta en su funcionamiento y muchísimas veces no son usados. Lo mejor de todo es que siempre me ahorro un buen dinero.

Voviendo al tema del disco duro... He de decir que no pesa mucho, es muy liviano.

La verdad es que es buena marca y tengo buena experiencia con estos discos duros.

La velocidad de cargar el sistema operativo es buena, bastante rápida. El abrir carpetas y demás también. Todo muy fluido.

Espero que me dure otros 7 años como me duró el otro disco duro. Recomiendo la marca y estos modelos en sí.

Die WD Blue Sata SSD mit 2 TB Kapazität ist eine schnelle und zuverlässige SSD für den Sata Port.
Ich nutze dieses Modell bereits in einem Gaming PC seit mehreren Jahren und der Status ist laut CrystalDiskInfo immer noch bei 100%. Nun hat sich im Laufe der Zeit so viel Hardware aus dem "alten PC" angesammelt, so dass ich mir daraus einen zweiten PC basteln konnte. Da ich auch dort meine Steam Games haben wollte, brauchte ich natürlich ein entsprechendes Datengrab. Leider bin ich so blöd gewesen und hatte mir auf Grund des damals niedrigen Preis eine BX500 von Crucial gekauft. Hätte ich mich besser vorher belesen, was ich eigentlich immer tue, bevor ich irgend eine Hardware kaufe, wäre mir der Fehler erspart geblieben. Denn die Crucial BX 500 mit 2 TB hat keinen eigenen DRAM Cache und der Speicher besteht wohl bei den großen Modellen aus QLC Speicher, was ich überhaupt nicht mag! Leseraten waren einigermaßen ok, aber die Schreibraten brachen beim Schreiben großer Dateien nach schon kurzer Zeit bis auf 27 MB/s ein! Das geht für eine SSD, die am Sata Port schreibend eigentlich so um die 530 MB/s schaffen könnte, gar nicht. Inzwischen sind die Preise auch für Sata SSD's der größeren Speicherkapazität im Preis gesunken und sah bei Amazon meine Lieblings SSD von WD für nur 99,90 Euronen. Ohne weiter nachzudenken habe ich mir diese bestellt, eingebaut, Spiele wieder drauf gepackt und .....Läuft! Datenraten sind am Sata Port absolut im grünen Bereich. Schreibrate ca. 530 MB/s und Leserate ca. 540 MB/s und das dauerhaft, ohne Einbrüche. Daher klare Kaufempfehlung meinerseits.
Es el mejor disco que tengo, lo encontré economico,y sin ningun problema, no te arrepientes

Lo uso da almeno un anno. Lo trovo ottimo: veloce, leggero. Ha messo il turbo al computer che con l'hdd meccanico era divantato davvero una pena. Questo o un altro non ha importanza ma togliete i vecchi hdd dai vostri computer e mettete un ssd. Noterete una differenza enorme nei tempi di caricamento e, in generale, nell'esperienza d'uso.

Cloned my old boot SSD to this one after a lot of difficulty but in the process connected and disconnected it a lot and it still works fine. You will need to buy a ssd tray to mount in your case If your computer doesn't have one included as most are made for the bigger hdd. Will need mounting screws but most trays have them included. Also Sata and power cables too.

Cloning a Boot drive:
I'm just including this part incase you run into the same problems I did because none of the online solutions I found worked. I used this for Windows 7 with Macrium Reflect so it might work differently on Windows 10 with another software. I'm not an IT guy just someone who likes to mess around with computers so no guarantees it works for you but It did for me. If you don't already have a cloning software you can download Macrium Reflect it is free.

1) Connect the new drive and go into the windows search bar and search for Run and then enter diskmgmt.msc, it should show all the drives and you can find the one you just connected and if it isn't popping up in my computer you can see if it has been given a letter like C drive. If not right click and give it a letter. Sometimes the old boot drive will have 2 partitions. One labeled System Reserved and a regular one. Both will cloned but sometimes all are include in one partition. If you look in diskmgmt it will say Active, Boot, Crash Dump,etc. Under the partition that is used to Boot from.

2) After that is done open up the cloning program and clone. Once that is done go back into diskmgmt and right click on the partition to mark it as active. Now this is where it goes wrong sometimes. Turn off the computer and disconnect the old drive and when the computer starts look for which key you have to press to enter the Bios or Uefi settings so you can change the boot order. Sometimes the computer will just go through every drive by default but it's better if you go and find the drive you want it to boot from first which will be your new ssd. Now hopefully it works and starts and everything is good. If not like on mine you will have to move on to the next step.

Now my problem was not because it was a bad boot record or file system compatibility issue. I tried all of those and there are guides for that. But my problem was that Windows would only recognize the System reserved on my new drive as being the place to boot from but not the regular partition. It would still only boot from the old partition on my old drive because it was labeled as Boot, Crash Dump etc. Marking it as Active didn't help because as far as I could figure out those labels were only placed when Windows was installed on the system and even without the old drive connected diskmgmt would not label it so.

1) You will need a Windows install USB or disc. If you don't have one you can try making a recovery disc from your old drive but I have not tried that way so I'm not sure if it will work. If that doesn't work try and find a torrent for your version of Windows. Don't worry about getting a product key or installing a crack you just need it to install Windows. Once you clone it will go back to your original install.

2) Format the new SSD. You may have to go unmark it as Active and switch the boot order back so that it will boot off your old drive. If like mine and it only recognized the System reserved on the new ssd it won't let you format until it goes back to recognizing the old drive. You may have to restart after marking it as inactive. Once you do that and format get a usb and download a program that will search for drivers as a clean install of windows might not have drivers and not let you connect to the internet. You can find one or if you want go to Windows on your old drive from my computer and look for Program files and copy the Macrium folder. Inside there should be a Application that is named Reflect and will launch the program without having to download on the new drive. If you used another program just put the install files into the USB.

3) Once formatted and you have the files on a USB disconnect all the drives except your new one and put in the Windows install CD or USB and install it on the drive. Once that is done and your on the windows homepage turn off the computer and plug in the old boot drive and see if it's boots to the new install of windows. If it doesn't fix the boot order.

4) Now open the cloning software and try cloning to the new drive now from the old one. If you are using Macrium it should say something about it can't do it and will need to restart and use Windows PE environment. Say yes and let it restart. It has to do this because unlike before where you tried cloning from the working drive to the new one now you are cloning to the working drive and it can't run windows and rewrite it at the same time. Let it load and then open the cloning software again and now it should clone and the partition will have the right labels as it was already marked so from it installing windows and all your old files should be there. If everything works now you should see that only the cloned part of the drive is popping up on my computer and all the extra space is unallocated in diskmgmt. Right click on the regular partition if your has 2 and choose to extend volume. Keep clicking yes and the extra space will be added.

Sorry if this isn't as clear and concise as I would have liked but I found a lot of people with a similar problem after cloning a Boot drive and none of the articles or forums helped.

reviews.review: Fonctionne bien dans la deuxième slot de mon ordinateur portable LG Gram 17"

I have a nice gaming computer with an AMD 5800x CPU, 32GB RAM and RTX 3080 video card. Before installing the Lexar NM 790 2TB, I had no issues. After installing the Lexar drive, I started getting blue screens when I was stressing the computer. I removed the Lexar and put a better heat sink on it. The one I had originally put on it was a very thin, cheap one. After putting the better heat-sink on it, the blue screens stopped. When the computer was blue screening, the Lexar was hitting 65C and warmer. With the better heat-sink, my temps are 59C and below.

I bought 2 of these hard drives to replace a failing HDD.
I am a software developer, by trade, I record hundreds of hours of podcast audio yearly, and I play videogames for fun, so I basically live on my PC. I've definitely put a few thousand hours on my PC over the past few months, and so far, I am extremely satisfied.

The speeds are just as advertised, and the temps remain well within acceptable ranges. Installation was the same as any similar drive, and the cost per GB is stellar. If you're looking for a solid midrange storage solution, I'm confident you will be satisfied with these drives.

7400///6000 R///W
35mb under on read, 700mb over on write.
Exceeded my expectations. 5/5 stars.

Aunque este producto es físicamente compatible con mi equipo, no fue reconocido por el sistema ni BIOS. Para referencia, la pieza que sí le debe de quedar a una T480 se describe como "m.2 PCIe 3x2 with a b-key".
Asumo que el producto funciona bien, lo conecté a otro equipo solo para asegurarme que no estuviera defectuoso.
Not reliable
