reviews.review:
These work pretty well with proxmox/debian, currently I have two of these, with 4 drives attached, doing Ceph storage in HP elitedesk 800 G4 systems.

No issues so far - they show up just fine, all the drives are working without dropouts, and if you know ceph, you know the controller is being worked pretty hard.

I'll note that I'm not trying to boot from them, but that shouldn't be an issue.

name: Phanteks (PH-ES614P_BK) Enthoo Pro Full Tower Chassis with Window - Black
description:
• Enthoo Pro includes 1 x 200mm fan in front and 1 x 140mm fan in the rear. Ability to upgrade to additional fans is possible. All fans included are Phanteks' new redesigned and better performing SP series fans. Budget friendly case
  • Appearance: Brushed plastic with an aluminum appearance; Stealth interior: hidden PSU / hidden HDD
  • Cooling: Extreme cooling capacity; 2 included Phanteks' premium fans ; The PWM hub makes it possible to control all the connected fans (also 3-pin fans) with PWM function through 1 PWM connector and create a better cable management
  • Extensive water cooling support. Provides up to 4 diff installation areas for radiators vary from single to triple (120mm & 140mm form factors). Clearance for push-pull fan configurations; Innovative liquid cooling mounting system
  • Closed HDD panel strengthens the chassis' rigidity, even when both HDD cages are removed. Removable Drop-n-Lock SSD bracket that can be installed on 2 different locations. (1 bracket incl.)
  • Removable dust filters for easy maintenance.Pre-installed cable management tools behind the motherboard tray that can be fastened and released.2x USB 3.0, 2x USB 2.0, microphone, 3.5mm audio jack
  • split-window design (PH-ES614P) and PSU cover

reviews.review:
Building a new PC over the past month, I first thought of Corsair for a case. But I was disappointed to find that neither Corsair - nor any other manufacturer - seems to be making full-size cases any more that have room for a proper optical (DVD-ROM) drive.

Then I discovered Phanteks, a maker I'd never heard of before. Glad I did! Despite the weird nomenclature the Phanteks Enthoo Pro turns out to be a great PC case, with solid construction and all the features I wanted. Construction is solid steel - and I mean SOLID. This case weighs a ton, it's built like a tank. But it's cavernously roomy and extremely well thought-out.

There's a 200mm fan at the front and a 140mm one at the back, plus a mesh top for water cooling radiators. All vents have removable dust screens. There's a proper rack for disk drives, with three externally accessible bays for optical drives or things like fan controllers. Sections of the drive cage can be removed to allow for extra-long video cards. There are several separate mount locations for SSDs.

It's easy to build neatly in the Enthoo. The power supply, at the bottom of the case, gets its own removable metal covering. The back of the case ('behind' the motherboard) has a plethora of little Velcro tie-downs, making it easy to route wiring. I mounted a Corsair iCue H150i radiator at the top of the case, with three 120mm fans - no problem, all the screw holes fit perfectly, and there was oodles of room to spare. (Double check me on this, but I'm pretty sure I could have gone to four 140mm fans.) The plastic top and front of the case are easily removable, a huge help to accessibility.

I put a big ASUS Rog Crosshair VIII Dark Hero motherboard in the case with absolutely no problem. Mounting an AMD CPU doesn't need it, but the case has a huge cut-out for rear access to Intel-style cooler mounts. Everything went together smoother than on any of my previous builds.

The front of the case has a built-in port panel, with USB and audio ports. A flip-up cover conceals this and keeps dust out when the ports aren't in use. I like the modest clear panel - I've got the Corsair lighting programmed to give me a reading on temperatures. However, one thing the Enthoo Pro lacks is venting for a side-mounted radiator.

There are lots of bonuses. The manual is good, with lots of diagrams. All the screws you'll need (and then some) are shipped in a nice plastic box with little compartments in it. This case is a class act all the way.

One caution: the newer Enthoo 2 adds a few nice features (such as room for a front-mounted radiator), but DROPS the optical-drive bays. If that matters to you, you might want to do as I did and snap up the original Enthoo Pro in a hurry. I don't think you'll regret it.

I upgraded some pieces to my PC. New motherboard, RAM, CPU, etc. But found it didn't fit in my existing tower. I'm not into the fancy lighting so I was happy to find this one. Also, I still use my DVD drive for some old cd's with programs in them so I was glad this had it as well. Be prepared. When they say it's full size; it's full size. Quite a bit bigger than my old one but that made it super nice to work with. Lots of room for wires to fit. This has a rear compartment for wiring to hide and made everything super clean. Huge fan in the front and 120mm fan in the back moves lots of air for cooling. My new CPU cooler has 2 fans as well so I'm not worried about overheating at all. Vents have filters, which is nice. Good looking unit at a reasonable price. I'd buy again if I had to. Also, more mounts for future fans if needed or desired.

I've purchased 3 of these over the past couple of years to make builds for myself and family members. Solid steel construction (very sturdy and heavy), no RGB nonsense to inflate the price, plenty of space for whatever you want to throw into it and space to rout your wires and allows for installation of optical drives (which is getting rarer every year and was one of the initial selling points that drew me to this case). The 2 included fans are fine (but I personally added 2 fans on the top grate for additional cooling, it really depends on how much heat the components you use generate). This is the best value for money case I have ever used and I would buy it again if I ever have to build a PC for someone else I know.

Interesting to note, the first 2 Enthoo Pros I bought included: 2 USB 3.0 slots and 2 USB 2 slots on the front panel, but the 3rd one I bought included: 2 USB 3.0 slots and 1 USB C charging port (no USB 2 slots), I assume they changed the design of their front panel in the last year to modernize it. So keep this in mind when buying. Otherwise it was identical to the other 2 cases and of the same build quality.

No flashy/tacky nonsense that will look dated in 6 months, it just works, has a classic look and doesn't look like a piece of tacky trash that was dug out of Optimus Prime's chest cavity.
Easy building in this.... Quality item.
Cela faisait longtemps que je voulais avoir une telle tour d'ordinateur.

Easy to figure out wiring, wonderful case. Was advertised with two SSD mounts, only came with one. An email with confirmation of purchase was all that's needed with customer service, and they sent me the replacement part. Satisfied all around

Really good case for $100~
Compares pretty well to some thermaltake cases I've had in the past; 2-3x the price.
Steel parts are heavy, with few sharp edges inside.
Drive Rack is just ok. Chassis is sturdy enough, but drive cages are flimsy (screwless plastic) and aren't suited well for 2.5" SSDs. The side mount is better but too tight to the side panel making it difficult to route power and SATA Ribbons. MB mount plate had standoff holes in exactly the right places for my MSI board. Standoffs are black painted or chromed? I prefer bright brass standoffs in case one drops in the black case.
PCI-e lines up well, and had plenty of room for a 3090 inside. There shouldn't be any trouble connecting large GPUs in this case.

Side covers are easy to remove, and provide good access to internals. 2 finger screws hold each in place securely.

Included fans were poorly centered, flimsy. I would have liked a version with no fans for a little less money.
All fans were replaced with Noctua industrial fans. It's large and vented on 4 sides; so good airflow is needed to avoid hotspots. No less than 5 high cfm fans recomended on an air cooled setup. This is not a quiet case, but far from the noisiest; it really depends on fan/hw selection quite a bit.

Front covers, fan covers, external plastic parts feel solid/tight.
Power button Is a big negative: It wobbles when pressed, colored the same (black) as the rest of the case, and a little too small. A silver or minimally backlit 1.5cm round button that doesnt wobble would have been nice.

Front panel with extra ports/audio/restart button works well.

-The case weighs a ton. It actually cracked the wood table I put it on! Feels like 90 pounds filled.

-Came well packed for shipping

I recommend it as a full sized, basic enclosure. Def no frills, but can't be expected for $100

Pros:
Built solidly and has lots of space.

It also has bays for Bluray players which is getting rare, unfortunately. Three is excessive, but it is better than none at all.

No spastic annoying lighting. It is so ridiculous that cases are lit up like Xmas trees.

It comes with quite a few screws and whatnot. Most I didn't need but it is great for any future needs. It is also in a nice plastic tray with a solid lid and they are not all tossed into a bag.

The power button is in a very convenient place.

The mobo standoffs were already installed, which is nice. It is often a headache to put them in. It is just the standoffs needed for an ATX board that are installed but it comes with extras if you are putting in an E-ATX board.

Cons:

The glass side panel is a worthless thing That likely adds to the expense.

The manual says that it is supposed to have 2 SSD trays but it only shipped with one. I contacted them, and the timeliness and accuracy of their reply will move the rating up or down. Edit: I emailed them on a Sunday evening, and they responded Tuesday morning asking for my invoice - totally reasonable - and within an hour I got a notification that it was being shipped.

The SSD tray is clunky. It should not require screws. It is nearly impossible to solidly screw the SSD in with 4 screws. It is also difficult to squeeze the SATA power cables through the slot.

The no-tool 5.25" bays do not work. It did not solidly clip my Bluray player in and required two screws.

The weird PWM controller is worthless and a potential point of catastrophic failure, and adds more to the cost. Losing the CPU fan to an untrustworthy addition is just asking for trouble. Luckily, it can be easily ignored and the fans plugged into the mobo like the nerd gods intended. It would have been better to ditch that and add an additional fan.

The reboot button is not in a convenient place.

The cover on the front USB ports is annoying.

----

It is probably my fault, but even all of the features to manage cabling don't help much if you are like me and have multiple SATA drives. That is not a pro or con.

Overall, there are no serious complaints and it feels like it will last a very long time.

I've been looking for a case that will keep my components clean, yet still provide as much airflow as possible. Also, that wouldn't break the bank. After a lot of searching, I decided to give this one a try.

I'd not heard of Phanteks before, but the price was considerably less than large cases by more well-known brands. I like to tinker with my case and swap parts in and out a lot, so the bigger the case the better.

This case is built well and is mostly metal. The frame and most panels are screwed on rather than riveted, so it's easy to take it apart when building in it. You can customize it to make room for liquid cooling if you want, or you can keep the optical drive bays installed if you still prefer using DVD and CD ROMs.

I have two optical drives, two SATA 'traditional' hard drives and there's still room for a plug-in SSD drive in there. I do also have an SSD drive, but it is the new NVME style that plugs into the motherboard.

There is room for a full-sized ATX motherboard and you still have room for a three-fan graphics card. I currently have a one-fan graphics card installed myself because it used to be in much smaller case. If GPU prices stop being crazy someday, I might upgrade the GPU.

The fan situation is amazing. It comes with a 200mm fan in the front and a 140mm fan in the back. There's room for either 120 or 140mm fans in the top and bottom of the case that you can add later. The brackets in the top and bottom will hold both sizes of fans. The Phanteks website says that the top of the case will hold three 140mm fans. I have three 120mm fans in it now. The front of the case can be modified to hold two 120 or 140mm fans instead of the 200mm fan if you want. Neither of the fans that come with the case light up.

In the other side of the case, there is room for cable management. It's the first case that I've owned that has this as well as the fan in the bottom. It's nice to be able to access the back side of the motherboard and to route most of the cables back there, making the other side with the window look neater. There's also a fan hub back here in which you can plug up to five fans (more if you use cable splitters). Then, you plug one more wire from the sixth spot on the hub into the 'Pump' power fan connector on your motherboard. That way, all of your case fans are controlled by the same controller on the motherboard and work together without having to have fan wires all over the main bay of the case. One bad thing about this hub though is that it can be a little tricky to remove wires once you plug them in. I accidentally damaged one of the brackets in the hub while trying to remove the wire. I got the wire to stay in by taping over it with electrical tape though.

The bay where the hard drives go is in the other side of the case opposite the window, so it hides them and leaves more room in the main bay. Air from the front and top of the case still flows through here though, so they won't overheat. The little brackets that you screw the drives into are easy to work with. Much easier than the bays in my previous cases.

Another thing that is much easier to deal with in this case than in previous cases I've owned, is the front bezel. It, along with the top of the case, snaps on and off easily making cleaning much easier. This is important since one of the dirtiest parts of a case can be where the air gets sucked into it.

Speaking of dust, this case tries harder to keep dust out than other cases I've had. It has screens in the front bezel, top bezel, and the bottom of the case to catch most of the stuff that tries to get in. The screens are easy to wipe off when you remove them. The ones in the bottom are in pull-out trays, so you can clean them without having to lay the case on its side.

This is a big case, so be sure that you have plenty of room for it on your desk. Also be sure that your desk is sturdy because by the time you finish building in it, it will be quite heavy.

One little issue with it is that once I finished building it and started using it, I noticed that after I had removed the windowed side panel a couple of times, it started rattling when the fans were running full blast. I tried all sorts of things. Finally, putting a thin piece of foam that came with the computer case (probably to keep parts from rubbing together) under the middle leg on the left side. That seems to have solved it for now.

Speaking of the bottom and the legs, be sure when you are using the case, to not sit it on carpet, nor to block the bottom of the case with anything since it is one of the ways that fresh air gets in the case, especially after you install a fan in the bottom. When you put a fan in there, be sure to have the back side (or ugly side) of the fan motor showing inside the case so that the fan will draw air into the case rather than blowing it out.

It's by far the best case I've owned and for a great price too.

I've built many (tower) personal computers, dating back to the first Intel 386 architecture. This is the nicest case I've worked with. It is large, and as such takes some effort to move around, and the feet are good... they prevent the unit from sliding around too much on a hard surfaced floor.

The case is wide enough that the bulk of any point-to-point wiring can be hidden behind the internal motherboard mounting plate, and there are lots of hook-loop straps attached on the back side to tie down the wiring very nicely. The motherboard mounted and everything lined up perfectly... from all the mounting holes to the rear panel connectors. The top is open enough to house a 3-fan liquid cooler radiator and fans, the case fan on the back (140mm) is mounted in slots so its height is adjustable to allow for such top mounted coolers. The front mounted 200mm case fan does a nice job blowing air over the 3.5" HDD bays. There's room for 6 3.5" drives, up to 3 5.25" drives and a bracket for a 2.5" SSD.

What I found was that it's not easy to find tower cases with 5.25" bays for things like DVD/BD readers/writers. This was a "must have" for me, as although I put gaming hardware in the box, I use it for some other intensive video rendering work.

Only a couple of (minor) negatives. The acrylic or polycarbonite "windows" in the side panel can be easily scratched... I suggest leaving the protective sheet on until you're finished with your build. I don't care for the lift-up door to access the front-panel connectors... you have to bend down to below the level of the little door to see the connectors.

Overall, for the price, this is an excellent case for a "business computer" build. Plenty of room for the power supply, lots of drives, even ATXe motherboards and handles liquid cooling components nicely. If you're going to do a custom liquid cooler that has a reservoir, there's even a reservoir bracket that you can mount inside the case. I'd buy it again if I were to do another build-out.

Baue seit '98 Rechner und habe viele Gehäuse unter meinen Schraubendrehern gehabt.
Aber dieses Gehäuse hat mir besonders gut gefallen, weil alles stimmig ist.
Solide und schwer, durchdacht mit Konzept, groß und individual.
Kurz um, man kann den Big-Tower empfehlen, weil Preis und Qualität passen.
Lieferung von Snowgard war blitzschnell. Topp!

name: StarTech.com 2-Post 8U Desktop Server Rack, Small Open Frame 19in Computer Rack, Compact Network Rack for AV / Studio / Data / IT Equipment, Free Standing Two-Post Home/Office Rack (RK8OD)
description: • For A/V Equipment, Server - 8U Rack Height x 19" Rack Width - Tabletop - Black - Steel - 110.50 lb Maximum Weight Capacity - TAA Compliant

reviews.review: I am happy with the purchase for building a customers IT room without the huge expense of a full rack server. Simple and out of the way design and my client is very happy with the low profile hidden server space.

This is a great unit that fits all my rackmount equipment perfectly. Much nicer having it all locked in to a cube like this. Easy to move and looks great. The only thing I don’t like is the backwards lean on the unit as a whole. Kind of wish it was straight/flush up and down but it’s only a minor complaint for me.

One star loss as the unit came defective right out of the box. One of the screw holes on the bottom left didn’t line up with the nut and I completely stripped it trying to screw it in with a power drill (literally the only way to get it started/on). It’s not a huge deal as the screw went in far enough to keep the unit together and stable but still, kind of a letdown. In the end though, I paid a fraction of the cost of other rack units out there but wonder if I could have just made something similar for a fraction of even its cost (with a little hunting at a big-chain hardware store or something).

Either way, a great unit that now houses my (exactly 8 units) all in one nice, tidy little package.

Initially I hesitated to buy it because I wasn't sure if it was the right rack for my audio equipment, but I am glad I've done it. It fits perfectly under my desk and so far has been very sturdy even though the 8 devices I installed on it are quite heavy. I didn't use the M5 silver screws it came with. I bought M6 black screws and used instead, which look better.

very robust and strong rack!

This one didn't have helpful user guides and setup diagrams but I figured the assembly of the product out over 1/2 - 1 Hour of trying to assemble it.

It's complicated from a beginner's standpoint for setup but once you get the hang of it, it was a frickin' breeze to use after setup!

Overview

I have only three devices that I wanted to rack mount, and I couldn't justify buying a larger rack than the 8U, so I picked this one. It looked sturdier than the Pyle model that was around the same size.

The Good Parts

* Very solidly built
* Moderately priced
* Comes with 20 cage nuts and bolts
* The cage nuts and bolts are nicer than the ones that came with my rack mount devices
* Easy to put together
* Fits on a desktop

Could Be Better

* It only came with enough cage bolts for 5 devices, even though it's an 8U rack
* It's slightly angled, no option for 90 degree upright position

screwing gear into this rack is not easy. you have to have access to the back which is not easy, Im constantly dropping screws and cutting myself. If you plan on moving stuff around a lot i would not recommend, it is sturdy and well built but the design of the screws and the access to install them is a real headache.

I am using this as a small audio rack inside a cabinet and it holds up the super heavy powered speaker amps without any issue. The angle it slants the equipment on means it is great for under counter units or desktop height units. Any higher and it would be a bit cumbersome to manage the equipment.

Overall it is a solid 4.5-5 out of 5 stars for me. Very happy and would buy again.

As mentioned in some other reviews, there is a panel that goes across the bottom front for extra stability. It is not mentioned in the instructions or seen in the product photo here, but it's there, and you won't need any instructions to see how it attaches.

The only problem I've had with this is if you need to rack something full length like a server, it can't go in the bottom U because it is tilted just enough that the back-end of your device will hit the ground. Anything half-length like most routers you might be using will work there just fine though. Overall I still give it 5 stars because it's very sturdy and in my opinion very good value.

Non conoscevo questa marca, ma da ora è la mia preferita. Il prodotto è di qualità eccellente, made in Taiwan, e la qualità si vede. La verniciatura è perfetta, il metallo, le viti. e tutto il resto del kit è eccellente. Ottima robustezza e materiali ottimi. A questo prezzo lo ricomprerei altre mille volte.
Ottima manifattura. Struttura solida e ben rifinita. StartTech è una garanzia.

Ich habe damit gerechnet, dass es ohne Gerät sehr wabbelig ist und erst durch Einbau derr Geräte stabilität erreicht. Aber das Teil ist von vorn herein sehr stabil und Hat eine Sehr gute verarbeitungsqualität. Kein Grat am Blech wo man sich die bei anderen Herstellern schnell mal verletzt, keine Gepfuschten Gewinde, keine billigen Schrauben. Jammern auf hohem Niveau: die Füße könnten noch Rutschfest ausgeführt werden und als Verbesserungsvorschlag für V2.0 der Winkel könnte ruhig verstellbar ausgeführt werden.

Fazit: Das Teil kann genau das, wie es beschrieben wurde in einer sehr guten Hersteller Qualität. Es ist mir noch nie so leicht gefallen 5 Sterne zu vergeben!

Works great for my Cisco lab, very sturdy and high quality metal, a little on the expensive side but always liked the brands reputation of good quality products.

Currently holding 2 switches, 2 routers and a power bank.

Very happy!
clean and high quality

name: CORSAIR iCUE 4000X RGB Tempered Glass Mid-Tower ATX PC Case - 3X SP120 RGB Elite Fans - iCUE Lighting Node CORE Controller - High Airflow - Black
description:
• Combining stylish tempered glass, customizable RGB lighting, innovative cable management and concentrated airflow, choose the 4000X RGB for a unique high-performance PC.
  • Show off your components and RGB lighting with tempered glass side and front panels, built with dedicated front ventilation channels for ample airflow.
  • The CORSAIR RapidRoute cable management system makes it simple and fast to build an immaculate, professional-looking system with major cables neatly routed through a single channel, with a roomy 25mm of space behind the motherboard for all of your cables.
  • Includes three CORSAIR 120mm AirGuide RGB fans, utilizing anti-vortex vanes to concentrate airflow and enhance cooling. Each fan is equipped with eight individually addressable RGB LEDs for brilliant customizable lighting.
  • Fully control and synchronize the RGB lighting for up to six fans with the included iCUE Lighting Node CORE and CORSAIR iCUE software.

reviews.review:
TL;DR: top power button and USB ports are defective *on my unit* while the restart button functions, but it's still a fantastic case; I just hate the glass and the distractingly annoying RGB lights that must be on at all times. I like the cable management, that was well thought-out!

Oh, what a saga. New-ish AAA game titles (specifically for me "Tiny Tina's Wonderlands" ) are now requiring a MINIMUM of 8gb of VRAM, so I decide to get a new card with ray tracing (which is a waste because "Portal RTX" is only for freaking expensive Nvidia cards, not cheaper AMDs).

It arrives, but is too long for my original case because, you know, MEASURING IS A GOOD THING that is easily forgotten in the throes of "ooh new, modern and shiny!" shopping sprees.

After some research, reading and watching reviews, I decide on this case.

Three days of struggling, swearing and constant insert/remove video card due to troubleshooting later, my husband and I find out that my tower is defective. The top power button and USB ports don't work, but the restart button does.

My husband tried the power switch from an old case he had, and that one worked, so yes, there is a defect. Oh well, at least my system turns on and works nicely now with new large-capacity SSDs and a faster, better video card in a well-ventilated case.

Corsair is back at it again with one of their best cases yet!

The Corsair 4000D Airflow is an exceptional mid-tower case that has impressed me with its superb design, outstanding cooling capabilities, and overall performance. Corsair has once again proven why they are a leader in the PC hardware industry, delivering a product that satisfies both enthusiasts and casual users alike.

The 4000D Airflow has exceptional cooling performance. The case comes equipped with two pre-installed 120mm fans in the front. The generous mesh front panel design allows for excellent intake airflow, while the ample space for additional fans and radiators enables customization to suit your specific cooling needs. The case also provides convenient dust filters, making maintenance a breeze.

The interior design of the 4000D Airflow is well thought out, providing a spacious and versatile layout for easy installation and cable management. The removable PSU shroud and dedicated cable routing channels ensure a clean and clutter-free build. The tool-free drive trays are a welcome addition, allowing for hassle-free installation of storage drives. Additionally, the case provides ample room for large GPUs and CPU coolers, making it compatible with high-performance components.

In conclusion, the Corsair 4000D Airflow is a stellar mid-tower case that ticks all the right boxes. Its sleek design, outstanding cooling capabilities, spacious interior, and convenient features make it a top contender in its class. Whether you're a PC enthusiast or a casual user, this case offers an exceptional balance between style, performance, and functionality. If you're looking for a reliable and visually appealing case to house your next build, the Corsair 4000D Airflow should be at the top of your list.

I liked building two computers using this white case. There are a lot of features packed into this compact case, which would also make it a good choice for someone building a computer for the first time. My main complaint is the panel that covers where the cables go around to the back almost always has to slide to the second position. I had to do this both times because there was no other way that my 24-pin cable could fit through the gap at such a sharp angle. Now the cables in the back are visible. Another thing to consider is that if you're using PSU cable extensions, a non-modular PSU, and RGB controllers, then that HDD bay probably won't fit. Quality is quite good overall. The only place where it falls short is the bracket that holds the three fans on the side is a bit flimsy. Anyways, bought twice and happy with it both times. Comes with plenty of screws, zip ties, and two 3-pin fans.
Real nice case for an affordable price. Good RGB Corsair controller included with RGB fans. Nice cable management. A bit on the flimsy side but definitely usable. Super quiet fans as well !

Nice looking case and fits an ATX board perfectly, it was my first pc build and i wasnt too stressed figuring this case out, comes with the cables on the back already organized and managed. Temps only reach 68c with an overclock to 5ghz and with the 3060 running the case doesnt really get that loud at all, when idle its really hard to hear it, i can only slightly hear the sound of my AIO.
Definitly can reccomend this case, Not sure if it can fit 40 series cards though like the 4090 but it fits my MSI 3060 Gaming x gpu, i also built a second pc and it was easy to install a micro atx aswell.
The only con id say is the fact there is only 1 usb port at the front but that doesnt bother me since my rear IO has like 8 ports and my keyboard has USB passthrough.
I recomend buying the one with the fans, the one without rgb fans isnt really my favourite since its only controlled via voltage since it is only a 3 pin. Also they could make more room to more comfortably install a commander core XT but i managed to stuff it in there at the back.

This case was really good. It was shipped nicely, and packaged well.
However, on the metal side pannel there was a very noticable scuff going diagonally up the botton corner, luckily for me, I have that side against the wall.

I dont have any pictures of this tower but i built a gaming pc for my brother and when it is paired with
Corsair H100x RGB Elite Liquid CPU Cooler
Corsair Force Series Gen.4 PCIe MP600 1TB
Corsair Vengeance LPX 32GB (2 X 16GB) DDR4 3600
ASUS TUF Gaming H670-PRO WiFi D4 LGA 1700 (or similiar motherboards)
Intel Core i7-12700K Desktop Processor 12
CORSAIR RM Series (2021), RM750, 750 Watt, 80 Plus

you can play fortnite, gta5 (at mid graphics settings) and many other games without a graphics card so when you add a gpu
it will unleash ALOT more potential my brother and i are very pleased so far and i still think he is running without a gpu
Super

Après plusieurs mois d'utilisation, je suis vraiment impressionné par le boîtier CORSAIR. Voici ce que j'en pense en quelques points:

----------- Design & Finitions :----------------
Le boîtier offre une esthétique sobre et orientée Gamer, notamment avec le verre trempé qui permet d'exposer les composants internes du PC. C'est sans doute l'une des raisons principales pour lesquelles j'ai choisi ce modèle. Aussi il y a une version avec vitre avant ou avec grille, celle avec une grille a un meilleur airflow, mais j'ai investi sur un bon kit de refroidissement et j'ai pris le boitier avec une vitre avant car il est plus esthétique pour moi.

------------- Éclairage RGB: ---------------
Le système d'éclairage iCUE de CORSAIR ne déçoit jamais! J'ai pu personnaliser l'éclairage selon mes besoins et il est très facile à utiliser, et il se marie parfaitement avec le reste de mon setup.

---------------Air Flow:-------------
J'utilise plusieurs ventilateurs et le boîtier est conçu pour permettre une circulation d'air optimale. Même pendant les sessions de jeu gourmandes, ce qui est un gros plus pour moi.

--------------Espace & Modularité:-----------------------
Bien que qualifié de "moyen tour", le 4000X offre suffisamment d'espace pour tous mes composants, et j'apprécie vraiment sa modularité qui m'a permis de gérer facilement le cable management.

------------Facilité d'installation: ---------------
Le montage a été un jeu d'enfant. Tous les emplacements sont clairement identifiés et accessibles.

Cependant, rien n'est parfait. J'aurais aimé avoir peut-être quelques passages de câbles supplémentaires ou des options de personnalisation (quelques câbles restes bien visibles sur les photos), mais ce sont des détails mineurs au vu de la qualité générale de ce boîtier.

---------------Conclusion :------------------
Je recommande vivement le CORSAIR iCUE 4000X RGB à quiconque cherche un boîtier PC alliant esthétique, performance et qualité de construction. Je recommande vivement !

I recently upgraded my PC case to the CORSAIR iCUE 4000X RGB, and I must say, it's been a fantastic addition to my setup. Here's my unbiased review of this product.

Pros:

Stunning RGB Lighting: The RGB lighting on this case is a showstopper. The three included SP120 RGB Elite fans illuminate your PC with vibrant, customizable colors. The iCUE software allows you to sync the lighting with other Corsair peripherals, creating a visually cohesive gaming or work environment.

Excellent Build Quality: The case feels solid and well-constructed. The tempered glass side panel provides a clear view of your components, and it's easy to remove for maintenance or upgrades.

Great Cable Management: Corsair has designed this case with cable management in mind. There are plenty of cable routing channels and tie-down points, helping you achieve a clean and organized interior.

Airflow: Despite the emphasis on aesthetics, Corsair hasn't compromised on airflow. The front panel has a mesh design that allows for adequate ventilation, keeping your components cool even during demanding tasks.

Spacious Interior: The 4000X offers ample space for ATX motherboards and high-end GPUs. It also supports multiple storage options, including SSD trays and HDD cages.

Easy Installation: Installing components in this case is a breeze, thanks to the well-thought-out layout. The tool-free drive bays and PCIe slot covers make the build process smoother.

Cons:

Price: While the features and quality are top-notch, the price point may be a bit high for some users. However, considering the included RGB fans and overall build quality, it's a reasonable investment for enthusiasts.

Limited Radiator Support: If you plan on using a large liquid cooling setup, the radiator support might be a bit limited, especially at the front. You'll need to ensure that your chosen components fit within the case's dimensions.

In summary, the CORSAIR iCUE 4000X RGB Tempered Glass Mid-Tower ATX PC Case is an outstanding choice for gamers and PC enthusiasts who prioritize aesthetics without sacrificing functionality. It offers a stunning RGB lighting experience, excellent build quality, and efficient cable management. While it comes at a premium price, it's a worthwhile investment for anyone looking to showcase their PC components in style.

Je suis absolument ravi de partager mon expérience avec le boîtier PC de chez Corsair. Dès le déballage, j'ai été séduit par son design moderne et élégant. Avec ses ventilateurs avant RGB qui illuminent subtilement mon espace de jeu, il ajoute une touche esthétique incomparable à ma configuration. Mais ce n'est pas que de l'apparence ! Ce boîtier offre une expérience d'installation et de gestion de câbles exceptionnelle.

L'un des points forts incontestables de ce boîtier est sa facilité d'installation des composants. Les emplacements parfaitement conçus permettent de monter les cartes graphiques, les disques durs et les alimentations sans aucun tracas. Même pour quelqu'un comme moi, qui n'est pas un expert en assemblage de PC, l'expérience a été fluide et sans embûches.

La gestion des câbles est un autre aspect remarquable. Grâce aux passages intelligemment placés, j'ai pu dissimuler habilement tous les câbles disgracieux, offrant ainsi un aspect soigné et bien organisé à l'intérieur du boîtier. Cette fonctionnalité s'est avérée essentielle pour maintenir une circulation d'air optimale et garder mon système au frais pendant de longues sessions de jeu intenses.

Les vitres latérales et en façade ajoutent une touche de transparence qui met en valeur l'ensemble de ma configuration. C'est un plaisir de pouvoir admirer mes composants et de montrer fièrement mon travail d'assemblage. Corsair a vraiment pensé à tout pour offrir aux utilisateurs un spectacle visuel incroyable, à l'intérieur comme à l'extérieur du boîtier.

Mais ce n'est pas seulement une question d'apparence. La qualité de construction du boîtier est exceptionnelle. Les matériaux robustes utilisés inspirent confiance et je sais que mes composants sont entre de bonnes mains. Le boîtier offre également une excellente isolation phonique, ce qui réduit considérablement le bruit de fonctionnement de mes composants, offrant ainsi une expérience de jeu plus immersive et agréable.

En résumé, le boîtier PC Corsair avec RGB et vitres latérales est un véritable bijou de technologie et de style. Il allie parfaitement le design moderne avec des fonctionnalités pratiques, comme une installation facile des composants et une gestion de câbles ingénieuse. Les vitres ajoutent une touche visuelle impressionnante, tandis que la qualité de construction assure une durabilité à toute épreuve. Si vous cherchez à donner un coup de boost à votre setup gaming tout en restant fidèle à la qualité, ce boîtier est un choix incontournable. Corsair a vraiment frappé fort avec ce modèle, et je ne peux que le recommander à tous les passionnés de PC qui veulent un boîtier à la hauteur de leurs attentes les plus élevées.

J'ai déjà monté plusieurs PC avec des boîtiers différents et j'ai été très surpris par la simplicité de celui-ci :
1/ Il est beau : Le mélange blanc et gris est nickel
2/ Il est très grand : J'ai monté un Ryzen 7 7800x3D avec un gros ventirad et la carte graphique est une Radeon 7900 XTX (la plus grande d'AMD) et j'ai largement eu la place.
3/ La "cable management" est très simple grâce à des passage très simple et des scratchs déjà monté.
4/ Nettoyage du PC facile grâce à des filtres en face avant, sur le dessus et en dessous.

Si vous aimez le look du boîtier et que vous montez votre 1er PC achetez les yeux fermés !!!

I had a prebuilt I bought a long time ago that I basically have upgraded into a new PC over the years. The only thing I haven't replaced is the case by this point. My old case wasn't awful, but it began to fall apart, and I always wanted a white PC case so I decided to give in and get this one! I don't regret it at all so far. It was really easy to set up, and the cable management is way better than other cases I have worked with (I have worked on a few PC's for my brother and friends as well). I also love how this case is a mid sized tower, but somehow has so much room? I found it much easier to work with compared to my old case, which was a large sized tower. Everything is really easy to remove and put back together, and it came with extra zip ties, velcro strips, and screws for fans and screwing in the motherboard, which is super nice. The only thing that I noticed was it doesn't fit a 140mm fan at the back of the case, which is what I had in my old case (this is user error, I didn't double check this. Just wanted to mention in case anyone might be unaware too). But the case came with two simple black 120 mm fans so I just used one of those no problem. It looks great and I am super happy with it!

name: Corsair 4000D Airflow Tempered Glass Mid-Tower ATX PC Case - Black, CC-9011200-WW
description:
• Combining innovative cable management, concentrated airflow, and proven CORSAIR build quality, the 4000D is a fitting choice for an immaculate high-performance PC.
