Le boîtier offre également une excellente isolation phonique, ce qui réduit considérablement le bruit de fonctionnement de mes composants, offrant ainsi une expérience de jeu plus immersive et agréable.

En résumé, le boîtier PC Corsair avec RGB et vitres latérales est un véritable bijou de technologie et de style. Il allie parfaitement le design moderne avec des fonctionnalités pratiques, comme une installation facile des composants et une gestion de câbles ingénieuse. Les vitres ajoutent une touche visuelle impressionnante, tandis que la qualité de construction assure une durabilité à toute épreuve. Si vous cherchez à donner un coup de boost à votre setup gaming tout en restant fidèle à la qualité, ce boîtier est un choix incontournable. Corsair a vraiment frappé fort avec ce modèle, et je ne peux que le recommander à tous les passionnés de PC qui veulent un boîtier à la hauteur de leurs attentes les plus élevées.

J'ai déjà monté plusieurs PC avec des boîtiers différents et j'ai été très surpris par la simplicité de celui-ci :
1/ Il est beau : Le mélange blanc et gris est nickel
2/ Il est très grand : J'ai monté un Ryzen 7 7800x3D avec un gros ventirad et la carte graphique est une Radeon 7900 XTX (la plus grande d'AMD) et j'ai largement eu la place.
3/ La "cable management" est très simple grâce à des passage très simple et des scratchs déjà monté.
4/ Nettoyage du PC facile grâce à des filtres en face avant, sur le dessus et en dessous.

Si vous aimez le look du boîtier et que vous montez votre 1er PC achetez les yeux fermés !!!

I had a prebuilt I bought a long time ago that I basically have upgraded into a new PC over the years. The only thing I haven't replaced is the case by this point. My old case wasn't awful, but it began to fall apart, and I always wanted a white PC case so I decided to give in and get this one! I don't regret it at all so far. It was really easy to set up, and the cable management is way better than other cases I have worked with (I have worked on a few PC's for my brother and friends as well). I also love how this case is a mid sized tower, but somehow has so much room? I found it much easier to work with compared to my old case, which was a large sized tower. Everything is really easy to remove and put back together, and it came with extra zip ties, velcro strips, and screws for fans and screwing in the motherboard, which is super nice. The only thing that I noticed was it doesn't fit a 140mm fan at the back of the case, which is what I had in my old case (this is user error, I didn't double check this. Just wanted to mention in case anyone might be unaware too). But the case came with two simple black 120 mm fans so I just used one of those no problem. It looks great and I am super happy with it!

name: Rosewill 4U Server Chassis 11 Bay Server Case 8X 3.5 + 3X 5.25 HDD, ATX, Rackmount Server Case, Include Front 2X 120mm Fans Rear 2X 80mm Fans Metal Rack Mount Computer Case 21" Deep, RSV-R4000U
description:
• Spacious Chassis: This massive 4U server case has 8 internal 3.5” HDD bays plus room for 3 additional 5.25” devices.
  • Expandable & ATX/CEB Compatible: 7 PCI expansion slots and ATX and CEB motherboard compatibility give you growth options for all of your needs.
  • Quiet Cooling: 4 pre-installed cooling fans provide excellent airflow and heat protection at reduced noise. 2 front 120mm fans and 2 rear 80mm fans ensure your drives and chassis avoid overheating.
  • Desired Features: Front panel LED indicators for power, HDD, and LAN status monitoring allow quick, easy visual assessment. Additional utility with 1 USB 3.0 and 1 USB 2.0 port and built-in front panel lock provides extra security for your server case.

reviews.review: Great choice for my home network! However, height is almost too short for a standard PSU and I had some issues with the pre-installed fans hitting the dust covers. On the bright side, drive bays are individually removable if not needed which improves airflow!

Does its job as needed. Everything advertised in the page is accurate and is noticeable in this high quality product.

- Definitely recommend.

This is a solid, well built budget rack mount server chassis. It's important to understand what you're getting here. So long as your expectations are appropriate, these chassis offer excellent value. First off, these are no SuperMicro. The target market is not enterprise companies. If you want a complete SYSTEM - and by that I mean, chassis, rails, etc. that all work together seamlessly - look elsewhere. But if you are willing to overlook a few potential warts, this is a great value. Now, let's first clarify some typical, appropriate use cases for this chassis. For starters, I bought the RSV-4500. This chassis comes with 8 fans and holds up to 15 3.5" hard drives. The hard drive caddies are up front, and mean there's air being pushed across them, and then air is pulled across them as well by the next set of fans, located about 1/3 deep into the case (measured front to back). The distance between both sets of fans is ~9". This leads me to suspect this amount of cooling is overkill for most disks, even with 5 of them per cage / per set of fans. The fans are 120mm. There is a sister case, which is Rosewill model RSV-L4412U. The only difference between them is the RSV-L4412U model has 12 hot swap bays and is missing the 3 front-most 120mm fans found in the RSV-4500. The hot swap bays provided with the RSV-L4412U model are 3x RSV-SATA-Cage-34, a 4-bay 3.5" drive cage made of plastic and have some questionable design characteristics. They retail on Amazon for ~$80 each + tax. If a budget hot-swap rackmount chassis is your goal, the RSV-L4412U is an incredible bargain. If you were to purchase the RSV-4500 for example, and then purchase 3x of the Rosewill drive cages, you would spend substantially more money than if you simply bought the RSV-L4412U in the first place. If you are more interested in getting the best overall combination of number of 3.5" hard drives, hot swap drive capability, and a good quality chassis, you are better off going with the RSV-4500 and separately purchasing 3x 3.5" drive cages manufactured by Norco or SuperMicro. Several independent tests have shown these drive cages to be among the best at keeping 3.5" drives reasonably cool. Avoid Icy Dock. iStarUSA used to produce good quality drive cages, but their current offerings are either flimsy and/or have poor drive cooling, and should also be avoided if you would like to ensure your drives don't fail prematurely due to constant overheating. There is one other option for a 15-drive bay setup. That is to go with the RSV-4500, not purchase hot swap drive cages, but remove the front fans. In this configuration, you still take advantage of the air filter built into the front of the flip down case fascia, and it is possible to position the drive inserts that come with the RSV-4500 case such that your SATA/SAS connection is facing rearward, while the clips to remove a drive and replace it when necessary are pointed forward. This will allow you to close the fascia and hide your bare drives, but access them easily when necessary. This approach is not for everyone, but it is a budget-conscious solution that will provide you with up to 15-drive bays in a well-cooled chassis, in spite of removing the front fans. With your drives installed in this manner, they will still be ~4" from the 3x 120mm fans still installed in the case. For most people, with most hard drives, this will be more than adequate air flow to keep your drives reasonably cool. To re-cap, there are several options for installing a good sized bank of 3.5" drives in this case, and its design offers considerable flexibility. One area that is a negative, is the documentation for the chassis is mediocre at best, and poor in some respects. For example, it fails to explain the fact that in order to depress the tabs that release the incumbent hard drive cages in the RSV-4500, you must first remove 1 or 2 screws for each cage that holds it in place. Once you have done so, the act of removing the drive cages requires one to simultaneously push down a couple of metal tabs on top of the drive cage, and apply force from the rear of the drive cage pushing it forward. Then, it will release out the front of the case. Furthermore, these acts require the removal (or at least sliding back) the top case cover. This latter point is noteworthy if you plan to install the chassis in a server rack and anything is installed directly above it. This, in turn leads me to my final point; the rails. I purchased the set of rails manufactured by Rosewill and compatible with this case. These rails are not included with your purchase of the chassis, which is a common issue with budget rackmount chassis. Unfortunately, the Rosewill rails use an old, rudimentary design that has fallen out of favor with most large, mainstream server chassis manufacturers, and for good reason. There are a lot of variety of server racks on the market now, and I found the Rosewill rail system would not install properly on my wall-mount server rack from StarTech. Specifically, the outer rail - where it wraps around the front and rear of a 4-post rack - was 1/8" too wide. This resulted in a narrowing of the space between both inner rails of 1/4", which was enough to make it impossible to install the Rosewill RSV-L4500 chassis in the server rack after attaching the inner rails to it and attempting to connect it with the middle rails on the rail system. Careful investigation after it became clear the unit was not going to fit into the rack revealed the flaw in the design of the Rosewill rails. I then experimented with a set of 3U/4U SuperMicro rails that use a more modern rail design, but I ran into the opposite problem. This combination resulted in an extra gap between the sides of the RSV-L4500 and the outer rails attached securely to the rack. I could have attempted the use of 5mm spacers, but this would have made the process more complicated by requiring 5mm longer screws. Furthermore, the rail screw holes in the SuperMicro inner rail did not align well with the side of the RSV-L4500 and it's pre-drilled rack rail mounting holes, meaning it would have been necessary to tap drill out multiple new threaded holes in the case for the purpose of utilizing the SuperMicro rail. In short, the LSV-4500 does not lend itself to universal rails (I also tried a set of StarTech rails, which also had alignment issues), due to the uncommon width of the server (it is rather narrow at 16.8" wide). That being said, if your server rack is designed in such a fashion that the Rosewill rack rails are able to wrap around the edge of the server rails without pushing back into the interior of the rack, as was the case for me, then it may be an option for you. Bottom line is this chassis is a solid budget choice, but it does have some drawbacks, depending on your needs. If you're willing to live with a bit of inconvenience and have a means to support it well enough in your rack (weight with all parts installed and 15 drives will be ~ 60-75 lbs.), it is a solid, economical choice for a large 3.5" drive system for a home network NAS or media server. It's not perfect, but it is a good overall value. YMMV ------------------------------- EDIT 01.14.2022: In my original review, I inadvertently failed to clearly explain an important step if you wish to front-load your drives into the LSV-4500 case. It's a big enough pain that I should have provided more details in my original review, but here goes.... The LSV-4500 is designed such that you must insert and remove your drives from the rear of each of the three (3) groups of five (5) drives. That means in order to exchange a drive or install a new one you must do the following: 1. Pull the chassis out of your rack. 2. Remove the chassis lid. 3. Release the drive cage and slide it partially forward. 4. Reach to the back of the drive cage, pinch the tabs for the drive you need to remove, and slide the drive rearward. 5. Remove the attached SATA and power cables. In my original review, I mentioned there is an alternative approach where the drives may be mounted from the front. What I neglected to mention is this method involves minor hacking of the drive cages. Specifically, there are small, metal tabs toward the front of the drive cage, which are designed to stop you from accidentally sliding a drive too far forward and into the path of the front fan blades. So, if you want to be able to front-load your drives you will need to bend these tabs inward so they are flush with the inside side walls of the drive cage. It's not particularly difficult. This can be accomplished with a good set of ordinary pliers or a vice grip. A downside of front-loading your drives is it also means getting rid of the front mounted fans. There's really no point in keeping that in this configuration, as you'd have to remove them in order to get to the drives, defeating the purpose of having them be accessible from the front of the chassis. The upside is of course it means there's no need to remove the top of the chassis and manipulate the drive cage to remove or add a drive. You may think of this as a "budget hot swap" option if you like. Personally, I don't recommend going that route, but if it suits your needs it is an option. SuperMicro Drive Cage Swap I've since found there is yet another option if you're interested in tinkering with the RSV-4500. It turns out that SuperMicro 5-disk mobile drive cages happen to fit very nicely in lieu of the stock drive cages. Remove the stock drive cages, insert the SuperMicro mobile drive cage with the LEDs at the top, and secure the SuperMicro cage with 2 screws on top and/or bottom. The cage will be firmly in place, and now you have just added 5 hot swap bays to your chassis. Next, you have a few possible configurations for this mod. You may then use the SuperMicro drive cage as a hot swap drive cage if you'd like. There is barely enough room to leave the 92mm fan on the rear of the SuperMicro drive cage in place, however I recommend removing it. I conducted some tests with an air velocity tester used by HVAC technicians to measure air speed and throughput, and I found with the SuperMicro 92mm fan blowing into a 120mm fan in the middle drive cage, it actually reduced the amount of air being pushed backward in the case (though I was not able to measure whether or not it improved the hydrostatic pressure). The problem is there's barely any space between the fans. You can move the middle fan rack back further by about 1/2" via an extra set of screw holes in the side of the chassis, but either way we're talking about less than 2" of clearance between both fans. Therefore, i recommend removing the SuperMicro 92mm fan from the back of the S.M. drive cage if you implement this design in your chassis. This also solves the problem of trying to route all your SATA cables from the back of the SuperMicro drive cage backplane to your motherboard without getting them in the way of the fans. Other Information Tid-bits 1. You must use the stock drive cages if you want to use the front mounted fans. The fans are bolted into the fascia of the drive cages, and these are in turn designed to be recessed into the front of the case such that the locking front panel is able to close properly. 2. There is an air filter built into the lockable front panel. 3. The middle fan rack can be removed. It may also be adjusted very slightly by moving it back about 1/2" in the chassis, by mounting it with an alternative set of holes on the side of the chassis.

I've had the luck of being able to buy two variants of these "15 bay" 4U chassis over the years, and they're actually better today than they used to be. My first introduction to them was for GPU mining a LONG time ago, if you are willing to remove the cross bar, secondary fan bar, and bays you could easily fit two E-ATX boards inside, or pack a bunch of GPUs on USB<->PCIE risers. The current design (2023) attaches the 120mm fans to the drive bays which is fine unless you plan on removing the drive bays (but want to have front-intake cooling.) These days we are buying them for gaming machines and studio/production workstations, we rack them in a cabinet from the center of the bullpen that exhausts into the attic space leaving our office space quiet and cool, the only cables coming out are 1xUSB and 1xDisplayPort per chassis. There is enough space to fit two radiators, but you may need to upgrade the case fans to exhaust the heat -- the stock fans are reasonably quiet, but the exhaust of the unit is maybe 60-70 cfm which is not enough when you have a 300-450watt GPU and 140-280watt CPU running at max, even with a climate-controlled cabinet/room with a proper barrier. For a typical backoffice server or JBOD box the stock cooling is more than adequate, and the secondary fan bar will actually ensure your drives aren't heat soaking. It's a decent chassis, and hard to beat the price. [10/10] will keep buying these 15 bay chassis for as long as Rosewill is profitable enough to make them :D

I recently acquired the Rosewill 4U Server Chassis, specifically the RSV-L4500U model, and I must say that it has exceeded my expectations in terms of build quality, functionality, and overall performance. If you're in need of a reliable and feature-packed server case, look no further!

First and foremost, the RSV-L4500U's construction is solid and built to last. The sturdy metal frame and rackmount design provide excellent durability, ensuring that your server components remain safe and secure in professional environments. The 25" depth of the case offers ample space for housing numerous server components and allows for efficient cable management.

This server chassis offers an impressive 15 bays for 3.5" HDDs, providing vast storage capacity for your data-intensive applications. The flexibility to accommodate up to 15 hard drives is ideal for anyone requiring significant storage expansion or operating a data-intensive server setup. Additionally, the inclusion of hot-swappable drive bays is a convenient feature, allowing for effortless drive replacement and maintenance.

The RSV-L4500U's compatibility with E-ATX motherboards is a standout feature, as it ensures support for a wide range of server configurations. Whether you're using a single high-performance motherboard or multiple smaller boards, this server chassis can accommodate your needs effortlessly.

One of the key strengths of the RSV-L4500U is its excellent cooling capability. The case comes equipped with six front 120mm fans and two rear 80mm fans, offering efficient airflow throughout the chassis. This ensures optimal thermal management, preventing overheating and maintaining the stability and longevity of your server components. The fan placement and airflow design contribute to low noise levels, which is particularly important in professional settings.

The overall design of the RSV-L4500U is well thought out, making installation and maintenance a breeze. The removable and lockable front door provides added security while allowing easy access to the drives and other components. The tool-less drive bays and motherboard installation mechanism are additional time-saving features that enhance the user experience.

Lastly, I must mention Rosewill's exceptional customer support. They were responsive, knowledgeable, and ready to assist with any queries I had regarding the server chassis. Their commitment to customer satisfaction is truly commendable.

To sum it up, the Rosewill 4U Server Chassis, specifically the RSV-L4500U model, is an outstanding choice for anyone seeking a reliable and versatile server case. Its sturdy construction, spacious design, compatibility with E-ATX motherboards, impressive cooling system, and user-friendly features make it an excellent investment for professional server setups. I highly recommend the RSV-L4500U for its exceptional build quality, functionality, and the peace of mind it offers in safeguarding your critical server infrastructure.

I replaced all of the internal fans with Noctua 80mm, and tbh...the sound difference isn't that minimal. I ended up reusing the stock fans in different parts of the case. I did two desktop conversions with these cases, and each worked out although the clearance between the onboard sata ports and the fan housing was so short, I had to remove that housing the get insert the sata cables (and I had to use differing directional angular connections (one up, one down) to fit one of the boards in. I managed to fit 8 drives (6 hdd, 2 sdd) in the drive bay area, but the gap between the drive bays and the motherboard enclosure is a bit small...fortunately, I installed a sas card with thin sata cabling (otherwise, they wouldn't have fit). Clearance between the drives and the fan enclosure is also a few mm too small...cabling coming out of the drives bends sharply against the fan grills (they're ultra thin too), and I ended up breaking one of them (finding out after reassembly...sigh). Being gentle helps there.

The one real gripe though, is that the psu compartment is too small for all of the psus I have. I got it to fit, but had to take out the mounting bracket as the psu length is an inch or so too long, so it's just wedged in there. The rails come out of the psu and run right into one of the 4 (optional) 80 mm fans, so I could only power the drives and fans off of the two rails that were far enough to the right to avoid that fan.

You will definitely need fan grills on all internal fans. The 80mm space in the rear doesn't have mounting wholes...do I used HVAC tape. It might sound janky, but its stable.

Zip ties area your friend as well at keeping cabling in order. I also ended up getting a Noctua low profile cooler to replace the typical monster sized desktop ones. I had to bend it a bit to get it to clear the ram, and still fit inside the 2U enclosure. Had to remove the ram heat sync's as well, but that Noctua was so large it covered the ram as well, so...I suppose that's a little bit of a positive side effect.

Note to self: never throw away low profile card brackets...the generic ones I ended up using don't really fit the cards.

In total, it was worth the conversion, although with a 10G and SAS card installed. Drives are the same temperatures as they were in the desktop case (29c-35c) even under continuous load. It took a lot of hours though to get things in and fitting...taking things apart when they dont fit and re-routing cables. The second time around though had a much more clean looking result.

I don't use rails...my rack has three shelves in place as-is, so they're just stacked (bolted, with spaces on the back side for the same clearance I would have gotten with rails)

I think I will go for a 3U or 4U next time just for better clearances for cabling, and more GPU options (which I didn't have for these conversions).

I am actually writing this review in hopes that Rosewill support sees this and lets me know where to get spare parts. One of the hot swap bays/modules in my RSV-L4412U is bad, and tech support ignored my email and the phone line hung up on me. Where can I get a spare?

I would advise against getting this unless Rosewill demonstrates publicly that they respond.

UPDATE:

Also this case came with 3 faulty SATA cables. I didn't even attempt to RMA these, I simply used spares I had on hand.

Don't call, their phone number in the manual, simply hangs up after a few minutes on the phone and provides no option to hold. The email in the manual techsupport@rosewill.com looks like it words and their people can check it, but they don't somehow this gets ignored.

To get a response use RMA@Rosewill.com and even then take response with a grain of salt because they have crap internal communication.

The spare part number for the hot swap module is: RSV-SATA-Cage-34

There are retail and RMA versions of this part. I am not clear on the exact difference, but RMA representatives promised me a replacement in 1-2 business 2 weeks ago and I never received any update after that, then I learned they were out of the RMA version. To be fair to them they said there might be other delays but I expected some communication, and that team ghosted me.

Eventually a Rosewill representative did call me but only because of this review. They wanted to make whole situation right and offered me the retail version of the part. This rep explained the inventory difference, was puzzled about the non-responses I got but recorded (and verified them, I had all the ID numbers and timestamps). I suspect this is a different team that is less dysfunctional.

Don't use this case unless you have a very reliable checksumming system on your data. I am using ZFS and its checksumming was key in identifying the faulty cables and faulty hot swap module. It is still cheap for what it is, the next cheapest solution is north of double the price. So if you can reliably find silent data errors and have a willingness to troubleshoot this can be made to work.

I moved this to two stars, for now. Since my complaints are mostly around service if I do get the replacement cage I will move this review to 4 stars, because it is now clear they are trying but have crap systems in place now. I can't give 5 stars, it has been more than a month in total and they still haven't gotten me a spare.

Update 2

This review resulted in a call to me, that resulted in a replacement for the faulty part being shipped to me. This took far too long and critical mismanagement like this is part of why I was avoiding NewEgg. Amazon isn't great but at least they respond, and now this replacement shows up in a NewEgg box?! Like they are proud of this level of service. If I had known newegg was involved. I wouldn't have ordered this to begin with.

I had been boycotting newegg because of them having ripped me off a few times and likely criminal levels of shenanigans. I can't go higher than 3 stars knowing this put money into the hands of people I specifically chose not to. I don't think I will be ordering anything from NewEgg or Rosewill for several years and if you do be ready for a hassle if anything goes wrong.

name: Internal 5 Port Non-Raid Sata III 6GB/S PCI-E X4 Controller Card for Desktop PC Support SSD and HDD with Low Profile Bracket. Jmb585 Chipset
description:
• Connect five SATA drives to any free PCI-E x4 slot, providing up to 1700 MB/s speed
  • Plug and play supported, no additional software installation or setting required
  • Can support port multiplier that is not in a RAID configuration
  • Complies with PCI Express base specification revision 3.1a. Compatible with SATA hard drives & solid State drives and computer systems with SATA controllers
  • This card is only design for storage use only, can not boot any OS/ system drives. Backed by syba 3 Year hassle-free warranty and lifetime customer service. Important Note: only work with PCI-E slot, not for PCI slot

reviews.review:
All I wanted was a card to add SATA ports, and possibly take advantage of the PCIe 3.0 slot I had on my newer ASRock AMD B450 motherboard. The first card I purchased (completely different brand) wouldn't even let my system boot properly, required 3rd party drivers, and was PCIe 2 1x. So, I was forced to return it, and landed upon this one. This one just worked, in both Windows & Linux. No driver install required, and speed tests yield the same speeds as my motherboard SATA ports, but only about 550MB/S. (No idea if that's good or bad) I plan to use this box in a future freeNAS/UnRaid build, so I wasn't interested in any fancy features or RAID support. Just something simple with native SATA support.

The only confusion I had was, the box hi-lights PCIe 2.0 support, and RAID 0-10. I'm thinking the packaging is wrong? Or, it's right, and the advertising material is wrong?

Not much else to say, as I've only had the card for 24hrs now. This same card is available from many suppliers, with slightly different prices. I would recommend sticking with IOCREST's variation. I think the firmware is written by the supplier, and so no two cards are the same, even though the hardware is identical. (Or the hardware/JMB585 requires no firmware, and I don't have a clue about what I'm talking about). Just a recommendation though.

On the product package there is a image state compatible with freenas. I installed the card with Truenas core 13 u4 and it work for some degree. I install 5 WD gold 2TB on the card and setup raidz1, everything seems fine and I can trasnfer files to the servers fine. However when I look at console I notice a lot of cam status uncorrectable parity /crc errors from all 5 drives. However if i connected the drive to my motherboard sata port there is no error be reported. I look it up it seem the issue is due to chipset use SATA port multipliers which truenas doesn't like.

I bought this to use in my custom NAS build. The motherboard provided 6 SATA ports but I needed more. Works really well in both TrueNAS and Unraid. Exactly what I was looking for. I just ordered my second one for the second NAS I'll be working on soon.

I have an unraid server with 8 HDDs and 3 running off this card and everything is working great so far without a hitch, I do not notice any slow downs or performance issues. Will report back down the road if there is an issue. The package also came with 2 SATA cables.

Was building a personal UNRAID tower out of an old PC I had with 2010-2014 parts and this card made it easy to expand the number of SATA ports/drives I can add to my array. Infinite vouch for this card, speeds are as advertised!

This replaced a cheaper X1 card which had 4 sockets but would only run 2 disks at a time. Apparently it need a driver which wasn't supplied and I couldn't find on line.
This X4 card with 5 sockets runs 5 disks simultaneously with no driver required.
Includes the most current SATA specs which means it will handle latest HDDs and SSDs. Good transfer speeds - same as drives connected to my top end motherboard.

Installed it into my Unraid linux server and was dedicated by the operating system and did not require downloading any drivers from the net. Card also supports my 4 bay Mediasonic Probox 4 bay e-sata external hard drive case. All 4 hard drives in the case were detected and work 100% with Unraid.
PCI x 4 (note this is not standard for non SAS) means this bad boy can move 1700MB/s, other ones top out around 400, the speed of one drive. Do the math.

I write reviews when I have the time or if I think it's something important people should be aware of. In this case it's the latter; I'm almost certain this device was the direct (or indirect) reason for my PC locking up anywhere from 1-3 times a day for a month. I'll thoroughly explain.

I bought this along with another hard drive as I was out of SATA ports on my motherboard and I'd need it to use the new drive. The second day after installation of both devices, my PC hung on the desktop after a few hours of use. The cursor wouldn't move, no BSOD, no input ability whatsoever. It required a reboot. From that day on, this would occur 1-2 times a day. It varied. I work nights, and if I left my PC on all night, I'd come home to it locked up almost always. I put up with this for a month.

Now, I had to wonder if it was the new hard drive or the controller as I installed them simultaneously. I decided I'd try another controller. I've been running *9 days* on another SATA controller I bought and I've had *zero* lockups. I mentioned earlier about the device causing the lockups directly/indirectly, and the reason I say that is, I have no idea if a fresh installation of windows 10 would remedy this -- but I wasn't willing to try. It could have been some kind of driver conflict or what not, or it was attributed to my particular OS installation or PC, who knows. It could also be that it's defective. Either way, it's apparent after 9 days of no lockups that the SATA controller was not working for me.

I won't say whether to buy it or not, and that's why I'm giving it two stars. I'm simply posting this for anyone else that bought this controller and is experiencing the exact same problems and don't know why. It's probably this device. If by chance the lockups continue despite my removing the device, I will update my review making note of this and changing the stars. I might also throw it in another PC at a later date for testing and update my review with my findings.

I'm using a couple of these to expand storage on my UnRAID server. I decided to go with these instead of a standard LSI SAS card since I wanted something that supports PCIe 3.0. It was just plug and play; I detached the hard drives that were plugged into my old IO Crest PCIe 2.0 card and into this one and it just worked. I haven't noticed any of the performance degradation under load many users report on Marvell-based cards (though I hadn't had those issues with my former IO Crest Marvell-based card either).

I currently have one of these running in an x1 slot with 5 drives attached to it. Having it running on only 1 PCIe lane reduces the speed to 850MB/s total but under normal operation I haven't noticed any problems with that. I wouldn't recommend using an x1 slot if you are attaching SSDs or get the 4 SATA + 1 M.2 version of this card, but if you're just using spinning drives and your motherboard has open-ended PCIe slots you can still use this if your x4+ slots are all taken.

Installed on asus prime x570-P. Was a bit nervous about it actually being plug and play. Installed it, and became concerned because the drive connected did not show up anywhere in bios. Left bios and entered windows 10, drive was recognized in disk management and everything has been working great. I have one hdd connected to it so far, and this hdd is a part of a stripe with hdd's connected to the mobo. Everything is working well, though I cannot comment on any bottleneck that may exist since I only have one drive connected to it right now. Truly plug and play, very very happy with installation. It's only been in the pc for an hour tho, so no comments about longevity. Also, since I bought this after returning a LSI HBA because the LSI did not fit my case, this fits in a standard atx case. So far, very happy, 5 stars.

I previously had a lower cost controller, and had issues with it. Motherboard tech support recommended this controller. It just works. Reliably. Been 6 weeks, zero issues so far. I've had no need for support from IOCrest, so did not leave a rating. There are easy to find drivers from IOCrest for this card on the website.

I have 2 of these things on my SuperMicro motherboard now as it only has native SATA II headers. Doesn't do anything for the traditional NAS HDDs I have but it allows me to pass them through to my TrueNAS Core VM on Proxmox which has been rock solid. The 2ns one I have holds my SSDs so they can run at SATA III speeds. No issues, just plug and play. Helps keeps an older board going for a great home lab.

name: Cooler Master MasterCase HAF 500 High Airflow ATX Mid-Tower with Mesh Front Panel, Dual 200mm ARGB Lighting Fans, Rotatable GPU Fan, USB 3.2 Gen 2 Type C and Tempered Glass
description:
• Mesh Front Panel: Large filtered intakes promotes high airflow, keeping internal components running at optimal temperature.
  • Dual 200mm ARGB Fans: The HAF series iconic 200mm ARGB fans move high volumes of air quietly and effectively due to their large size.
  • Rotatable GPU Fan: A 120mm rotatable fan positioned on top of the HDD cage, provides dedicated GPU cooling to ensure maximum performance.
  • USB 3.2 Gen 2 Type C Support: USB 3.2 Gen 2 Type C ports built into the I/O panel allows multi-purpose, streamlined data transmission.
  • Screwless & Tool-Free TG Side Panel Design: The tempered glass side panel is secured with pins for easy removal without the use of tools.

reviews.review: This haf 500 case has good and bad features. The dual 200mm front fans are "haf" blocked by the 120/140mm chassis fan mounts. Airflow will be affected even at full 800rpm. No front intake filter means more dust will enter the case. The perforated mesh is not fine enough to be used as a dust filter. The picture in the ad says it supports 140mm exhaust fan but only 120mm can fit. The gpu swivel fan on top of the hard drive bay seems nice but has no argb. It would have been nice if the hard drive bay had a cover. The removable plastic psu shroud is nice for those who want to show their high end psu or have air intake from the inside of the case to help with airflow. The 200mm fans has a slight wobble at any speed. It's a nice big case but the small fan mounts on the front ruined the potential high airflow. This is basically an old case back from 2010 that has rgb lighting and a glass side panel to make it look modern.

I built a computer for my daughter using this case and it turned out extremely well. I used an ATX motherboard, 850 watt PSU, large air cooler for CPU, and a full size RTX 3080 GPU. The case is solidly constructed, made with quality materials, and easily accommodates standard size components. Being a mid size case, I'd recommend it for an average or common component set. If you're going for super compact and light, you don't need a case of this size or weight. If you're building a mega computer with huge liquid coolers and such, probably you should look for something specifically designed for that. But for the majority of self built computers, this is an awesome case that will give you zero problems with your build.
Was packaged very well

This case is the best out of the CoolerMaster 500 series but I found airflow works best with the 200mm fans on top and DO NOT hook 200 mm fans up to the same hub as all the other fans otherwise all fans will have max speed at 800 RPM. I have 200mm fans into a 2-1 splitter right to mobo. GPU fan is pointless if you have a large video card like RTX 30 series. If you get the case you will be better running fans in the position like I have. The 200mm intake fans are shrouded so 120 or 140 fans work best in front
Good

I looked for a case for a long time and I was so happy to find this until I actually received it and saw that they lied about having room for a 140mm fan in the rear and the 200mm fans are not sickleflow as advertised, but really crappy MF200R, and you can see the led bulbs clear as day. Other than these 2 lies in the advertising, and one of my fans being wobbly on arrival, the case looks nice.

name: StarTech.com 1-Port USB 3.2 Gen 2x2 PCIe Card - USB-C SuperSpeed 20Gbps PCI Express 3.0 x4 Host Controller Card - USB Type-C PCIe Add-On Adapter Card - Expansion Card - Windows & Linux (PEXUSB321C)
description:
• HIGH PERFORMANCE: Add 1x USB-C SuperSpeed 20Gbps port to your desktop PC with this USB 3.2 Gen 2x2 PCIe Card; Expansion card provides up to 15W (5V @ 3A) to power & charge devices
  • FULL USB 3.2 GEN 2X2 SPEEDS: Featuring the ASMedia ASM3242 host controller using x4 lanes of PCIe 3.0, this card is fully capable of speeds up to 20Gbps enabling fast access to high-performance devices like NVMe drives and SSDs
  • MAXIMIZED USB PERFORMANCE: USB Type-C PCI Express card supports Multiple INs to reduce bandwidth loss when mix speed devices are connected to a Hub (hub must also support this feature); UASP support improves performance with storage devices
  • COMPATIBILITY: Add-on card installs in full or low-profile (bracket incl) PCIe 3.0 x4 slot (Backward compatible w/PCIe 2.0); Windows/Linux/macOS w/auto drivers Win 8 & up; Works w/USB 3.1/3.0/2.0 devices
  • STARTECH.COM ADVANTAGE: IT professionals' choice for over 30 years; This USB-C PCI-e adapter card is backed for 2-years by StarTech.com, incl. free 24/5 North America based multi-lingual tech support

reviews.review:
Using this in my motherboard's secondary PCIe 4.0 x16 slot (effectively x4). Bought this card since it was one of the only options to get a USB 3 Type C port at least 10Gbps to provide 3Amps of power without any additional power connections.

Connected my Meta Quest 2 VR headset using the UGREEN 16ft USB-C cable for VR.
Works perfectly, running PC VR games at max refresh rate 120Hz, & battery stays at 100%.

drivers under Windows 7 pro will not be automatically identified. Card became invisible for Windows. Calling for help support was unsuccessful as driver installation process for this case is not available

Veni, Vidi, Vici!!! I installed it in 20 seconds. The computer recognized it on first power on. No drivers to install, maximum speed benchmark right away! I'm so amazed! Will buy it for my other computer.

Installation was easy. Powered up, and I had no internet. My network adapter is on the same bus as the new card and will not function when this card is installed. The card did not function, my computer would not load the software from STARTECH website without the card installed, THEN once installed, the software would not recognize the equipment as installed.

Well when I installed it I was so happy to have fast usb-c transfer rates to transfer videos from my cards and portable hard drives. My PC is a file server with a 20TB raid array and 40tb of storage space. it was blazingly fast... for 5 minutes. now card is showing in the hardware but no transfer is possible.

Hefty price for something that dont work.
works great i was able to use this for my quest 2 and it was able to charge and play at the same time.

amazingly fast card! has support for linux all windows operating systems and all microsoft server revisions from server 2012 forward! added usbc/thunderbolt 20gbps port to my dell server running server 2012r2 wich is hard to find products that support all commercial and home operating systems from microsoft. i cant ask for better when moving large files with external m.2 case enclosure at 2000mb/sec transfer rates 1tb of transfers in under 5 minutes!! As long as you have Pci express slots in your computer you can have the latest and greatest transfer speeds via usb-c and thunderbolt 2 it is the best if you need high speed data transfers from devices and backup/use from linux and all windows operating systems, including Intel powered Apple Products!

It does exactly as it states. 20gbps is what im getting. Easy to install. No drivers needed. Just dont use cables that are advertised 2x2 20gbps. Ordered 2 from amazon and both wouuldnt even see drive. Im using cord that came with it. Cord is short but long enough till i discover one that works with this drive.
See over 900 MBytes/sec sometimes which I have never gotten before. Another brand board was not recognized by my Dell Optiplex 5000.
If you own a USB 3.2 Gen 2x2 (20Gbps) External SSD then that's what you're looking for! It's not cheap but it works great!

This board works very well. I connected a couple of CF-Express B USB 3.2 Gen 2x2 readers (Transcend and Lexar) and I got the expected speeds without any problem. (More than 10Gbs, so certainly unobtainable with plain Gen 2 that is capped at 10 Gbs). I addition it worked with any other device I tried 3.2 Gen 2 and 3.2 Gen 1 . This is contrast with the 3.2 Gen 2 ports on my motherboard (ASUS ROG Crosshair VIII) that often have trouble working with 3.2 Gen 1 devices and are in general very picky. Very good experience for me! (Caveat: you should use the right cable. Not every C cable is the same, you need a 20 GBs cable. I used a 3.3ft Cable Matters USB4 (look for B094STPLX3) and it worked great.

Yes, this USB 3.2 20gbps USB-C pcie adapter DOES work in MacOS. I am using it in a 2010 Mac Pro 5,1. It is the fastest and most stable USB-C adapter of MANY I have tried and returned. With the right cable, I see speeds from an external OWC USB 3.1 enclosure, 2 SSD Raid 0 over 800mbps r/w, and around 950mbps with a 3-SSD raid. Every other card I have tried maxes out around 700mpbs, and shows no improvement with a raid spread over more disks. These speeds are still below the theoretical maximum but that may be due to the fact that this card is installed in a pcie 2.0 slot. Probably faster still if installed in pcie 3.0. Great card! (oh, and even slightly better performance under Windows 10 via bootcamp on my Mac Pro.

name: Kingwin KW525-3U3CR Multi-Function Super Speed USB 3.0 Hub w/ Card Reader Includes 1 USB 3.1 Port + 1 ESATA Port Transfer Speed 5 Gbps 5.25” Front
description:
• Super Speed USB 3.0 supports up to 5 Gbps of bandwidth
  • Three front accessible USB 3.0 Type-A ports
  • Three front accessible USB 3.0 Type-A ports
  • One front accessible USB 3.1 Type-C port
  • One front accessible eSATA port

reviews.review: Somehow difficult to fix it with screws, but maybe it was my case. All ports are working fine even usb-c.

so the screws included with the device doesnt actually fit the device, when you try and install it into the expansion bay the screws will need to eat into the threads of the device. the device is loose upon installation unless you really screw the screws in which might damage the device. they probably need to provide proper screw sizes. the device functions but rattles around when i try to put a usb cable onto it because the screws are loose (once again if i tighten the screws any more, it will damage the device, im not braindead i know how to install something into the expansion bay, the manufacturers just didnt check if the screws fit the device when they manufactured this)

This was pretty straightforward to install - but being in the CD slot, I had to remember what to do.

It was installed in 5 minutes - the cord just reached the USB3 slot as I did have one CD slot occupied. Booted up immediately with no drivers as advertised and is working with my existing slots without issue. We will see how everything goes in time. I am writing this the day after installation.

When you put CF or other cards in, there is nothing to guide them into the pins. This results in two problems:

1. The CF card gets stuck below the pins and falls into the PC case. This is super annoying. I had to get tweezers and tools to get it out, and this happened several times now. Or it falls completely in and you have to go into your case to get it back
2. The improper guiding also makes it easy to bend the pins inside. More tweaking and fixing.

If you have the cash, go for a more trusted option. Other than this it does work well.
It does the job
Super fast delivery, item came as described.

I bought this just over a year ago and thought it was great worked fine. But just recently i had to do some BIOS setting changes and found out with this hooked up my mouse does not work in the bios. as soon as i unplugged the big usb3.o plug everything worked fine. I have been forced to remove it as i have no idea what else may or may not be interfered with.

This installed easily and had the mounting screws, thanks! I got it primarily for the card readers. The CF card slot is very short so the card barely goes in. While it does work, I can see there is a great opportunity to bend the pins if the card isn't inserted exactly straight. There is plenty of depth in the device, why not use design it to allow the card to slide in deeply so it is secure and straight before making contact with the pins?

This hub and card reader combination seems like a good idea when I purchased it. However it is a bear to install and the one cable put a lot of pressure on the motherboard USB3 header. The USB3 cable to connect to the header is extremely inflexible and unwieldy to cable manage. The SATA connector is only 2, which is fine I guess, but it would be better for it to have SATA 3. All of the card readers that I had cards for worked, and all of the USB ports on the front also worked at the proper speeds. if I were to go back and weigh this purchase again I would likely buy something different/skip this.

Kingwin has been a good product for me over the year so I chose this expander. The unit is only 3" deep so it can't attach to the 2nd line of mounting points like most 5 1/2" devices. I used the self tapping screws to secure it as my rails have slots close to the front. Electrically and mechanically the unit is of good quality. PS: The frame is plastic - not metal, but it seems sturdy enough.

Update 2017-08-15 Additional Testing

I did some additional testing after the tear down which revealed the USB pass thru on the first port and the valid USB 3.0 hub chip. I was very curious at this point as there was no reason that this should not perform at least as well as other devices have plugged into the same 19 pin header. Additional testing shows that indeed, this device does perform above USB 2.0 speeds for the USB ports. However, the card reader is definitely USB 2.0 and the USB-C port labelled as USB 3.1 is truly a USB 3.0 port with the USB C form factor.

The issue was an add in USB 3.0 PCIe card that I had bought to add an extra 19-pin header for this device. In my testing however, I had directly connected the device to the motherboard 19pin, so I did not suspect this PCIe card as being the problem. However, it seems it was creating some angst on my PCIe bus which resulted in decreased performance of even my onboard USB. Removing that USB card allowed this USB hub to perform inline with expectations.

I have added a star, though I still see the false advertising as unforgivable given that the card reader is USB 2.0.

Update 2017-08-11 After Mfg Comment

After the comments by the mfg, I did further investigation. I have attached photos to support that investigation. This investigation verified my assertion that the card reader portion of this device is __not__ USB 3.0 but rather is a USB 2.0 device. The card reader is supported by the Ascore AU6477DL, a USB 2.0 card reader chip, it is not capable of reading moder SD Cards at full speed.

On the other hand, the USB ports seem to be in order, with the exception of the port labelled USB3.1, which is a USB C 3.0 port. The USB C connector does not make the port USB 3.1. The first USB 3.0 port is a direct pass thru from the 19 pin header, and should have no issues. I will do some additional testing to see if this proves true. The other USB ports including the USB-C port are connected to an internal USB 3.0 Hub supported by a VIA VL813, a legitimate USB 3.0 hub chip. There is no explanation for the low performance that I saw. I will do additional testing.

Original Review

I wanted to like this. I needed it to work well, it is a flop. I have always seen Kingwin as an excellent brand, albeit a bit overpriced. At this point I didn't care. I am desperate for a high quality high performance card reader insert. This is not it.

Immediately my hopes were shattered after examining it out of the box. There were 3 connectors, a 19pin for the USB3.0 and USBc ports. A Sata connector for the eSata port and a USB2.0 header for the card reader. Yes a USB2 header connector for the card reader ports meaning that performance of the card reader maxes out at USB 2.0 speeds 480 Mbps or 60 MB/s. I thought hmph.. well ok at least I will go from 2 front facing USB3.0 to 3 + a USB C style USB 3 port. So I installed anyhow and booted up and started to benchmark some SD cards, the main reason I need the card reader. I knew that using the card reader was pointless so I stuck with my Saitec USB3 reader and started running tests. The Saitec plugged into one of the previous 2 USB 3.0 ports, plugged into the same 19 pin motherboard header has no problem sustaining 90MB/s reads and writes on quality SD cards. So I connected the Saitec and ran a benchmark on what should have been a very fast card, and it capped around 40MB/s. I tried three other cards, with the same results. I tried the same cards in a HooToo USB C reader plugged into the USB C port and again the same results.

I purchased a PCIe card with a 19pin header to work with this. Unfortunately my computer doesn't seem willing to take another PCIe card, but if you need one this looks like a good option.
http://amzn.to/2wIEzsd

I do recommend this Saitec USB 3.0 reader though, it has worked very well for all but the most cutting edge SD cards.
http://amzn.to/2vjHXvE

Conclusion. The card reader will only connect to a USB 2.0 header. The USB 3.0 ports seem to be managed by a USB 2.0 hub. All in all this was a waste. I'll have to try again.
convenient to be able to read about any type of external storage device.

Bought this to add front USB 3.0 support to my computer case. Connections looked pretty straightforward, so the lack of instructions didn't seem important. One 19-pin USB 3.0 header cable, one Molex power connection, one eSATA cable and a USB 2.0 harness that connected the various card reader slots on the panel to the motherboard. Everything seemed to work until the computer went into standby. Touching the mouse or keyboard seemed to wake the computer, but not the video monitor. Had to do a hard reset (not a soft power off) to reboot the computer so I could see something. Played with various BIOS settings, changing video output from native to add-n video adapter...nada. Unplugging the 19-pin connector from the motherboard fixed the blank monitor problem, but cancelled out any USB 3.0 support to the panel. Was going to send it back, but found there are not a lot of 5.25 front panels to choose from. Made one last attempt to get it to work by unplugging the 4-pin Molex power connector which appears to be the fix. It did not affect the USB 3.0 capability far as I can tell. Don't know if it affects the eSATA function. Going to order an add in card with a 19-pin USB connection and spare my motherboard from possible damage.

  • 【Fully Compatible】: The S880 NVMe SSD has a compact design(2280 M.2), making it easy to install and use. It is compatible with PS5 and most computers and systems on the market.
  • 【Quality Guarantee】: We have our own factory and packaging equipment, which allows us to better control production costs and quality. Compared to similar products, our product performance is more powerful, and our price is more competitive.
  • 【Premium After-sales Service】: We provide professional and efficient after-sales service. Whether you have any questions or concerns before or during the purchase, we will promptly solve them and provide satisfactory answers.

reviews.review:
In an Alienware 17R5, running at PCIe 3.0 x4 mode, it still has impressive performance as compared to a Samsung SM961 (low budget Samsung SSD, equal to a 950 Pro in performance). The picture is NVMe mode "Real World Performance" test suite on v8.0.4 of CDM, with 31% used space on the 2TB size SSD.

Be sure the device this SSD is intended for is compatible with PCIe Gen 4 NVMe drives, otherwise you will see about 1/4 of the performance claimed by this brand. Gen 4 drives were cheap and are backward compatible, so I knew to expect different performance than advertised, which I'm alright with.

**ignore the reviews that claim it doesn't run at advertised speeds, they probably do not understand that you need Gen 4 PCIe to get those speeds**

Went with this product for the price and performance. Not a manufacturer I’ve used before but figured for the price and the reported speeds I thought it was value (I always expect the speeds to be lower than reported so didn’t want a 5,500 drive that comes up short). The ps5 reported this drive was running at 6,100 so above the minimum requirements. I transferred 300GB+ from console memory to the drive, took just over 3mins. Can’t think of an occasion where the drive will be transferring a higher load so shouldn’t be any issues with over heating. However the ‘graphene heat shield’ is literally a heat proof sticker and not a heat sink (as it appears from the image, it’s a clever illusion which makes the sticker look 3D) in any event I did not have any issues with performance or thermal throttling while transferring the entire console memory to the drive. I have ordered a heat sink in any event, as maybe I’ll get closer to the reported 7,300 speed but this is mainly for peace of mind more than anything.
Bought an ADATA NvMe hd but it was not compatible with my laptop. Returned it and purchased this HD instead at 30$ savings. Easy to install and was recognized by windows right away. Highly recommend
Easy install for a 2nd drive . The speeds on point with what was advertised and the price was great

I saw a YouTube video mentioning this drive. I had never heard of the brand, but willing to give it a shot. It turns out to be an excellent choice. The Dynamic SLC is what is causing this drive to perform so well, technology keeps getting better.
There might be alternative TLC drives, and they can perform fast too - they might not have the single level cell technology. Will test it further, so far I am impressed.

I was highly skeptical before buying this S880-1TB NVME as I generally go for known brands. However, I took a risk and went ahead. After testing the drive on Userbenchmark and CrystalDiskMark, I have attached my finding via the images. The benchmark score are encouraging. You may find three different test outputs in the attached images. Namely; Default test, Peak Performance+Mix Test, and Real-world Performance+Mix.

A bit about my setup:
Gigabyte X470 Aorus Ultra Gaming Motherboard (PCIe 3.0) Hence the drive performance is limited due to the board's capability and not this drive. I plan to soon upgrade my motherboard and may update the benchmark scores for your reference later.

Pros:
Runs cool under full load. I did not see it go past 43 degree Celsius in all of my testing. (Important to note that the drive slot is right below my GPU)
For PCIe 3.0 slot, its performance is comparable to other known brands.
Package included the screw and a tiny screwdriver.

Cons:
For backward compatibility, Fanxiang can consider adding a motherboard support screw as this drive is 2280 and most motherboards only drop a motherboard screw on 22110 point. I could not screw the drive to the mainboard and had to use the heat sink to keep it in place.

Since I received the drive today, I may update the operational use-related findings later. I hope you find this review useful.

So far - Im VERY happy with this SSD. I bought it for my Razer Blade 16, which needs a single sided SSD. Havent had any issues yet and speeds are as advertised.
I’ll update this review if it ever goes A-wall.
Unbeatable at this speed and this price.

Si quieres ampliar la capacidad de tu PS5 y buscas un SSD PCIe 4.0 que sea muy barato, entonces no puedes dejar escapar esta oferta. El fanxiang S770 de 1 TB tiene un descuento del 15 % respecto al precio anterior en Amazon y su precio es una locura. Por si fuera poco, este SSD tiene un disipador de calor, algo imprescindible si queremos mantener a raya la temperatura.

PUBLICIDAD

Los SSD de 1 TB de marcas como Samsung y WD suelen costar a partir de 100 euros, mientras que el fanxiang S770 de 1 TB puede ser tuyo por tan solo 67,99 euros. ¡Vaya chollo! Es un precio muy tentador y más si tenemos en cuenta que estamos hablando de un SSD compatible con PS5. A nivel de rendimiento, algo de lo que hablaremos más adelante, no tiene nada que envidar a otros SSD de marcas mucho más conocidas.

SSD PCIe 4.0 fanxiang S770 1 TB
Este SSD fanxiang proporciona velocidades de transferencia muy rápidas
Instalar un SSD en la PS5 es muy fácil y no anula la garantía. Solo necesitas un destornillador de estrella y quitar una de las cubiertas para tener acceso al compartimento del SSD. En dicho compartimento hay un tornillo que hay que quitar para introducir el SSD. Una vez instalado tienes que atornillarlo de nuevo y poner la cubierta.

Es hora de hablar del rendimiento. El fanxiang S770 de 4 TB ofrece una velocidad de lectura de hasta 7.300 MB/s en PC, mientras que en PS5 es algo inferior. A la hora de escribir puede alanzar hasta 5.400 MB/s. Como puedes ver, son unas velocidades de transferencia muy rápidas. Así pues, no hace falta decir que este SSD se convierte en una excelente opción para todos aquellos quieran ampliar la capacidad almacenamiento de la consola de Sony por poco dinero.

El fanxiang S770 de 4 TB también es una opción a tener en cuenta si juegas en PC. De hecho, cada vez hay más juegos donde se recomienda tener una de estas unidades de almacenamiento rápido, por ejemplo, The Last of Us Parte I. En definitiva, es uno de los SSD más rápidos que puedes conseguir ahora mismo a buen precio, y por si fuera poco incluye el disipador de calor, algo que nunca está de más.

Los SSD de 4 TB de marcas como Samsung y WD suelen más caros, mientras que el fanxiang S770 de 4TB puede ser tuyo por tan solo 230 euros. ¡Vaya chollo! Es un precio muy tentador y más si tenemos en cuenta que estamos hablando de un SSD compatible con PS5. A nivel de rendimiento, no tiene nada que envidar a otros SSD de marcas mucho más conocidas.

Encore peu connue en France, Fanxiang est une marque chinoise qui propose des SSD à des prix particulièrement compétitifs. Mais pas cher ne signifie pas médiocre pour autant. Le SSD S880 a subi 88 heures de tests rigoureux ainsi que 5 tests stricts histoire de garantir sa résistance et sa fiabilité sur le long terme. Le SSD dispose d’une garantie de 5 ans et Fanxiang annonce une endurance de 2800 TBW.

🔳 Caractéristiques détaillés du SSD S880 4TB :
Modèle: 5880
Interface: M.2 2280 (protocolo NVMe 1.4)
Contrôleur SSD : MAP1602A from MaxioTech
Modules Mémoire : 232-layer TLC NAND flash (Made by YMTC)
Température de fonctionnement: 0°C-70°C
Température de stockage : -40°C-85°C
Poids: 0.045g
Taille: 80*22*2.5~3.4mm
Capacité: 4To
Service après-vente: 5 ans

Installé dans un boitier externe USB-C Thunderbolt 3 (40Gbps) en tant que disque de sauvegarde 4TB pour mon Macbook Pro (oui je sais c'est overkill), ce disque annonce des performances vraiment excellentes (7300MB/s en lecture séquentielle et 6800MB/s en écriture séquentielle). Hélas je n'ai jamais réussi à les atteindre puisque le TB3 même à 40Gbps n'est pas assez rapide.

Voici mon feedback sur ce disque SSD S880 4TB:
✅ RAPPORT QUALITÉ/PRIX IMBATTABLE à ce niveau de capacité/performance
✅ Équipé d’un autocollant de dissipation thermique au graphène, cela permet une dissipation de la chaleur et empêcher le SSD d’atteindre des températures élevées.
✅ Format M.2 2280 compact tout ce qu'il y a de plus classique.
✅ Il exploite à merveille l’interface PCIe 4.0 NVMe 4X pour offrir des débits extrêmement élevés...
✅ ...tout en conservant une consommation et une chauffe maîtrisée (ça chauffe quand même pas mal hein, on ne va pas se mentir)
✅ Vitesse annoncée jusqu’à 7300 Mbps en lecture séquentielle et jusqu’à 6800 Mbps en écriture séquentielle. De mon côté, j'étais plutôt sur environ la moitié des chiffres annoncés (en USB-C donc). Je n'ai pas pu vérifier sur un PC en PCI 4.0 4X.
✅ Débits théorique 13 fois supérieurs à ceux d'un SSD SATA.
✅ 2800 TBW !!
✅ Garantie 5 ans.... 👍🏼👍🏼👍🏼👍🏼👍🏼
❌ Pas de cache DRAM ! Mais il y a un pseudo cache SLC pour les bursts d'écriture
❌ Une marque encore très jeune (les S880 sont sortis en Avril 2023, c'est très récent...). Il y a peu de recul encore sur la fiabilité long terme. D'où le fait que je l'ai mis en disque de sauvegarde, car il sera peu sollicité, et si un jour une sauvegarde n'aboutit pas car le disque est défaillant, je pourrai toujours le changer rapidement, plutôt que de perdre toutes les données d'un disque principal en production ^^

Le mot de la fin : Sur mes premiers essais depuis plusieurs mois, les performances restent stratosphériques pour un disque utilisé en externe en plus. C'est pour moi un excellent achat. Je vous le conseille.

È un SSD con dissipatore di calore, adatto per Ps5, serve per aumentare gli 825 GB disponibili della Ps5 che si esauriscono con pochi giochi.

È un SSD del modello M2 PCle 4.0. con una velocità dichiarata di lettura e scrittura di 7300 MB/s, che poi rivelereanno effettivamente essere circa 6500 MB/s.

Veniamo alle fasi di montaggio dell'SSD:

Si prende uno dei due cuscinetti termici, si rimuove la pellicola e lo si posiziona sulla base del dissipatore di calore, poi si mette sopra l'SSD con il chip verso l'alto e si mette l'altro pad termico a coprire la parte superiore dell'SSD. Fatto questo si prende il dissipatore che si posizionerà sopra il pad termico e si preme verso il basso cosi da fissarsi.

All'interno della confezione troviamo 5 viti nere, ne vanno usate 4 per bloccare l'SSD al dissipatore con il piccolo giravite in dotazione.

Fatto questo è tutto pronto e dobbiamo smontare la ps5 prendendola in posizione orizzontale, facendo scorrere prendendo gli estremi e sollevandola leggermente. Davanti a voi dovete avere il retro della ps5, messa in posizione orizzontale dovete farla scorrere verso sinistra. È una procedura che richiedere una leggera forza all'inizio e pazienza, anche se non riuscite subito, prendetevi un attimo e riprovate con calma senza farvi prendere dalla foga.

Rimosso il pannello, in alto troverete un alloggiamento per l'SSD aggiuntivo. Rimuovete la vite, il coperchio e inserite l'SSD completo di dissipatore nel giusto verso. Con la rondella e la vita presenti fissiamo il tutto e richiediamo coperchio e Ps5.

Una volta accesa la Ps5 apparirà il messaggio che vi dirà di aver rilevato il nuovo SSD e se formattarlo. Cliccate su formatta, fatto questo vi indicherà la velocità massima di lettura e sarà pronto all'uso.

La procedura non è difficile, richiede molta pazienza ma è fattibile per tutti, nulla di trascendentale. Adesso c'è tantissimo spazio e non bisogna più cancellare giochi e salvataggi.

PRO
Ps5 finalmente completa in tutto, installazione intuitiva, SSD capiente

CONTRO
Velocità effettiva inferiore a quella dichiarata

Adesso la mia Ps5 ha lo spazio necessario per poter giocare con serenità senza stare lì a rimuovere o fare calcoli su cosa salvare o cancellare.

Peccato per la velocità dichiarata che non viene raggiunta e per questo motivo lo valuto 4 stelle ma resta comunque un valore di tutto rispetto.

Se volete una Ps5 capiente e funzionale con più giochi installati sopra, questo SSD può fare al caso vostro, va bene per entrambe le versioni di Ps5.

Spero di esservi stato utile.

👋 Ciao lettori, oggi vi parlo di questo SSD targato Fanxiang che mi ha lasciato molto colpito!
☁️ Personalmente ho acquistato la variante S770 da 2TB

📢 PRIME IMPRESSIONI:
Packaging con l'SSD, nulla più nulla meno, dissipato passivamente che promette teoricamente delle ottime performance, ma sarà vero? Controlliamolo insieme!

⚙️ SPECIFICHE TECNICHE:
Fanxiang lancia questo prodotto con un bel pacchetto di specifiche, partiamo innanzitutto da un PCIe 4.0 che garantisce alla PS5 di leggerlo (PS5 non è compatibile con nessun NVMe che non sia almeno PCIe 4.0), poi troviamo ben 2GB di DRAM nel caso della variante da 2TB della Sk Hynix, chip che promettono bene, affiancato da una NAND di YMTC ed un controller di InnoGrit entrambi assolutamente niente male, a livello di componentistica usata per quanto mi riguarda, c'è da stupirsi considerato il prezzo!

🚀 MA QUANTO E' VELOCE?:
Mantiene la promessa fatta, infatti grazie al PCIe 4.0 affiancato da delle componenti evidentemente di livello, raggiunge senza problemi i promessi 7000MB/s in Read e 6600MB/s in Write, assolutamente niente male!

🎮 PS5 READY:
La PS5 digerisce tranquillamente questo SSD ed una volta in game, le prestazioni che fornisce sono assolutamente equiparabili al SSD nativo della Play, carica molto velocemente i giochi e grazie alla DRAM li sposta anche molto velocemente tra SSD Esterno e interno o viceversa.

🟨 Nota: Il profilo del dissipatore passivo è ottimizzato per PS5, questo significa che lo shielding che devi rimontare per chiudere il vano del inserimento SSD su PS5 si chiude tranquillamente anche con il dissipatore installato.

🔥 DURABILITA':
Fanxiang garantisce ben 1400TBW di durabilità (ovvero 1400TB di scrittura su disco), che sono tantissimi, facendo finta che ogni gioco per PS5 sia di 100GB, dovreste scaricare 100GB di giochi per 14 MILA VOLTE.

🕒 3 MESI DOPO E QUALITA' PREZZO:
Ad oggi non ho avuto nessunissimo problema con questo disco e mi sento di essere pronto a consigliarvelo, le performance che ho ottenuto sono state davvero ottimali soprattutto per il prezzo pagato, per quanto mi riguarda ne vale la pena.

🏁 FACCIAMO IL PUNTO:
Un disco di un brand emergente che contro ogni aspettativa (considerando i trascorsi dei nuovi brand di SSD orientali), si comporta benissimo ed ha velocità assolutamente adeguate a quello che promette.

⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐/5

reviews.review: I used this solid state drive to replace an old mechanical drive in my Lenovo R500 laptop. I checked YouTube to find out how to replace the drive. It looked simple, so I ordered this Linkmore SG500 SS drive after wading through the many SS drives available. When I received it, I popped the old drive out. Popped the Linkmore drive into the old drive enclosure. Slid it back into the laptop. Super easy. Then I loaded an Ubuntu CD into the laptop and installed Ubuntu onto the Linkmore drive. Everything went smoothly. And boot up and app responses are now much quicker. Very happy!
